reviews.review: Peae in heart of bustling Hong Kong. What a delight to find this place in Hong Kong. Peaceful is the best way to explain this temple, nunnery and bonsai gardens. It is easily to get to by a No 5 bus or by MRT. The Buddhist nuns are a silent order and can be seen working in the gardens. There is a large pond with a large school of koi or (Oscar) fish. allow at least 3hr for the visit so you an sit on the benches and ease your mind and body. The temple has larger religious buddas and there are people praying in front of most of the altars.There is no entry fee but a donation box is available and the gift shop is well worth a visit.

Lovely. We took the MTR to Diamond Hill and went to see the Nunnery. Thoroughly enjoyed walking around viewing it. The Chi Lin Gardens back on to the Nunnery. These are the gardens with the little temple and red bridge if you are interested in seeing it. Would recommend see it. Very peaceful and pretty.
Best place in town. Calm, peaceful, really beautiful.Easily reachable with MTR.Great prices in the gift shop.Better than any other temple in HK.

Great piece of local culture. Visited the nunnery and gardens together as we were staying a short walk from both. Would highly recommend! The nunnery is beautiful with amazing statues and prayer areas. Must see when in Hong Kong

An insight into Buddhisim. We spent a morning visiting the Nunnery and Nan Lian Gardens. Wonderful layout that exudes peace and serenity. Allow 2 hours to really appreciate them.Easy to get to via the MTR station at Diamond Hill and a 5 minute walk.The gardens are magnificent and the temple complex was constructed without the use of nails/fasteners, undoubtedly the work of master tradesman.It is not hard to understand why Buddhism attracts those seeking peace and understanding.

Very nice nunnery, feels old. This nunnery has a real 'old' or 'historic' feeling to it. If only it wasn't just one (or two) decades old. The shrines are beautiful and the woodwork is amazing, so are the gardens in the courtyard. Worth a visit!

excellent view and atmosphere! Beautiful architecture!. Go there when the weather is good! You will totally enjoy the architecture, beautiful flowers & plants, fish pond, nice temples - all give you a peaceful mind. But sometimes you may not find it peaceful when there are groups of Mainland Chinese visitors. Good luck!
Spectacular. One of the highlights of our visit. Spectacular grounds in serene surroundings. Truly a peaceful environment.
Serene. A serene, quiet monastery with Buddhist statues(?) and places to pray. Not a huge monastery, but a great place to pair with the garden next door.
Peaceful. Another great relaxing destination. You can de-stress yourself here before heading to dinner or chill out after lunch.

A unique place in Hong Kong. Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden are neighbours. You can go from one place to another since they are connected. Both of them were built in the style of Tang Dynasty. Taking MTR is the best way to get to these places. There is also a shopping arcade next to the MTR station.The temple in Chi Lin Nunnery is closed after 5:00 p.m. The golden structure and the red bridge in Nan Lian Garden is the focus of it.The vegetarian restaurant is very good. Don't miss it.

A beautiful Chinese nunnery. It is near the MTR station of Diamond Hill. Just a few minutes walk. Not the whole part is open to the public, but you can have a stroll and look around in certain parts inside and the surroundings. There is a garden adjacent and is accessible freely.

A hidden gem in the city. Make up of the main Buddhish complex (close at 4pm) and the Nan Lian Garden (close at 6pm). Reconstruction started at Year 1988 and completed 2000. It is the world largest hand-made wooden building without a single nail. It is in Tang dynasty style (AD 618–907) and therefore resembles the look of Japanese shrines (main period of cultural influence to Japan）which many travellers familar with . It is more for appreciation of Chinese classical building and landscape architecture than taking this place as one of the temples of worship. The place is free of charge and well kept. Take the time to appreciate the finer details. It is totally worth it.BTW, you can have veggie lunch and dinner in the restraunt inside the garden but suggest to make reservation in advance esp. for dinner.

Beautiful nunnery and garden. Beautiful place and special in the way that it is sorunded by tall buildings. Every thing is being cared for, and it a bit special to walk around the gardens.Free for visitors and expect to spend about an hour.

“Nun” the less …. Linked by an overhead bridge from the Nan Lian Garden leading to a nunnery with water gardens and massive bonsai. Nonetheless it’s quite an interesting temple to behold especially with the surrounding highrises as backdrops.DIRECTIONS:MTR Diamond Hill station, exit C2 and follow the signs.These are HK’s seldom ventured upon Gardens and Temples (at least for the hurried ignorant tourists) - You can visit all 4 sights (Nan Lian Garden, Chi Lin Nunnery, Sik Sik Yuen Temple, and Kowloon Walled City Park) by taking the metro or walking about 20 minutes between sights as they are linked by 3 adjacent MTR stations.

wonderfully peacefull and beautifull. we never visit Hong Kong without spending a few hours at this nunnery, it is an oasis of peace and tranquillity in world of hustle and bustle and a reminder of the value of peace, quite and the beauty of well tended gardens. Lovely place to stroll around or to simply be still for a while.

Must-see. This is a great place! Nested between HK highrises and all the hustle and bustle of the city, this is a perfect oasis. The buildings themselves are awesome to look at. All the Buddhas in the temples are extremely beautifully crafted and amaze you! The atmosphere inside the nunnery is so peaceful! Definitely one of the top-five sites to see in HK

Very Peaceful . This is well worth the trip as the temple is a fully functional worship place. The gardens and ponds are extremely well designed and maintained. The temple area was lovely but keep in mind that it is a place of worship and people are there praying. Please be aware that you can't take photos inside the temple. Visit the gift shop afterwards as there is some nice items in there too. Make sure you cross the road to the Nan Luan Gardens.
Beautiful. The nunnery and the surroundings are beautiful, and the various views are a must see. It's a small area of calm in HK's noisy madness.
Hiding in the rain. Really enjoyed the architecture, peace and tranquillity, but most of all, the rain in the gardens.The incongruity of the old with the new (surrounding buildings) set it off.
Worth seeing!. Loved every minute we spent there. So very beautiful and peaceful. Put it on your list of things to see!
Worth the trip!. Chi Lin Nunnery was so beautiful! It took us 20 min by taxi from our hotel. I had 2 kids with me (10 and 7) and they both enjoyed it. We spent about 45 mins.

Come to find peace in mind.... although rebuild in the 1990's, it is the world largest hand-made wooden building (all cypress wood and without a single nail !) where everything is so quiet, clean and clear.. an invitation to meditate..
Serenity in the city. A beautiful quiet contemplative spot amongst the modern day chaos surrounding it. A great place to relax and reflect.

the garden is a wonderful place of calm. We had several plans for the day but the gardens at the Chi Lin Nunnery were so fantastic that we scrapped our list of plans and spent the day there! To get to the nunnery we had to walk through the Nan Lian garden -- a large traditional Chinese garden that is managed by the nunnery. What a surprise! We didn’t know there would be a garden and it was the most beautiful garden either one of us had ever seen. And we’ve been to England and other places to see gardens. It was magical seeing it in the rain and with not many people around. The bonsaied pines and other bonsaied trees, the many beautiful and strategically placed large rocks and pieces of petrified wood, the ponds, bridges, water wheels and traditional-style buildings, the many different types of trees with interesting bark and foliage including banyans, plus a variety shrubs and ground covers made for a calm and peaceful day right in the middle of Hong Kong city!! The garden also had some beautiful exhibits in traditional styled buildings including a showing of Marino glass pieces, bonsaied small trees, petrified woods, and an exhibit on how the nunnery was made without nails. It also had a restaurant plus a teahouse where we had tea (with assistance in the traditional way) and a light snack. It was a highlight of our trip to Honk Kong – it was truly stunning. We think the best to enter the gardens is by taking the metro to Diamond Hill.
Interesting. This is adjacent to the Nan Lian Garden, a large place of worship with statues and nice lotus ponds. Interesting to pay a brief visit and take some pictures.

absolutely beautiful. This is a must see It is Absolutely Beautiful we went there it was rain but was worth getting wet for make sure you check out all the gardens as well there is places to eat in the gardens And drinks the shopping center that you get off MTR is worth a look around has good clean toilets LOL

Perfectly peaceful.. This really is a must-see when in Hong Kong. Apart from in Nara, Japan, this has the most stunning wooden architecture I have ever seen. The courtyards and temples are truly beautiful and a delight to explore. And the (no photos allowed) Buddha statues inside the halls are pretty incredible too. Don't miss the gift shop downstairs either as it sells some good souvenirs.

Beautiful setting. We did a quick trip trough the nunnery and were forced to slow down to admire the architecture, plants and the general pleasant setting of the nunnery. We badly wanted to take some photos of the idols but it's not permitted (they are outstanding!).

Lovely buildings. A lovely example of cultural icons, religious buildings and beautiful garden. A big tourist shop is located in the basement along with the toilets. Nice day activity, easy to reach by MTR.

Peace and tranquility. You can get here easily by using the MRT (MTR Diamond Hill Station Exit C2, follow the signs and walk for around five minutes). It is near the Nan Lian Gardens and by visiting both places you will be uplifted by the beauty, attention to detail and the harmony present. Definitely worth taking the time away from the bustle of Hong Kong to quietly wander and take in the peace and tranquility. Read the Buddhist quotes as you wander.

Serene. Simply beautiful. Symmetrical lotus ponds fill the outer courtyard, beautiful rocks surrounds the outer wall, and intricate woodworking are highlights of this Nunnery. It was practically deserted when I came here on a Tuesday morning, making it an absolutely perfect place to get some peace and quiet. It's connected to Nan Lian garden by a footbridge that goes over a road. See both and you will have a wonderful morning and a different appreciation for Hong Kong's bustling nature.

Finally a peaceful place in HK. Coming from the countryside in the UK I find HK very busy and hectic at the best of times! The Nan Lian gardens and the nunnery are joined and less than 5 minutes walk from C2 exit of Diamond Hill MTR station so super easy to get to. It's one of the quietest places I've been in HK and was lovely and peaceful!The gardens weren't anything special but very peaceful and the nunnery was beautiful! Only a short trip required around an hour but well worth it!

It's so quiet.... What a lovely place! There are several things you can do here; first, you can read Buddhist scriptures/quotes on all of the rocks they have lining the walls; second, you can contemplate on those rocks sayings; third, you can be utterly startled by a frozen/meditating nun in the main hall (she was just frozen and when she moved it was like aaaah!); and lastly the lily pads and garden view are lovely.

A must see place in Hong Kong!!. The destination is incredible. The nunnery has some nice statues of Buddha and you will see people worshiping here. There's also the Chi Lian Garden which is just across from the nunnery. The trees are very nice. If you are from Europe or America, these trees are very different from what you will see in those countries. Also, the pond and waterfall are very nice. There's a pagoda in the middle of this garden which is well worth the stop. Plan to spend around 1 to 2 hours here. There's also a vegetarian restaurant and some other cafes. I haven't been to any of them but the prices are very reasonable and it looks good.
A wonderful oasis in an urban environment. This is a must see destination. THe gardens are delightful and there is vegetarian food to be had. It should be on everyone's list of HK destinations.

Peaceful Retreat in the City!. Pair this with NanLian Garden for a lovely escape from the city. It is hard to believe this exists within the hustle and bustle. There are small scale samples of how the Nunnery and other building were built without even one nail, Fascinating! Take Diamond Hill MTR Exit C2 and look for the signs!

Beautiful place. We wanted to go here when the sun was not harsh, but we ended up being here after 2:00 PM. Still, we had good photos, and the place was just stunning. Advise to go here on weekdays as opposed to weekends, fewer people. The architecture and the calmness of the place was what I loved here. :)
Peace in the city. Amazing place.. a must visit if you want to experience tranquility n HK! right in the middle of the city!!

Find some Zen in HK. Chi Lin nunnery is one of the most beautiful places I have been to. I came here on a solo visit to do some drawing, if you are an artist like me then you can only draw below size A4 and you can only use dry materials. The nunnery is very peaceful and everything is very pristine, the carvings are all perfect the setting is perfect. I could have sat there all day. The souvenir shop is pretty pointless and when I found out the nunnery is not all that old it kind of disappointed me. However it cannot take away from the fact that it is a very beautiful and peaceful place.
A beautiful place in Hong Kong. Even though this nunnery is relatively new, It is a jewel in the middle of a working class district in Hong Kong.
Well worth a visit!. A beautiful place of peace and quiet in contrast to the rest of Hong Kong busy lifestyle. Walking over from the Nan Lian Gardens was wonderful. It was such a calming place.

Tranquil, Spiritual and uplifting. A most beautiful Nunnery and adjacent gardens, Visit this attraction away from a tour so you can take time to absorb it's beauty, the souvenir shop run by the Nun's is worth supporting, near the shop is a sign directing you to the some food, the food simple yet tasty fund's are donated to their good works. When in the adjacent gardens take time out to enjoy traditional Chinese tea, in the tea house.

Another heavenly haven in the New Territories. Having lived in HK and visited all the main sightseeing spots, this nunnery and the adjoining Nan Lian Garden were a welcome change. A real haven amongst the bustle of city life …. And both are free – what’s not to like?! Diamond Hill MTR (Exit C2, 5 minute walk)

A quiet place within city. Chi Lin Nunnery situates near Diamond Hill. Entrance is between 2 highways underneath. Once you walk inside, it is quiet and the garden is designed in Chinese style. It can take 40 minutes to go around the whole place. A quiet place within city.

Ways of the Buddha. This is an intricately designed venue not far from Daimond Hill MTR. Easy to get to and to find. Place of great sanctity and almost symmetrical design. The influence of Buddha is well communicated in this place of sanctity- revealing the virtues of wisdom and compassion. Very quiet and peaceful during our visit.

Gorgeous, peaceful. Beautiful and peaceful. No photos in the interior area. A beautiful, peaceful, quiet stroll viewing all of the different shrines. English language signage explains who the different deities are. Worth the detour away from other main tourist areas.
Away from the crowds. After a few days in the chaos of downtown Kowloon - this is a much more meditative place than the Big Buddha. A wonderful wooden structure housing a modern Nunnery.

A wonderful tranquil place. A retreat from.the hussle and bussle Hong Kong. A beautifully constructed place of worship. Fine timber construction with excellent attention to detail. Built to last a thousand years. Please respect the sanctity of the place and do not let your camera come between you and a wonderful experience. Enjoy the fountains and the wonderful harmony of this unique place.
Quiet. Interesting seeing how important Buddhism is in Hong Kong, very quiet place next to Chi Lin Garden, easy to get to on the MTR, not much time needed there

It is very good location to visit near MTR. . It is near MTR (Subway station). Have a beautiful roofs with garden. Many people pray. Well kept and a bit hot in the August. I recommend visit together with Wong Tai Sin 黃大仙, Nan Nin Garden (? One stop away at Diamond Hill station). It has small mountain background with skyscrapers but still have a good views. Must see in Koo Lung (九龍). :)

No "nunsense" - this is a must see!. The gardens leading into the nunnery and the architecture provide a peaceful break from the busy city while also giving a glimpse of traditional Chinese architecture. Soft music plays throughout the gardens and skyscrapers tower in the background which provides a very interesting visual contrast. Make sure to enter the large building in the back of the lotus pond courtyard; it's not posted and the guards won't direct you. This contains huge gold statues that are amazing and are some of the prettiest we saw during our trip. Sadly, no photos are allowed.
Hidden Gem. Found this by chance and so glad I did. Quiet but beautiful with a peaceful atmosphere. Easy to get to using the metro and then we'll sign posted.

An oasis of piece in fast-paced Hong Kong. This is a wonderful little place to go when you want just a little bit of peace and quiet, and you don;t want to go miles out of your way to a remote part of HK. The vegetarian restaurant is excellent value, and fortune teller is good fun (though some people take it very seriously !)Very easy to get to (just outside Diamond Hill subway stop), and well worth taking visitors to HK to see, when they need a break from the frenetic activity.

A snippet of calm in the hectic city life. The garden more than the nunnery worth a visit.Maniacally taken care of by a host of gardeners in constant practice.Take your time to walk the windy way up to the bridge and the nunnery itself, where you can admire a reconstruction of ancient wood building techniques.In the garden another building usually hosts special exhibitions.Very pretty corner of HK..even if all "fake"..

Nice place!. Great place to visit if you want some peace and quiet. The nunnery building are lovely and the garden is pretty too. It's quite the contrast in the bustling city of Hong Kong. Easy to get to by MTR from central station.

Cultural Visit. By taking the underground to Diamond Hill station and walking up around 5 minutes, you may reach Chi Lin Nunnery - easy and convenient.You will be impressed by its lovely scenery - a temple which was renovated in Tang dynasty style. There is a pathway connected from the temple to Nan Lian Garden which is filled up with potted plant, rock, and timber structure. Don't miss it.

A world away from the hustle and bustle. Well worth an hour to wander around the temple, visit the gift shop, have a cup of tea or a vegetarian meal, and forget all your cares. A lovely place that doesn't feel like anywhere else in Hong Kong.

The Gardens, Waterfalls and Golden Temple are Spectacular!. Chi Lin Nunnery is definitely worth a trip if you're in Hong Kong. It's easily accessibly by subway and a very short walk so there's no need to book a tour. The Nunnery is charming but the gardens steal the show - breathtaking and beautiful!

Very nice . Very nice place to visit in addition to Nan Lian garden but not marked well as to know you are there. But it's on the opposite side of the cross over walkway We lucked out with the weather this week As with Nan Lian garden. ..beautiful landscaping and city backdrop views

Peace in the middle of Hong Kong. If you are after some time out from the hustle and bustle of HK - this is the place. It is easily accessible from the MTR and you can easily spend an hour walking through the gardens and the monastery. I guarantee you will feel calmer and more relaxed afterwards than before!
Serine place. Visit with gardens across the road. We really enjoyed the information provided and the gift shop.. Then cross the road for the gardens and lunch. Excellent vegetarian restaurant.

Buddisht temple of Tang Dynasty. Highly recommend. One of the few places in Hong Kong where you can taste the Chinese tradition. The place was built in the style of Tang Dynasty using wood. Very elegant. There is also a small lake with a golden temple.

Free easy to access via MRT. Chi Lin Nunnery, Nan Lian Garden are next to each other, dont miss the wonderful Wong Tai Sin Temple about 10 minute walk away.No need to take a tour to visit these places, the MRT is easy to use, they have information desks at each station and the maps are easy to follow and also stations have names in English. along with Lantau Island Big Budda these are other best places to visit in Hong Kong

A peace of heaven!!. On our first day in this busy City we decided to visit the Nunnery. It is absolutely delightful. Very quiet and not crowded so we could just leisurely stroll around. Amazing statues and with powerful vibrations. Quite incongruous really as you look around at all the skyscrapers around you. Then take a walk around the adjoining gardens.A great day out!

Incredible potted plants . It's hard to imagine there is such serene and sophisticated nunnery built in the middle of this hectic city. The plants are beautifully arranged and looked after. Definitely worth paying a visit, especially nice to a day with your parents.

Very tranquil and beautiful. Like most, it seems, I visited the monastery having just been to Nan Lian Gardens and it was just as beautiful and even more peaceful than the gardens themselves. The shrines to the Gods were impressive both in their size and beauty and the architecture of the monastery as a whole is stunning, especially contrasting with the modernity of skyscrapers in the background.

Well worth a visit. Visited the Nunnery and associated gardens. You access the Nunnery through beautiful gardens. The Nunnery doesn't disappoint either. Well worth a visit, accessible from the centre by MTR to Diamond Hill. Well worth a visit for the beautiful gardens and the serenity of the location allied to the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

Gardens stunning!. The day we toured at Chi Lin there was a tornado warning so we arrived in the afternoon to discover that the actual nunnery was closed (May 27th). It was a bit showery but nothing like the rains of the night before, oh well! However the walk around the grounds was superb, and well worth it. The nunnery is an easy walk from the Diamond Hill station and well signposted. The Hong Kong Metro is clean, cool, and safe, and although Diamond Hill looks like quite a long trip it was really quite fast.  A guard at the entrance to the main garden area was full of really interesting facts and spoke English quite well, so that was an added benefit. There's a small tea room, but when we arrived the main restaurant had already closed. It looked like a lovely spot for a casual lunch, whereas the tea room was rather basic. A special oasis that feels so far away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and Kowloon!

Tranquil. Great to have a relaxing day away from the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong, do the Nunnery with a walk around the Nan Lian Gardens. It is definitely worth the cost of doing tea service & dim sum in the gardens too (approx $25 AUD - from memory). But was very relaxing and nice service. Really lovely walk and easy to find/get around.

Serene surroundings. After a visit to the Nan Lian Garden, you immediately come to the entrance of the Chi Lin Nunnery. We enjoyed the fountain area with water lilies blooming and spigots shaped like dragons. We saw monks there and immense beautiful Buddhas inside the temple. They do not allow interior photos to be taken.The entire setting is very peaceful and artfully arranged.

A calming tranquil temple. A calming tranquil temple with good interpretation signposted around the site to understand what you're looking at. Just over the road from Nan Lian gardens, it's a good idea to combine these 2 visits together for a combined trip of a couple of hours. There's a nice souvenir shop underneath, and evening service starts around 4-4.30 which anybody is welcome to join in.

Nice final touch to a visit to the Nan Lian Gardens. The nunnery doesn't have too much going for it on its own, but it's a nice final touch if you're visiting the Nan Lian Gardens across the road. You can only walk through the outer courtyard with some pretty rocks and a gift shop.

Good looking temple - but not old. If you have time in Hong Kong, a trip to this Nunnery is a nice detour. The temple itself isn't old. And I didn't see any nuns myself. But the place makes for some good pictures. and you can read up on some history. Plus the inside is decorated with Bonsai trees. If you have time worth a visit. But if you are on a short schedule - skip it.

Stunning place. Wow....what a beautiful peaceful place. For a truly authentic experience this is a must do. The scenery within the nunnery is stunning, it is audit.support@concur.com"so well looked after and the Buddhists are incredible. Kowloon offers a much more authentic experience of Hong Kong and this place is fantastic, absolutely loved it. Even our 6 & 9 years old children enjoyed the experience and were amazed at the golden Buddhas.
Contemplation in the city. Very peaceful, tranquil and beautiful. Amazing architecture in the style of ancient China. Lots of buddha statues to admire or meditate in front of. Awesome

Peaceful, lovely temple complex. Combine this with the Nan Lien Garden for a perfect sunny afternoon. The temple is the largest hand-made wooden temple in the world, and constructed without a single nail. It's quiet and peaceful and, combined with the Garden (adjacent to the Nunnery), it really does make for a lovely getaway. It closes at 4:30 PM.

Tranquility abounds. A beautiful nunnery over a walkway from nan Lian Gardens this is a peaceful temple has undercover walkways surrounding internal courtyards/gardens. It also highlights different large stones / rocks on pedestals from all over China and displays information & ages of these, (may sound weird but they are beautiful). There are buddhist deities in this complex of wooden architecture built in 1934 as a retreat for buddhist nuns.
Formidastic. A must see for all visitors. An oasis of silence with only few visitors. Enjoy the chants while visiting this beautiful complex
Memorable. Well worth a visit, the Nunnery is peaceful and enlightening, with great multi lingual signage and information on Buddhism and artefacts within the site.
Amazing place. This place is very quite, calm place. its design from Tang Dynasty from China. the architecture was amazing. the garden was very beautiful
A quiet retreat. After a short underground ride we enjoyed wandering through this peaceful respite for about an hour. This and the adjoining Nan Lian Gardens were beautiful.

Beautiful tranquil Chinese Nunnery in the middle of busy Hong Kong district.. The nunnery is easy to get to, Diamond Hill MTR station then about 5min. walk. It opens up into a beautiful Chinese garden before you head on to the main buildings of the nunnery with excellent architecture and a place of peace and quiet. They also have a excellent chinese vegetarian restaurant(It is popular for lunch and early dinner so be there on time or wait in line!)
Visit this across from the Gardens. Not as note worthy as the gardens I feel for photos, but just as peaceful. Beautiful waterlilly pond. Gift shop worth a visit.

A day for reflection. The buildings really take you back to another time in cultural existence away from the demands of modern living. A great thunderstorm had everyone running for cover. The smell after rains soaks the hot grounds and soil a very special moment to enjoy.

An oasis in the middle of bustling Kowloon. If you are tired from all the shopping and eating that Hongkong has to offer, this is the place to be. It is patch of beauty & calm in the middle of skyscrapers. Beautiful Zen garden, airy temples, instagram worthy spots. Small snack shop and souvenir shops where you can get more noteworthy gifts to bring home. Best of all, it's just a short subway ride from the city center.

Timber temple. After coming from Sik Sik Yuen, one will find the nunnery over beside Diamond Hill eerily quiet - but no less beautiful. The Nan Lian gardens are worth checking out first, but once you are finished there step over the bridge to the large timber temple complex across the road. The outer courtyard is stunning, with small pools neatly organised around the garden and shaded cloisters around the edge if the sun is too overbearing. A large golden Buddha overlooks the square from the far end behind a wall of glass; photos are permitted of the courtyards but not of the interior rooms or statues. There are plenty of photo opportunities for the courtyards, but taking them from the side aisles may prove too dark for anything to be visible. The inner courtyard is smaller and lacks the pools of the first, but is just as serene. At the end of the walk, one will find the altar room of a giant golden Buddha enthroned and surrounded by four Boddhisvatas in statue form. It is a breathtaking sight, and a rather unique one as well. The main chamber was rather hot because it is not air conditioned; curiously they had several fans on, all facing Buddha rather than the viewing gallery. I am not sure why they thought Buddha might need to cool down; after all, he is only a statue.Security guards patrol the public areas, but aside from that any kind of administrative presence is non-existent and overall the entire place feels entirely free of westernisation or commercialisation. It is a tourist site, but not your typical attraction that is just there to get people through its doors spending money. Perhaps that is what makes it so peaceful.
Serene and tranquil! . Located at Diamond Hill MTR, peaceful and beautiful garden.. Relaxing 2 hour walk away from the hustle and bustle of life. Worth going if not in a hurry to leave Hong Kong!

Beautiful and calm. Tranquil place. Easy to get to from diamond hill mtr. Well signed. Well groomed facilities with lotus gardens and ponds. Entitled made without nails. Run female Buddhist nuns. Worth the trip. Not over crowded either with lots of room to move around.

Amazing - must do visit. A tranquil and beautiful place in the middle of bustling Kowloon. Slightly out of the way but worth it - easy to get to on MTR. Very meditative place. Great contrasts between old style and new.
Perfect. Such a nice quite and inpressive place in the middle if the hustle and bustle, if you want to join to the prayer with the locals make sure you bring long pants and socks

Stunning and peaceful. . This is located across the road from Nan Lian Gardens, and only a very short walk from Diamond Hill MTR Station. Easy to find by the street signs. Entry to both is free, and absolutely worth visiting. The buildings alone are worth seeing and they also provide a bit of information for the visitor, to help you understand what you are looking at. Lots of places to sit, relax and contemplate life.
Lovely. Even on a busy day this Nunnery is tranquil. Right next to the gardens it's a must see and also free.

Quiet and serene place to visit. The landscaping here is quite impressive, particularly the large bonsai trees. On the day we visited, there were very few people there, so we could thoroughly enjoy the spirituality of the temple without crowds of selfie-taking tour groups.

Tranquility amongst the "hustle and bustle" in Hong Kong. These beautiful buildings are set in the most serene gardens and ponds. An array of bonsai trees can be found here too. No photos allowed in the main building.
Gorgeous buildings. To think it is built without a single nail is amazing. Stunning buildings and serene garden in the middle.

Elegant wooden architecture. Chi Lin Nunnery is a large Buddhist temple complex located near Diamond Hill. You reach here taking MTR Diamond Hill Station Exit C2 and follow the signs (Walk for around 5 minutes). The temple treasures buddhist relics and soul-soothing lotus ponds. The statues are made from gold, clay, wood and stone. It's open to the public daily free of charge. Advice: It's not allowed to take pictures inside the nunnery with the selfie-stick!

A calm, beautiful place.. The nunnery and the adjacent garden are lovely and well worth visiting. There's a restaurant in the garden located behind a waterfall. Unfortunately we didn't visit at meal-time. This is a great place to escape the Hong Kong crowds. It's easy to access via the MTR.

Located in Diamond Hill, this peaceful little monastery is absolutely beautiful.. About a five minute walk from Diamond Hill MTR station is this remarkable large Buddhist temple complex which was founded in the 1930s. You wouldn't believe you were just a stone's throw from a busy main road, as the noise from outside disappears when you enter and you find yourself in a peaceful oasis to collect your thoughts.At first glance you'd think the buildings were very old, so I was surprised to find out that what you see was rebuilt completely out of wood in the late 1990s without using any metal - no nuts, bolts or nails, nothing! You can while away an hour or so wandering through the temple halls and the large gardens, complete with bonsai trees and decorative ponds. A definite must see.Tip: The halls and Chinese garden in front of the nunnery are open to the public daily and it's free entry.

Love it!. I went there intentionally, despite the far away location from our hotel. But the fact that it is close to the MTR makes the distance wont be a problem.The place is beautiful and serene. I'm glad when it is recommended to be one of the heritage sites. I believe it is worth it.

Nice positive sayings. The atmosphere of goodness prevails here with many sayings posted around the perimeter walk attached to sculptures. It was nice to listen to the chanting of the nuns and see the peaceful surroundings.

Nice Reprieve from busy Hong Kong. Lovely place for a peaceful stop away from the madness of Hong Kong. So many beautiful bonsai trees and amazing landscaping. Would not go out of my way to see it, but it is worth a visit if in the area. No more than a hour needed just to roam. Nothing fancy, just a lovely escape.

Must See. Something different and in a different location than expected.I implore anyone to travel to HK to visit this. Not only is it free but wonderful (and the best fridge magnets ever).I would also suggest coming here and eating at the nearby shopping centre as it has a big eatery with lots of authentic food to choose from.A surprise find and I certainly wouldn't miss
Good Park, landscape and peace. Coming here as my wife want to pray, but i found this place is quite peacefull, not so many people around, calm and nice landscape... love this place overall
Interesting place to visit. We really enjoyed the garden and the nunnery - beautiful peaceful place- it wasn't too crowded, very pleasant and worth experiencing.

Quiet Oasis. Beautiful place and a must see if you are in Hong Kong. Get the MTR to Diamond Hill and cross the road. Really well sign posts and less than two minutes away from the MTR. Quiet, peaceful, beautiful and we loved the music as we strolled around the temple. We then crossed the road via the bridge to enjoy the gardens and lunch in the restaurant. There is a cafe too if you don't want lunch.

Peaceful!. This is what an oasis in the city looks like. Beautiful and serene. This is a working nunnery and people do go there to pray. This is not a place for children. Excellent for quiet contemplation. Go early in the morning to avoid the tourists

Ancient Tang Dynasty style structure. A quiet place in the city centre. Had an illusion of going to Kyoto, haha. Better go there in the morning or late afternoon as the weather is getting very hot at noon.

A nice building with interesting statues. I'm not sure it's worth a separate trip, but it's right across the road from the Nan Lian garden. The building and the courtyard are very nice, the statues are quite interesting. Very close to the subway.

Quaint Nunnery. Modern timber built nunnery and courtyard. You are not allowed to take photos in the main hall or the inner courtyard (about half of the site). It is a little out of the way, but makes a decent trip if you see the neighbouring gardens. The nunnery is about 300m from Diamond MTR station. Free entry

A Hidden Hong Kong Gem. Headed out here today at the suggestion of my sister, an expat living in Hong Kong. What a great surprise to find this beautiful and peaceful place. Well maintained and stunning grounds. The gold Buddha is quite breathtaking. Not a lot of info available, but just a place to enjoy and amaze at the sheer size and grandeur. A hidden gem well worth the trip out to Diamond Hill.
probably the best example of traditional architecture in HK. try to go early in the morning, it's very serene. enjoyed the dimsum too, but was a bit pricey. easy access by mtr

Chi Lin Nunnery, Built Without Any Nails. This review is from our four week trip to Asia.Chi Lin Buddhist nunnery is easily reached via the MTR, Hong Kong’s underground train system. The MTR is very easy to use and incredibly efficient; select your destination by touching it on the map of the ticket machine, select how many tickets you want and then feed in the required amount of money. The machine will then spit out your tickets. The train lines are color coded so it’s easy to follow the signs in the station to your desired platform. The nunnery is famous for being constructed entirely from wood with no nails or other types of fasteners. Entry to the nunnery and the adjoining gardens is free and access to the temple halls is open to all, though no pictures are allowed to be taken in the actual prayer halls. There are 4 main halls that surround a series of lily ponds; though only constructed in 1997 the place has an ancient feel to it and is still very much an active facility. The adjoining Nan Lian Gardens are simply stunning; every tree, flower and shrub appear to have been precisely positioned around a central lake and each is perfectly pruned to create a wonderful experience. A large pagoda sits on an island in the center of the lake and a pair of brightly colored bridges connects the lake to the surrounding gardens. We followed a sweeping path for a peaceful stroll around the lake where we found a beautiful waterfall and further on a small teashop run by the nuns.
So different from Giant Budda. Don't try the lunch but enjoy a step back in time. Visited here right after the tram at Buddha and found it totally different but still a much see.
Peaceful. Absolutely loved this place. So peaceful and great to walk about on the sun. Excellent spot for photographs also. definitely worth a visit.

Add this to your itinerary. Take the time when visiting HK to catch the MTR to Diamond Hill and visit the Nan Lian garden and the Chi Lin Nunnery. Can be busy with crowds but its still a beautiful site outside of the shopping malls and crowded streets

Unbelievable beautiful place. Nan Lian Gardens are situated at Diamond Hill in Kowloon. They are connected to Chi Lin Nunnery Its all a short 2 min walk from The DHill MRT stationWe got greeted by a very friendly Security guard.The entry was free and we couldn't stop shooting photos.What a beautiful, calm place.Its very well looked after, clean and peaceful.All the people who we saw working on the garden beds were friendly and smilingThere is a vegetarian restaurant just behind a waterfall.The Bhudda trees are spectacular. The oldest tree we got told is over 300 years old and not really tall. We had the wow factors every minute.Inside a Hall is a Souvenir shop and a big Rock displayThe gardens closes at 4.30The Nunnery is very interesting as well but unfortunately no photos allowed.We would recommend 1.5 hours to see everything

If you love gardens you will love the Chi Lin Nunnery. Very accessible by MTR the Chi Lin Nunnery was a very spiritual experience. The gardens are spectacular. The atmosphere is very calm and relaxing.

Wow, a interesting look at Eastern Religion. The gardens are beautiful. like an oasis in the middle of a city. We took a taxi to get there, which I recommend, but took the MTR to go on to Big Budda from there.
Worth 30 minutes of your time. We were at the garden next door and ended up strolling into nunnery. Its beautiful chinese building with nice courtyard.

Amazing place - so beautiful and calm!. What a great place - full of grace and calmness. I enjoyed the atmosphere there very much. So peaceful and nice people. No place to take pictures, but to take great impressions with you. A must visit in HK!

A place that a Princess from an European country requested to visit. Because of my previous job, I went to this place frequently. The place was funded by some Hong Kong very famous celebrities, and the 'theme' is buddha (but not a temple). This 'park' was built, following the buildings of the ancient Chinese 'Tong' Dynasty. There is one vegetarian restaurant and also a Chinese tea house (both open day time only). I highly recommend the vegetarian restaurant.The place is close to the MTR station (Diamond Hill) and after your visit, you may consider to visit Hong Kong's most iconic temple in Wong Tai Sin, just one more MTR station. However, Chi Lin has very straight rules - quiet (not a children friendly place), no blocking (don't bring your camera stand) and they do not even allow you to read newspaper (not my concern). But I think it's a great way in enjoying a quiet atmosphere. BTW, even an European princess came to Hong Kong, she personally asked to come here for a visit.

Peaceful and tranquil. A peaceful, tranquil place to visit - not often known to tourists I don't think. It is very easy to get to, once you get off at Diamond Hill MTR station. The signage to the nunnery is good and it's only a five minute walk. It is only a small nunnery, but features lovely landscaped gardens and 'hall's which you can spend some reflection time. The gardens next door are lovely too, and Hollywood Plaza is a good place for shopping and food in the area (also right next to the MTR).

local sightseeing in hongkong. a beautiful and very serene place to visit. there is no entry fees. it has beutiful ponds with lotus, bonsai trees all around. You can offer your prayers in front of buddha statue. Adjoing is a beautiful park named Nan lian park which has pictursque views. A covered restaurant under waterfall, lake, a small museum which has chineese handicrafts but very costly. Alltogether nice place to spend 2-3 hours.

Off the tourist track but worth a visit. You will be hard pressed to find anyway as peaceful in this busy city.We visited on a Wednesday morning and it was almost as if we had the place to ourselves. We had plenty of time to have a good look around, take some photographs and appreciate this fine building.

One of my favorite places in Hong Kong. I love visiting this nunnery and the garden right next to it. It is so beautiful and relaxing. It is also free! I learned on the last trip there that there are no selfie sticks allowed as you can mistakenly hurt other people, i.e. turning around and hitting someone with it. This is definitely a place to visit when you come to Hong Kong! I always recommend it to visitors and then to visit the temple at Wong Tai Sin afterward or vice versa.

Breathtaking. It was an honour to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery, with its beautiful gardens and wonderful temples. It is requested that photos are not taken of the shrines as a sign of respect which is understandable.

Quiet oasis in the midst of chaos. This was my daughter's first choice of places to show me. It is just spectacular. Had it not been for the heat, I would have spend much longer just sitting and enjoying the peace and quiet.

This is part of the Nan Lian Garden. Another Buddhist temple in HK. This is part of a beautiful garden. The place is very nice but remember there were lot of restrictions on photography and to access certain areas.

Peaceful, meticulous, art in architecture at its best.. This is a welcome respite in a hustle-bustle city. The gardens, ponds and pavilions are perfect. Look at the artwork, special exhibits, and the detail in the planning and layout. The chanting of the monks can be heard but the incense is not overwhelming as at other locations. Then, walk from here to the Nan Lian gardens. You will not get the full effect of either location unless you have visited both. Don't rush--sit under the cool banyan tree glade and listen to the birds.

Chi Lin Nunnery - worth a visit. We went here and surprisingly there was no one here. Good place to visit for some history, the place was spotless and the Buddas and explanations were very good - worth a visit. The ladies in the souvenir shop were pleasant and happy for us to just look around.

Peaceful, fascinating architecture. It's a temple in outskirts Hongkong city. Everything made of wood and NO nails all. If you are intrigue with architecture, this is really the place for you. You can feel the peacefulness immediately when you step in. There's another garden opposite this, so don't get mistaken. It seems you can get vegetarian food free but I can't locate where. Place is quite big. 1-2 hours more than enough to explore
Don't miss it.....literally. We were so taken with the gardens that we nearlly missed the connecting bridge over to the nunnery. Look for sign to Lotus Ponds Garden and be amazed. It is stunning.
Peaceful Walk. Nothing special or exciting, but if you want a peaceful walk in the afternoon with family and friends, its a nice place to be and can bring little snacks and walk along
Calm and peaceful in the midst of skyscrapers. beautiful buddhist nunnery with tranquility and bliss. Visit the nunnery and Nan Lian Garden together (its right next to the nunnery).

Attractive nunnary convenient location.. The traditional style nunnary is conveniently located next to diamond hill metro station and connected to Nan Lian gardens via a foot bridge over the road. The nunnary is on a reasonable plot although it is really only the temple section you can see, but the mountain back drop and simple wood style makes it a attractive example of this try of building. it was also quite quiet when we went even though it was a weekend making it a good way to escape the hussle and bussle of the city for a while. Both the nunnary and gardens opposite are free.

Lovely Oasis in Hong Kong. The Chi Lin Nunnery is a very beautiful, tranquil nunnery in Hong Kong. It's in most of the tourist books for visiting the city, but is kind of buried behind more popular sites such as the Big Buddha (Po Lin Monastery) and Wong Tai Sin Temple. The nunnery is very easy to get to and is a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. Entrance is free, however donations are recommended. There's a nice gift shop downstairs from the main temple. The nunnery is crowded with exceptional bonsais and beautiful gardens, including the water garden. It's very much worth the visit.

Mosquito Haven. We were literally eaten alive by sand flies so don't forget the bug spray!Otherwise, the nunnery makes for a perfectly pleasant stroll and a great respite from the concrete jungle of Hong Kong. Admission is free but there're boxes for you to leave a donation. Get there early because tour buses sometimes make a stop at the nunnery.And while here, don't forget to have lunch at the vegetarian restaurant located in the Nan Lian Garden next door.

Peaceful Haven. When we entered the nunnery, we were taken aback by the beautiful setting, lotus flowers in bloom, water ponds and the ancient feel of the building. it looked like a scene from a Chinese movie. It is set with the mountains in the background and is stunningly beautiful. Photos of the altars are prohibited however you may take photos of the surroundings.

The most beautiful temple in HKG. Easy to reach from Diamond Hill MTR station, with a very lovely (Japonese style) Park in front of it, this wooden temple is just amazing.Surrounded by buildings, it offers a hiding place of relaxation, with a quiet atmosphere, beautiful and symetrical bonsais or other ornamental trees in the courtyard.A visit I systematically suggest to all HKG visitors !

Beautiful oasis in Kowloon. Enjoyed a stroll in the gardens after a nice lunch in the vegetarian restaurant at the nunnery. Beautiful well kept garden with a host of water features. They also have a museum, cafe, restaurant and gift shop. Well worth the visit.

Wonderful. This is a truely great experience, wonderful gardens, peaceful and also smells great, lovely plants and tress and also educational, a nice cafe inside to buy a cold drink, well work a visit.

Peaceful and interesting place in the heart of Kowloon. It is a nice place to visit and learn about Buddhism. They also maintain the gardens, which are beautiful. The vegetarian restaurant they run is also very good, if slightly pricey.

Nunnery and gardens. Worth your time to walk through this peaceful and lovely setting. It is up the stairs near the end of the path in the Nan Lian gardens. Entrance is free to both the gardens and the nunnery. An unexpected delight in the middle of a busy city. Just a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station with English signs pointing the way.

Peaceful and Zen in the midst of hustle and bustle. Chi Lin Nunnery is easily accessible by MTR (Diamond Hill station). Close by there is another attraction, Nan Lian Garden. Housed in a monastery complex, the nunnery is reminiscent of the Tang Dynasty in its architecture, and was built in the 1930s. It is a gorgeous place with impressive woodwork and craftsmanship. There are several lotus ponds and great photography opportunity during lotus season. Lotus represent purity in the ancient Chinese culture which is befitting of the serenity and zen-like atmosphere of Chi Lin Nunnery. Lotus flower bloom early in the morning during summer time so go before 10am if you want to take pictures of the blooming lotus.
Peaceful place for reflection. This was a lovely treasure of a place, a peaceful oasis from the busy city. Attached to the Nan Lian gardens, which were also great.
Peaceful . A peaceful/tranquil place to hang out and reflect on life. A great place to visit for the afternoon or morning. You don't feel like you are in a city at all.

Peaceful, chill and fresh air. Here is a very peaceful and quite place. I like the traditional style of temple and stunning golden pavilion inside the garden.Moreover, there's a very nice design of waterfall cover the restaurant. That's cool.

Chi Lin Nunnery and Vegan Restaurant. . My husband and I are frequent travellers to Hong Kong. We try to find something new each time we visit. This trip found us at the amazing Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautiful grounds well maintained. However across the road is the Nan Lian Gardens which are maintained by the Nunnery. Quiet, peaceful, a little peace of heaven in a busy city. Manicured lawns, gorgeous array of flower beds and trees and as you walk through you come across a waterfall. When you look closely you can see people sitting inside the restaurant which is hidden amongst the trees. It is the Chi Lin vegan restaurant. We decided to have lunch and we were lucky enough to sit behind the waterfall. Truely magical. We ordered the lunch special as we didn't quite understand what we were eating. It was 3 courses and all tastey. For a quiet escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong this is the place to come and to feel at peace.
Beautiful. Its always nice to witness and experience new things. The lotus ponds are so pretty and Buddhist hall is calming. Recommend to anyone looking for some nature and calm in a busy city.
Worth a visit. Free admission, attached to the gardens. Peace and serenity abound. No tripods or selfie sticks allowed!!

Great sight!. It's a lovely sight. Beautiful nunnery.. It's easy to get here with the mtr to Diamond hill station and the a few minutes walk. And there's a lovely garden right next to it. Worth the trip.

Stunning architecture and quiet piety. This large temple complex in Tang style has been artfully rebuilt about 20 years ago, all in cypress wood and using classical joinery techniques. I visited a half dozen times over the years and it was never crowded, being so big (16 halls, plus other buildings). It is a functioning monastery and the large golden statues of Buddha, Guanyin and other bodhisattvas are not meant to be photographed (but no restriction for photos outside). The atmosphere is of quiet serenity and the contrast with the high rise buildings in the distance is striking. Visitors usually access it from the Nan Lian Garden, over the broad bridge linking them. Access to both places is free and they are less than 5 mn walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station.
Stunning. Shame there are no photos permitted in the inner area, for it was jaw-dropping. However, I understand and respect that. Photos are permitted in the outside gardens.
Peaceful. Easy to get to on MTR. Well worth spending an hour or so in Chi Lin Nunnery. It is peaceful and a welcome break from the hustle of Hong Kong.
Zen. Worth the tube ride to Diamond Hill. I also enjoyed the adjoining public park. Quite a different place than the rest of HK. Recommended if you get bored of shopping.
Peaceful. Do this and the Nan Lian garden and the restaurant run by the nuns in 1 go. Such a great way to see Hong Kong

Peaceful Zen Garden. 12 Mar 2016, visited.Took MTR to Diamond Hill. Exit from C2. Will find a direction board indicating the route. Walk about 3 minutes.Peaceful monastery linked by an overhead bridge to its annexe garden. Zen garden with pond, waterfalls, pavilions surrounded by light soothing Japanese music. Heard the Japanese music accompanied by the birds chirping and water sounding really all perfect. Enjoyed. Took about an hour to see all. Little visitors as it's not really popular with international tourists. Glad to be there.
Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful place in HK. Take your time around the Nunnery and then go down to Nan Lian Garden just across the street (take the overpass that goes straight from one to the other).

City Tranquility . Located next to the Diamond Hill metro station, this temple covers a good size of land in the hustle city. All low buildings were constructed without a single nail. There is a small exhibition there to explain how this works.It is a pleasure to talk around this Nunnery which has a big fish pond and a few beautifully constructed pagodas next to many beautifully crafted plants.Entry is free. There is a vegetarian restaurant inside which is not cheap but of super quality. An inexpensive cafe too to allow visitors to pause, rest and have a cup of nice coffee.

Really worth it. When one goes to Hong Kong and thinks of Buddhist temples the one most people go to is the Po Lin Monestry at Lantau island. Having been there on a few ocassions apart from the cable car ride I cannot think of another reason for going there. This is however a review about Chi Lin Nunnery, a place well worth going to.The nunnery has a very interesing Buddhist temple with great statues set inside some fantastic old buildings. The traditional archetecture is very interesting and full of character. The gardens are large and well kept with many different types of features. These include water features including a working water wheel, fountains and ponds.The vegetarian restaurant set in the grounds serves excellent food. I went there for the afternoon tea set and was surprised. The sweet platter I choose had a great taste and the cheesecake was one of the best I have had in a long time and certainly one of the best I have had in this part of the world.Overall, I would now try to make it a point to go to this complex everytime I visit Hong Kong and I would strongly suggest anyone visiting to also come here.

An Absolute Must if you visit Hong Kong.. The nunnery is an expanse of tranquility in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The quietness and serenity along with fabulous landscaping are well worth the visit.

Nice Vegetarian dinner at a nunnery. Located within walking distance from Diamond Hill MTR station. We came to the restaurant for dinner. It was packed since it was a public holiday but they did have two seats at the bar. The food was not bad, esp. since I prefer to eat meat. The scenery outside is great and most importantly, free admission.
Peaceful. I really loved this place, How calm and peaceful to just spend couples of hours wondering around and taking pictures of the nature.

A great place for some peace and quiet. This is one of my favourite places to come in Hong Kong. It is very peaceful, not normally very busy and the gardens are lovely.It is right next to Diamond Hill MTR so easy to get to. Its nice to combine this with other sites in the area. I recommend seeing 10'000 buddhas, then back to Wong Tai Sin, then one stop over to this place.On the way back to your hotel stop off at Prince Edward MTR and head to Tim Ho Wan for some Dim Sum
Beautiful. A quiet moment in a buzzing city! Come and enjoy the beauty. You will not regret it. It is a short ride by MTR and there is a teahouse also with great snacks.
A tranquil retreat. One of our highlights in Hong Kong, the nunnery is set on a hillside and would have had an amazing outlook when first built.

Goosebumps. What a gem of a place, so glad I visited the nunnery. It is a beautiful temple (and pretty colossal) tucked away in the centre of Hong Kong next to a stunning garden. The atmosphere is one of complete peace and tranquility. No tour needed - just walk around and take it all in.

Worth a visit. Beautiful nunnery with gardens, very pleasant. You wouldn't know you were in the middle of Hong Kong except for the surrounding high rises. It was Buddha's birthday so we got to "bathe the baby Buddhas" at the altar. Beautiful altars and shrines. A peaceful place.

Wonderful! . A great place to go. Connected to the gardens , together they make a lovely and calming environment. The temple is absolutely gorgeous and the staff were very friendly, showing us how to participate in a bathing Buddha ritual which was neat to see. Overall both the gardens and the temple are a must!

A little and unknown gem in Kowloon. Chi Lin Nunnery is a lovely buddhist temple complex in the Diamond Hill district of Kowloon. Situated opposite site of Nan Lian Garden, the complex offers a nice setup for relaxation. Since it is not nearby any major tourist attractions, Chi Lin Nunnery is not visited by many people.

Excellent. You should definitely take out the time to visit Chi Lin Nunnery and the gardens there. We went quite late in the day so only got about an hour before they closed so check the times before visiting.

Tranquility in the midst of millions. This is such a beautiful place to visit to get far from the maddening crowd. It is beautifully cared for and is so amazing to have this tranquility, surrounded by high-rise and millions of people. Compare it with the Wong Tai Sin temple on the same day to get a glimpse of Hong Kong.

Beautiful architecture. This temple is easily accessible via the MRT. It's very serene with beautiful wooden architecture, lush bonsai trees and water lilies. Free entry, closes at 4:30 pm. No photos allowed in the inner courtyard. Definitely worth a visit.
good . This place was quite. It's for pray. I like the water and that plants on it . Also the design . From there you can go to the garden and spend more time with the nature.

Tranquil Oasis within HK. Within easy reach of an MTR station and a mall, this temple is surrounded by beautiful gardens and is a very peaceful place to visit even when fairly busy. There's many places to sit in the gardens too. The temple itself is worth visiting, no photography inside as it's a 'working' temple.There's a restaurant within the gardens too, but we did not like that so much.

Peace in the midst of chaos. This is a beautiful spot which feels quite peaceful and serene even though you are very close to busy roads and buildings. It is a very short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. The nunnery itself has very nice architecture and small ponds with lotus flowers and statues. It is also attached to beautiful gardens to walk around. The whole place is very photogenic. The gardens have restaurants and gift shops attached. I would highly recommend visiting here if you want a break from shopping and walking the busy streets.

Gorgeous. Beautiful oasis in the middle of high flats. The nunnery and the gardens are beautifully maintained, almost Japanese like, more tone downed than the usual glitzy Chinese style. A lot of use of wood which makes it very archaic and beautiful. It's all rebuilt in 1990, but the nunnery exists already since 1934, so it's authentic. Beautiful to the eye and for the soul in busy Hong Kong. Recommended!

Away from the crowd... zen. This nunnery is next to nan lian garden within walking distance to diamond hill mtr station. It is a place not many go to because it is not on the common tourist group list. Hence it is a good place to visit for tourists like us who dislike crowds. Over here the nunnery is a very serene, peaceful and zen place to visit. There is rich chinese and japanese architecture involved here with a golden pagoda that resembles the gold pagoda in kyoto. The place is not huge but it is a good place to walk around to enjoy the flora and fauna.
Beautiful oasis smack in the middle of housing estates. There is a beautifully designed Japanese style garden in the grounds near the nunnery which provides one with an oasis of peace and serenity.
Chi Lin Nunnery. This is totally a place worth visiting. Its a short walk from the MTR station. It is so beautiful ! quite magical really. I would say a "don't miss" on your trip to Hong Kong.
Chayuttorn . the place is nearby mrt and easy to find. there are so green inside ,full with green tree, like forest covered you,Nice place nice view

Chi Lin Nunnery. You have two phenomenal attractions here in one place. The Chi Lin Nunnery AND the Nan Lian Garden(s). IF you have the time and are willing to go to the effort to visit the two of them you will not be disappointed in them. I am NOT ' into ' such places but my wife's niece took me with her on her visit to Hong Kong and my life is just that much better for the experience.

My Favorite Spot in Hong Kong - Tranquil and Beautiful. This nunnery is so tranquil and beautiful. The ponds, gardens, bonsai and temple are all exquisite. Go and spend time relaxing in this lovely environment. If you only have time to see a few things in Hong Kong, this must be on your list. Not to be missed.
Beautiful and serene. Situated opposite Nan Lian Gardens thus serene Nunnery is quiet and peaceful with many large Buddhas in several locations.

A peaceful oasis. This park was a real find. Never have I seen such a collection of rocks, many adorned with wise Chinese sayings. It was so quiet, an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. There was a fine collection of Murano glass wear. A cafe was attended to by the nuns and there is a restaurant as well. I would recommend this park, a short walk from Diamond Hill station.

Beautiful and serene. Hard to find if you take the bus (thank goodness for Google maps) but super easy if you take the MTR! A lovely serene oasis in the middle of HK. The gardens opposite are beautiful for a stroll around. Worth a visit!

A soul fix. During a visit in hectic Hongkong where you can sometimes hardly move in the masses of people, this place is an absolute must. I had to get a real close look at some of the trees and plants to check if they were real because they look so perfect. Apparently the Chi Lin vegetarian restaurant also seems to be really good, unfortunately I did not have enough time to eat there.

Architecture and peace!. This is connected to nan lian garden by a short walk way. The buildings are very traditional Japanese in style. Lots of Buddhist statues. Very well kept and maintained. I found it very peaceful. The buildings are just gorgeous. Photos inside the shrines are not permitted. Gift shop.One of the must see places in Hong Kong

They DO build them like that anymore!. I'd read tourist guides, spoken to our concierge, and read the TA reviews, but it wasn't clear that the Chi Lin Nunnery were worth visiting, they sounded new and tacky. But we were nearby anyway, so we did. It was lovely! An oasis in a metropolis. The attached Nan Lian gardens where immaculate but still organic and friendly. But the monastery is really quite something from another era. It was actually built in the 1990's but could have been built a thousand years ago. They used construction techniques and materials contemporary with temple construction from up to a thousand years ago, as showcased in the gardens. The grand scope, yet attention to detail in all the fountains is amazing! Not a screw in the entire place and apparently one of the largest pure wood structures in the world. And it exudes a sense of calm, as you would hope. The various shrines all have statues that all have stories behind them of the craftspeople that create them.I think in another thousand years time the Chi Lin Nunnery will still be standing and considered one of the most impressive feats of 20th century building.

beautiful buildings and peaceful. Free, easy to get to, and nice to walk around,
Check the opening times and if there are any events at the time, as it closes to the public during certain events.
Nice to look around, very peaceful and interesting and not as crowded as expected.
I would go again for a relaxing few hours.

Beautiful and Peaceful. We went to the Nunnery during our stay in Hong Kong.It was very quiet and serene. We walked and took many pictures. You can walk around it in less than an hour but it is worth it to see. I love seeing the Chinese culture and design.(Getting a taxi from the area was hard. Taxi's here cannot stop on a solid line and will drive right by. )

Don't miss the gardens when you go!. My wife had seen reviews on the Nunnery and Adjoined Gardens. Easy enough to get there on the MTR and very glad we went early in the day when it was cooler. The site is immaculate and tranquil. We wandered through the gardens and exhibits there first and then migrated to the nunnery. The architecture was impressive as well as the central courtyard. Would go again if in Hong Kong.

Beautiful garden in the midst of the city!. We made it here by bus. We actually went April 2015 but this does not allow me to select an earlier date. He weather was quite humid - bring umbrella & wear sunscreen. I just brought a hydration pack (small camelback) to keep cool & keep my wallet & phone; this was convenient when traveling by public transportation. sunglasses & umbrella helped quite a bit too. There is no entrance fee to the garden but I believe some museums within the garden either asked for donations or required a fee. Midway through the garden there is a little shop that served cold drinks & snacks. The Nunnery itself was closed the day we went (maybe that's why it wasn't busy). Wear comfortable shoes because to see is to walk! A lot! Great photo ops throughout!
Nice. Its a good place across the road from the Nan Lian Gardens, you have to go to both and its different, not very big but good for a few hours relaxing
The Nunnery . A must visit on a trip to Hong Kong. The Nunnery was built using no nails which is truly an amazing feat of construction. Very calminv and peaceful. Very easy to get to on the MTR

Chilin' haha!. Very nice and relaxed walk around the grounds at the nunnery. An escape from the busy city. The gardens across the bridge is also worthwhile heading to. I prefer this place to the busy OTT temples.
Unexpected. Beautiful, calm and quiet, very diferent from the gardens in Shanghai surroudings full of loudy people. Amazing images and altars. And the garden attach is amazing.
good place to visit. enjoyable experience in the middle of built up area, relaxing and enjoyable. the vegetarian restaurant is definitely worth a visit

Very cute little place for couples in Hong kong!. In the middle of a modern themed looking nunnery, there is a chi lin restaurant which looks beautiful. Although its all vegetarian the dishes will be enjoyable and healthy , meat look alikes and definately worth the experience. Not overpriced too!

Serene place amidst HK city. Go there if u like to admire the finer details like art and history. Personally liked the wooden buildings built without any screws but with the ancient way of inter locking wood. The Buddhist halls transport you to a different world altogether. The lake and the overall architecture are noteworthy too. Go there for a quick getaway from the usual malls and hustle bustle from the city.
Nice scene. Its a beautiful place amongst the high buildings in a busy city. Also nice to visit the garden that lies across the street.
Tranquillity in a bustling city. Beautiful, tranquil place and definitely worth a visit to escape from the frenetic pace of the city.

Beautiful and peaceful. We made the trip to the Nan Lian garden and it connects directly to the Chi Lin nunnery. Both places are free, and Definately worth the trip. It was a relaxing day, after the hustle & bustle of the city. Really easy to get to....take MTR to Diamond Hill. Just follow the signs. Just one block away from train.

Just beautiful - a must see. The Chi Li Nunnery is a spotless clean temple with lovely gardens. The atmosphere is serene with religious music or chants played. Beautiful wooden structure, and impressive Buddhist statues. Amazing rocks are exhibited. Easily accessed by MRT Diamond Hill, exit C2, 5 mn walk. Free entrance, and access to Nan Lian Gardens across the street. Bus N°10 direct to Kowloon Walled City Park.

A relaxing moment far from the modern-day Hong Kong.. It is not as old as it looks, but built in Tang Dynasty architecture. Built of cypress wood, without the use of any nails. Located at the foot of Diamond Hill in north Kowloon amidst high-rise apartment blocks. Filled with beautiful Buddha figures contain gold, clay and wooden statues

WOW. Breath taking beauty. I highly recommend visiting this place for a little piece and quiet. The architecture, ponds and flowers are so beautiful and they each have a spiritual purpose for being there and you will find one to:)
Interesting. Worth a visit combined with the garden. Didn't quite live up to expectations but worth visiting with the garden. Allow max 2 hours for both
Serenity in the midst of the hush bush. Very nice place and atmosphere to say especially if you are in Hong Kong for longer. The atmosphere is very calming and the architecture is worth noting.

peaceful and quiet. this nunnery is connected to nan lian garden by a walking bridge. like nan lian garden, chi lin nunnery was built in a japanese art and architectural style rather than the chinese ones. it is amazingly located in the hilly surrounding with a contrast city skyline as a backdrop. there is not much info provided. no monks or nun anywhere to be seen. it would be much better if they run a tour with info of this place. people particularly foreign visitors would get more idea what is nunnery, and why it is there.note: admission to the nunnery is free.

Such a peaceful walk. A bit away from all the main attractions in HK but worth the journey to come and explore this beautiful and peaceful place. Bring your camera with you, you will need it. Located right next to a big shopping mall, so if you want to grab some food this is where you will want to do that.

An hour is not enough . This place is so beautiful and calm, you almost instantly get carried away from the street noises of the big city. Chanting monks, smell of incense, carved walls and pillars, intricate rocks with buddhist wisdoms... You simply forget you are in one of the most crowded cities in the world! I had just an hour for my visit and it definitely is not enough to thoroughly enjoy this amazing place!

Interesting. Visited the Chi Lin Nunnery which was interesting and the Buddha's were mind blowing but unfortunately you could not take photos in the main hall which was disappointing but well worth a visit.
Peaceful place. This place is very quiet, with beautiful gardens and temples with gold statues. Areal is very clean!
Peaceful temple. Very peaceful and beautiful temple with huge garden full of flowers and trees!! My parents and my young children love it so much!! Will visit again!

Chi Lin Nunnery. Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens are a must see when in Hong Kong. Both are situated together and a very short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station. Set in beautiful garden surroundings, the nunnery is a peaceful haven from the traffic and noise of busy Hong Kong. The building is a very impressive timber structure and contains many Buddha statues of worship, many inlaid with gold.

Beautiful Relaxing Afternoon. Went with my GF at her request and I was pleasently surprised. It's not a place I would have chosen on my own, but I really enjoyed the beautiful Bonzi garden, Koi Ponds, water falls, and over all beautiful scenery.

A beautiful temple complex. My wife and I visited Chi Lin Nunnery when we went to Nan Lian Gardens. The two are seamlessly connected. The nunnery was modeled after Tang Dynasty architecture. It is a large temple complex consisting of many wooden structures, elegantly designed and built. Entrance is through a few flights of steps. After passing through the courtyard we entered the first of three halls. The halls housed many gold, wood and clay statues of various buddhas. We did not visit the second hall. It was more of the same. The third hall was closed to visitors.At the side of the temple complex there is a lotus pond, but it being winter time the lotus were not in full bloom. Nevertheless, it was soul-soothing when relaxing by the pond. We can also have another view of Nan Lian Gardens, this time from a higher vantage point.Most visitors would combine these two attractions in one visit. It would be time well spent, away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Beautiful. Really lovely spot to visit if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of every day Hong Kong life. Really quite beautiful and serene.

Beautiful peaceful temple and gardens. A perfect escape from HK Island and the centre of Kowloon. I'd recommend taking the bus and seeing more of HK on your way. We spent around 2 hours exploring the temple, eating vegetarian food from the Nunnery and enjoying the adjacent islands. It is all free to visit. The gardens are impeccable and the carp and bonsais are a real treat. Highly recommended.

Beautiful gardens. This is really a place you should not miss. In the middle of the buzzing atmosphere and street hell of Hong Kong one can find this place of relative tranquillity. The gardens are fantastic and a great example for the Chinese way of portraying and re-creating nature in a pre-defined space. Great! To be put on the top five list for Hong Kong.
Interesting.. Visited here 8years ago, nothing has changed, a lovely, interesting place to visit. Very quiet which is quite amazing as it is by a main road.
Peace in a busy city.. Lovely and relaxing. A gem of a place to visit in Hong Kong. Surrounding park area was beautiful....

OK if you are vegetarian!. I am not terribly impressed with the nunnery. It is poshy looking and very formal .I was taken there because one school classmate of mine is a vegetarian and likes to take us there whenever there is an old student reunion. The worst part is that we have to eat vegetarian meals whenever we go there. Fair enough , it is a nunery. But count me out next time!

Beautiful and peaceful. Stunningly beautiful place and so refreshing after having visited the Tian Buddha which is so commercialised. The gardens on the other side of the road are simply gorgeous and serene. The architecture is fabulous and we were really impressed by the scale models of other temples.

Tranquil and pretty oasis in HK. Although living in HK for a few years only recently visited the nunnery when we had visitors from overseas. HK is remarkable with the juxtaposition of extreme urbanization as well as green pockets dotted around the city. Chi Lin nunnery is a little like that, not due to its green nature but due to the tranquil, peaceful and slow paced environment. It is kept in perfect order and is a pleasant 1 to 2 hour place to visit whilst in HK and wishing to seek a little culture and/or history. It has a number of small temples within which like the grounds are well kept and in prefect order.If you want to go beyond shopping in HK I would recommend a visit.

Go back in time. Combine a visit to the gardens next door and you will experience a quieter element of Hong Kong. 2 minutes from Diamond Hill station this is a lovely place to visit. You will also see lots of locals always a good indication. You will see a number of shrines and the locals will be praying so some respect is necessary.

Great Buddhist temple.. Connected to the Nan Lian Garden, this temple is also a must see. There are several shrines along the side of the compound, and the main one in the center is breathtaking. Entry is free and you can take your time walking through and still be done in about 30 minutes. Take the Diamond Hill MTR stop for this site. It is well worth it.

Peaceful!. 5 minutes from Diamond Hill station (exit C2) and located within the Nan Lian Garden complex, the nunnery is beautiful. They have different rooms dedicated to different deities. Very serene and calm.
Tranquility in midst of Chaos . The place to visit to clear one's mind. Back to the nature and listen to the nature by closing your eyes. The perfect retreat place.

Very interesting. Right next to the park - diamond hill mtr and follow exit c2 and follow the signs! It's beautiful inside and very tranquil- no photos allowed inside - I don't know much about Buddhism but they have signs to explain - it was well worth the visit!

Wonderful place - Highly recommend a visit. This place is a peaceful oasis in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. It is easy to get to - just a short walk from Diamond Hill off the MTS subway. I had a wonderful walk around a very serene garden and nunnery.
Please go if you can - you won't regret it!
Beautiful temple. This temple is bigger than most of the temples in HK. People go there to worship their gods so one should observe silence when visiting this place.
