You feel peace in your soul and enjoy every minute there.Not to be missed if you have the time ,you can go there using MTR also there is a shopping mall nearby if you want to grab something to eat and rest.

Gorgeous Bonzai. The Chi Lin Nunnery is one of the "must see" in Hong Kong. The tranquility and beauty of the garden was awesome. The bonzai trees were spectacular. The various temples could only be seen from the outside, which was a bit of a shame but understandable as this is a inhabited nunnery. Tip: If you take a taxi there, be prepared to take the underground back. It is impossible to flag down a taxi and the underground station is just down the road. Very easy to figure out where to go too.

A superb and tranquil Buddhist experience in the heart of Kowloon. This is an amazing park! With incredibly well manicured trees and with good exhibits to explain how wooden buildings are constructed with the interlocking beams.Of course the highlight are the temples that are relegated to the upper part of the park.A little vegetarian restaurant on the Eastern edge of the park can expand your Buddhist experience when visiting this venue!

Oasis of calm in the busy city. The nunnery is an oasis of calm and tranquility in the midst of the hustle and bustle that is Kowloon. The Nan Lian a gardens are a prelude to the nunnery with remarkable landscaped rock gardens and samples of nail less timber architecture. The nunnery has long corridors with rock art and lily ponds. A gorgeous place! For more details and photos please visit my blog at www.travelswithrarecat.blogspot.ca search for Chi Lin Nunnery.

Stunning Architect. Stunning Architect. The tour guide will tell you every piece of the building is made by wooden nail and ancient technique. Very impressive. A must, if you fascinate about Chinese ancient building.

The manicured gardens,and the Temple and the history behind it is great. A lovely security man had the patience to talk to me and explain more about the nunnery than what was written in the handouts Thanks

Beautifully Maintained Garden. Not far off a walk from Diamond Hill MTR. The nunnery and the Nan Lian Garden surrounding the nunnery was so so beautiful. The weather in July was so hot, but if I had more time and the weather was better, I'd spend the whole day. Wonderfully maintained.

Oasis in the City. A bit out of the way but worth the trip! It's a lovely oasis in the middle of the usual conglomeration of Hong Kong high-rises. Lots of photo opportunities and a great to just sit and contemplate beauty. Eat before or plan to go somewhere else after -- but the gift shop was lovely...I would go back there.
Zen experience with wonderful food. a highly recommended place for tourist even if you are not vegetarian.must go must go. good food good people

Tranquility in a busy city. If you are looking for something different, Chi Lin is something that will give your a very good surprise. Set by Diamond Hill MTR Station, the temple is a place to worship and to enjoy an escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. You could also enjoy very nice vegetarian lunch in the restaurant. Landscape are very special.

Tranquility within Hong Kong. This is a beautiful newly built and perfectly maintained monastery in the middle of the hustle and bustle on Hong Kong. There is an amazing display of bonsai trees and elaborate shrines. Across the street are the gardens with a fantastic vegetarian restaurant. Makes for a very enjoyable afternoon.

Excellent in combination with the Nan Lian gardens!!. Built in 1933, the building itself is absolutely gorgeous.Specialy if you look at the contrast with the concrete skyscarpers in the back.Make sure you behave appropriately ( like in every religious site) as there are a lot of people coming there to pray.Together with the the gardens it makes a perfect half a day trip.To get there take MTR to Diamond Hill, once outside there are signposts, follow them.Free admission.
Worth the trip. A beautiful oasis in the hustle of hong kong. The nunnery is easily accessible by either train or bus and is surrounded by beautiful gardens.

Quite heaven in the middle of an urban jungle. Visited with my wife last year and it was absolutely phenomenal and quiet. Which is surprising, given it's surroundings in the urban jungle. The gardens are quite elaborate and expansive so you may want to print out the map and plan your visit. There is a huge shipping mall nearby.

interesting for a look while visiting the gardens across the road. had a good look around. The building itself was made out of wood with no nails used ! that was interesting.. there are nice little ponds with fish (of course) although the gardens across the road are worth spending more time in

Great cultural experience. Very close to MTR train station with Nan Lian Garden across road so two great visits in one, both with free admission.
The nunnery is a very beautiful sacred building which is designed amongst beautiful landscape gardens and brings a sense of calmness. The temples have spectacular Budda's, their history and stories.

Very spiritual experience. The nunnery is a very calm and peaceful place to visit. For me however, I found the different rooms around the courtyard with varying icons in each to be most moving, at the time there was also locals worshiping these icons with prayer.
A surprising temple in a beautiful setting.

Also Fantastic. Next to NanLian gardens.
A real gem in tourism that you would never believe.
Well worth the visit.
An historic religious area in the middle of high rise.

Perfect place to pause and reflect. Our children and ourselves loved the nunnery. Free to stroll individually and enjoy the quietness in the midst of the city. Well kept, manicured gardens, gorgeous setting. Be respectful to the surroundings and environment.
Toilets are available.

Most beautiful gardens in Hong Kong. The Nunnery itself is close to the public, but you may visit the prayer room below the gift shop. BUT if you go across the walkway over the busy road, you will come to the most beautiful gardens in Hong Kong !! Stunning, and so amazing in the midst of the big rises and hustle and bustle of this incredible city that seems to utilize every square inch of land for building on!! It is a must visit..... just gorgeous - the Bonsai trees alone make it worth the visit. If you like vegetarian food there is a lovely restaurant too. Also a dim sum restaurant and afternoon tea place. Both quite expensive however. Across the road is the HUGE Hollywood Plaza Shopping Centre is you need lunch, a drink or snack.
Go in the evenings!. Peace and serenity in the bustling HK! Do pay a visit if you are in the area. Very accessible. Go later in the day to catch the evening sun. It's also much cooler in the summer.

Calm and beautiful.. A calm oasis in this busy town. Beautiful! Quite amazing how far one seems to be from the traffic and the crowds of people that are everywhere in Hong Kong. Absolutely worth a visit. I am very glad that we went here on my third trip to Hong Kong.
Calm. In the busy city of Hongkong this monastery was wonderful and calm. It's beautiful and the garden around is fantastic.

A relaxed palce to visit. It was a very easy place to get to on the MTR and a short walk form the station.We spent 2 hours there, which was long enough for us, but you could be more relaxed and spend longer enjoying the gardens etc.While it was not very old, it gave the feeling of a sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of the outside world.

Beautiful garden and Nunery!. Very easy to find right in the heart of Kowloon. The GardenIs absolutely beautiful and well maintained which leads to the Nunery. Both are beautiful and interesting to see. They are both well worth the visit!
An oasis of peace!. it is a must visit.very calm and peacefulgreat vegetarian food, veg fried rice was too goodamazing bonsai treesthe nan lian garden was a pleasure to walk around

Nice free site in the city. This is a very easily accessible site within the city, and it's free! Although the city is filled with modern buildings and noise, this is a very peaceful and quiet site. Make sure to be respectful since it is a Nunnery. This is a site which is close to the Nan Lian Garden so you can combine those two sites in around 3 hours.

Good for a quick visit. The nunnery is accessible via MRT and busses - easy to get to from pretty much anywhere in HK. I would schedule about 45mins at the nunnery and another 30mins at the adjacent park.

May be the most peacefull place in HK. This may be one of my favorite place in HK. Easy to reach via MTR (subway), Station Diamond Hill, Exit C2, then follow the signage, it's very well indicated. From the MTR station, you need in about 5min to get to the park.Then you enter into one of the most peaceful place in HK. it's a big garden where there are often exhibitions. And the Nunnery by itself is such delicate architecture.There is a tea house in the middle of the park that is a beautiful place. You can drink amazing teas in the old house above the small lake. Be aware that each tea is around HK$200 (US$25) and the bill can be scary.

Please be respectful. There was a lotus garden in the middle and different statues of buddha inside and if I remember correctly it is the different reincarnation of buddha for each of the statue inside.It is a new nunnery but it is still a nunnery. There was some tourist inside shouting and rising his voice telling is kids to lower their voice.
Insightful!. The place was just right beside Nan Lian Garden. It was insightful, beautiful and peaceful. A within the city escape.

A pleasant surprise. Chi Lin was a pleasant surprise. I was in the area as I had come to visit the adjoining garden - Nan Lian Garden. I knew that Chi Lin was connected to the Garden via a bridge but I was planning on giving Chi Lin a miss as I thought at the time that it would be like every other place of worship which all seems to blend into one after a while. What sets Chi Lin apart is the atmosphere and the sensory experience to be had at Chi Lin.At each of the altars, they burn fragrant incense (I think it might be high quality sandalwood) which smelt so lovely that I took another walk around the altars just to smell the incense. When I was there, I also heard some chanting (I couldn't figure out if it was a CD being played or if it was the sound of the actual monks chanting) which added to the mystical atmosphere at Chi Lin.You can't take pictures of the altars. That wasn't really a problem for me as I thought that a picture wouldn't do Chi Lin justice. The lotus ponds at the entrance of Chi Lin are photographable and make for pretty pictures. I was there on a weekday at about 2 or 3 in the afternoon, and there were only a few people walking around - a welcome respite from the crowd in Hong Kong.

Nice Courtyard. It looks great on the outside, however, the main building was closed during the time that we went there. So, we didn't have a chance to see what's inside.
I guess I would've rated this higher if I got inside.
But then again, the view of the courtyard is nice.
Peaceful relaxation. A lovely peaceful place to visit with beautiful gardens, I spent a very happy afternoon there enjoying the oasis in the city.
Peaceful. The Chi Lin Nunnery had beautiful lotus ponds and gardens. It wasn't crowded and was very peaceful. The buildings are interesting .
Eat, Pray & Love. Yes I ate there, pray there and love the sights. A beautiful and serene place. It's worth it and nobody should ever complain since it is free. Photography heaven.
An oasis in HK. Super place. Fantastic gardens. Gentle. Incongruously situated next to Hollywood Plaza, a huge shopping mall. Loved it. Probably a bit boring for children.
A Quiet Paradies. An amazing place in the city, not sure why it's not in the top three of places to visit. So tranquil but so Honk Kong. A must for any visitor.

Nice way to begin a trip to Hong Kong. After a long flight, touring Central with traffic and high-rises is too busy and hectic. Far better to jump on the underground and head to Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden (they are connected by a pedestrian overpass/bridge). Both are beautiful, calm and peaceful. Across from the garden is a shopping mall. Watch your time, so you don't go in when the restaurants are full.

What do you expect. What do you expect in a buddish temple? Meat... of course not!All veggies here, Dishes were cook in traditional buddish way, what you eat is just as same as the monks, want to be a Shaolim monk! Start eating veggie in here! Maybe you'll learn something.

A Quiet Place. A place for quiet contemplation. Beautiful architecture. Visitors are quite naturally respectful in this place, and sometimes all you hear are chanting. It sets you into a solitary but peaceful environment.

Gem in the city. If you know HK, you will find it weird to have such a large park in the middle of the city center. Land is always in a high demand in HK, but yet the government is willing to dedicated such a large area to protect the heritage.You may not learn much about Buddhism after the visit, but you can sure have a taste of it. Whats more, the building is of Tang's style. It is rare to find such gem in HK, not to mention in the city centre.
A tang village. a little bit off the usual Tourist may but iof you like old china and The Tang dynasty then it is worth a visit to see what life was once like many years ago

Peaceful. Hong Kong can wear a newcomer down very quickly. If everything gets to you on the second or third day than take some time out to relax in the Chi Lin Nunnery. Easy to get to and so peaceful despite the fact that it's in the heart of one of the busiest districts. The gardens and Temples are magnificent and free of charge.

Interesting. Really nice place, more than just a tourist site. It is a working site and it is therefore interesting, and it was not very busy despite being there at the peak of tourist season. It is close to the Nan Lian Garden which is also worth a visit

Worth a visit if you are done with the other places. Overall the place is easily accessible by MTR, I would not recommend a visit on a hot day - so do consider the weather before planning the visit.Also, the place is nice but nothing out of the world for people who have traveled before. It is well maintained and has a good collection of plants/vegetation.

Serene. So serene and tranquil. You feel almost lost in the peacefulness of the atmosphere. I guess I personally felt a little weird seeing skyscrapers in the background, and left wondering what I, a tourist, was really doing in a Buddhist monastery, but it was an interesting place to visit on Kowloon.Connects nicely after the beautiful gardens.
Very peaceful and tranquil place. Beautiful temple and peaceful surrounding. Well worth a visit if you wish to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city.
an oasis of serenity in a noisy metropolis. Check out the construction of the different temples and halls. Respect the tranquillity. Do not take pictures inside the temples and halls.
Lovely. A small piece of the real China but located in Hong Kong. Especially nice to escape the bustling crowds for some peace and quiet.
Get thee to. Worth the trek out of the main drag. Serene gardens and majestic wooden buildings. Be respectful and it will stay in the memory.

Wonderful traditional buildings and lotus ponds. The Chi Lin Nunnery has some beautiful buildings. The temples are full of wonderful altars and statues. There is lots to see and the lotus ponds are very calming, even though this is in the centre of a busy busy city. Take time to ponder and really look at the altars in the temples. Lovely.

Peaceful Hong Kong. Alongside the Nan Lian gardens the Nunnery is well worth visiting. Enjoy the peace, leaving the hectic pace behind. You may even be rewarded by catching a fleeting glimpse of one of the nuns.

CAN'T MISS. A must visit in Hong Kong . Not of typical touristy stuff but if if you love bonsai and tranquility then this is the place for you. It is located with in walking distance of Diamond Hill MTR station.

Nice. Nice piece of architecture. Bonsai gardens & lotus pool. Next to Nan Lian garden.
The sky scrapers form the backdrop to this quaint place.

Beautiful and peaceful environment. Pros: stunning traditional Chinese architecture, tranquil environment to get away from the hustle and bustle, convenient location (especially if you are visiting Wong Tai Sin and/ or Nan Lian Garden), free.
Cons: small (finished walking about in about 20 minutes), having a guide to explain things would be alot more informative about the history and architecture of the place.
A good place to visit that will not cost you a penny.. Good place to stroll with free entrance fee. The place is clean and amazing with lots of things to learn about their culture.

Walk through the garden. It's a natural visit if you walk through Nan Liang Garden. A more respectful place, so even more peaceful.
It's also inspiring in that there's an old age care home at the top of the Nunnery.

Beautiful architecture. Really nice place to take overseas visitors who want to experience old Chinese architecture. Amazing gardens, special rocks from China. Should have a guide to explain things as you go around the gardens to appreciate everything you see. Best to go in the cooler months. Lovely vegetarian restaurant on the grounds.
Not spectacular. Nice to see, but not really spectacular. Nice to walk through but after about 10 minutes you've seen everything.
Amazing. This was an amazing place to visit. Great Chinese architecture and scenery. Well worth the walk to get there and loved it. Recommended definitely

Peaceful. Located in Diamond Hill in Hong Kong, near to the New Terriroties and being attached to the Nan Lian Garden, which is amongst the highrise buildings and overpasses, full of trucks and cars, its hard to imagine that you are in a Nunnery and a place of such peace and prayer...The noise seems to be taken away with the air of spiritualism...The atmosphere is breathtaking with the most amazing golden bhuddas, offerings, enormous bonsais in pots everywhere, being lovingly tended to by the gardener. The dragonheads cleansing the colorfull lilyponds with their showering fountains, while being protected by the rooftop ornamention of dragons...Wow, we were so pleased we went on our last day...We stayed on Hong Kong Island and the bus ride was approx 40 mins.

Cool spot. Worth a visit if you're in the area/going to Nan Lian anyway. The temple and its surrounds are lovely, the architecture is also pretty interesting, especially when juxtaposed with the modern high-rises you can see in the hills behind.

worth a visit. Chi Lin Nunnery is a 5 minute walk from Diamond Hill station.Although the building itself is not that old and may not have the history of similar places.However the history of Buddhism and the beautiful statues does not change just because it is in a young building.We thought it was a lovely and peaceful place, worth a visit

Very attractive. This is a nice add-on to a visit to the Nan Lian Garden. You can only really visit the Lotus Pond and the Main Hall, and photos of the statuary within are not allowed, but it's worth seeing, and is free after all.

Serenity in the midst of urban hustle and bustle. The Nunnery is part of the Nan Lian Tang Dynasty Garden, a must see for anyone interested in garden history and Chinese culture. Cross the bridge from Nan Lian and you are inan elegant formal courtyard with lotus pools, bonsai trees and the beautiful Tang Dynasty timber monastery, a perfect example of the Chinese ability to do "new old" so effectively.

Discover Hong Kong inside the city. you will be astonished when you see what Hong Kong can hide within its buildings.It's one of the very best attraction I've visited here and I am very focused on details: here nothing is out of its place.

Tranquility. Beautifully maintained bonsai gardens around the Chi Lin Nunnery. Easy access and well sign posted from MTR. The nunnery is in excellent condition, tranquil. A nice break from busy Kowloon
Beautiful!. The Chi Lin Nunnery was one of my favorite parts of the trip. The grounds are immaculately maintained, and the old-style building is beautiful. It's a very spiritual place.
Beautiful place to go. Don't miss this place. Despite being surrounded by roads and traffic this place is so serene. Spend some quality time there in this peaceful atmosphere.

Serene and peaceful. iWe were surprised to find that this nunnery was built in 1993 as it seems much older. There is a tranquility about it that seems more older world than modern world.It could have been even more peaceful if it was not next to a very busy and noisy road which does seem incongruous. The gardens are green and attractively set out and there are a number of water features set between the gardens. Easy place to relax and spend an hour or so. It can be reached easily from the Diamond Hill MTR.
Chi Lin Nunnery. Chi Nin Nunnery is next to the Chi Lian Gardens. It is a Buddhist environment. The feng shui is peaceful. The gardens are magnificent and the Temples are so serene. Must see.
Nice. Is a nice please to go for visit although I am not the Buddhist. Learning a lot and getting to know about other religious

very nice.. Easy to get to from hkc. Beautiful grounds, Koi ponds, bonzai trees, streams, waterfalls. Very neat vegetarian restaurant. Gift shops but not tacky. Nunnery is very spiritual. Disliked nothing

An Oasis in Hong Kong. Chi Lin Nunnery was a real treasure in the bustling city, an oasis of beautifully landscaped walkways. sculptures, and magnificent Chinese buildings, there is a restaurant adjacent to a waterfall that serves traditional dishes, all delicious

No worth your while. The site itself is a question mark. Such buildings have never set foot in Hong Kong in history.
Anyway, there is nothing else around the site and it's just not worth your time to see it.

Excellent park off the beaten path. I really like Chi Lin Nunnery. It's such a beautiful and peaceful place, normally not too many tourist there. Never get tired of going there. Easy to get there because close to Diamond Hill MTR station.
Great place. Lovely gardens, good restaurant behind the waterfall. Busy and a bit noisy in places but worth a visit certainly. Free too!

Tranquil bubble in the middle of town. This is a very beautiful attraction with clean, sculpted grounds. It is surrounded by a mass of humanity and tall apartment buildings but you feel very protected and there is a sense of calm tranquility that surrounds you.
Peaceful. Good to get away from the hubbub of the city life, go from the Nunnery garden into the temple which is really beautiful. To be recommended.

Great place!. Brought my parents here couple days ago where i believe not many tourists will know this Japanese style buddhist temple exists in HK. Such a beauty I have to say. And I just feel the calmness and the "zen" each time I was here. You can catch a MTR to Diamond Hill and walk to here For the last two times I was here, we went by car. Not really sure where to park though as there is no car park nearby and you just have to take the risk to park ilegally near the area.

Beautiful and tranquil. We decided to skip going to Victoria Peak and decided to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden instead. We visited on a Saturday and expected it to be busy. It wasn't and we were able to walk around in peace and quiet. The nunnery isn't the biggest or most splendid tourist attraction that we visited during our trip to China but we really enjoyed the experience. There are a number of ponds scattered around the courtyard with flowers and fish. The buildings are also worth a look as they contain some stunning buddhas and other statues. Our tip would be to combine a visit to the nunnery with the Nan Lian garden.

Heritage. This is close to the Diamon Hill MTR station on the green line. Opens at 9am and can be coupled with the Nan Lian Garden as well around which the nunnery is situated. They do allow photography but do not allow tripods on the ground. It is very well maintained. There are ponds with lotus flowers and a variety of Bonsai trees in the garden. The nunnery itself is a huge wooden structure and stands beautiful against the sky scrapers in Hong Kong.

An amazing and tranquil place to visit. Lovely place to visit when you've been to the park. Just remember it is used by local people to pray and you need to be respectful of this.In a busy full on city this place is a calm oasis and it manages to whisk you away and almost feels as though you are no longer in Hong Kong

Symbiotic with Nan Lian Gardens. Try to keep it simple.No trip here is complete without being in the attached Nan Lian Gardens.They come as a package.To go in one first followed by the other is important spiritually.No photos of religious idols but the view are worth it and do not miss a smaller gardens on the west side of Nunnery.You may well have started your visit entering this way into Nunnery and then going on to Gardens.I usually start in Gardens but former may be nicer way to do it.I cannot rank Temples etc but this would be in my top 2-3 of a growing list of 10.For its type,size it is close to top if not top one.Big Buddha is a different animal as are Tin Hua Temples etc See review Nan Lian gardens and make sure you visit the Temple in adjacent MTR stop before Diamond Hill (which caters to this Nunnery) and all this can be found in Hong Kong Tourist Board Walks Brochure.A must for those with short time and no itinerary. The Walks Tour is present in electronic downloadable form and as Mobile Apps in Travel Kit section of Thing to Do

Beautiful & Traditional building. It is a very beautiful place which I highly recommend. The traditional building was beautifully built with woods which make you feel comfort & heart of silence. Many trees and flowers are planted in the garden. Large pod with water lily which is a perfect match with the environment.

Peacefully. I came here every time I visited Hong Kong. Very beautiful landscape and best place for relaxing your mind. More over you can visit Nan Lian Garden which located in the opposite. Just a short walk from MTR Diamond Hill Station.

Beautiful. I came here on the advice of the hotel concierge and was very pleased I did. It is a very beautiful and quiet place that gives you a break from the hustle and bustle of downtown. The gardens are very pretty and so is the Temple. This was a very good place to visit - one of my favourites on my trip.

A tranquil and delightful Scene in Town. It is a place located not far away from MTR (rail station), shopping center and even residential area but once you get inside the Chi Lin Nunnery, you feel much relaxed and released from all busy schedules. While you're walking slowly insdie, you feel peaceful, calm and tranquil and you also find history, traditions and culture of the Chinese over there. If you have time, try to experience the famous Chinese Vege lunch. Due to limited walk-in quota, advance booking is recommended.
Solemn. The place was very peaceful and clean. Even if the place was situated in the city but it was very peaceful and calming. The place is for free and do follow rules and respect others praying.
Amazing. Only steps from this busy city and you can find peace and tranquility. No admission cost, very clean

Very peaceful and calming. The feeling you get inside the nunnery can be summed up in one word: peaceful.It's totally different from the hustle and bustle of materialistic downtown Hong Kong, where everybody is in a hurry to make money or more money. Here, things are slow paced, and you find yourself in a different world, a very spiritual one. You are not judged by how you dress, what you wear, and whom you are.I like it.Unfortunately, the rain on that day had delayed my visit so it was about closing time when I reached there. And it also prevented me from really exploring the nunnery in detail, but still, I had a good look at most of what was inside. You could really spent an hour or so, strolling around and taking in the peace. No wonder they say, when one enters the mountain gate (the main entrance to the nunnery), one leaves behind the tribulations of the secular world.
Amazing Gardens!!. Highly recommend everyone going here if you're in Hong Kong for than 48 hrs. Absolutely stunning gardens & temples. One of the highlights of our time in Hong Kong!!
Chi Lin & Nan Lian. We visited Nan Lian & Chi Lin as they are just across the road. They are both a huge contrast against the modern high-rise buildings.
Last but not least. Headed to Chi Lin Nunnery on the last day of our trip, but it's worth to pay a visit. The temple is significant with its lotus pond and statue.

Chi Lin and Nan Lian are a great two-for one package. Most places in Hong Kong open late and close late - not so the Chi Lin nunnery which closes at 4pm (you can still enter the outer courtyard but that's it).
It is still a beautiful spot and worth a visit.

Visit Chi Lin Nunnery & Nan Lian Garden at the same time. Truly unexpected peace in the middle of Kowloon. As I said about Nan Lian Garden, when I viber-ed photos to friends who frequent Hongkong for shopping, they asked, "where are you???" Precisely. Meandering through these 2 enclaves, I somehow got transported someplace else other than frenetic Hongkong.
Serene oasis. Easy to get to via the metro system and combine with NanLin Gardens. Very pleasant spaces with amazing backdrop of the mountain on one side and Hong Kong towers on the other. Serene.

A Peaceful Oasis. Adjoining the Nan Lian Garden at Diamond Hill is this peaceful area. Lovely architecture, plants, ponds and peace amongst the hustle and bustle.
See it along with the garden, MTR to Diamond Hill station and follow the signs.

PEACE AND QUIET. A beautiful place to visit away from the hustle and bustle of most of Hong Kong. Very relaxing with gorgeous lily ponds and, despite being modern, buildings are all in traditional style with amazing carvings.

Quiet Refuge in a Noisy City. Of all that we saw in Hong Kong, the Chi Lin Nunnery was the greatest surprise we had. It is a peaceful sanctuary surrounded by the noises of a busy city. Take the time to walk the entire gardens. People strolling at a relaxed pace and couples of all ages walking hand in hand is a norm here!

A Welcome Break in the Middle of a Bustling City. When I read the great reviews of this place being calm and exceptionally beautiful, I knew I had to squeeze this into my itinerary. I wasn't wrong, it was sooo serene! It was right smack in the center of Diamond Hill, and just a minute walk from the MTR station. Better visit in the morning, you'll have the place to yourself. :) And don't forget to bring your camera, it offers one of the best photo ops in Hong Kong.

Serenity amongst the crush of HKG. This place is a very serene place amongst the urban intensity of Hong Kong. I visited once here and walked the grounds of the nunnery and garden on my own. The second time I was on a tour, organized by friends, that took us across the grounds on the garden side. I believe it was free. The docent told us about the various architectural features of the grounds and garden. Supposedly, this tour can be done in English and Cantonese. I'm not sure if any other languages are available as well. When you are here, don't forget to also visit the gift shop on the nunnery side of the grounds as well as the restaurant on the garden side. It is a very beautiful, peaceful, and quiet place.
A haven of peace. The beautiful temple, the gardens, the peace and quiet, right next to Diamond Hill MTR. Restaurant and coffee shop also there. A perfect place for meditation.

Another Great, Brief Stop!. The nunnery is stunningly beautiful with large facades and wonderful Buddhist statues. It is right next to the Nan Lian Gardens, so I'd recommend doing both at once. The only drawback is how modern/new the nunnery is. In an region with tremendous history, the nunnery is more of a modern beauty than a historical feat.
To get a peace of mind. The place where you can stroll for a few hours plus enjoying the distinctive vegetarian food inside the nunnery

Tranquility in the middle of a bustling city. Didn't know about this nunnery until the 2nd last day of our visit to Hong Kong. Conveniently located within a few minutes' walk from Diamond Hill MTR station. The temple is a mix of Chinese and Japanese design and setting. With all wood structure and no nails used, the dark wood structure with the setting demands peace and quiet. You'll feel compelled to mediate and admire.If you can ignore the high rises close to the temple and look onto the garden side, you thought you are in another place, another era. There is no incense burning to sting your eyes and nose. For some reason, this site is ignored by tourist groups. So visit on a weekday and admire the temple structure.

Island of tranquility in a sea of public housing.. Located in Diamond Hill and only a 5 minute walk from the MTR station, this place is worth visiting if you have the time. The nunnery is split into two sections, on one side is a park with various small exhibits that is meticulously kept with beautifully shaped trees and shrubs. The exhibits are only okay, nothing spectacular but worth a quick look. There is a nice souvenir shop that sell some nice stuff that is well displayed and some of it is exclusive to the nunnery. My favorite part of the park section is the restaurant that is behind the small waterfall, the vegetarian food is very good and is run by the nunnery, the hours are a little weird so check their opening hours before heading there. The only thing I don't like is a gaudy gold pagoda that is located in the park that doesn't seem very fitting. The nunnery is out of the way enough that it isn't a huge tourist attraction, so on most days there shouldn't huge crowds.The other parts of the nunnery include the main temple complex across the road from the park, its also very picturesque and a little Japanese Zen inspired in its landscaping. Its very clean and well kept and definitely worth a visit. Next to the temple complex is a school that is often overlooked by tourists. In it you can join free meditation classes and there is an awesome book shop that sells a huge array of books and paraphernalia related to Buddhism. I've found quite a few gems in this shop in my time. Highly recommended!
Wonderful Visit. Beautiful peaceful temple complex right next to beautifully tended Chinese garden. Definitely worth a visit.

Personal experience to an attraction that highly objection as the Heritage Sites. Personally it is a beautiful garden and monastery to visit in Hong Kong located at Diamond Hill accessible by MTR directly. The monastery founded long ago but too bad it was rebuild with modern architecture without proper procedures even the temple constructed using inter locking system without iron nails. Here is my review on Chi Lin: - Attraction Highlight: There is Nan Lian garden and Chi Lin Nunnery Monastery where the garden built with beautiful bonsai and resting area in Chinese garden style follow by the traditional Chinese temple Chi Lin attraction.Attraction Tip: Go directly to Nan Lian Garden first to enjoy the beautiful garden before visiting the Chi Lin Monastery. At Chi Lin there are 2 sections when you enter the main entrance then you come to the first big sector of garden area, then enter the center building to go to the main hall where there are Buddha and goddess located at the second section.

Beautiful and peaceful. This building was neat to see, we especially enjoyed the trees. I will say you couldn't spend more than an hour here unless you're Buddhist and want to do some praying or meditation. For basic tourists, it's good for about an hour :) You can pop over to the Nan Lian Garden though to spend more time in the area. It's right across the street.

Very peaceful. When I walked into this place I found it soooo different to the temples we had been visiting in the rest of Hong Kong. This is Buddhist temple is a place of peace and beautiful energy. The others although very interesting were noisy and busy. Not here. Although tourists were walking through everyone was quiet and respectful. The place is beautifully landscaped with small water lily pools and large bonsai. Very lovely. Different Buddha statues in the buildings. Definitely my favourite temple now in Hong Kong. They have a small gift shop which has lots of interesting things. Money raised to fund the Nunnery. There is a restaurant but we did not try it but ate at the restaurant in the Nan Lian Garden across the road. Will try the restaurant here next time

An oasis of a tranquility in one of the busiest cities in the world. An unexpectedly moving experience. The Chi Lin Nunnery should be on everyone's itinerary when visiting Hong Kong. Less is more with this review, so, please just go and see for yourselves. It was my highlight a of a very busy 8 nights in Hong Kong. A vision of perfection.
Peaceful place. I am not a Buddhist, but you may find inner peace here. Al-thought it is definitely an artificial sight, it still worth to sit there a whole morning.

Stunning and peaceful grounds. Strict rules - no food, no sitting.. Beautifully constructed, traditional style monastery. None of the usual cloud of smoke in the air from all the burning incense found in other temples.Within the courtyard where all the individual rooms are for the individual Buddhas, the security guards are strict and does not allow sitting or extended prayers. There is really no place to sit down to rest, better to go to the park across the bridge.This place is purely for observing silence. I saw people being turned away for bringing their own vegetarian meal and hoping to eat it on a bench. Their reasoning is remnants of food brings critters.There is a small gift shop for souvenirs.

Great quiet spot in the middle of Kowloon. This little slice of quiet in the middle of busy-bustling Kowloon was fantastic. Such a gorgeous little place to visit for a bit of peace. Be sure to also visit the Nan Lian gardens next-door to this place. Easy to reach by MTR.

lovely oasis of calm in the midst of the city. went here on a saturday afternoon and included the park as well. very nice setting - green, calm - an oasis surrounded by 'peaks' of tall buildings. well worth the MTR subway ride from central

peaceful and beautiful. Easy to get to by Metro. The gardens are so restful and a good escape from the activity of the city. It only takes a couple of hours to wonder around the garden and attached nunnery.

Hidden Gem. This place really is a nicest away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Its perfectly manicured gardens are incredibly impressive with what can only be hundreds of years of work on the Bonsais. There is a little lady who walks around hand picking out all of the imperfections in the landscape. the temple is stunning and perfectly maintained. only downside is there are typical hong kong style old filthy apartment blocks surrounding it so its hard to get a feeling of being back in time. Its hard to drown out the noises of constant tooting of traffic but its still nice to be more than 10 feet away from someone in hong kong

Give it a go. We tied this in with the Nan Lian Gardens as its right next to them....the Nunnery is lovely but you are not able to take photos inside which is a little disappointing....but we understood the reasons why.

Simply marvellous / Simplemente maravilloso . It was the best place to visit during my stay in HK. Quiet area and fantastic architecture and garden.La mejor visita durante mi estancia en HK. Una zona tranquila con una arquitectura y jardines fantásticos.

A haven of peace on HK. A fantastic peaceful place to visit right in the heart of HK. Easy to get to and just a very short walk from the MTR.You should try to visit if you can and couple with a walk around the Nan Lian Garden

Quiet place to visit. Easy to get to from the Diamond Hill metro station. Plenty of opportunities to take quality photos. Less crowded than I expected which was good.
Go here as part of your visit to the Nan Lian Garden.
Peaceful Gardens. The gardens were so beautiful and peaceful that it didn't feel like we were in HK. The staff were lovely and took time to explain the history of the place to us.

quiet & inspiring place close to the city noise. If you are a little tired of all the buzz in the shopping malls this is the place to try & visit
large nunnery with excellent view of the new and the old, bonzai trees, lots of stones and a lot of rest
Lovely Oasis. Peaceful bit of greenery right in the middle of such a busy city. The buildings and religious icons are not like what you would see in mainland China, but are well worth the visit.

A place of tranquility in a hectic city. A beautiful place to spend half a day getting away from the hustle and bustle of the city. The nunnery is calm and a spectacular site amongst the high rise blocks surrounding it. Beautifully maintained gardens and amazingly constructed wooden buildings to see. At the time of our visit, an exhibition of cloisonnés was on which was well worth a visit too.

Oasis of peace. What a fabulous place and well worth a journey to it. Considering it is so close to the city it is amazingly quiet and peaceful. Gardens are stunning - we spent a happy couple of hours wandering around among the bonsai trees. One of the favourite places we visited during our Hong Kong trip.

An oasis of peace in a busy city. We were pleasantly surprised by the beautiful gardens, ponds and stunning display of bonsai trees around the monastery. The monastery is not huge and it was pleasant to stroll through the religious buildings and enjoy a peaceful morning away from the bustling areas of Hong Kong. It is so easy to reach by MTR with only a short, well sign-posted, walk from Diamond Hill Station and it is something you can do on a whim without having to plan or book a tour.

Wonderful Nunnery with water features, temples and gardens. Loved the architecture, bonsai trees, gardens and temples. Glorious nunnery and well worth a visit. Walk through the NanLian gardens next door first and visit the nunnery second. A wonderful afternoon in Hong Kong!!!
Serene. Lovely idyllic place in the midst of all the hustle and bustle, well worth a visit. The gardens were beautifully kept and found the whole experience interesting. Nice gift shop too.

Stay for the vegetarian food!. What a beautiful location - a sanctuary in the middle of the hustle and bustle that permeates Hong Kong! You can see the distant skyscrapers while also enjoying plenty of natural elements, lovely architecture, and Buddha statues with colorful decorations.Nestled among the many buildings is a lovely vegetarian restaurant which boasts a nice setting and plenty of delicious food choices. Note that they do have a minimum required amount that you have to spend per person. You will walk away more than satisfied with the food. If only they allowed photos inside the restaurant!
Beautiful. A lovely place to spend a few relaxing hours. Check out the lovely gardens opposite the nunnery. The architecture and landscaping are truly breathtaking.

A beautiful abode of peace and quiet in Hong Kong. This is one place in Hong Kong which one just should not miss. The garden is so beautiful and tranquil. The ceramic ware museum is stunning. There is a rockery, a timber museum and a small bonsai garden, all worth a visit. The traditional Chinese vegetarian lunch in the little vegetarian restaurant (located interestingly beneath a waterfall!) at the back of the garden is highly recommended.

Excellent place to visit. Next to Diamond Hill MTR. Easy to find. Free entry. Beautiful setting with mountain backdrop.Next to it is the beautiful NanLian garden. Superb landscape. Loved it especially when the sun sets.

Beautiful scenery and amazing statues. Breath taking scenery of different trees and rocks. There is a vegetarian restaurant that tastes amazing. You will enter into the temple with huge golden statues of the Guan Yin and Buddha. Would definitely visit again. It not far from Diamond Hill MTR station.

My favorite in HongKong. I know this garden is definitely over the top but somehow I really like it. Exit the Hollywood station and than 300m away the little place of peace in the middle of all this huge apartment buildings. Entrance is free and not too many people visit that place actually. For me it's a little tradition to have a walk through the garden and enjoy afterward a Japanese curry in the Hollywood shopping mall.

Beautiful calm space. This was a beautiful escape from the hustle and hustle of downtown Hong Kong. This a must see with fantastically maintained gardens with many bonsai and serene buildings. The gardens surrounding the nunnery are a treasure in a place where space is a premium. Make the time to visit.

Serene, peaceful and worth a visit.. This nunnery is beautiful, very peaceful and worth a visit to escape the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. It is a very easy walk from Diamond Hill station. The gardens attached to the nunnery are also worth visiting. Turn off your phones and enjoy the peace and Buddhism.

Beautiful complex. The monastery is very well maintained and adjoins a beautiful Chinese garden/park. One of the very few remnants of antiquity left in Hong Kong. You can see Chinese architecture and Buddhist and Taoist statues and sculptures and there is a temple inside where people still offer prayers.
A bit of tranquility. A beautiful nunnery set in gardens which provides a little bit of an escape in amongst all the buildings.
chinese manastery. This place is a beautiful garden revealing the style of Chinese manstries and architecture. Great scenario!

A great Chinese style Garden with great architecture!. I like most the building structure inside with Chinese element (of course....this is Hong Kong...). The garden there is worth to visit and you cannot imagine in the over-crowded city centre there is such a spacious garden for people to enjoy. Not many freedom walkers and mainlanders inside. Good for local and foreigners!

A beautiful, peaceful sanctuary amid the chaos. Only one more MTR stop from TST (to quote Wikipedia, "Tsim Sha Tsui often abbreviated as TST, is an urban area in southern Kowloon, Hong Kong") beyond the Wong Tai Sin Taoist Temple, this is a very special place to visit, one that establishes an island of peace and tranquility in the cacophonic and hectic city. The absence of the hordes that we saw at the Wong Tai Sin Taoist Temple and the large outdoor courtyard no doubt contributed to the more serene feel of the nunnery. The buildings were almost all wooden, simpler in style than the Taoist temple and without ornate decoration. There were, though, beautiful prayer rooms in which gorgeous statues relevant to the faith were situated and which statues had lovely, exquisitely arranged offerings of fruit and flowers. Gentle music was piped in with a chanter singing a soothing song or prayer. This is truly a refuge and one very worth a visit. The gardens below the nunnery were also very attractive and serene having water features, perfectly manicured trees and landscaping that was immaculate. Well worth an hour or more of your time.

Nothing too special. The restaurant is pretty gross.. As a vegetarian, I was excited to eat at the restaurant. However, every single dish was made from weird mushrooms. I typically like mushrooms. But corticeps were in almost everything. Corticeps are caused by a parasite and create a fungus that grow out of the heads of caterpillars. That should not be considered a vegetarian dish. Bleh. The people at the nunnery are lovely and it is pretty but it shouldn't be on the top of your list of things to do.

A serene spot. This was a pretty little spot that was close enough to main parts of the city to be accessible, but far enough away that you didn't feel like you were being suffocated. It's right near the Nan Lian gardens, which are also beautiful. If you have time, this place is worth a stop; it's a cool little photo op with cool architecture, sky scrapers and green hills in the back ground.

serene place to visit. The Chi Lin nunnery is easily reachable by MTR (exit at Dimaond Hill station) and bus. It's across from the Hollywood Plaza mall, and linked to adjoining Nian Lian Garden by a little footbridge. The quiet and calm of the nunnery and the adjacent Nian Lian Garden contrast with the hustle and bustle of the neighbouring highrises. I like to go there and wander along the covered corridors, the beautifully manicured plants and ponds, bonsais, etc.

A place of traditional chinese architecture and horticultural skill. If you are interested in the traditional Chinese architecture and horticultural skill then you won't regret in paying this nunnery a visit.
ch lin nursery. very very peaceful place to visit, must not be missed, very near hollywood plaza mall, right in the centre of the city

Fantastic and fascinating. This is a beautiful serene place so different to the hustle and bustle of the rest of Hong Kong. One of my favourite experiences during our Hong Kong trip. The Temples are beautiful and the atmosphere calming and peaceful.
Beautiful. a serene oasis with lovely gardens and a great shop with friendly staff! Check out the bonsai varieties.

A must see in Hong Kong. Loved it! Once you get off the train, there are signs guiding you and it was about a 5 minute walk. Definitely a must see in Hong Kong. It wasn't crowded. No entrance fee. Just beautiful and tranquil.
Lovely Ossis. This is a lovely oasis of tranquility amidst the bustling city. This is a wonderful place for photography and reflection.

Essence of Tang Dynasty. This beautiful temple is a replica of an ancient temple found in the Dunhuang caves in the Buddhist civilization hub since before Tang Dynasty over two thousand years ago. It is built with out a nail and the architecture style is quintessentially Tang style. Spend a half day wandering in the beautiful garden and enjoy a vegetarian lunch at the temple restaurant for true tranquility and peace.
Beautiful place. The temple is different from other temples in Hong Kong. Decorated with beautifully and peaceful. I like this place more

Amazing!. We almost had the place to ourselves! ... It was beautiful, enlightening and tranquil ... One of our HK highlights so far. My two year old daughter loved the Buddha's, and is now Buddha obsessed! A must visit, coupled with a visit to the Nan Lian Garden immediately next door. And incredibly easy to get to, with the MTR station a five minute walk down the road. Allow two hours to see both without feeling rushed.

Gardens are beautiful. The nunnery itself was mildly interesting, with several temples and similar buildings. But what was really exceptional was the Nan Ling Garden, which is adjacent to it. This is a really beautiful and serene spot with a pleasant vegetarian tea house, where we sat down for dim sum (nothing special) and I bought some teas to bring home.

A quaint place. A picturesque nunnery that is so glaringly opposite to the bustling city life of Hong Kong. Try to visit either early in the morning or late in the evening. The sun is quite unpleasant when walking inside the plazas of the nunnery. The buildings on the other hand are totally beautiful and so peaceful, making your trip totally worth it! It's quite a short walk up from Diamond Hill MTR and close to Plaza Hollywood, allows you to take a break after walking in the sun.

Hard to Believe Tranquility in Metro Hong Kong. A group of teachers told me about this nunnery (and the attached Nan Lian Gardens). What a great find. The nunnery buildings are quite impressive, with their wooden structure, and courtyard containing several "bonsai" type trees. The Nan Lian Gardens are even more impressive. There is a great souvenir shop an vegetarian cafe (try the dried blackberries).
Peaceful,beautiful Buddhist Temple surrounded by Nan Lian Garden. Spent an hour visiting this lovely Buddhist temple located close to the Diamond Hill subways stop.Peaceful and serene

Double happiness!. Our family greatly enjoyed the peaceful serenity of the Nunnery, and the fact that it is free makes us doubly happy. It was a short taxi ride ($60 HKD) from the cruise ship terminal. One tip is to walk to the nearby mall to catch a taxi back since it is difficult to catch one from here.

Peace amidst the chaos. We loved just wandering around the gardens, which provide a peaceful oasis in the middle of the city. If you have time, enjoy some if the food prepared by the monks-- delicious!

Fake garden. it was a complete diappointment. i was so looking forward to this attraction given all the great reviews but it turn out that it was big disappointment. you may be tired of the bling bling side of hk, but that doesnt make this place a good garden. you really should wake up if you think this place is good enough to grant you tranquility
Not to be missed. This is a fantastic piece of Hong Kong history..a very spiritual place in the midst of the hectic pace of HK

peace and tranquility in the midst of hustle and bustle. Ease of access and calm and peaceful surroundings to contemplate life and the universe. Spent an enjoyable morning viewing the wonderful settings designed for us to enjoy.

Serenity in the middle of a bust city. I've looked at a number of other reviews and can add but little. I'm not a very religious person, but the sense of peace and calm was so pervasive. The grounds are beautifully laid out and the statues of the Buddha and other gods were magnificent. Definitely a change of pace from the hustle and bustle of the rest if Kowloon.
Peaceful. Its located at the center of the city and surrounded by greenery.The atmosphere inside is very peaceful. good to spend an hour .nearby MTR.

Beautiful oasis amidst the high rise buildings. This is well worth a visit. It is close to the Diamond Hill metro stop on Kowloon. Wandering around the gardens was very picturesque and peaceful and the nunnery itself is a lovely building. Lots to see and appreciate here.

Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautifull setting ; what a tranquillity and serenity in the middle of the hectic traffic and noise of Kowloon !Beautifull inner court with fountains and small pools with goldfish, kois and turtles. This courtyard is surrounded by a covered gallery and niches with Budha-statues.From the courtyard you climb some stairs to what appears to be the central temple of worship with Budha as the centrepiece. No photography allowed here.An incredible tranquil place of worship with skyscrapers jutting out all around.Certainly one of the must-see sights in Hongkong.
Peaceful spot in a busy city. Would recommend a visit of an hour to the Chi Lin Nunnery. It's a beautifully calm serene spot that has no entrance charge, in a busy and sometimes expensive city.
Hidden attraction. Not an attraction many locals know about, it is usually less crowded than other attractions in HK! Perfect place to escape city life and to check out some beautiful architecture!
Worth a visit - a piece of tranquility. The gardens in particular are worth spending 30 minutes walking around, admiring how well they are kept and all for no entrance fee.

Pure serenity and a beautiful temple and garden area. Chi Lin Nunnery is a very unique type of temple with a more Japanese feel as everything is perfectly placed, trees and flowers perfectly manicured, whispers in the air instead of the hustle and bustle that is experienced at many of Hong Kong's largest temples. Chi Lin Nunnery is one of my absolute favorite places in all of Hong Kong and the fact it is so easy to get to, free to enter and changes with the seasons makes it a place that never gets old.

A tranquil oasis in a bustling city. The alters are gorgeous and so impeccably cared for and the neighboring gardens were so calming. There's also a great vegetarian restaurant in the gardens. One could spend an entire morning or afternoon simply soaking in the tranquility of this special place.
a calm, relaxing place.. A very relaxing experience, beautiful temple and gardens surrounded by skyscrapers. It was a bit of a hassle finding it at first but well wort it.
Must see Nunnery. The trees here are so legendary, it may be thousands of years oldWait till the sunset, and you will see the true beauty of this place

Lovely quiet place in a crowded city. Definitely worth a visit combined with the gardens on the other side of the street.Beautiful old wooden nunnery still in use, a place of peace in the midst of Kowloon and the high rises. Walk towards the gardens over the elevated walkway for a stroll and a lunch underneath the waterfall.....

Quiet, peaceful and beautiful sceneries.. Gardens are beautiful and so the woodworks. It's right by the MTR Diamond Hill station. It's amazing that there's this sanctuary right in the middle of a busy urban city. Must try the vegetarian restaurant.
Good place. Visited the temple complex... was really beautiful. Have huge statues of different bodhisattvas. Peaceful and quiet.
Beautiful Buddhist temple. A must in Hong Kong, near Diamond Hill MTR station.Closes at 4:30pm, visit also adjacent Nan Liang gardens.

Feels like a Time Warp. This place is like you got time-warped back to ancient China. Not a piece of nail on any of the floors or structures, everything is made of wood. There's also a nice display of trees and bushes. Very serene. Too bad the middle structure/temple was closed for the day when we got there.

A beautiful place to visit. The Nunnery is easy to find as signs are well placed and easy to follow,The gardens are the main attraction for me, beautifully kept and in the tradional style, the buildings are very nice, and it is easy to wander around and appreciate the serenity of the place.

Beautiful, even on a misty morning. We were easily able to take the Metro to Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden early on a Sunday morning. Unfortunately, we had the only light rain here on our entire monthlong visit to Asia that day. We especially loved the Golden Buddha on the inside and were disappointed that we could not take photos. Very worthwhile when combined with the garden.

Oasis of calm. The nunnery is well worth a visit. The buildings are relatively new but the nunnery was constructed in traditional style. The outstanding part of the visit for me was the courtyard and gardens. The courtyard contains many old bonsai trees and ponds with water lilies. Across the bridge lies a well maintained traditional garden where it is possible to find a quiet spot to just sit amid the calm. All this is set against a backdrop of high rise buildings.

A Quick and Quiet Visit (Also Totally Free). Many of the things at this nunnery that you might want a photograph of you are not allowed to photograph. Oh well. Even with a moderate number of people, it has a serene atmosphere. We spent about 30-40 minutes here before checking out the nearby parks, which had lovely landscaping and a diverse population of birds.
Peaceful place in busy Hong Kong. Spend an afternoon in the nunnery and in the garden next to it. Really relaxing and peaceful place considering that it is in the middle of Hong Kong.
Beautiful place. when the first time i came here, i thought this is the most boring place. but actually i was wrong. it is a beautiful place

From Bonsai to Buddha. A wonderful place for both couples and families. Such a mesmerizing silence in the middle of a vivid city as HK is almost not believable. But it exists. We had several moments when we couldn't decide which direction to go first. A paradise filled by bonsai trees which must be older than any sky scraper surrounding the nunnery and create an amazing flair of ancient Asia. Further the monastery itself has a memorable scenery providing beautiful photos from every possible angle. A Walk through the garden as well as the nunnery is free of charge.

I love the serenity and beauty of Chi Lin Nunnery!. Located in Diamond Hill, Kowloon, on the mainland side across from Hong Kong, this is a very beautiful area. I love how peaceful and quiet it is, amongst the towering buildings surrounding the land. If you sat down, out of site of the skyscrapers, you would never know you are near some of the most densely populated areas in the world. Just take the MTR to the Diamond Hill station and it is so easy to find. I go here every chance I get when visiting Hong Kong.

An oasis among the highrise forest. Chi Lin Nunnery and its associated garden are an out of this world oasis 'hidden' among the forest of highrise in this busy city. The garden has impeccably manicured lawn and many expertly sculptured Buddhist pine. Pagoda and Tang Dynasty styled buildings are scattered among walking path, pond and flower beds, you will have a pleasant walk among such tranquility and serenity. There are exhibition of the Tang Dynasty way of building the wood structure without the use of a single nail. A nice overpass (over a city road) lead you to the Buddhist temples which are also built according to Tang Dynasty standard. It is beautiful, peaceful, perfectly positioned, very easy to go to (a short walk from the Diamond Hill subway station Exit C2), don't miss it!

Beautiful Gardens. Visited here in October 14 adn was very impressed by the well manicured gardens in particular the Buddist pines which had been sculptured and well manicured. Great place to visit to escape from the city and enjoy the tranquility and peace and quiet of this lovely place.

vegetarian foodie must try!. Went for lunch, a busy place, but food taste good, not too much mock, simple and nice. We were surprised with their cheese cake, so yummy, and you almost won't believe is vegetarian, five stars !!
Beautiful. A very serene and peaceful oasis which is easily accessible with beautifuly maintained landscape. An escape from the hectic CBD
Peaceful and pretty. One of the prettiest and most peaceful spots in Hong Kong. Of the many temples I have visited over the years, in my view this is by far my favorite.

Beautiful gardens, beautiful temple. This is so well worth a visit. Straddling the road, slap bang next to a huge shopping mall, this nunnery is hushed and uplifting. The bonsai alone are worth a visit; the gardens are beautifully manicured. The temple is large and fairly typical of its kind insofar as the statues are concerned. It is well set up for tourists, with a prescribed route through the temple and out through the gift shops. There is some lovely stuff on sale there, probably very expensive. The rockery (indoors for the most part!) is full of huge polished rocks, some of which are placed for sitting. Somewhere I will definitely revisit.

Peaceful haven in busy Hong Kong. There is a beautiful garden here, you would not believe you were in the centre of bustling Hong Kong. There is a gorgeous waterfall with a vegetarian restaurant hidden behind it fabulous restful place to eat. The Nunnery is a Buddhist temple and is beautiful no pictures allowed inside. Well worth a visit.

Well worth a visit. What a lovely place. Tranquil, well away from the bustle of Hong Kong. Beautifully manicured trees and lily ponds. Buddhist temples opulent, with explanations in English and Chinese, very interesting. Would recommend it highly, and afterwards walk over the road to the Nan Lian Gardens.
Beautiful Gardens. It is really worth a visit. The lovely green gardens, the unusual trees, the quietness. It is a beautiful place for photos and very easy to find via MTR.

A beautiful oasis. Although a relatively recent replica of traditional Chinese architecture, this is absolutely worth visiting. The architecture is absolutely fascinating and the grounds and gardens are beautifully maintained. Even if you are not spiritual, this is a moving place to visit. I would recommend this to any first time visitor to Hong Kong, probably above most other attractions. The Nunnery and adjacent gardens are within an easy walk of the Diamond Hill MTR. If you need a break from fighting the crowds everywhere else you go in HK, this place will be your peaceful oasis in the middle of the HK madness.
Very interesting place. Beautiful Chinese style gardens and buildings worth visiting. It gives a nice view on the lyfestyle of the Buddhist nuns although their housing building cannot be entered.

Great combo with Nan Lian Garden. Located by the Diamond Hill MRT station makes this an easy place to visit. Nice and serene temple to visit and relax from the hustling city center. If you make the trip out here, it is worthwhile visiting Nan Lian Garden as well.

Buddhist Oasis. Built at the same time as the Nan Lian Gardens (adjacent) the nunnery is a peaceful haven of metaphysical tranquility. It's difficult not to be moved by the beautiful buildings, the wonderful Buddhas, resplendent in gold and in various meaningful reposes. After spending an hour or so in the Nan Lian garden, climb the steps and cross the bridge over the road into the nunnery.If visiting places of worship interests you, don't miss this

Top temple / Nunnery. Surprised when arriving.
In the middle of the city, crammed in, you have this beautiful nunnery/temple and a fantastic park.
Tranquility, peace and beauty.
Very different than most of Hong Kong
You should go..
Nearby also Kowloon City - really non turisted and very local

Peaceful and tranquil. A must see on your visit to Hong Kong. I have been to HK a few times but had not visited until now. It is only about 30-40 minutes from the centre of Kowloon, of which 25 minutes by MTR and then 10 mins max of walking. It is a Buddhist temple in relatively modern building, but built in a traditional style. It is very well kept and a haven of solitude, despite the roaring noise of the rest of Honk Kong just a few metres away. Don't forget your camera, you will want to take plenty of photos.
Beautiful!. A wonderful way to spend a Sunday. Exploring the gardens and Temple were beautiful! A bit of a trip on the MTR but worth it

Big Temple in the City... I have been to HK several times but this is the first time I have seen this place. How could I missed this place!It's very easy to reach it, just ride the MTR and exit at Diamond Hill. Walking distance only. The different bonsai plants surrounding the temple are such a beauty. It has a serene and quiet factor in the middle of city. Another YES Finds for me.Selfie sticks are not allowed here but the guards are quite helpful enough to take your pictures.

Be sure to visit the Nan Lian Garden next door too!. Chi Lin Nunnery is so out of place with Hong Kong's skyscrapers and I love it. When you enter you see well kept gardens, including bonsai. As you stroll around you see people who have come to pray. But the most beautiful part is the golden statues. My only disappointment was that they have signs saying photography is not allowed. And don't miss the gardens across the street; they're nice too!

Huge and worth a visit!. It was a nice monastery, many statues and friendly staff. It closes at 4:30 pm but I think they put curtains before the statue at 3:30. I visited around 3:30 and most of the statues were covered.

WOW!. This temple is nice but the garden around: WOW! You forget that you are in HK.You can spend a lot of time here. Its quite and you here the birds singing. There are also a cafe and a restaurant in this area.You can take the MRT to Diamond Hill and use Exit 2. You will see the mall Plaza Hollywood, and it`s around 500 m to walk. You will see some signs.No doubt this place is worth a visit!

Beautiful and peaceful. we never made it inside as it seems to close earlier than most of the sights but we could explore the gardens and external areas. So beautiful and peaceful, the minute you walk in you can feel the calm

Serene in Hong Kong. Wonderful place to explore and learn about buddhist religion. Convenient from Diamond HIll MTA and a calm walk through Nan Liang garden. Nice gift shop and coffee spot in the garden near entrance to Chi Lin. Great half-day trip.
Serenity. This was my 2nd visit and every bit as beautiful as the first two years ago. Beautiful architecture, statues and just an immediate sense of peacefulness a much needed commodity in busy HK

well planned garden. The place is so nice. You can see the details and the hardwork of landscaping and growing those plants. The harmony of the trees and water is visully seen in its raw contex. It really is a worthy visit.
Lovely park. This is lovely outing to have a peaceful afternoon stroll through the pretty park. There are numerous photo opportunities and the temple is beautiful.

Beautiful & Calm Place. This place defines the meaning of serenity. Located amidst skyscrapers , the nunnery is modeled on traditional Chinese architecture. One can find number of idols of Gods and Goddess from the Chinese literature, each with a description to aid in understanding the role of each figure. Th nunnery in itself is huge, with three prominent halls or 'aangans' as we call it in Hindi. Visit to the nunnery can provide a good mix of freshness and relaxation to the otherwise packed & hectic tour of Hong Kong.But if you are not the kind who likes visiting gardens and temples, then you should probably pass this place.

Hidden Gem!. Who would have thought amongst the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and a few steps from a mall, you would find gorgeous gardens, peace, tranquility and the beautiful Chin Lin Nunnery!! Our friends who had been to Hong Kong many times had never visited the Nunnery- we all agreed this was a very worthwhile stop- not to be overlooked,

Nice water features and bonsai. Chi lin nunnery is connected to and just behind Nan Lian Gardens offering a peaceful and serene environment to visitors. They have water features and a couple of impressive bonsai behind cages (!) .

Interesting place. The grounds are beautiful, well maintained, a quiet and tranquil retreat in the middle of the buzz of the city. I tried the vegetarian restaurant located in the adjacent park/garden, which is also nice. The set menu was a little pricey, but the food was pretty good, but got me out of my comfort zone. Lots of mushrooms and bean curd, veggis, etc.

enjoy a quiet afternoon. I come with my family at CNY. My mother loved here so much.I think there is not Wong Tai Sin temple kind of busy.You can enjoy a quiet afternoon and spend a quality time with great engineer art.

Fantastic. Since it's just after Chinese New year, I managed to be at the Nunnery when it was very quiet and hardly anyone was around. One of the few free historic sights in china, it was a nice change in pace from the usual “pay to enter the grounds then pay to enter the buildings plus there's shops everywhere”. The park just across the street was also free and also lovely!

a peaceful place to visit and wander around. definitely can't fault this place at all, such a tranquil environment, so peaceful just to wander around. the gardens are spotless, sitting down under one of the trees there was so relaxing.

A slice of Kyoto in Hong Kong. This well-maintained, quiet, and peaceful temple complex is one of Hong Kong's hidden gems! The site is easy to access from Diamond Hill MTR station (2 minutes outside the station) but yet feels tucked away and totally remote. The nuns don't come out (they're in the back complex) so don't expect to see any live religious activity. Go for an afternoon stroll and enjoy the gardens and make a wish or two. Bring a book or a Kindle—it'll be an afternoon well spent.

Chi Lin Nunnery. This beautiful Nunnery is situated opposite the Nan Lian Gardens,
As you walk into the Gardens of the Nunnery you are immediately aware of the serenity & peace of the Nunnery. The gardens are beautiful. The various different rooms are beautiful. Very worthwhile to visit.
A peaceful haven. The Nunnery and it's gardens are a shrine to tranquillity in the middle of one of the noisiest cities in the world. An hour here is complete refreshment for the spirit

Wonderful to see. It was great to go here and see what it was like for the people when it was overseen by the British. The nunnery is a great place to visit and I would recommend coming here to see if not to walk around the entire area.

Quiet in the center of the city. This garden is sitting just next to the mtr station -diamond hill and is a good place worth to visit, you can find traditional structure of Chinese building and landscape. Good for a relaxed afternoon

Beautiful architecture, temple, gardens.. After 8 days in Hong Kong was happy to stumble upon this place as I was disappointed we had seen very little traditional pagoda style architecture. Several buildings at this site fit the bill. The temples, gardens, grounds are pristine. We even got to speak with a monk. There is a vegetarian restaurant (no signs…it's way in the back, well beyond the snack bar) that looked awesome. Warning, restaurant closes 1/2 hour before their posted time, so we unfortunately did not eat there, despite arriving 31 minutes before "close".

A gem in Diamond Hill.... It's a bit of a trek by MTR but worth it. The gardens are a great photo-op, the restaurant is fantastic for vegetarians and the nunnery itself is beautiful - the temple staff are a little assiduous with their rules for photos and sitting in the correct areas... However it's a good and easy trip out of busy Hong Kong city.

Definitely worthwhile. We went here on a Saturday afternoon, not knowing whether it would be worth the MTR ride from HK Island. It definitely was. I found it beautiful and peaceful, even moving. And it's such a refreshing change from HK's other touristed areas.

Serenity within Kowloon. Having researched Tripadvisor for places to visit, it is understandable why this is so highly recommended. We took the MTR, so it easy to access; it was no distance from Diamond Hill station. It was very quiet, midweek and just before Chinese New Year. We found it very peaceful and serene. A great getaway from the hustle and bustle of the city itself. We enjoyed the walk around the gardens first and were overawed by the beauty of the nunnery and its surroundings. Pity photos weren't allowed inside but understandable that it was a place to be respected. It was immaculately clean and the offerings to Buddha were so colourful and beautifully laid out. The most amazing orchids I have ever seen! Such a treat as I love them. We came away feeling calm and peaceful. A wonderful morning spent in such a lovely place.....highly recommend this visit and it is free!

Amazing place. We spent a very enjoyable couple of hours at this place, which is like a huge landscaped zen garden. It was tranquil and soothing, a welcome break away from the skyscrapers of HK! Don't forget to visit Nan Lian garden and Wong Tai Sin Temple, they are all near to each other.

Beautiful and Tranquil. A great place to come to for a moment of peace and tranquility, residing above Nan Lian Gardens (also worth visiting).Came during the Chinese New Year public holidays but fortunately it wasn't crowded.Very easy to get to by MTR - jump off at Diamond Hill station and signposts direct you across the road and straight into Nan Lian Gardens.

Tranquil surprise. An amazing oasis of tranquility in a busy town, which is easy to get to and well worth the trip. It was also interesting to know that the nuns are only there for as long as they need/want go be and it is not expected that they make a life of being nuns (or so my guide told me). Beautiful spot.

Worth a visit. While not an ancient, historic sight I'd definitely recommend a visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery and work it in to others in the Kowloon City area like the Kowloon Walled City Park as they are sights fewer travellers seek out. The nunnery is connected by footpath to the Nan Lian Garden making it easy to explore both. The gold pagoda in the garden is very scenic.

A place of deep contemplation. Set above the Nan Lian Garden is this Nunnery. It felt quite serene and we did not want to disturb the peace. There were formal paths and gardens and Buddhas and other statues. The second part of the building could only be viewed from the outside and signs requested no photography of the statues. Along the return walk we passed by numerous elaborate wood carvings and each was accompanied by a saying that fitted into the Buddhism mantra. Well worth a visit and different to other temples.

a very decent private park. excellent gardening work, good design of low rise house in the pond. Better go in weekdays.. many domestic helper stay there in holiday and Sundays because of free of charge.
Great veggie Chinese food.. The restaurant here looks beautiful and the food does a fair degree of justice to the appearance of the place. It fits together nicely.

Tranquility in Hong Kong. It a beautiful place to visit. If you are looking for a tranquil spot in bustling Hong Kong, visit the Chi Lin Nunnery. The simplicity of the design of the structures and courtyard is beautiful.
Austere but calming. Compared to other temples, austere but very calming, with lots of greenery and Bonzai trees. The gardens next to it were quite beautiful.
Heaven of peace. Beautiful complex close Diamond Hill MTR station. A visit to HK must include this temple. Across the street a very attractive parc.

Fantastic - so peaceful and great start to our time in Hong Kong. Thanks to Trip Advisor reviews, we visited Chi Lin Nunnery on the first proper day of our holiday and we are so glad we did. Such a peaceful atmosphere in amongst all the hubbub of Hong Kong. Beautiful gardens, buildings and very interesting interiors etc
Peace in the city. That the metro to Diamond hill and follow the signs across the road. Great gardens and Nunnery. Just sit and chilax
Old meet new. If you are near, go and see this. The place is beautiful and theres nice contrast with new buildings behind the nunnery.

Quiet, peaceful. Such a nice getaway from the hustle and bustle. Easy to get to. If you have time while in HK, go visit. We didn't have time to have lunch but enjoyed tea in the cafe instead. Will go back to enjoy traditional fare in beautiful setting

Tranquil retreat in the middle of a big city. It is still one of my special go to places after living in
Hong Kong for eight years . Love the quiet and architecture of the nunnery and the vegetarian lunch under the waterfall in the gardens across the road.
really cool and nice. awesome garden and Nunnery. A little commercial but still very nice. I was impressed with how well kept the whole property was.
It was under renovation. This was actually my second visit, and I was looking for some peace and quiet. That was really hard to do with all the renovation going on. Eventually I just left.
an oasis in a urban jungle. This was a well kept secret. The gardens were beautiful and we truly enjoyed it. Everyone should visit this place when you are in Hong Kong.

Beautiful and immaculate. Lovely garden, temple and nunnery with immaculate and beautiful grounds. Lovely little oasis. Nice to take and hour or two to wander around... there is a cafe but have not heard much about it, only one bad review.

Best monastery ever. Just next to the Nan Lian Garden. Obligatory place to visit. With a lot of beautiful bonsai trees and great architecture inside. Peaceful place , completely different than rest of hongkong
