Temple. Just across the Nan Lian garden you should be able to visit this place. The temple has different levels. One could take a lot of photos here.

Stunning Gardens. This is a great place to take an easy stroll in the hot Hong kong summer and to see some beautiful plants and gardens in peace. Also a great vegetarian resteraunt located under a waterfall - mainly mushrooms but worth the visit

Escape and have tea. I was not disappointed, I just didn't find it special. I'd recommend going for a moment of quiet. The adjacent gardens have a traditional tea house that is worthwhile. They walk you through the process of selecting the right tea and brewing it according to custom.

A welcome surprise. We went to the Nan Lian Gardens to which this was attached. Gorgeous landscaping and the carvings and way it was laid out were just wonderful. The view of the city was great, too. I'd go back in a heartbeat.

Great Photo Op!. Loved visiting. Amazing places for photos and get those "asian-y" photos and architecture. Unfortunately, the main building was covered in scaffolding. But alas, it just means I have to go back!
Take you're time there. It's nice to just wander slowly without feeling the bustle of the city.
Peace and tranquility in the middle of mayhem.. Amazing bonsai. Beautifully kept and the ancient artifacts were stunning. Well worth the taxi ride I would go again
an oasis of calm and tradition. One of the highlights of our trip to Hong Kong and well worth seeking out. Totally stunning setting against the backdrop of the modern high-rise city.

Beautiful place. Such a gem in the middle of a crowded city!
Beautiful place to visit, relax and have a vegetarian lunch.
So calm and peaceful. Definitely worth a visit.
Surprised that there weren't many people there at all (except for the restaurant in the gardens).

Nice place with a no selfie stick policy! haha. Chi Lin Nunnery is definitely worth a visit for anyone spending a few days in HK.
It's not crowded, easy to find, free of charge and the gardens and surroundings are really nice.
Plenty of photo ops but beware you aren't allowed to use selfie sticks! I had to remove my go pro from it's housing.

Superb vegetarian restaurant. Amidst a very tranquil setting, the pleasure of an unhurried meal is not to be overlooked. Afterwards, a second stroll will ease the digestion of the healthy foods consumed. Over the recent years of visitations to the Nunnery, I have never suffered a poor dining experience.
Oasis of calm. Beautiful temple and outstanding gardens in Kowloon section of HK. Definitely worth a visit. Diamond Hill MRT stop.

Stillness and Peace even with people around . It is one of those places where you feel at peace and quietness even if there are people all over. I've been 3 times, that's how much I loved the place and even though it was never too full, you just feel like you are on your own and the stillness of the Buddhas, the bonsais and the lotus flowers... A truly amazing place, definitely worth a visit if you are in HK!

Tranquil garden full of bonsai near great plaza. The gardens are a treat to visit after spending days pounding the busy pavements of the CBD. Weren't busy, even on a Sunday. The trees are amazing. There are bonsai and also full-size trees that are taken care of as though they were bonsai (branches are groomed and shaped using wire, etc). Lovely gift shop and good plaza nearby (Hollywood Plaza) with Giordano, Uniqlo, Lees and Levi's, M&S, HnM and more. Food Republic is the place to get incredible and authentic cheap lunch!

A nice way to spend a morning. This place looks amazing with the beautiful wooden construction. We went first thing in the morning so it was relatively quiet which was nice as Hong Kong is not exactly a quiet destination. I do no think there is much to say about this place; good for a quick look but need not spend too much time here. The tacky gift shop is always a little off putting in a place which is supposed to be about spirituality. Like most public attractions this place was kept immaculately clean and easy to get to from the MTR.
A peaceful place to escape. The Nunnery and the connected gardens were an oasis in the concrete jungle of HK. It was wonderful to be surrounded by green and the gardens are so beautifully cared for.

Beautiful architecture. After visiting the Nan Lian Garden we came to the Chi Lin Nunnery. This place is quite amazing, a display of beautiful Chinese architecture. All wood construction with thousands of joints is quite amazing. Great to see these old buildings with the modern sky risers in the background.Place is very clean and organised. It is a place of worship for locals, but not sure if the Nunnery is still in use.If you are visiting the Nan Lian Garden should not miss this place.

Good vegetarian food. very good vegetarian food. It's located inside a garden owned by a budda organization with its temple next to it. the garden is really nice in environment which giving you a peaceful feeling.
Clean & well maintained. The place is not crowded most of the time. Very good garden with temple. easily walking from the MTR as well

Quiet tourist area. This is a paradise in the centre of sky scrapers. The gardens are really easy to find, if you catch the mtr it is located at diamond hill and is only a 2 minute walk from there. When we first got to the gardens it was just after 9 and it was so peaceful and a place I could spend all day relaxing, it seems that it's not huge tourist attraction so you get to experience them as you should.The nunnery has some beautiful buildings which are located within the gardens although you do not get to enter them the Chinese architecture is enough to keep you in awe. With a beautiful gold building in the centre of the water is stunning. All in all I love that you can find peace and tranquility in a big city !
Chinese Style. if you like china history, may consider pay a visit.Garden style is stick on Tang Dynasty , if you are interested in Chinese old style architecture, it worth to have a look

Definitely Worth a Visit. This beautiful oasis of Asian gardens, temples and ponds is something to visit. Stroll the grounds, and it's as if you have gone back in time. It's very easy to reach by MTR, and you can have lunch at the large shopping mall that is adjacent to this sanctuary. Yeah, you can't really go to far in Hong Kong without running into a shopping mall.

A welcome breather. In the middle of the city, this respite from commercialism and concrete is the place to be for a 1/2 day "off". The temples and grounds are gorgeous and the Gardens to which it is attached are calming.

Stunning & peaceful. Beautiful small temple hidden in Kowloon with great gardens. Very peaceful and not as busy as some others I have been to. Very helpful staff around who were keen to share their knowledge which just added to the whole experience

Awesome & Peaceful. Chi Lin Nunnery i very peaceful and beautiful location that we discovered in Hong Kong, you can see all the different avatars of Buddha and their significance is also explained. Landscape of the place is just awesome, every visitor to Hong Kong if loves to see the beautiful landscape and wants to visit temple of Buddha then have to visit this place.

Sanctuary in the city. A must see in Hong Kong. This nunnery is beautifully constructed around a courtyard with immaculate gardens. It is a little oasis of calm in a hectic city. Make sure to visit the Nan Lee gardens across the road as well. Both are free to visit.
peace on earth. what a great place to visit,so peaceful.a place of beauty and the architecture from a builders point of view was great.the gardens were kept in perfect condition.well worth going.

Elegent, Serene, and Peaceful. I have to say firstly, this place is a complete sanctuary tucked into a really busy neighborhood in Hong Kong in Diamond Hill by a huge mall! The upkeep of this place is spectacular, it has been kept immaculately and is just the place to go for some quiet time. The landscaped gardens and small prayer rooms that line the temple are an absolute treat to look around and it was one of the most beautiful attractions I visited in Hong Kong. Simply a must go, and is extremely easy to get to by MTR from all over Hong Kong. Make the time to go!

good place to visit. the place is excellent and worth a visit. It is set in a lovely setting. It is better to reach there early and enjoy the calm and peace of the early morning. well connected by public transport

Peaceful Place Amongst the Concrete Jungle!. This place which is located behind a Mall in Diamond Hill is beautiful. Loved the serene ambience. Interesting architecture and lily pond/gardens to view. They also have a couple of gift shops and vegetarian restaurants. Tried one vege restaurant which is nice if you like Chinese vege food otherwise, it is an acquired taste.

tranquil. Great place for photos and to spend some time to have some quiet time. You cannot take any photos of the buddahs, but there are lots of signs about what each Buddha is for. From here, go across the foot bridge to the nan lin gardens for more photo opportunities.

Relaxing place. This is a beautiful modern temple with classic features. We enjoyed the landscaped gardens and paths that were easy to walk. the location is easy to get to by MTR at Diamond Hill stop. we came from Kowloon.

Worth a visit. I found this place quite by chance in a guide book. It is easy to find on the MTR and certainly worth a visit. It is both peaceful and interesting. Opposite the Nunnery is the Nan Lian Garden. Another oasis with a coffee shop! If you have the time it is certainly worth a trip.
Well worth a visit. A wonderful oasis just a little way out of the city on the MTR. The gardens are really wonderful and well managed. Lovely tea room as well. Nunnery itself is very interesting.
Wonderful place. Reminded me very much of Japan, and none of the crowds like at nearby Wong Tai Sin. Very different from the other temples in Hong Kong, and a beautiful garden to wander in.
Serene. Very nice place. Worth a visit. We went on a weekday and there weren't many visitors around which was good. Landscaping was beautiful.
Lovely. Very close to MTR. Easily accessible, lovely spot for a few hours of R&R away from the bustle of Hong Kong city centre

Chi Lin + Nan Lian Garden. Quiet and serene environment - a good temple combo visit with Nan Lian Garden and Sik Sik Yuen temple (one metro stop West). There's an outer courtyard with ponds and an inner courtyard line with buddha halls. The temple is built in an historical style, however, it looks and feels new - it was refurbished in the 1990s.

An Oasis in Amongst the Chaos of Hong Kong. When you visit Hong Kong you are bewildered by the busyness, noise, sights and sounds of one of the most dynamic and interesting cities in the world. Therefore to find a place like the Chi Lin Nunnery is an oasis of peace and quiet in the chaos of Hong Kong. The place I stunning and so peaceful. Make sure you visit early in the day so you can appreciate the architecture and the history of the nunnery before wandering the gardens. The souvenir shop provides some 'treasures' that make great presents for folks back home. Would highly recommend this attraction to anyone visiting Hong Kong.
Worth a visit. Amazing space in the middle of town. A good gift shop with some interesting items. The adjacent gardens are magnificent.

Straight out of an awesome movie set. In our recent HK visits, we felt like we ran out of things to do. So we thought of walking around wherever our feet will take us and land ho! What an unexpected pleasant surprise. Chi Lin nunnery was nestled in the middle of the city. Like a secret garden. Entrance is free and people are allowed to take photos everywhere except inside the templed themselves. The temples were mesmerizing. Like standing in the middle of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. We're glad we found this beautiful and peaceful oasis.
tranquil beauty. Walk in from the Nan Lian Garden and you enter a world of absolute tranquillity. The temples are stunning and one can watch the monks performing their rituals.
Greenery love. You will love it if you love nature! A relax walk with your loved ones is good! No admission fee require! Taking photographs on the greenery is so much love!!
Beautiful & Unexpected. This was a great, unexpected spot in the city. It is beautiful and peaceful. It is very easy to follow the signs from the MTR- just a short walk away.

Beautiful Oasis!. This was one of my favorite stops in Hong Kong! Beautiful gardens and stunning architecture. There were not throngs of people, as in other parts of the city, and it was a very reflective environment. Highly recommend

Intersting. Very nice and beautiful location. Very impressed with the design and decoration for a very modern building. The rock garden/museum makes some radical claims that we found interesting. The bonsai trees were amazing and very old. Another location in Hong Kong that needs an option to take a guided tour in English to truly appreciate the full attraction.

Peaceful break away from all the hustle and bustle. This was actually one of my favourite tourist attractions in Hong Kong. From moment you step inside the beautifully maintained gardens, you feel sense of calm and peace. We were lucky that we visited this place on a sunny day which enable us to take our time walking around and enjoyed the scenery. Location is only 5 minutes walk from metro station with clear signage.I would highly recommend it for something different from all the high rise buildings, busy roads, the shopping.
A new attraction!. Visited the nunnery as it is next to Nan Lin Garden which is highly recommended in TripAdvisor. The place is very beautiful and peaceful, an ideal place to take beautiful pictures.

Beautiful temple. I loved visiting this peaceful and beautiful place. The nunnery is very close to the city and convenient to the subway, yet you feel very removed from the hustle and bustle of HK. The attached gardens are stunning, and again so beautiful.

Diamond hills heart. Diamond hill is the stop you need and it is very easily sign posted once you exit the MTR. You will probably spend between 30 - 45 minutes here. Great escape from the heart of the city and chinese architecture not to be missed. The atomsphere here is wonderful! Dont miss the gardens opposite. Have a great time in Hong Kong :)
Peaceful buddhist garden. A great place to go in the end of the day. Just across Diamond Hill metro station - one of the most peaceful places in Hong Kong. There's a nice vegetarian restaurant there.

Oasis of calm in a frentic city. I have been to Hong Kong many times and only this past December did I have a chance to visit the Chin Lin Nunnery. It is extremely easy to get to via the metro - the Diamond Hill stop. There are signs from the metro stop to the Nunnery and the Garden. Allow a 2 to 3 hour together with the Nan Lian Garden - to absorb the atmosphere. Start with the Nunnery and through an overpass you can get to the Garden. Please note, you are not supposed to take photos at the altars.
Peace and Quiet. Loved it here. A little piece of peace in a crazy, bustling city. Train to Diamond Hill and a few minutes walk is all it takes.
Great Place, do not miss it.. excellent place to chill out and take a break from the city, also across road a large shopping centre at Diamond Hill MTR station.
Very pretty~. Part of our tour, stopped for 1/2 hour to walk around and take pictures of the beautiful building~ I especially like the chinese zodiac animal statues at the base.
calming. visited here and loved the gardens which are well worth a walk through, it was amazing to see and you could not believe you were in the middle of the city
Beautiful and peaceful. The nunnery as well as the adjacent gardens are a welcome contrast to the rest of the city. The restaurant is also very good

A peaceful place amongst bustling Hong Kong. This nunnery was established in 1934. Its elegant wooden architecture houses several golden Buddhist relics. The gardens include lotus ponds and many bonsai plants for ones enjoyment.I would recommend to visit early in the morning to avoid the crowds, then cross the overpass into Nan Lian Garden.Access via MTR Diamond Hill exit C2 and follow the signs - it's just a short walk across the road.

Surprisingly serene with great mini museums in the park. Over the years in Asia I've been to more Buddhist temples than I can count. They're usually timeworn and exotic and in low density locales. Quite frankly I was curious as to what this place would look and feel like in the middle of my favorite mega-city. It is definitely a sharp counterpoise to the rest of Hong Kong. Even though it is surrounded by highrises, the atmosphere is quite calming. It feels self-contained and relaxed. I meditated there and in retrospect, there were no extraneous sounds of the City seeping in - just rustling leaves and some gurgling fountains. I can definitely use the word refreshing. Also, it was not particularly crowded.Adjacent to the nunnery is a municipal park which we entered almost as an afterthought. Glad we did: beautifully maintained and with two small museums- one full of huge scale models of the various temple types and the other for "connoisseurs" of rocks. Both were quite engaging and also a pleasant surprise. It's all about a 5 minute walk from the Metro and a nice interlude from the crush of urbanism that is Hong Kong.
An oasis in the middle of the city. What a lovely place to stroll, sit, take in the scenery. The gardens are magnificent. Visit the center where they describe the construction of the buildings. Wow!
A peaceful place in a crowded city. This was a welcome surprise. It had a beautiful garden and was only minutes from a busy road and shops. Very nice place to visit. Beautiful temple.

A peaceful haven and beautiful site surrounded by urban Kowloon.. Chin Lin Nunnery lies adjacent to Nan Lian Gardens. Entry to both are free, but garden rules are strictly applied. No food or drink can be eaten in the gardens. There is a restaurant, snack bar and plenty of toilets in Nan Lian Gardens but not the Nunnery. From Tsim Sha Tsui take the red line MTR toward Prince Edward Station and change there to the green line. Get off the green line at Diamond Hill, exit Hollywood Plaza. The Nan Lian Gardens are across the road - follow signposts. Let the photographs show what is difficult to explain.

Our 1st taste of culture. After arriving in HK this was the 1st place we visited. Quiet, beautiful serenity in the middle of chaos ! Free to get in and a lovely shop to purchase some keepsakes. This is one of the things I loved about HK, tiny pockets of culture and peace within such a busy cosmopolitan city.
Unexpected find. A great place to visit for some time out from the hustle and bustle; Calm, serene and beautiful temples and gardens.

Great!. This was a wonderful example of an active religious sight. We saw monks working on the shrines while we were there. Limited picture-taking allowed. The gardens across the street (via footbridge) are worth a visit as well!
Lovely peaceful sanctuary. This place is a real gem amongst the noise and mayhem of HongKong. Very easy to find. Peaceful, meditative and spotless!

A very good experience. Was trying to go and didn't find the chance before as it is located not at the touristic area. Took the subway to the other side of the island and walking distance you are there. There are 2 parts and nunnery part closes a bit earlier than the park side. They had a bit of the introduction of the architect and also a "bonsai"??? garden, you get to see glamourous little trees, thought only Japan has it.

A must see in HK, the oriental side of the city.... Nice place to be visited in HK... After a city life in HK, this place is a refreshment to see the Asian touch and green part. It is very easy to access and located just next to a nice shopping mall which may give you the options to have a coffee-meal break after sightseeing...

A true hidden gem! Don't miss it!. After the "main" sights, put this on your list. The nunnery is beautiful and peaceful--more Japanese in style than other HK temples. The garden is awesome. Don't miss the "rockery" and any special exhibitions. This pairs very well with the Sik Sik temple that is just 1 MTR stop away. Do the temp,e first, if you are heading our early--it is open all the time and the nunnery opens a bit later.

Tranquil escape. Whether you're into Buddhism or not, Chi Lin Nunnery is a lovely tranquil escape from Hong Kong's typically busy streets and shopping malls.Even though the temple is relatively new, it was laid out in a traditional Chinese old fashion.A very interesting visit.

Is this in HKG?. Lovely afternoon, tucked away from the big city's hustle and..., you get my drift. There were birds singing this early January. There was a ceremony and people praying, while chants were quietly heard. The park across the street was most suitable. If you need a break, this is quite the place.
Peaceful oasis in the city. Easy to access from exit C2 Diamond Hill MRT and directly across the road from Nan Lian gardens. Free to see and worth a break from shopping.

A different type of temple. I saw many temples in Hong Kong and Taiwain for the last 2 weeks but this one is very different. It has a different architectural design like a Japanese pagoda, not colorful as many Chinese temples. I was very impressed with the numbers of bonsai on site, The restaurant with waterfall outside was very nice.What I did not like was being chased away by site staffs because they did not want people to take pictures of the buildings in the back even from the outside.

Peaceful Oasis. This location is not what comes to mind when your in Hong Kong. An amazing experience and location. Very nice to walk through this well maintained garden and a well needed break from the concrete jungle surrounding this area.Some awesome photo opportunities around this area. Make sure to check if any works are happening on the grounds, because when we were there in November the golden temple was fully scaffolded and closed off.

Tranquil and beautiful. We visited here after reading good reviews and weren't disappointed. A 2 minute walk from the Diamond Hill MTR station and next to Nan Lian Gardens, Chi Lin Nunnery is so peaceful and a really beautiful place to visit.

Not what you expect in Hong Kong...but absolutely worth it.. I first saw the reviews on TripAdvisor and thought this would be an interesting visit. However, when we asked our friends in Hong Kong, they had never even visited it. Their loss.Very easy to get to on the MTR, these beautiful grounds are in the heart of Hong Kong and provide a nice respite to the hustle and bustle from the rest of the trip.It is quite serene and offers time for reflection and a general sense of relaxation. It probably takes about 1.5 hours to walk the whole grounds and visit the different buildings.It's quite incredible that the temple was built without a single nail. It really is something else.

Peaceful oasis in the city. Chi Lin Nunnery together with the Chi Lin Garden offers a nice getaway from the busy and people packed city. Enjoy the peacefulness of the garden and the calming sounds at the Nunnery. Worth visiting definitely.

I would recommend everyone to visit this place. Its beautiful architecture and also so peaceful in the middle of the city. The place very well maintained and does not have any entry fee as well. Its a walking distance from the Diamond Hill MTR station
Great garden. Very well maintained beautiful garden and there's some exhibitions inside (rockery, architectural). And it's free

Zen like oasis. This oasis in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong is a must-see. It's convenient to get to (Diamond Hill MTR, Exit C2), then a 5 minute walk. It's refreshingly simple yet peaceful to stroll around the garden and temples. A great way to spend a couple of hours.

Beautiful and serene. The nunnery and the gardens nearby were a wonderful counterpoint to all that is the HK experience. They were serene, quiet, and contemplative in the midst of the mass of humanity that is the shopping district of HK!
Peacefull. Surounded by skyliner, a place to meditate and a visit is a must.The garden outside is beautiful. I would go again.

Serene & lovely. Chi Lin Nunnery is easily accessible via Hong Kong's MTR. Simply take till Diamond Hill MTR, and follow the directory and i'm sure you'll able to find your way. This place is suitable for peeps who's prefer sightseeing, w serenity and calmness. The area is clean, and well-maintained too. I spent almost 1-2 hrs touring the area, and this is one of my favourite place. Rest assured there's no fee involved to enter. It's open (foc) to everyone and they even have an information counter too if you've any enquiry. The architecture is stunning as it's kinda similar to forbidden city, but this is occupied with temple halls and ponds. I spent my early evening strolling around Chi Lin Nunnery and i must say, it's all worth it. I would recommend to visit it during early evening probably between 3-5pm, when the crowd level is really low. This place gives me a peace of mind, it's eye-opening.
Beautiful Gardens. Well worth a visit, an oasis in the constant noise of Hong Kong, beautiful gardens and temple, close to Diamond Hill station

A very special few hours . We visited the nunnery and gardens today and were blown away by the beauty and tranquility. It's hard to believe that it is so close to high rise and a big shopping centre. The architecture is amazing and the grounds beautiful - we all highly recommend this as a place to see in Hong Kong

Lovely building. This is a well laid out area, made to look like some part of the forbidden city. It cannot hide the fact that it is as old as my teenage neighbour. This is a very clean zone where you can try to imagine the workings of a nunnery (to actually hear the stories, the 'nuns' charge a fee). It's a very calm and quiet place, but just a large building with a sizeable court and a small area for you to burn some incense around the side (back) of the building. You can exit from here and catch the 92 bus to Sai Kung (buses every 17 minutes according to chart), Overall 7/10

So peaceful and yet still part of the city. A modern nunnery, laid out beautifully with several separate temples. A very peaceful place, just over the road from the Nan Lian Gardens. Together the two make for a must-see 1/2 day out.
An oasis of calm in a bustling city. In a vibrant place such as Hong Kong the Chi Lin Nunnery provides a quiet place to recharge. A rare gem among the hustle and bustle of a hectic life style.
Serenity. Beautiful nunnery and gardens -very relaxing, beautiful and calm. Take a bit of time out after a busy visit around the city. Bonus points - it is FREE!

The best in Hong Kong. The Chi Lin Nunnery is such a beautiful location in the middle of a bustling city. It is peaceful and so beautiful. I'm not Buddist, but still found it a very interesting and amazing place to visit. This should be at the top of your list when visiting Hong Kong.

Peaceful. This is a nice and peaceful nunnery within the city. The place was filled with tourists when we got there but the atmosphere was very calm and tranquil with a lot of people engrossed in their prayers. The architecture of the temples was superb.

Mini-Forbidden City-ish. The inside of the temple kind of resembles the courtyard of the Forbidden City. You could just roam around for a while checking every area of the temple, but there isn't much to see. But there are lots of points to take photo ops. It's real hot there during summer or mid-autumn.

Stunningly Beautiful. I was blown away by the impact of these structures and how amazingly peaceful and beautiful it all was. This place truely inspires the practices of meditation, mindfulness and serenity. I could have stayed for hours to soak it all in.

Gorgeous. Genuinely delighted with the experience. Kind of happened upon the nunnery whilst in the gardens, but all these reviews make this clear. My 9 year old was swept away by this place with its peace, serenity and intensity. Gardens are a delight if somewhat over-officiated. Shop has some nice items too.

Peace in the middle of everything. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs. Chi Lin Nunnery is a Buddhist temple surrounded by busy roads, the Hollywood Plaza mall, and high rise apartment blocks. The architecture is fantastic, with temples built entirely from wood without any nails. The structure was built in 1998, but intended to replicate, as closely as possible, a much older structure. The Buddhist art work is wonderful, and the entire site is well maintained. All in all, it's a calm oasis in the middle of an extremely crowded and busy city, and worth the visit independent of your faith.

Urban oasis. Lovely gardens and religious center made in traditional Chinese style. All buildings are made with NO nails, just complex wood joints and fittings. Peaceful and lovely traditional gardens, water features and small shops. Good retreat in a busy city.

Go and enjoy :-). Not far from the Diamond HIll MTR in Kowloon. In the style of the Tang Dynasty, the temple houses many beautiful statues of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas made from gold, stone, wood. The setting is very peaceful with formal gardens and water pools with lotuses. One feels the atmosphere is very spiritual and blessed. It is said that when one gazes upon statues of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, one receives many blessings. Following a tour of the temple, visit the Nan Lian Garden which is connected to the temple, and have a memorable lunch or dinner at the Chi Lin Restaurant overlooking the waterfall. I highly recommend this outing to anyone visiting Hong Kong.
Impressive Gardens. A little hard to find the entrance to the nunnery - but if you go to the gardens first, you can walk up the stair over the street to get to it.

A GEM NOT TO BE MISSED!. We came upon this by chance. How lucky we were! It is a haven of peace in a busy area of Hong Kong. The gardens are lovely and the nunnery is superb. Well worth a visit. One of the highlights of Hong Kong for us! Far more memorable than the very disappointing Symphony of Light in the harbour!

A nice complex, but it is a modern replica. The architecture is lovely, but I found it hard to be inspired just by this aspect alone. A visitor to Hong Kong surely comes firstly to be immersed in the hectic reality of one of the world's busiest and most vibrant cities. The Nunnery is a lovely reconstruction, and an enjoyable visit with the adjoining gardens. But if you are going to travel further into Asia there will be other real experiences in temples and historical sites much more inspiring than this. Fight the crowds in Canton Rd or walk Hollywood Road instead if your time in this crazy city is short.

Living History. Super easy to get to via Metro.As we walked up to the Chi Lin, the thing that kept running through my mind was, centuries ago a nunnery was an escape a place out of the city typically at the top of a hill or up the mountain. But here we are walking from the subway across a street and up a slight incline. By the lay of the land you can tell the development around the nunnery has swallowed the history yet left it in tact. Recently renovated, if you look closely you can see the original roofing components, so different from western roofing. It is a builders dream to see such a building standing and renovated. The culture and daily practices make this a very special and sacred place to the locals and Buddhists a far. If you are traveling in July or August make sure you have plenty of water. There is a place to buy refreshments, but even though it is a short walk as always in Hong Kong the heat will get to you. When you cross the road to the park another magical experience comes your way as you are able to see the old style pagodas and gardens that the Chinese cultures prides itself on. I do agree with others who have posted here, These Gardens rival any Japanese style you will find. Simply beautiful. Unique components are found looking past the renovations and looking for the original land barriers, fences and internal roads of the nunnery. This is what takes you back to understand how these people lived in comparison to today;s modern Hong Kong/Kowloon.The pictures you can take at this location are truly a kodak moment(s) when you plan and shoot across the pond or at the waterfall across the street, and at night when it is all lit up it is spectacular. You will want to catch as much as you can without a flash.

An Oasis of Tranquility. Beautiful and peaceful place to recover from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Refresh your mind and your spirit as walk among bonsai and ponds, wonder at the silence and peace after the noise of the city
Must go. It is worth the effort to see the Nunnery. It is a very impressive building. Cross over the road and visit the gardens - they are excellent.

Enchanting place in the middle of the busy city!. Once you walk in this premises, you will feel like you are in Japan. The architectural and garden style is zen and japanese. Easy to go by MTR, just 5 minutes walk from the MTR station. There are also vegetarian restaurant and gift shops inside. The garden is peaceful and relaxing. Although the temple closes around 4:30pm, the entrance gate closes around 6pm. There is separate entrance to the vegetarian restaurant for dinner.

Peaceful and Serene Place. There were not a lot of visitors there which made the place a lot more peaceful and pleasant to be in compared to the bustling city areas. The brown wooden structures, grey concrete tiles, water features, lily ponds, bonsai plants and greenery feels very zen and sure to calm your mind. The statues of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas were magnificent and beautiful different from the ones you see in the traditional monasteries. What probably ruin the picturesque nunnery are the high rise estates surrounding the place.
Worth a visit. It's hard to believe you are in hate middle of Hong Kong when you visit this Nunnery. It's very peaceful and lovely to walk around. Visit the gardens too.
Lovely place for a visit. The buildings are new,and nicely laid out,Nice surroundings with garden,water ponds with water lilies

Stunning gardens - definitely worth a visit. The Chi Lin Nunnery and adjacent Nan Lian Gardens are stunning and so meticulously maintained - you can watch the gardeners as they tend to the plantings to keep them perfectly trimmed. You can easily reach the Nunnery and Gardens just across the street from the Diamond Hill MTR station - just follow the signs. The gardens are free and a great place to enjoy some solitude and serenity for 1-2 hours. The gentleman at the information booth was so welcoming to me as a visitor of his city and that was a special touch. In certain parts of the garden there is spa-type music playing and it was delightful to just sit for a little bit to enjoy and contemplate the beauty. The morning that I was there, it was softly raining so I can only imagine how beautiful this garden would be on a pretty day! Note that the Pavillon is currently under bamboo scaffolding and wrap for restoration until late January 2015. That was the only bummer.There are numerous clean restrooms onsite, a wonderful gift shop that had unique items at surprisingly reasonable prices and a little snack house where I enjoyed mik tea and toast for 25 HKD/$3 USD. There is also a more formal Tea House that is open in the afternoon that looked exquisite - unfortunately I was there in the morning before it opened.

Experience Serenity and Inner Peace Amidst This Bustling City.. If you are interested in Chinese religion and architecture, here's a great itinerary: First take the subway to see the popular Taoist Wongtaisin Temple (Wongtaisin stop) to mingle and worship with hundreds of followers. This colorful but "slightly" garish temple compound is exciting, with lots of people praying, chatting, smoke and incense, red lanterns and colorful paper offerings. When you finally need a break to breathe in some fresh air, exit the temple and have a nice 15-minute stroll up the main road. Suddenly, in front of you appears an absolutely beautifully landscaped Nan Lian Garden. You feel you are in a different world. The Chinese-style garden is a public park in which every tree, shrub, rock, waterfall and hilly mound are designed according to traditional Chinese landscaping and geomancy. It has some resemblance to a Japanese Zen garden. It's the perfect place for resting your tired body and mind. Air is purer here, it seems. Everywhere in the park is photogenic. Adjoining the garden is the Buddhist Chi Lian Nunnery. It was renovated in 1990, and is most famous for its Tang Dynasty-style wood architecture. The complex includes temple halls, lotus ponds, and many Buddhist relics and scriptures. There were only a number of visitors, and no burning incense etc. We could hear soft soothing Buddhist chants and prayers being broadcast through speakers. So take your time to enjoy this serene and body/mind-cleansing place, because very soon you will be lost in the real bustling Hong Kong again.
peaceful nunnery. if you are looking for a "quiet time", away from the masses, this place will be ideal for you. I strongly recommend it.

A beautiful and serene place. It was a beautiful place, the buildings were stunning. You could wander round and enter a lot of the buildings. The garden area with ponds. Was so relaxing. Very enjoyable amidst the bustle of the city.

Stunningly Beautiful Amidst City. I loved this place! It's completely different from the outside surroundings of the hustle and bustle of the city! Take your time here to walk around, take some photos, and enjoy the peace. It wasn't crowded when I went but I arrived towards the end of the day.
Fantastic place. the nunnery is next to nan lian gardens and is absolutely beautiful, very calming and contemplative as well as informative with information about different Buddhas etc.

Beautiful place!. After visiting nunneries, pagodas etc. in Vietnam and China, we can easily say that this was the winner!!! Very beautiful and relaxing place, spectacular view and we enjoyed every minute.

Peaceful oasis. The Chi Lin Nunnery is well worth a visit!! If you are looking for a quiet and relaxing day out then this is the prefect place. Also go to the nunnery if you are interested in old Chinese architecture and of course religion.

An oasis of beauty and tranquility in Kowloon.. The "Chi Lin Nunnery" is a large Buddhist temple complex located in Diamond Hill, Kowloon, Hong Kong founded in 1934. It was rebuilt in the 1990's following the style of Tang Dynasty traditional Chinese architecture. The present-day buildings are wood frame buildings built without the use of any iron nails. This construction is based on traditional Chinese architectural techniques dating from the Tang Dynasty that uses special interlocking systems cut into the wood to hold them in place. The Chi Lin Nunnery buildings are the only buildings to be built in this style in modern day Hong Kong.Within the grounds of the temple are beautiful Lotus Pools with dragon head fountains, immaculately trimmed tress and shrubs and the contrasting views against the backdrop on Kowloon tower blocks is awesome.There is a bridge / walkway that goes from the Chi Lin Temple Lotus Pools to the 'Nan Lian Garden' which is also worth a walk around as it's another special place of tranquillity.
nice place. You'll come from the garden directly to the nunnery. The temple there is not to big, but in a good shape. A Little garden with Ponds is inside.

The best Chinese tranditional wooden architecture. Chi Lin Nunnery established in 1934 and renovated in Tang dynasty style (AD 618–907) in 1990, the Chi Lin Nunnery is a large temple complex of elegant wooden architecture, treasured Buddhist relics and soul-soothing lotus ponds. The complex also includes a series of temple halls, some of which contain gold, clay and wooden statues representing divinities such as the Sakyamuni Buddha and bodhisattvas.
Calm oasis in the centre of Hong Kong. Beautiful setting and building. Well worth a visit once you have finished pounding the pavements of Hong Kong to recharge your batteries.
Beautiful!. A very strong spiritual home. Beautiful lotus ponds and intricate shrines. A neat place to walk around in silence and observe.

Amazing. What an amazing place, a real gem in this urban jungle, one of the world's best kept secrets. The calmness and tranquility is surrounded by the towering apartment blocks, almost a contradiction in time and place. The Restaurant is remarkable and the food delicious.

Great opportunity combine with Nan Lian Gardens. The Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens sit together in Kowloon and are both well worth a visit. They are very popular and easily accessible on the metro (Diamond Hill station). It is a chance to combine and ancient temple with a relaxing walk around the gardens

lovely place and great architecture. This is one of the hidden gems off the usual tourist track and displays greatlythe combination of religious and modern urban living - peaceful, quiet templein the midst of skyscrapers.Great photo opportunities!Don't miss the park next to it...

Charming. Beatifull space well maintained and very quiet. Not the easiest place to get to by public transport, but worth it. I used the MTR got off on Diamond Hill sta, nearby is the Nan Lian Garden and the Plaza Hollywood Mall with a great food court, much upscale from McDonalds and Burger King.
well persevered temple . Just went past weekend, and didn't notice Hong Kong has such beautiful temple. If you are into cultural stuff, worth to check it out.

Beautiful garden. A wonderful peaceful garden and oasis in the centre of Hong Kong. We saw the walls and the trees and decided to have a change of plan and spend a little time here. We didn't regret it...
How it should be. If you are more interested in seeing a temple, and learning about some different incarnations of buddha, than being in a crowded temple, this is the stop for you.

Great Contrast. Chi Lin is a garden of serenity and peace in the middle of the concrete jungle. Located right behind a mall in Diamond Hill, it epitomizes a great contrast between bustling economy and a backward lifestyle that can co-exist harmoniously together. With its existence within the central district, locals and visitors find a place to retire or take refuge in search of freedom from stress of city living. Inside is a Buddhist Temple of amazing architectural designs and unbelievable craftsmanship, a beautiful garden with koi fish and lotus ponds. On rare occasion, one can see a monk or nun at the garden. A tourist shop and a restaurant make one's stay more relaxing. The Nunnery is easily accessible, MTR to Diamond Hill then a short walk from the station.

Serene and quiet place in the middle of Hong Kong. Easy to get to, take the MTR to Diamond Hill station and you will find signs to lead you there. Nice and quiet change from the usual hassle in the city.
Relaxing. I always have an impression that hongkong is a very bustling country. So when i went here, i was surprised because it's very peaceful here. The garden is beautiful and worth the visit.

Remarkable!. This is an amazing place. The history there is overwhelming. A kind guard pointed out that a beautiful tree we were admiring is over 3,000 years old. The craftsmanship of the Nunnery alone is worth the trip ... not a nail was used in the construction. Thankful to have this experience.

Beautiful Gardens & Buddhist Temple. In the midst of the hectic pace of Hong Kong are these magnificent gardens and a working Buddhist Temple. You may be lucky to catch sight of one of the nuns or monks.Architecture and construction details of the temples is amazing and well worth a visit for this alone.We were lucky enough to meet one of the garden ambassadors (Gloria) who gaves us a personal tour of the Temple and gardens explaining the significance of the various parts of the Temple and gardens.Easy to get to from anywhere in Hong Kong, take MTR to Diamond Hill and 5 minute walk from there. Allow minimum of 1 hour.Absolutely free and suitable for all ages.

Solemn Temple in the Midst of a Busy City. While the nunnery/temple is located in the outskirts of the main tourist & business district, it is still located in a rather busy area next to a shopping mall, so it was a pleasant surprise to see how quiet and solemn the Chi Lin Nunnery was the morning we were there. Buddhist monks chanting really gives the place a solemn feel. Check out the lotus ponds in the main courtyard as well.

Calm amidst the bustle. It was to sample the vegetarian food in the Nunnery's restaurant that my friend and I ventured to Chi Lin Nunnery.After getting out from the MTR, it is a very short walk to the Nunnery. The place covers both sides of the road and it is beautiful and calm. There is a bonsai garden. Even the tourist shop is calm and gives a less than commercial feeling. There were not a lot of tourists, which makes the enjoyment of the Zen surroundings even better.We headed for the restaurant and since it was lunch time and we did not have a reservation, the wait was about 45 minutes. We took that opportunity to walk around the grounds and visit the koi fishes in the pond. The restaurant has a water wheel next to it and indeed, both picture windows were behind waterfalls, Once seated inside (and be prepared to share the table with other guests), there is a menu for two, specially geared towards the minimum charge required. We opted to upgrade to the next set lunch and turned out there was so much food we had doggie bags. The food is very good and non greasy and for a non-vegetarian, it was a pleasurable experience.I would recommend visiting the Nunnery and a reservation beforehand is recommended for the restaurant.

tranquil and quiet. A great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of the world. Beautiful and serene. The adjoining gardens are beautifully designed to help you to forget that you are in thw middle of the big city

The Perfect Buddhism Experience. This is the perfect place to visit if you want to learn more about Buddhism and the devotion Chinese people have towards it. In fact, 80% of all Chinese believe in Buddhism. Chi Lin is not a tourist attraction and in fact a working Nunnery. There is a building that takes care of children with special needs, the Nunnery and the area in which you will be most interested, the Temple rooms and gardens. Each room is special and features extraordinary Buddha statues. It is quite fascinating. The gardens and Bonsai plants are also very special and you understand the relaxing feeling with water ponds and elaborate Temple colors on the roof. If you want to visit a Daoism Temple, check out Wung Tai Sin Temple (this is a tourist attraction).
Nan Lian Park and Chi Lin Nunnery. Chi Lin Nunnery is next door to Nan Lam Park which was a beautiful, quiet place in the middle of Kowloon. There was also a beautiful lotus garden in the nunnery.

Very tranquill. This place was so clean and peaceful. Great to escape the hustle and bustle for a little while. Its just a shame that there are not any seats anywhere to relax and soak up the atmosphere.

Very peaceful and serene. Like the Nan Lian gardens, this is a little oasis of peace and serenity in the middle of the concrete skyscrapers of HongKong.It has a beautiful collection of bonsai trees surrounding the nunnery and is a great place to escape to from the hustle and bustle of the city. It is easily accessible and is a very short walk from the MTR station.
Peaceful. Temple is far from downtown but you should go there. Some areas you can't take picture. but you would like walking and seeing the temple.
Serene garden worth visiting. Nice garden to spend a morning if you find tracking the nearby 狮子山 too demanding. Nice scenic spot for photos and bird watching amid tall skyline.

Stunning, peaceful and moving. Every time we have visited the Chi Lin Nunnery, I leave with a peaceful feeling and thankful for such beauty. From the entrance to the courtyard and statues, everything looks perfect and is beautifully planned. It is amazing that steps away, there is an expressway and energetic city while in the Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden, it is so quiet and peaceful. I would definitely make sure the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden are both on your itinerary.
Loved Chi Lin. One of the most beautiful buildings and surrounds I've been to anywhere. Make sure you walk all around the grounds and see the scale model architecture pavilion.

Peace and quiet . A real escape from hectic Hong Kong. Having entered - time stops. You do not even hear the street sounds - only peace and quiet. Several ponds, trees inside the territory together. Standing near one can experience a remarkable view of the Nunnery at a megapolis city scape - something very unusual and thus precious!

Juxtaposition. How else can you define it? it’s a juxtaposition with being located right in the center of a busy metropolitan city. Its like the world outside and inside the walls are completely different. The nunnery provides a completely different ambiance and one of serene and calm. The gardens are a treat to the eyes and mind. So many beautiful foliage family and spaces around for a good and pleasant stroll experience.
Peace and Tranquillity in Hong Kong. As soon as you walk through the gates the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong is left behind and a peaceful aura takes over.

Worth a visit. We were glad we made the short trip out of Central Hong Kong to visit. The nunnery was empty when we visited, it was a welcome break from the usual crowds at some of the other sites. The nunnery and gardens opposite took us about an hour to look around. This was one of our favourite trips and it was free!

Peaceful and Beautiful. I am so glad that I went here. It is a moment to breathe and experience the serenity and peacefulness of the place. Many people I met in HK have not been here but it was a first stop for me and the second was the gardens. Beautiful - take the time and visit. You will be rewarded for your effort.

A Hidden Gem in the heart of the city!. This is something we missed in previous visits to this dynamic and diversified city! A hidden oasis of quiet and calm and beauty right in the heart of bustling Hong Kong! Easily accessible by Metro, and one leaves with a sense of peace after strolling through this delightful and well done set,of,gardens. A tearoom available for those seeking a break is an added plus. Add this atop to your itinerary when visiting.

Nice stroll around the gardens and nunnery. The Chi Lin Nunnery is an oasis of peace in the busy Hong Kong city and we really enjoyed a nice afternoon stroll around the Nunnery and Gardens one Sunday, It was also not too busy which is nice.A good area to explore but not a must see on a short stay in HK!

A beautiful spiritual place of calm. On a personal note there was nothing that I disliked of the nunnery. The gardens are sympathetically maintained. The whole experience is one of tranquility and intrigue - there are certain aspects of the whole site that I'm still mulling over a week later. It lends itself to serenity and courtesy. We enjoyed the restaurant which is strictly veggie but made the mistake of adding dim sum to the set meal. I say mistake as, although the dim sum was delicious, the set meal was more than enough.
Amazing recreation. The weather was perfect when we visited but these gardens are a highlight of any trip.Go when the sun is setting and just enjoy the beauty.

An Oasis in the city. We spent a couple of hours wandering through the temples and gardens. It's hard to believe this is just a short walk from the metro station. It's calm and peaceful, the temples are beautiful.

An island of serenity in Hong Kong. Such a peaceful place to visit. The gardens, grounds and buildings are meticulously maintained. We visited on a Tuesday morning and hardly any other tourists were there.
Well worth a visit. An oasis of calm and beauty amid the noise & bustle of Kowloon. Take time to also visit the neighbouring Nan Lian Garden.
Truly worth a visit. One of the highlights of Hon kong. Despite the traffic around an oasis of peace. Just go slowly around and soak up the atmosphere Close to MRT.
oasis in urban area. Beautiful gardens and buildings, very tranquil given it is in Diamond Hill and very close to the MTR, There is also a vegetarian restaurant.

Refreshing!. A short climb up some stairs at the back of the beautiful gardens and you will come upon the peaceful nunnery. Beautiful koi ponds beckon you towards the nunnery towards the shrines that encompass three sides of the compound. Serenity abouts in this beautiful respite from the hustle and bustle of life that exists in Kowloon/Hong Kong.

A Gem in the heart of Hong Kong!. After reading the reviews on here and only having a few hours left to spend in Hong Kong, I decided that I wanted to see something else then tall buildings and concrete while in the city and this place had exactly what I was looking for!The feeling you get while walking though the fist "door/archway" is unbelievable as this place is not buzzing with hundreds of people and as it is so quiet and peaceful. The fact that these little shrines still are part of the Hong Kong way of life is fascinating and amazing to me. This is the kind of place you expect to see in Kyoto Japan, not in the middle of this vibrant city.The other very cool thing about it is that it is completely free to roam around this little oasis. The colors and the banzai trees all over make you feel so relax and a ease with yourself. The one strange thing is the very tall buildings in the background in some of my pictures. They gave you such a unique look and broad perspective on how different the two architectural designs are.This is definitely a must see while in Hong Kong if you ask me as it will take you away from the hectic and vibrant lifestyle that Hong Kong as to offer...

Peace of Mind within the City. An amazingly peaceful Zen garden right in the middle of the city. Once inside, you become oblivious to the sounds of traffic. A short walk from the MTR it is a visit worth your time. Artificial waterfalls, watermill, steam rocks and manicured bonsai trees decorate the place.The shrine itself is beautiful with the idols of different gods, goddesses larger than life mythological legends add to the spiritual presence of this place. The idols themselves were so mesmerizing that you tend to lose yourself watching them with reverence. To add to the sublime beauty of the place, we were blessed with showers (we visited in July) that gave the whole place a different aura.
Beautiful place. A must-see place in HK. This Chinese classical garden amazed me. The landscape was beautifully created and everything was well maintained.

Nice place for pictures . There have been only tourists and some guards. No nuns or monks. The garden is nice, the monastery looks great and good panorama pictures can be taken. Free entrance to the park and monastery. But the vegetarian restaurant and the tea house (cheapest tee 6g 180hkd) are expensive. We didn't go there.

Worth A Visit. This nunnery is very much worth a visit whilst in Hong Kong.The gardens are beautifully planned and are so tranquil and serene. The temples architecture and the Buddhist shrines are a work of art. A peaceful escape from the busy city.

A well designed garden. A well designed garden and ponds, have many kinds of "guardians" displays but not allow to take photo of it. Overall, I enjoyed it the garden as it is peaceful and beautiful just looking at the garden. It overlooked the suburbs and with a clear sky, you might think you are away from the city.

Authentic and serene. FREE. Lovely Buddha statues, serene, calm and peaceful. Well maintained gardens, loved it, great way to spend an hour or two just chilling. not something one could experience in London!!!

Peaceful and beautiful. Easy to find, easy to get to, this is a lovely oasis in the city. There were barely any other visitors when we went and it was great to be able to wander and sit away from crowds.

Imposing, worth a visit. Very tranquil atmosphere around buildings with several beautiful Buddist small temples within the complex as well as the main one. Heard the monks chanting (could have been a recording) which added to the atmosphere. Central gardens, beautifully maintained & everything spotless. Lovely examples of large bonsai & interesting trees & bougainvillea pruned in the cloud formation which the Chinese do so well. Go there at about 10.00 a.m. Before the crowds arrive. Most enjoyable.
Worth a visit. Worth a visit at same time as Nan Lian garden next door. Very peaceful and some amazing bonsai trees

Don't Miss the Nan Lian Gardens. The Nunnery is a delight but if you do go you mustn't miss the Nan Lian Gardens located across the road. It is absolutely stunning and makes for a wonderful break from the intensity of Hong Kong.
Peaceful. Large and so peaceful. Not so many people, but enough to buzz the air into a worshipping ambience. Garden is nice and lotus flower blooming. Nice place to shoot beautiful photos.

Stunning Architecture. My wife and I spent the morning between here and the Nan Lin Gardens next door. Chi Lin is a Buddhist Nunnery and as such is very peaceful and tranquil, a perfect place to spend a few relaxing hours. Photography is permitted in the Courtyard but not in any of the Temples. Chi Lin, although very modern, it was only completed in 2006, is built in the Tang Dynasty style. Of interest no nails were used throughout its construction. Chi Lin is now on the 'Tentative List' of China's World Heritage sites. Highly Recommend.
Nice to see. A quite nice place to see. Silent, clean and full of photopossibilities.The employees are very descent but cear professional for the sight.
New but Beautiful. Easy to access on the metro. A new temple but still very beautiful. Gardens are some of the best I have seen

You do not have to be Buddhist to take this all in. Attached to the Nan Lian Gardens the Nin Chin Nunnery and the Lotus Garden is just magnificent. Do take note of the signs requesting no photography of the Alters and Shrines within the Temple and read the stories attached to each of the alters. Marvel at the majestic golden Buddha statues located around the Temple.If you are in need of a break away from the busy cities of Hong Kong then here is where you will get it. A short ride on the MTR and just a stroll across the road from the station and you will enter the Nan Lian Gardens, follow the paths around to the Nin Chin Nunnery.

Pretty, but connecting Nan Lian Garden under construction. Pretty and peaceful nunnery with lots to look at. This type of architecture is what you think of when you think "China." You are allowed to take pictures of the facility, but not of the worshippers. The Nan Lian Gardens connected to the nunnery were under construction as of 10/29/14 and you can't see the pogada or water feature surrounding it, which you've probably seen in the pictures. That said, this will likely take you less than an hour to visit, and then you can head on the MTR one stop to see Sik Sik Yuen Wong Tai Sin Temple.

Stunning. Even though it was raining when we visited I thought the garden and nunnery were beautiful. Although comparatively small that was lots to look at and the place was serene and calming. Even my 13 year old boy seemed to enjoy wandering around. Would highly recommend.

Interesting insight into another world. This Buddhist Nunnery is located adjacent to the Nan Lian Garden. It is a quite authentic reconstruction of a Tang-dynasty monastery, intricately built completely of wood, using no nails, and is said to be the largest cluster of handcrafted timber buildings in the world. It is a serene complex with worshipers coming to offer prayers and tributes to the various Celestial kings and gods, each housed in their own room, surrounded by lotus ponds. You enter through the three gates of Buddhist belief, finally arriving at the statue of the Sakyamuni Buddha. Nuns go about their duties in prayer and silence – it is a place of quiet meditation. Near Diamond Hill MTR, admission free.

Fabulous. Totally worth the visit combined with the gardens across the street. Massive stone paving and railings around serene ponds and precisely pruned trees. Lovely juxtaposition between modern and ancient China. Huge Plumaria tree just outside as well. Easy to get to as it is just around the corner from the Metro.

Attention to detail. Right next door to nan lian garden and wel worth the visit. A great place to spend a few hrs, the workmanship in buildings and features are divine. A real tranquility in Hong kong.

Beautiful!!!!. *) http://www.chilin.org/*) Opening Hours: 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM Daily*) Nearest MTR Station: Diamond Hill MTR Station Exit C2 so that you land directly in front of the Hollywood Plaza Mall. From there follow the directions to Nan Lian Gardens. The gardens are about 100meters away. There is no entrance fee. The visit will take you about 2 hours, including the Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens, technically another attraction, by a bridge. Both can be visited without ever coming on the road.*) As with other Buddhist Worship places, photography is not allowed in the Prayer Halls. In the rest of the area you can take pictures.*) As far as I can say, Chi Lin Nunnery does not have any eateries. Its the Nan Lian Gardens that has a full-fledged restaurant and another snack place. *) A lot of wooden artifacts and beautiful ponds with flowers and lots of bonsai trees. The whole architecture is magnificient.*) The nunnery is an amazing replica of a Tang dynasty Bhuddist nunnery and is built totally from hardwoods using no nails or glues only joints in the timber. For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://hongkongandmacauitinerary.blogspot.in/2014/10/hong-kong-macau-itinerary.html
Beautiful. Quiet and beautiful architecture and construction. Easy to get to and still in use by prayerful members.

Peaceful and beautiful. If you did a bit of research before reading this, you of course already know that the nunnery is built without a single iron nail (don’t ask me how =). It’s a fabulous place, peaceful and truly beautiful, with incredible masterpieces of traditional Chinese architecture (and I am not speaking about numerous skyscrapers around!) and lotuses in the little ponds nearby.Don’t miss out on a leisure stroll around Nan Lian Garden nearby!

Respite from the city. This was a pleasant respite from Nathan Road. Gardens and buildings are beautifully maintained. My visit was during Chinese New Year and all visitors were given the traditional gift of red envelopes containing a coin. Combine with a visit to the Nan Lian Gardens next door. Easily reached by MTR.

Peaceful and beautiful. Very easy to get to via the MTR and a short walk. A great place to go for a break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Combine with the Nan Lian Garden next door for an afternoon.
calm and beautiful. Very lovely place and there is no admission fee. Good to get some peace and quiet in hectic Hong Kong. Tube takes you all the way there, you need to exit at Diamond Hill Station.
Not as wowed as I thought I'd be. Not sure why but I was not wowed. I expected the food to be tastier - I love vegetables but the food was too bland for my taste.
Very interesting. Well set out and photogenic. Set in a lovely garden area with sculptured trees and rocks, lakes and goldfish. Also had eating facilities.

Great setting!. We weren't sure about visiting the nunnery but turned out to be a great choice. The nunnery itself is beautiful and the setting in the middle of the city makes it really unusual. Try to fit this in on your trip!

Time well-spent in HK. If you have an affinity for peace and tranquility in the midst of a bustling international city like HK, then you will probably love this place. We certainly did and I would recommend it to anyone visiting Hong Kong. This is a very lovely place to spend a few hours, particularly if you´re wanting a respite from the big urban setting. The grounds and various temples are immaculate and beautifully looked after. Recommended unreservedly!

Not sure what the fuss is about. Certainly a nice quiet spot in the midst of the city, but see s over-hyped to me. There are a couple of. Ice courtyards and some interesting shrines, but overall a bit dull. Check out the Nan Lian garden across the street instead - we enjoyed it more.

Beautiful, peaceful, magnetic place. Nestled right in the middle of the city, the Chi Lin Nunnery is peaceful, enchanting and surrounded by a beautiful garden. It's a quite place where you can spend hours just sitting on the steps or strolling in the garden. Do step in to the pottery museum if that interests you.

ZEN. As of october 5 , 2014 there is an ongoing renovation on the zen garden right next to chi lin nunnery. The nunnery is open until 5pm only so try to be there earlier. I think you can take great pictures during early mornings and late afternoons when the sun is not so bright.The place is a complete zen, you are lucky if there are only a few tourist, you will better enjoy the scenery and the serenity this place emits. This is a must see in hongkong a breakaway from the bustling noice of the city.

Peaceful Oasis. I love the serenity in the middle of crazy Hong Kong, in conjunction with Nan Lian Garden it is a truly peaceful calming way to spend a couple of hours & to learn more about Buddhism & appreciate it. Super Easy to get to, Diamond Hill is the MTR

Impressive. Being the largest nunnery in the region, the Chi Lin nunnery is a very impressive structure. Then when told that it was rebuilt without a single nail you appreciate the architecture even more. It is a tranquil place of worship with several statues dotted around the sides and ponds in the centre. Definitely worth a trip. After this do visit the Wing Tai Sin temple which is a 10 mins walk away to appreciate the contrast between the two places of worship.
Peace and serenity. We came here after walking around Nan Lian Garden. The two go hand in hand. It is beautiful and the grounds are well maintained. It is very peaceful. Well worth the visit.
Peaceful and interesting. This adjoins the Nan Lian Garden, and was quiet and interesting, with beautiful woodwork and temples.

Disappointed. I went to the nunnery as it had such good reviews; perhaps it was because of my high expectations that I was disappointed. It is always interesting to see a place like this amidst the high rises, but there are better examples.

MUST visit!!!. The place is so quite and peaceful. I like it that it's so contrast with other busy area of Hong Kong. I could see the skyscrapers surrounding the place from inside. I do like the city but short escape to Chilin nunnery is also a good experience. It it the place any traveler shouldn't miss. Love it. PS. However, it's more like Japanese style rather than traditional Chinese style.
Great spot to visit. It is a great place to visit in such a crowded and rush city. It can make me feel calm among the high buildings.

Beautiful but no English guides. The Nunnery was beautiful and just being there felt peaceful. It however lacked some English speaking guides or information personnel that could offer some more insight to the place and we relied on the written boards to give us more information. It was well kept, clean and presentable and very much worth a visit.

peace amid a bustling city. it takes less than an hour to tour this abode of peace. the Nunnery is right next to a MTR station (Diamond Hill) and opens early. The souvenir shop is on the expensive side but even for people, who are not rigidly religious, the wooden wonder is a must-see. There is no need for a guide. Just follow the instructions and read the descriptions of each areas.We went there early October and spent around 45 minutes. After you finish seeing the Nunnery, just take the over-bridge to Nan Lian garden.

Tranquil oasis in Hong Kong. Sitting beside the Nan Lian Gardens, visiting these 2 sites together provides an opportunity to take time out from the hustle and bustle of Kowloon and Hong Kong in general. The nunnery is beautiful and serene with individual rooms dedicated to some of the gods and goddesses of Buddhism. The gardens are beautifully maintained and the ponds of brightly coloured lilies with many varieties of bonsai trees add to a sense of order. The buildings are beautifully constructed.

Well worth a visit. The nunnery is a quick train ride from the central city and is an oasis of calm. The buildings themselves are a marvel. In the park across the road is a small pavilion which has models of the nunnery and other well known building in this style. What I had not realised is that all of the buildings are effectively slotted together, no nails or bolts involved. I should have started with this exhibition before visiting the nunnery so as to better appreciate the building effort required. The gardens are all well manicured and the interiors are quite breathtaking. In addition the place was relatively deserted by Hong Kong standards so a nice place to go and enjoy some calm

Highly recommended a must!. It's so peaceful you wouldn't believe that the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong is just outside. I was really surprised that is was so quiet with next to no one walking around. It is well maintained with ground keepers at every turn. The garden, rooms and ponds well presented with scented sticks filling the air.

Great half day trip from Central HK. Easy to access from Central via MTR (Diamond Hill Exit) - about 30 minute journeyI had planned to visit the Nan Lian Gardens and the Nunnery since they are next door to each other. Unfortunately the Nan Lian Gardens were under renovation (Oct 2014) and a disappointment. However, the nunnery more than made up for that disappointment.Beautiful architecture and grounds. Cool setting against the wooded hills and surrounded by the ubiquitous HK apartment towers. A great escape from the bustle of Central and an easy 1/2 day trip.

Stunning and Peaceful. Coupled with the Nan Lian Gardens, a great way to spend a morning outside of the general pace of Hong Kong. Beautiful lotus ponds, quiet central grounds, and elaborate rooms with many Buddhas with well-written and instructive explanations.
Great place to visit. Relaxing location to visit. I like the Landscape and the architectural of the location.
Surprising!. An unexpected tranquil oasis in the city, and a treat to stroll through the peaceful garden, followed by a tasty and inventive vegetarian 'feast' in the restaurant. Highly recommended.

Peacefull. At a friends suggestion we made it up to Diamond Hill where close to the metro stop we visited this place, the nan lian garden and the vegetarian restaurant making this a very enjoyable visit. The nunnery is a large buddhist complex with towering hi rise buildings in the background giving it quite the contrast. ..its clean,quiet, almost solemn and nice architecture....one gets a sense of true harmony here.Make this a stop while you visit hong kong along with the other two places noted above...its a very nice and refreshing change from the rest of the city.
Peaceful. Definitely worth a visit, so peaceful and beautiful. Nan Lian Garden and Hollywood Plaza Shopping Centre are in the same vicinity so it's worth the trip.
Stunning!. Great architectural with stunning surrounding skyline view! It can be very hot there so do wear sunscreen, sunglasses and bring along umbrella!

Beautiful craftsmanship. This is a new building built in an old style. Don't expect a rustic patina. That said, it is lovingly built. At the time of the visit, the place had a handful of devotees and only a couple of us sightseers. Its exudes peace and harmony, especially in contrast to the bustle and colour of nearby Wong Tai Sin temple.
fusion vegetarian. after visiting the nice garden and having a creative vegetarian food there. however, it is hard to book a table
A photographer's dream. If you're into taking snaps, don't miss this chance to get some stunning pictures of the beautiful architecture set against the Hong Kong skyline backdrop.
Don't miss this. Memorable architecture, stunning gardens and water features and great sense of calm in the middle of a bustling city.

Find your inner zen. A delightfully ornate and well manicured respite from the hustles and bustle of Hong Kong. Soak up the rich cultural heritage and buddhist temples and walk around the scenic gardens before heading back down to the hustle and bustle of Kowloon.

Ancient and peaceful. The Chi Lin Nunnery is still relatively unspoilt,and still a working Nunnery doing what it always has-helping those in need.A beautiful,peaceful group of buildings,with some of the biggest and best Bonsai trees we've ever seen in the courtyards and surrounds.You really can feel the spirituality in the air here.Excellent gift shop too with some stunning quality artefacts;not cheap,but all going towards a very good cause..The extensive public gardens on the other side of the road shouldn't be missed either.Currently partly under renovation but well worth a look on the way back to the metro station.

An oasis of calm. Easy access from Diamond Hill MTR, this site and the surrounding park includes a number of temples and provides a welcome oasis of calmness and serenity. Free to get in. Some areas are shut off and limited to the live-in monks. Photography of temple interirors is restricted. Souvenir shop and vegetarian restaurant are available.Well worth a visit. Also handy for some retail therapy at the nearby Plaza Hollywood mall.

A serene place surrounded by tall buildings. This is a perfect place to escape the busy streets of Kowloon. Adjacent to Nan Lian Garden, I was surprised to find this place empty. If you only have few hours to spare for sightseeing, don't miss this place.

Pleasant surprise. An oasis in an otherwise frantic city. Nice gardens and ponds. Interesting museum displays and a gift shop that was quite appealing. I didn't expect to like the place, but it was well worrth the trip.
Elegant . The landscape is so elegant and gives a calming effect. The tall buildings on the background contrasting the area make it more interesting. A must visit!

Peaceful. This is the most light and peaceful place in the city, full of peace and spirituality. Beautiful architecture and the lack of tourists - particularly striking in such a crowded city. We spent wonderful hours in meditation and contemplation courtyard.

Peach and Elegant. This is like a heaven in a busy city. Hong Kong is always busy and when we first step in to this place, everything is so calm and quiet. You can feel the energy inside it. The air is fresh. The day i went was rainy, however it does not spoil our mood.

A Peaceful Refuge. The juxtaposition of the ancient architecture against the modern city back drop is brilliant and makes for great photo opps. I went on a weekday afternoon and literally had the place to myself. I think this contributed to how much I liked it because I can't imagine how it would be if it were packed with tourists. There's a vegetarian restaurant on the premises that's worth a stop. I tried few different dishes and all were good. Mushrooms are the star of the show there so if you're not a fan you probably won't appreciate it as much.
peaceful, quiet gardens. Love the tranquility of the environment and the beautiful scenery all around. A good escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.
Must see in HK. Located directly at Diamond Hill MRT it's a great architcetural and spiritual treasure. You should not miss to visit it.

worth a visit. One of the best places to visit in Hong Kong.Take your time to wander around.Interesting backdrop of skyscrapers by way of contrast to the building. Easy walk from Diamond Hill train station.

The most tranquil place in Hong Kong. It is the most peaceful and quiet place in Hong Kong. Beautiful buildings surrounded by tall communal housing - quite a contrast! It is worth a visit - any time of a day and year. Opposite there is a beautiful garden with a vegetarian restaurant (you will be amazed what they serve there), cafe and souvenir shop.

Beautiful places. The best place to contemplate and rest. In this place live is not to fast like HG. Beautiful perspective and building. Silent in big city. Minus the most important building is closed for the people. But if you have time. Go there.

Feeling peaceful in HK. This is one of the place where you can escape from a full pack of HK crowd. This is where no people rushing and hitting you on your leisure day. Especially, there is no smell of cigarette. Hoorayy!! The place itself is amazingly beautiful. Even though I went there in a hot and humid summer, it's still cooling by the wind as the place constructed and situated in the perfect spot where it allowed wind to flow through.

Special Place. It was located at the residential area in hong kong. A peaceful place with statue of several chinese deity. The construction and design of the nunnery is also v beautiful. Took a stroll at nearby park with do take note the some part of the park is under renovation.

Have a rest before start running again. You can perseive the quiet after you enter this place. The inner garden with waterlillies and bonsais let you start again to breath. It is a strange paradox this relaxing place just next to a mall. This increase more and more this extraordinary sense of peace. The statues and temples are japaneese style. A must see in HK if you would like to know other then the business life.

Wonderful Bonsai and Easily Accessible. This lovely garden is just outside the Diamond Hill mall, which makes it super easy to get to by subway (just get off at Diamond Hill). Beautiful gardens, featuring lots of bonsai, and cute buildings, with a koi pond and some nice exhibits, explaining things such as architecture of the buildings, viewing stones, and bonsai. Also it's free!

Serene & Nice. it's a beautiful scenery in a bustling town like HK.
to bad we can't take photos at the inner most of the nunnery.
For those that like garden, greenery, Buddha statues, and bonsai this is a great place!

Relax in the middle of a bustling city. I was completely surprised at how relaxing stepping inside the nunnery would be. I wanted to visit the picturesque tourist site for some great photos, but I ended up experiencing something on a completely different level. How lucky HK is to have this oasis in the middle of a busy city!

Absolutely loved our visit here!. If you love peace, beauty, and gardens, and need respite from the craziness of Hong Kong, this is the place to come. We'll be back, hopefully on a sunny day next time - but bring an umbrella just in case!

An oasis of calm. What a delight. This is a real find in the heart of a metropolis. It is so calming and soothing. But that is probably the nature of the Nunnery itself. This is a Buddhist temple that is not that old but is truly magnificent. The gardens across the road are serene as the temple and offer a great respite from the tempo and pace of Hong Kong. We loved it and will be back when we return to Hong Kong.
