Lovely and peaceful. The Chi Lin Nunnery is lovely and peaceful. The buildings are wood-frame and constructed without iron nails. The buildings here are the only buildings in Hong Kong to be constructed in this way. As you stand at the temple and gardens, in the background you will see high-rise, modern buildings - so quite a juxtaposition.I don't know that this is a "must-see", but it is beautiful and serene.

Beautiful oasis in the city. My wife and I really enjoyed our visit to the Chi Lin Monastery. The beauty and tranquility of this site is much more impactful in real life vs. what you see in pictures. There was a lite mist / rain the day we went which added to the atmosphere and may have kept the crowds at bay as it was relatively empty. One minor disappointment was that the main red bridge and adjoining temple / pagoda that you see in pictures is currently under construction (until 2015 I believe) and for that reason is covered. There is still plenty to see however I really would love to have seen that key element of the nunnery.I also wished there had been some sort of interactive display at the start to provide some context to the history of the nunnery. The facility is free of charge and my expectations are therefore adjusted accordingly and stands on it's own based on sheer beauty, but I would have loved more context on the history.Overall, it was a great visit. Lastly, I think it would be amazing to be there at dusk when the lights go on...

Immerse in Chinese culture in the middle of the city. Off the beaten path for most Hong Kong tourists, the Chi Lin Nunnery offers a different glimpse of the city.Despite being a very modern and heavily Western influenced city, Hong Kong remains to have Eastern roots.Visited Chi Lin Nunnery early morning as was lucky to be there for the opening of the gates where I heard the nuns doing their morning prayers in front of the statues and Buddhist gods.

Don't miss. So serene, well maintained , free, peaceful. Don't miss this experience, cab ride probably easiest way to get there. Didn't eat at the cafe although it looked interesting, a bit too pricey

Tranquil oasis with unique fusion of the ancient and modern. I was blown away with the views of the nunnery set with the skylines of the buildings! Such an interesting fusion which yet gels together without any conflict. Wonderful place for photo taking without the usual hustle bustle crowd in the other more famous but typical attractions in HK. Nearby Nan Lian Garden is also another great place to chill out.

Peace away from the concrete jungle. It was such a beautiful escape from the concrete jungle we live in. It's a nice getaway from the hustle and bustle of HK. Serene and calm surroundings. Don't forget to make a reservation at their Buddhist vegetarian restaurant. I'm not a fan of vegetarian food but this was truly astounding.
Beautiful and quiet. An incredible garden in the middle of the city. A must-go! The gardens are breath-taking. Can spend as long or as short of a time as you'd like. Easy to get to.

Calm and peaceful. Lovely beautiful place, the architecture is amazing and it is so peaceful! The shrines are great and even if you are or aren't religious they are well worth a look! it was nice to get out of the busy city and really relax and learn about the religion! Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful. Fantastic place to come to in diamond hill.
We really enjoyed this place and it's heritage. There are a few no photography signs around which need to be respected. Not overrun with tourists, very calm and quiet
Nice and calm place. Nice and calm place in the middle of the city with high building. Great architecture and good place to take a few hours from the busy city.
Worth the trek. Beautiful, peaceful spot. The Buddhist shrines are great, but don't miss the lily ponds or the Rockery.

Beautiful architecture. Very peaceful place with beautiful architecture. The staff at the nunnery took very good care keeping every on this place perfect and in order.
Throughly enjoyed it to have some peace from the busy street.

Absolute Serenity in the City. The Chi Lin Nunnery is one of the most beautiful settings I have ever been so blessed to witness. It is so peaceful and is well worth the visit. Stroll through the gardens, contemplate by the magnificent koi pond, our luncheon behind a waterfall. The building is stunning and is in complete contrast to the busy city which surrounds it. This visit requires a good few hours to truly appreciate its beauty.
Great place. This was one of the best Buddhist temples I've seen. A must see for all travelers. Very wel maintained with beautiful plants/trees.

A place to peace your mind. It is a wonderful Japanese style nunnery with awesome wooden structure and lotus pond. It gives anyone that enters a peaceful feel of mind. It is also a perfect spot to play all sorts of photography tricks with your camera.
A bit out of the way. It's a little off the beaten track bit still good for a visit. Interesting place where one can enjoy some quiet. take pictures too

Don't miss it. Probably the most peaceful and beautiful place in Hong Kong and well worth a visit. It is located under a ring road and you'll almost think you are in the wrong place but stick with it. There is a great restaurant as well.

Zen Gem in Urban Jungle. One can not miss this together with Nan Lian Garden. Both are quiet havens surrounded by natural beauty and calm. Lovely place to visit for a morning or afternoon of quiet reflection.

Nice place of ease within a bustling city. It's a nice place to visit. Once inside the walls of the nunnery there is a full sense of ease. You can escape the business of the huge city that Hong Kong is. Even if you are not into Budhism this should be on the to-do list for HK.

serene and zen. they said there was no greenery in Hong Kong come here and tell them you found a place where there is a lot of green in the city. the temple has two sections. visit them both. very zen very serene

One of my favourite places in Hong Kong. Head out to Diamond Hill on the MTR and head across the road to the Nan Lian Gardens and the Chi Lin Nunnery. Have lunch at the vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall. It's a sanctuary away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

Pleasant day in the park.. It is a peaceful place to wander around. There is also a vegetarian restaurant on site. Amusingly, there are numerous condo skyscrapers not too far away. By the way, it's a Buddhist nunnery/monastery...some sections are closed off either due to restricted religious access or due to construction and repair.

Let down by the workers. We loved this place, a 100% place of tranquility in amongst the hustle bustle and high rises of Hong Kong. There are great plaques giving you information on the Nunnery and the architectural style is unsurpassed. However, during our visit there was a break coming up to allow for prayers. We thought this even better as it meant it was clearly still in use. However, instead of allowing us to slowly move away following acknowledgement that prayers were to commence (so not to intrude on the religious activities), instead the local workers felt a better way to shoo a few tourists (no more than 8 of us total) was to shout and start pushing us away using metal fences. Such a good way to ruin the tranquility. A massive let down!

Peaceful, quiet and an oasis of calm. The Nunnery is set amongst blocks of high rise living flats but sits in an oasis of calm and tranquility. The main worshipping areas are inside a solid wood structure in traditional Chinese style of building with nice gardens surrounding .The gardens are well laid out with large bonsai and beautiful green trees.The Buddha's have plaques explaining their provenance and telling you a bit more about their role and place.Overall a very peaceful, relaxing place to visit and escape the hustle and bustle of the busy city.

A Hong Kong Oasis. East to get to on the MTR System,and suggest you walk through the Plaza Hollywood Shopping Mall and its directly opposite.The gardens and Nunnery are well maintained,and it makes for a very pleasant stroll around the Lake.Plenty of places to sit and take-in the surroundings,its hard to believe you are in HK.There was quite a lot of restoration work being carried out on my visit and some areas were not accessable,but it made for a welcome break from the bustle of the City

Peaceful and beautiful. The whole place is a Buddhist worship area and you have to keep it in mind while visiting the place. The temple insides are prohibited for cameras but fortunately the gardens are open for photography and it deserves to be with being one of the most beautiful gardens that you will come across in Hong Kong. The place is beautiful and most importantly gives such a peaceful atmosphere. To get there you only have to remember one name Diamond Hill MTR station because that’s where you need to get down to reach the place. From there it is pretty much easy and even at walking distance.

Fantastic Nunnery. This place was my favourite in HK. Wow! Everything was so well maintained, so peaceful. If you happen to spot a nun you'll understand what it means to be at peace with yourself. The place was big and airy and so even though the day was hot the nunnery itself was very cool. You can't take pictures inside which is fine, but you also can't buy picture post cards of the insides. I'd have liked to have had some to show people how wonderful a place this is. Don't forget to cross the road and visit the gardens next door. They are equally as beautiful
Simply Beautiful. I know little about Buddhist culture, however this modern creation of gardens and temples is beautiful. Definitely a must-see for a Westerner visiting Hong Kong.

Tranquility amongst the chaos. No time to read a long review? Let me help you: Go here. Do this.The Chi Lin Nunnery is an oasis of peace set amidst the wonderful chaos of Hong Kong. The gardens are well thought out with enough simple and tasteful displays of information to while away a couple of hours. The nunnery is also "broken up" so that at each door you go through it's like going into a different exhibit. Walk up the road from Diamond Hill MTR and look for the signs.
Piece and tranquillity. Visit to Chi Lin Nunnery gives a soothing effect to mind. Its so calm, quite and natural that you feel amazing. Its in walking distance from Diamond Hill MTR station's exit C.

Very pretty. This quiet nunnery is one stop away from the famous Wong Tai Sin temple, and I suspect gets forgotten about as tourists reach Wong Tai Sin and don't go any further.It is very pretty and very quiet, and has a bridge which connects to the magnificent park on the opposite side of the road. Housing over 200 Koi Carps, the Park is a must see place.

beautiful. couple of minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR. Such a beautiful and tranquil place, gorgeous gardens. Well worth a visit. I spent an hour walking around and then the heat got to be too much.

Calm place in busy HK. Breathtaking place to visit, an oasis of calm in one of the busiest cities I have visited. Easy to reach, just 5 minutes from the MTR, close to a shopping plaza for air con and a great lunch.
average. We were a bit surprised to see this was rated so high on TA - it is architecturally nice, but deserving of a 5 rating.

Beautiful spot for a brief visit. This is a very well-kept and well-presented Buddhist temple. The gardens and grounds are beautiful, and the courtyards are redolent with incense and the chanting of the nuns. Each temple shows statues and shrines for one or more gods, the Buddha, and bodhisattvas. Brief signs explain each one in Chinese and English. The complex is not large, so unless you want to sit and contemplate the atmosphere (there are kneelers at the temples but no benches anywhere), it's only half an hour to slowly walk around and absorb it all.The gift shop is above average (and mercifully out of the way), and there are public toilets. The Diamond Hill MTR stop is four minutes away, and the signs are pretty clear. Cross Fun Tak road on a crosswalk to footbridge to reach the temples. Unlike some other temples in Asia, this one does not require modest dress to enter. But I would recommend following the same rules. Show some respect.

An oasis in the middle of skyscrappers. We had a short transit in HK and Chi Lin Nunnery was our main destination in this short transit. It was a nice stroll in the park/nunnery. It was busy but not to a point where you can't walk. And definitely it is a nice oasis in the middle of concrete high skyscrappers.

Very serene and worth a visit. Very serene and relaxing place. Recordings of the monks chanting softly are piped in throughout the two large buildings. Built around large open courtyards with several small pools containing various water flowers and potted bonsai trees, etc. Impressive Buddhas. We went early (and it was raining) so we were among the few people present. Very nice oasis of quiet in the clamor and crowds of HK.

Clean and Serene. A little touch of serenity surrounded by HK's bustling city/ high rise. Prayer chanting could be heard from the nuns. Walking into the compound you can feel time wash away, you can see the loving care given to the ponds, the toporised shrubbery and the buildings. WOW what a place to visit.

Good place to go to relax. I decided to come here after a couple of days of trying to navigate through the hectic streets of Hong Kong and needing some quiet time. It was definitely easy to get here and the attractions were really cool. The only reason why I didn't give it a high score was because there wasn't anything amazing that you haven't seen before; however, if you need to get away from the busy life and have a couple of hours to spare, I would recommend coming here.Make sure to follow the path the whole way!
Very spiritual. This was an amazing building, when you think that it was built entirely of wood, and not a nail in sight !The buddha's are magnificent, glad I made the visit, well worth it.

Much more than we expected. We weren't sure what to expect before we visited Chi Lin, as it's completely surrounded by a modern neighborhood, but we were pleasantly surprised! The courtyard is beautiful and there are a number of active Buddhist shrines within. Highly recommended to those interested in history or religion.
Another peaceful place to get away from the noise. The nunnery adjoins the Nan Lian garden and is also immaculately kept. Worth the visit, just to see the bonsai and lily ponds.

Must see. Beautiful place with such a spiritual feel in such a hectic city...the restaurant under the waterfall offers excellent food and is genuinely a very beautiful place to see....do not leave HK without visiting.

So peaceful!. A must to visit if you are in HK, what a beautiful and tranquil place. Surrounded by apartment/office blocks you wouldn't think this to be a peaceful place but it is surprisingly beautiful, stunning and quiet all at the same time. A real treasure to visit.
Lovely Temple and grounds. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and follow the signs. Check out the Gardens then walk over to the Nunnery. Beautiful grounds, worth a look.

Don't miss this place.. I've been to Hong kong several times and not once have i been here. This time I went and there are no regrets at all! I simply love this place its an amazing contrast to what hong kong is and yet so peaceful and tranquil.See my blog on more details of Chi lin and Hong Kong :http://airydreamer.wordpress.com/category/hong-kong/The architecture is amazing and the gardens are soul-soothing. The nearby Nan Lian gardens are very beautiful so if you're new to Asia and would like to check out something about more like traditional and beautiful don't give this place a miss.I highly recommend it this and i've been to hong kong very often!

a little haven of zen amidst the chaos of HK. I lived in Hong Kong for a while and absolutely loved trekking out to the nunnery. By HK standards, it's a little bit further out than most are willing to venture but it's super convenient given HK's transport system and cheap taxi rates. Definitely worth a visit, as it is a very different experience from the hustle and bustle of the touristy Central or TST. The gardens are beautiful and serene, you feel transported miles away from the crowds in the shopping malls and high rise buildings. There is a gorgeous vegetarian yum cha restaurant under a waterfall which gets very busy but which I would also recommend for visitors. It's such a change from the normal touristy activities in Hong Kong (basically eating and shopping) and you get to see further into the Kowloon side than you usually would on the trip there. Definitely worth a visit! Reminds of Japanese gardens and temples, it's just divine! There is also a cute little souvenir store with lots of very affordable little trinkets and mementos - we loaded up for presents!

Peaceful. The Nunnery and attached Nan Lian Garden were a highlight of a few days in Hong Kong. The Garden is so beautifully planted, and the Nunnery is lovely with some amazing Buddha figures. It's hard to believe that there is this oasis of peace in the midst of bustling Hong Kong, almost like being in another plane of existence! Highly recommended!

Chi Lin Nunnery. Not too much to see here. This place is right next to the Nan Lian gardens. There are some statues and ponds inside. Lots of the statues say no photography and there were some worshipers around too. There is really not much to see here, I wouldn't spend more than 30 minutes to an hour here.

Favorite place in HK.. Definitely a must go during a trip to HK. The architecture of the whole complex is simply beautiful. The Japanese style influenced garden will definitely bring you serenity and romantism in a peaceful atmosphere. This place is a perfect getaway to have a break from all the HK noise and crazyness. The location among all those tall building is quite unreal. Loved it.

Beautiful!!. Beautiful and quiet. The different buddhas were nice to look at. The greenery is well manicured and the grounds are nicely kept. Since it is a place of worship cameras were not allowed in several places in the Nunnery. Take the MTR's green line to Diamond Hill and just follow the signs. It is a quick five minute walk and is just steps away from the Nan Lian Gardens. Was able to walk the grounds in 15 to 20 minutes.
a peaceful spot in the noisy Hong Kong. I love the place, it is beautiful and spiritual.Cameras are not allowed in some areas.We really enjoyed our time there.

A Welcome Escape From the Crowds in Hong Kong. It is most worthwhile to take the MTR to the nunnery and Nan Lian gardens. When you get out of the train station, there are well marked signs which lead you to your destination. The nunnery and gardens are so well maintained and peaceful and are amazing to see juxtaposed against the soaring heights of the surrounding apartment buildings. Do yourself a favor and spend a few hours here.
Awesome place. Must do while in HK! 3 minutes walking from Diamond Hill station. There is a great mall to have a lunch or dinner before or after visiting that place! Enjoy your trip...
Beautiful. Learnt a lot and was very a peaceful atmosphere. Enjoyed it immensely, very nicely attached to the Nan Lian Gardens which I would too recommend

An Amazingly Spiritual place . Following on from the Nan Lian gardens (often confused for the Nunnery itself) the Chi Lin nunnery is spectacularly laid out with many golden Buddhas, water features and walkways. Please observe the notices as this is a peaceful area and photography is not always appreciated or allowed in certain areas. We spent about 2 hours here in the Chi Lin and Nan Lian area. It is a Wonderful way to experience the cultural / spiritual side of Hong Kong.

A Peaceful and enjoyable experience. A must see in my experience.
Combine with a visit to the gardens.
The buildings are a delight.
You cannot use a camera inside the temple, though there are many areas to take great shots.

Something to look at. This was a good thing to do so it may be worth looking at it if you have time.
Not a must see but you will not be diasappointed.

Peace, tranquility. Our favorite day in Hong Kong. Our visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery was the highlight of our 12 day trip. It is an absolute oasis of tranquility within the hustle bustle of the city. There is a quaint vegetarian restaurant, just off the main nunnery as well. But it's the nunnery that is the highlight. It is peaceful, quiet, and just such a wonderful experience – no matter what your religious background. We saw devout Buddhists pray alongside teenagers from North Europe – and they were equally at peace and ease. The individual Buddhas are fantastic and there are clear explanations of each statue and reason behind the worship. Do NOT miss this. Easily accessible from the Diamond Hill MTR - and a 10 minute walk past the other MUST GO TO place - the Nan Lian Garden. Little bit of heaven on busy Hong Kong earth!
Yummy vegetarian dim sum lunch. Big servings. Healthy options and fruit juices. Efficient and friendly staff. The Nan Lian gardens are a welcome respite from urban life.

Great vegetarian food!. Great vegetarian food at the restaurant, and the shop has awesome vegan chocolate too! Must visit the garden, and appreciate the bonsai trees and plants there. If time allows, the tea ceremony service is good too.

A complex of interesting Temples. This large temple complex was built in 1934 and went through a lot of renovations. You will find here lotus ponds with numerous bonsai plant collection. The temples were made of lovely and elegant wooden architecture. They said that when they built the temples, they did not make use of nails. The wood, clay and stone are held together by traditional bracketing techniques.We found out also that the Buddhist relics here are actually treasures of Hongkong. Inside the complex you will also find various temple halls, some containing wooden, gold and clay statues representing Sakyamuni Buddha and other divinities.Lovely complex that a traveler should not miss.

When the city gets too much, head here. The nunnery and the gardens across the road are a fantastic oasis, literally surrounded by the tower blocks. It is beautiful and spiritual but completely welcoming. It is the kind of place where you can engage with it to whichever extent suits you - and take as much or as little time as you like to enjoy it.It is highly photogenic too - I guarantee you will come out with some great pics.When you first get to HK, it is a good place to go if the jet lag kicks in and the city seems a bit too intense.

For the devout and the curious.. I went to the Nunnery this afternoon. It was... all right. For the devout Buddhists and the religiously curious, this is a good place to be. The Buddhist music throughout the grounds sets the tone for the place. But the hustle and bustle of the souvenir shop is an abrupt change from the peace in the Nunnery itself. Not all of the grounds are available to the public. You're not allowed to take photos but I saw people taking them in full view of security and they didn't do anything so I guess it should be all right. Don't visit in the afternoon in summer either because it is hot enough to get a heatstroke.

Beautiful and serene. We visited the Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens early in the day, since we worried about the mid-day heat. It was the right decision, come early and be prepared to take many photos and enjoy a serene walk around the grounds. It was a beautiful way to spend a few hours of strolling through lush gardens, past a stunning pagoda, and seeing how they built the nunnery building without nails. It is spotless, peaceful, and a great break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and Kowloon. There is a nice gift shop at the end where there are some unique purchases. Highly recommended!

A slice of serenity amongst the hustle and bustle. We were advised to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Liang Gardens by family (HK residents) and we are so glad we went! The nunnery is beautiful with gorgeous Buddhist shrines, in sense and prayers. The gardens are stunning and definitely worth a visit. We visited around lunchtime: it was HOT! If we visit again we'd go early morning or late afternoon as it's cooler. You can walk through the Hollywood Plaza when you leave the MTR for some AC relief before and/or after your visit though! A must (free) see!

Peaceful. This nunnery located inside Nan Liang Garden. I came here using MTR and stop at Diamond Hill Station exit C2 then follow the sign pointing to Nan Liang Garden. Its only 5 minutes walk. The atmosphere here was very peaceful. Really enjoy my time here.
Peaceful. Very peaceful and serene, connected to the Nan Lian Garden by a bridge (both are must-sees). The buildings were all very beautiful with interesting bodhisattva statues.

Magnificent!. One of the most beautiful places I've visited. The convent per se is a magnificent piece of art, but the real protagonists are the statues. You will find several gold statues from Buddha and many other bodhisattvas. It's a shame that it's not possible to take pictures, as all of the huge statues are spectacular. It's very easy to get there with the MTR! (Diamond Hill Station)It's definitely worth the visit!

Beautiful serene setting to clear your head. Came here in October 2013 but I can still remember how calming and peaceful it was to visit this nunnery. Definitely go earlier in the day to avoid crowds, and not to sound cheesy, but let your mind be in the present as you enjoy the serenity of this nunnery. Visit the gift shop with very beautiful trinkets and souvenirs after your stay - staff is very helpful inside and helped me with my purchase of a gorgeous fan. Great quiet spot within a busy city.
Oasis in the concrete Jungle. It's a very calming, serene oasis in the chaos that is Hong Kong.There are beautiful gardens, and an amazing temple there.
Beautiful Oasis. Gorgeous (and very peaceful) experience and the attached gardens are well worth a wander. Try and go early or late as it does get unbearably hot during the day.....

A great experience. My wife and I were urged to get to see the nunnery and it was great advice. We took the subway up from near the Nikko Hotel...(that was a fun experience in itself in that as an original New Yorker it's a kick to ride a subway that is so clean and so punctual and so affordable and so quick and MAKES A PROFIT!)....but the short walk to the nunnery was easy. It's a beautifully maintained and quite serene area. There were quite a few worshippers and the (few) guards were quick to keep (little) kids quiet and to help maintain a proper ambience. The park just down from the Nunnery is also quite worthy of your time...late in the afternoon with long shadows on a clear day made it all the more pleasant. If you're a 1st time visitor to Hong Kong it's a 'must see'...but if you return to HK you'll find yourself there again as well.Just do it!

Lovely and peaceful. The Nan Lian Garden and Nunnery are adjacent to each other and a no brainer to go to both at the same time. The gardens are lovely and extensive. Very peaceful place to stroll and take a break from the hectic city. The Nunnery is beautiful and very well kept. Another perfect place to take a break from the frenetic city life outside. I was amazed at how clean, tidy and well-kept the Nunnery was - and super interesting. There can never be enough explanation on Buddhism...so the more signs the better. They had some good descriptions but still, super hard to understand what Buddhism is all about. It doesn't take long to go through the Nunnery; not a huge place.
Serenity amidst the concrete jungle. Really worth the trip. It's beautiful and peaceful amidst the concrete jungle. Didn't expect such a place existed in Hong Kong!
Chi Lin Nunnery. The peacefulness and the artistic interpretation as displayed in the trees and plants are amazing. The architecture, without nails is astounding.

A slice of serenity amongst the craziness of the city. It has taken me nearly eight years to finally visit the Chi Lin nunnery: so glad I finally made the effort. Myself and my three children traveled by MTR: it is super easy to access the nunnery from the MTR station. We wandered around the nunnery for about 45 minutes and then corssed the bridge to the gardens. We stopped off at the restaurant for some excellent and very cheap vegetarian dim sum before exploring the gardens. Whole trip took about 2 hours and we all thoroughly enjoyed it. Will now add it to my schedule for all visitors. It is a venue which has something fro everyone, kids loved it and I can see that it would appeal just as much to our older visitors.

Serenity in the city. Beautiful wooden structures house the different worship rooms, where we saw nuns going about their jobs and prayers. Coming from the gorgeous Nan Liam gardens, you enter the nunnery through the Lotus ponds. The gardens are just beautiful. It is a serene, peaceful haven away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Highly recommended.

A beautiful and tranquil place. This park is situated in the middle of a very busy district and it is truly amazing how once you enter all modern worries are simply forgotten. The park is so pretty and well maintained that we enjoyed a 1h walk completely forgetting about the terrible heat and light co stant rain. I could imagine walking in one of the emperor's gardens back in the days. The temple at the top of the park is also highly recommend if you would like to brave the stairs. Especially amazing were the lily ponds and of course the views from the top. If you would like to get a break from the hectic life in Hong Kong, this is the place for you.

Quiet Place. I love the big space in the temple and across it is a park with a lot of greenery but it's a shame that they disallow people to walk on the bridge to take photos or the shelter place. There are security guards in the park too. Inside the temple, there are big ponds and they look lovely. Nice place for a moment of peace and tranquillity.

A place to enjoy the peace. Amazing place. Could stay for hours. A kind of another world in the middle of a big city. Even if there are hundreds of others it is quite and peaceful. Just next to the wonderful Nan-Lian-Garden

Beautiful and tranquil. Beautiful place over a back drop of skyscrapers makes Chi Lin a unique place to visit. Very peaceful and serene makes it a nice change to the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Amazing statues and religious figures with English descriptions makes it an experience well worth making the trip. Finish it off in Nan Lian Gardens for a complete experience.
Brilliant. What an awesome garden. I was in awe. Expected a big Wooden structure, but got so much more. Well Done Hong Kong.

Very peaceful and beautiful place. The nunnery offers great place for travellers who wants to take a break from all the happenings in HK. There is relaxing music played all over the nunnery while you are strolling around the place. It is very clean and full of greenery and flowers. There are museums, restaurant and souvenir shop. Bear in mind all the charges (some are free) are going to support the maintenance for the nunnery. Remember to get a free copy catalog that introduces to you the Chi Lin Nunnery. A must go for all who visit HK!
A peaceful place. Very peaceful and quiet. Beautiful temple architecture, pond and details. Great vegetarian food in the restaurant.
Love it!. Together with Nan Lian Garden this place is one of the most recommended place to visit in Hong Kong, the architecture was just nice and I love how the security guards it,

Fascinating architecture and gardens. A short walk from diamond hill MTR this provides a fascinating looks at traditional architecture set in a delightful garden. Great contrast with the high rises around

Serenity in the Centre of a City. The Buddhist nunnery is off the beaten path but easily accessible by the MTA. The gardens were peaceful and a severe contrast to the surrounding buildings. Beautifully maintained the nunnery's main area is open to the public. Icons are lovely and if you are fortunate you may see the head nun.

Nice enough. It's quite a plain building with a few small shrubs etc in the courtyard. Photography is not allowed inside the nunnery but ok in the gardens. The security staff are nice but the nuns I saw looked as miserable as sin. It's free so can't complain.

Peaceful oasis. Lovely peaceful spot to visit - best first thing in the morning if you are here in summer before humidity gets too high. Beautiful gardens and great juxtapositions of old Hong Kong with new.

Very large and quite modern.. The gardens and fountains are extensive and well-maintained. The buddhas are beautiful and well-kept. The light fixtures, architectural features, and access from the garden across the street is easy. Don't expect to be able to sit as there are only a couple of benches and the security personnel will not let you sit on any of the walkways even in a rainy downpour.

A little peace within a busy city. Visited this site three times and was impressed with the serenity of the garden . Had the good fortune of dropping by when the nuns were chanting and the echoes off the buildings sent chills down my body despite the 35 degree heat. The bridge setting is iconic and the cleanliness and maintenance impressive. Went at sunset for dinner in their vegetarian restaurant and had some delightful dishes. Would recommend for anyone to "get away from the kaos " if only for a short while.

Peace within Hong Kong. This place is a rare gem. Go there if you are looking for some quiet contemplation. It's not a typical tourist destination, thankfully, and I think it could easily ruined by large groups visiting.

Secret garden amongst a concrete jungle!. Let's face it. Greenery is pretty hard to find in HK with that "bright lights, bigger city" vibe pretty much everywhere. Tucked away in Diamond Hill, you cross a bridge and encounter this absolutely beautiful garden, which serves as a nunnery for Buddhists. The cleanliness, serenity, and peacefulness blew me away mainly because the rest of Hong Kong is so busy. There weren't a lot of tourists either - so that made me very pleased. Whether you are a devote Buddhist or a person who just enjoys taking quiet walks, this place is definitely a must visit. The greenery is absolutely gorgeous and everything is just so well maintained and kept. The people there are also extremely nice and their restaurant is also fantastic. You will not be disappointed with this lovely gem in Hong Kong!!
Awesome Stop. The nunnery is easy to access using the diamond hill metro stop. Visiting the Nan Lian Gardens should be paired with this site as the physically connected. A great place for photos.

Peaceful and odd to see it in the middle of high rises.. An easy walk from Diamond Hill. Remember to check out the Nan Lian Gardens. Both feel so strange being surrounded by high rise buildings and fly overs along it. No eating in either place.

Oasis of quiet in busy HongKong. We visited the Nunnery on a Sunday and were amazed at the quiet and tranquillity in the middle of this busy city. There are four temples with impressive golden statues of Buddhivista in (I think) various stages of his journey to enlightenment, together with some of his key disciples. We could hear, but not see, the Nuns chanting while we were there which added to the atmosphere of our visit. The wooden buildings are incredibly intricate and were designed to avoid the use of any nails by using very complex mortise-and-tenon joints.The temples are surrounded by superb lotus ponds and small trees. These provided lots of opportunities for photo - enthusiasts. (But photos of the Buddha were not welcome!)We recommend visiting Chi Lin if you need to "recharge your batteries" after a lot of shopping or are tired of hustle and bustle.

Not a famous place for locals.. To be frank, as locals, this is not the place we visit frequently especially for those do not have religions. But in terms of the architecture, it is visit-worthy for sure. It is quite surprising for this attraction to be ranked No. 2 in HK.

Was there because of tripadv second rank. I was there due to the fact that this attraction is nr. 2 on tripadvisor.com. Indeed, worth to visit this nunnery. It is one of the most known temple, reknowned for its solemnity, statues, yards, etc. You will not be dissapointed after the visit.

An oasis of peace in the midst of a concrete jungle. I visited the nunnery and adjoining gardens with a friend and had such a wonderful time taking in the beautiful surroundings. The nunnery consists of traditional wooden chinese style buildings. I was told, that apparently no nails were used to build the wooden structures but that the sections of wood were handcrafted to fit together perfectly. In the middle of the nunnery there are beautiful, serene lotus ponds and bonsai gardens which makes for stunning photographs. Inside the various halls there are ornate buddhist shrines with fresh offerings of fruit and incense. You will not be allowed to take photographs inside the halls/temples though. There were peaceful, musical buddhist chanting in the background but it's a CD that is being broadcast over hidden speakers. Nevertheless, it still contributed towards the ambience whilst taking the beautiful surroundings.And it's free to enter! In most other countries a beautiful place like this would have an entrance fee so quite impressed. There is a souvenir shop that sells the usual tat but they look slightly better quality than that you'll find at Stanley market, for example.Then, adjoining the nunnery is the Beautiful Nan Lian garden that's accessible via a relatively new foot bridge across the road. The gardens reflect the same serenity than the nunnery does. There are sparkling clear ponds full of Khoi, traditional looking footbridges leading to colourful pagodas, perfectly manicured trees and shrubs. I must add that one was not allowed on these footbridges, they are probably ornamental but still adds the beauty. There is a vegetarian restaurant within the gardens hidden behind a man-made waterfall. We had a set lunch there which was good value at around $120HKD p/p consisting of around 4 dishes. However, the food was completely bland and we had to ask for some chillies and soy to make the food edible. But overall it was still an enjoyable experience and the gardens make for stunning photographs.

A nice getaway from the busy and hectic HK. If you enjoy peace and quiet with beautiful surroundings, then this is the place to go. Well kept place, very clean and scenic. Just make sure to have a full battery camera with you!

Quiet getaway from the city. It’s a bad time to go during summer, my attire is wet with perspiration from the heat. Else, its a nice place to get away from the city for a change. Peaceful and quiet. In my opinion, it’s not a “must visit” place, come by if you have 2 hours to spare. Conveniently located within walking distance from Diamond Hill MTR.

Peace and quiet in this hectic city. A nice and quiet part of this crazy city. When I visited, I was the only tourist. Nice to walk about, and make sure you visit the gardens opposite the monastry as well.

Quiet oasis.. This is a little gem. It is beautiful and very serene. Even our teenage sons were blown away by this place and the gardens across the street. The little gift store under it has some "different" things in it compared to al the other souvenirs you come across.

A perfect fake built for political purposes. A fabulous place, just don't try to cross the bridges to the pagodas - they're blocked. Make sure you read the 20 rules on the pamphlet before entering. Do not sit down or the security guard will ask you to move on. Suspiciously you will find no locals here. A beautiful empty carcass
Worth the trip. Easy to get to and the gardens are amazing. In such a fast and busy city, the gardens were a real delight.

simply the best veggie restaurant!. I love the gardens there, and I love the vegetarian restaurant there even more! Highly recommend it to everyone who is going to visit Hong Kong. You really can get a moment of zen there amid the hustle and bustle of Kowloon.

Perfectly silent. This nunnery is a place of peace and quiet. There are a lot of mockups of various Chinese temples inside, but taking photos is prohibited. I cannot even begin to imagine the amount of work that needed to be done in order to complete such mockups. The attention to detail is extraordinary. I enjoyed it a lot.

great ancient architecture. this historical place will remind you of old chinese movie, but now it feel so real. i really like this place and its so easy to get there by thr MTR (diamond hill station) but its not allowed to take picture of things inside the building. And dont forget to visit the Nan Liang garden just opposite of this area

Breath of Fresh Air. Chi Lin Nunnery is a needed break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. As you step through the doorway into the beautiful lotus pond courtyard, you feel instantly relaxed. The Buddhist shrines to different Bodhisattvas are wonderful pieces of art that you won't find anywhere else in HK or much of mainland China.Take the metro ride to Diamond Hill on the green line and follow the tourist signs to Chi Lin. You won't regret it.

Oasis in a busy city. Architecturally interesting and thoughtfully maintained Chinese monastery just a stone's throw away from Diamond Hill subway station. A quiet oasis in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

very calm. This temple is built by the money from Hong Kong people (and surely from the rich people also such as the superstars in Hong Kong). near this temple has the Nan Lian Garden that you can walk around to touch the peaceful and nice plants. And the golden pavillion with the red bridge is very beautiful. In the garden, there are the volunteer that can take you travel around and tell you about the informations. But you have to contact for asking for the volunteer.
Beautiful, tranquil place. Hard to believe that this beautiful, tranquil place is in the middle of a busy city. The gardens are very pretty as is the nunnery itself. Enjoyable hour or so spent here.

Fantastic place, calm environment. Visited the place in June 2014 and liked it very much. The garden is beautiful and the nunnery is also good. Was a very calm and quiet place away from the noise in the city. Worth visiting on trip to Hong Kong.Much of the nunnery was however closed for visitors to see, but still a good place to visit.

Tranquility. Beautiful gardens with Bonsais and many other interesting plants. Simplicity and peaceful surroundings are top here. Especially after the hectic of Diamond Hill MTR. Friendly nuns and a place to buy good quality souvenirs

ah the serenity. you can visit this place along with another attractions in this area and make a nice afternoon trip. taxis are great, not that expensive if you cant be bothered with bus or train.amazing gardens and a great place to find a quiet place when in the hustle and bustle of hk...

Wonderfully peacefull. I would thoroughly recommend spending some relaxing time in such a humble temple, very peaceful and spine tingling. Visitors are informed very clearly of where photos can and cannot be taken. Very touching place.

Temple in the city. I visited here on my own as a fill-in as I knew the people I was with and due to arrive to Hong Kong later would not be interested. And so pleased I did. Set amongst high-rise blocks on all sides, it and it's gardens are a master in tranquility. Having said that, they are rarely empty.

The most beautiful temple. This buddhist nunnery is definetely worth visiting. It is very easy to access by metro from central to Diamond Hill station and you go there through a very beautiful garden. There is also a souvenir shop, washrooms and light refreshments at the downstairs of nunnery.
Beautiful! Abfab!

An extremely serene and transquil paradise in the midst of the bustle of HK. A peaceful paradise park and buddhist nunnery is a wonderful place to slow down, breathe in fresh air, take in the serenity and just enjoy that you are living. It has exhibits of the ancient architecture of building without nails, old giant precious stones, Halls of prayers with buddhas, an amazing walk through the park brings you to another world.Serves vegetarian food too.
must go. u will not consider a hong kong sightseeing tour without adding this into your itinerary. many just go for shopping for food but they forgot this little place that makes hong kong really is.
Peaceful Place,beautiful garden. Peaceful place in middle of hong kong busy city. Worth to visit especially after roaming around the city.

Peaceful place. Even though this nunnery is located mostly in the city center, it is a very paeceful place. The gardens and the nunnery are beautiful and we could take a very relaxing walk.My suggestion is to use this place as an excape from the crowded Hong Kong!
Serenity amidst a crazy city. Everytime I visit here I fall in love with this place again, Its so quiet and peaceful, a real oasis in Kowloon

Very peaceful and calming place. I did not expect much when I planned to visit the nunnery but I was wrong. The whole place was beautiful. The temples were situated behind the garden and the statues were beautiful. I did not expect myself to like this place this much. The vegetarian restaurant situated within the garden is excellent. It is a place I would definitely visit again on my next Hong Kong trip.

Definitely worth a visit. Great gardens with rivers and a number of temples and oriental architecture offering a very relaxing environment to escape for a while from the craziness of the city. Free of charge to visit you can get there using the underground

Oasis in the middle of the skyscrapers. What a beautiful and tranquil place! Well worth the visit, the buildings and gardens are kept up wonderfully, the architectural designs are wonderful and so quiet and restful.

Beautiful and peaceful. Totally worth a half day trip out to Diamond Hill MTR and combine with the garden across the street. Magnificent stone structure and beautiful ponds. Nice bathrooms too. Very air conditioned gift shop.

An oasis of tranquility. The Chi Lin Nunnery is very a worthwhile place to visit, even during a relatively short stay in Hong Kong. It's a beautiful tranquil Oasis and a respite from the hustle and bustle of HK. It's also quite easy to get to from the diamond hill MTR station. also take the time to cross the road and visit the lovely Nan Lian Garden and lake opposite (it's all free!)
Very serene and beautiful. Beautiful place. Outstanding craftsmanship! Enjoy on a sunny day and wander quietly round the gardens
A beautiful, serene location. Step a few feet away from a shiny modern mall and you'll be find yourself in this oasis of calm. A welcome break from the manic rush of the city, well worth a visit.
Beautyful and peaceful. I verry love this place it's very beautyful and peaceful . It's great chinese architecture in Hongkong.
Nice little gem. Easy to reach and it's surprisingly beautiful. Good location for photography too. Combine the trip with nan lian garden across the road and you'll not regret it.

Paradise for Photos. I took a taxi from marco Polo HK hotel. It took around 30 to 40 minutes. Very nice and peaceful place. You can take thousands of beautiful pictures here. Photos are not allowed in front of Buddha statues. But you can take the inside of the temple except the statues, No problem. A must visit place in kowloon
Nice tranquil place to visit.. This is a nice attraction to visit if you fancy escaping the hub bub of Hong Kong. You can wander round and it's a good way to relax in some peace and quiet.

Peaceful oasis. I love the Chi Lin nunnery. A short walk from Hollywood Place this is a fantastic architectural and religious oasis. When you want to escape from Hong Kong craziness and centre yourself it's a great place to visit.
Nice place to escape the city rush. just a nice place to take some good photos and to get away from Hong Kong' hussle and noise.easy to get to take the MRT to Diamond Hill and follow the signs.

A Must Visit........ This is a must for all visitors to Hong Kong. Why?1. Beautiful gardens with ponds2. Tranquility yet only yards from high rise blocks and shopping malls3. Quiet, peaceful, and relaxing4. Historic5. Can be done in an hour6. Suitable for families with children7. Excellent photo opportunity8. Easy to get to9. Free entryTake MTR to Diamond Hill and follow sign - should take no more than 5 mins walk.

Amazing. This was a hidden little gem. We caught the MTR and walked a few minutes. The nunnery is serene and so calm despite being amongst the traffic. The gardens were stunning and the lack of people made visiting a pleasure.

Interesting contrast. It's interesting to see all of the modern high rise buildings and shopping malls surrounding this very traditional, peaceful nunnery and gardens. We only had 2 days to do touristy things in Hong Kong, this is the first place we went and are very glad we did.
nice small temple. A quiet and relaxing place to escape the noisy street of Hong Kong. Wooden temple which making a grand standing.

Quiet Garden in the Middle of a Bustling Metropolis. I went to the garden on the same trip as I went to Mainland China and it really reminded me of the Chen Family Academy in Guangzhou. It is quite a beautiful garden and a very quiet place next to the bustling metropolis of Hong Kong. Bonus points for being free.In theory this is how a real Chinese garden should look, which would make it a must-see attraction, but for some reason though I didn't feel any amazement or any special feeling toward the place. Maybe it's because I had visited dozens of Chinese temples in Mainland China beforehand, or maybe it's because I was tired after a long (and hot) day in Hong Kong.Still, it is worth a visit if you're in the area, and the Nan Lian garden right across is a great place to just sit back and relax.

Peaceful place and place to breath in the crowded city. Nice temple with beautiful park nearby along with the silent, peaceful, calm, and clean temple without the noisy tourists or crowded people as anther temple in HK.A good choice to relax and relieve from the very busy and noisy town.

Glad we spent the time to go back here. We were on a tour that rushed through here. After looking at Trip Advisor reviews, we took the subway back the next day and spent more time. If you go, be sure that you go through the attached gardens and both of the gift shops. These aren't your typical souvenir shops and you will find some nice things to take home. Not junky. Look for the "rock" garden downstairs too. The garden is the largest bonsai garden in the world.
Temple. It is a very nice place in the city. Peace and quiet to relax. U can walk in the nunnery to see some nice Buddha statue and walk in the garden.

Excellent reprieve from the hustle and bustle. This is a nice break from the hustle and bustle of HK. The Chinese garden with the miniature trees and the adjoining monastery is excellent. The vegetarian restaurant is outstanding, but crowded. Much better when it is cool. Summer might not be as pleasant

It's The Nan Lian Garden with attached Nunnery.. One goes here for the Nan Lian Gardens as the Nunnery whilst adjacent cannot be accessed by tourists. One can see through the spaces and notice the architecture but on our visit we did not see a soul within the Nunnery. Focus on the Gardens which are free and well worth the trip.

Peace and tranquility. I have visited here several times and it is one of my favourite places in HK. The gardens are extremely well maintained. It is very peaceful walking through the manicured gardens within such a busy city. I also love the stunning lotus flowers floating on the pond. The vegetarian restaurant within the garden is definitely worth going to.

Beautiful Architecture & Details. It is easy to feel overwhelmed by the the homogenous style of post 1970's buildings in Hong Kong, the nunnery offers a refreshing change - the structure follows that of the Tang Dynasty, and it is inspiring to see traditional wooden joinery details. This place is a must - see for Architecture enthusiasts and designers alike. The space is quiet and offers a moment of tranquility for tired locals and tourists, I love this site.

Great vegetarian restaurant. My husband and I went to the vegetarian restaurant in the gardens. It was quite busy and we were asked if it was ok to share a table. We ordered a set menu comprising 4 dishes plus soup, congee (plain) & fruit. The food was delicious. Vivid , bright flavours, (not spicy) and well matched. The congee is plain so expect it to taste of plain boiled rice but it is a nice contrast to the other dishes. A pot of tea is also included. 105HKD each and we were full. Not the usual western idea of vegetarian food. This was really good. They also have an extensive a la carte menu. would absolutely go there again. Gardens are worth a visit too. We spent best part of the day here.
Nice place in the middle of Hong Kong. There is nothing to dislike, its pretty quite calming when you have been walking around the nearbye shopping centre for an hour or so.

Fascinating glimpse into local culture. I'm not sure what I expected, having not seen photos or read reviews before visiting the nunnery. The complex is beautiful, simple, and really quite interesting. We visited on a rainy day in May, and spent a pleasant half an hour walking around, seeing the carvings and reading the explanation plaques. This is a lovely place to visit if you're already doing the adjoining gardens, which are worth a visit in their own right.
Very nice place. Love it, the historical, interior and architecture are great. Peaceful and beautiful garden. It's a must!!
What a pleasant surprise. I am surprised that the Nunnery is not on more "must visit" lists. It is magnificent and well worth a visit, and you get to learn a little about Buddhism as well.

Must-See Sanctuary. The gardens and monastery here are absolutely beautiful and peaceful. The gardens are well-constructed and maintained. Access to the monastery (nunnery) itself is partially restricted because nuns are actually engaged in worship and meditation here. However, there is plenty to see. The ongoing dedicated practice gives the location both a spark and a somber note that many nearby temples don't have. Wrap up your visit at their vegan restaurant with a very light dim sum and tea snack, or stay for a delicious, more involved dinner. The gift shops (in the main nunnery and also near the restaurant) have many lovely, devotional (and non-devotional), and artful items.

Spiritual Place. Chi Lin Nunnery is absolutely beautiful. The architecture and craftsmanship of the buildings and grounds are superb. We strolled in the gardens prior to visiting the Nunnery and also stopped in the garden gift shop. The area inside the nunnery was created with smooth wood surfaces and then enhanced by the special areas for housing the statues and areas of worship. The atmosphere is quiet and peaceful which is a huge contrast to the world outside the grounds. If you are in Hong Kong it is a must see.

Most beautiful Buddist temple I have seen. This temple is adjacent to the Nan Lian Garden, and we visited both during the same trip. It is a peaceful and beautiful temple with many Buddist statues and decoration. I would highly recommend to visit if you have time.
off the tourist trail. A beautiful temple peaceful except on Buddas Birthday. Hard to imagine amid the busy Diamond Hill. Easy to get to on MRT Located next to Nan Lin gardens
Beautiful temple grounds. The nunnery is a must see in Hong Kong. the temple grounds are beautiful and it is a very peaceful place.

Peace and calm. Interesting place to visit made all the more interesting for us as we had locals take us. I'm not sure I would recommended it on its own but as it's across the street from Nan Lian Garden well worth combining both.

Different temple. Lovely place to visit, very peaceful. Visited Nan Lian gardens first, and they are absolutely fabulous as well. Would prefer these 2 attractions to the Big Buddha if I was predder for time. The gardens are like out of a book, very chinese and to see the nunnery in its plain wood with the bonsai trees was very relaxing

Gorgeous.. Went in May, on a Sunday AM. Almost no one there. It's a very compelling place. Glad I went ~ no pictures but for good reason. It's free too, which helps. Just across from the Nan Lian Garden so that makes for a nice morning.

Not your ordinary temple. Chi Lin Nunnery is like a garden temple to the city because you can see the skyscraper buildings from the location. The temple is just so calm and peaceful because of the spacious area with the manicured plants in it. Just a reminder, you are not allowed to take photos inside the temples...My visit here is really worth it and so convenient as it is walkable only to the nearest MRT Station (Diamond Hill Station) and neighbouring the equally beautiful Nan Lian Gardens. If you want to see more you can check: http://jlordalmighty.blogspot.sg/2014/05/asias-world-city-hong-kong-trip-14.html#.U3toB142nwI

Calmness in a busy city. We went to Chi Lin Nunnery during the Golden Week. It was extremely busy, but extremely peaceful & calm. The Nan Lin Gardens were also very beautiful. 2 must do's are1- enjoy the All Veg lunch at the Nan Lin Garden Vegetarian Kitchen. 2- enjoy the beautiful vistas & buddha worship idols inside the Nunnery.Great experience.
Beautiful manicured gardens. We traveled via public transport from hong kong island, it was clearly signposted all the way and we enjoyed the beauty of the garden and monastery
Get thee to thy Nunnery. The nunnery is a huge contrast to the sky scrapers around it. It was raining the morning we were there, but still was beautiful and enjoyable.

great peaceful place. To get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong visit the Chi Lin Nunnery where peace is found. It is a place of tranquility and one can find nuns praying or offering food to Buddha. It is also a place of culture as this was built during the Tang dynasty.

Great visit of culture and history. The Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Garden are side by side so you can do both easily. To get there, take the MTR to the Diamond Hill stop. It is on the green line, so if you are on the island, go to the central stop, change for the red line to take you to Kowloon. Change at You Ma Tei stop for Diamond Hill. Take exit C2 and and you will exit into the Hollywood Plaza Mall. Exit to the right and walk around the back of the building past the rest rooms and then cross at the corner and you will be right inside Nan Lian Garden. The Nunnery is to your left. The rich dark wood architecture of the buildings and temples are very beautiful. There are many buildings but some house the monks and schools, so not all are accessible but still more than enough to see. The Buddha statues are some of the most beautiful I have ever seen. The entire complex is very serene, peaceful and moving. Great for a day to slow down, see great cultural historic scenes and reflect for awhile. A definite visit. On your walk back to the subway, the mall offers a chance for something to eat or drink and a chance to sit for awhile. Hats recommend for hot sunny days as you will be without much cover out in the open most of the time.

A picture of quiet and calm in Hong Kong. This attraction is easy to find, conveniently located near the Diamond Hill MTR, and is a place of quiet beauty. The accompanying Nan Lian Gardens are a must -see and bring your camera- there are countless photo ops. Most of the places of photographic interest are roped off so that you can enjoy their beauty without having mobs of silly tourists climbing all over them for that "priceless" funny photo. Your photos will be of the natural splendour or the lovely buildings- not of a bus tour gone wild.Once you enter the main building at the Nunnery, cameras away as this is a place of worship and must be respected as such. Enjoy the surrounding singing, calm and serenity of the experience. Most guidebooks tell you this attraction will take around 2 hours to enjoy- I spent over 3 and could have stayed longer!

A landmark in Hongkong. This is a very special place to visit when you have 2 hrs to spare. Easy to reach via metro, Diamond Hill stop and only a couple of minutes walk from there.Established in 1934 and renovated in Tang dynasty style (AD 618–907) in 1990, the Chi Lin Nunnery is a large temple complex of elegant wooden architecture, treasured Buddhist relics and soul-soothing lotus ponds. The complex also includes a series of temple halls, some of which contain gold, clay and wooden statues representing divinities such as the Sakyamuni Buddha and bodhisattvas. No nails were used building this complex. It’s amazing. Has a very nice souvenir shop and little vegetarian restaurant as well as coffee shop.

Interesting oasis in this busy city. Easy to get to well sign posted from Diamond Hill MTR. First take a relaxing walk around Nan Lian gardens and take note of the architecture display as it then makes sense of the building style. After wondering around the gardens take the bridge across the road to the monastery. Very quiet and relaxing place. The Buddhas in the main temple are beautiful and worth spending time admiring the handy work. Also sign in English explain the background of each which was very useful.
Garden lanscape. Nothing special but if you fancy a stroll in a beautiful landscaped garden, this is the place to be. It is also connected to the monastery nearby.
Amazing and Spiritual. Beuatiful grounds, it's free, the temples are gorgeous, you see a lot of faith in the people worshiping these magnificient Buddhas.One of my favorite places.

Good addition to the Nan Lian Garden. At it is right next door it is an easy visit to make. Not a place to make a special visit for. Its nice, lots of interesting things to see but a half hour will see it out. Add it in to the Garden visit and it makes a good half day train trip, garden visit, nunnery visit and train trip home. Watch our for the exit you take from the train station. If you take the wrong one you will wander for ages without seeing any sign of the gardens.

Peaceful and Beautiful!. The Chi Lin Nunnery is located close to Nan Liam garden. Its beautiful architecture is breathtaking. The place is well maintained. It gives you a sense of tranquility and calm. Simply awesome!

An Urban Oasis!. This was located very convenient to the Metro. When we first arrived, we were not quite sure we were at Chi Lin...there is signage for a public park. There is no entry fee, and the gardens you walk through to get to the nunnery are breath-taking!! You will walk through pagodas, around koi ponds, waterfalls, an architecture museum (that explains how pagoda can be built with no nails)....I was in awe of the beauty of the gardens. There is a vegan restaurant we stopped at for lunch that is run by the monks of the area. For 4 of us, we paid a total of $60. USD. The food was very good and well presented, the surroundings were peaceful. After lunch, we continued through the gardens to the Chi Lin Nunnery...it seemed to be more of a monastery to me. The temples on the grounds are "active" and many of the people there were there to pray to the Buddha. There is no photography permitted of anything inside of the temples. I found the Buddha statues and the altars to amazingly beautiful and peaceful. We headed to the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery after this, and it wasn't that far away by taxi. I highly recommend this attraction!

A quiet haven. We happened to visit this Buddhist temple on Buddha's birthday so there were numerous worshipers present, which added to the mystery as we filed by the large gold statue in the main temple. The adjoining gardens are an exquisite haven of peace in the midst of this bustling city. It is not possible to stop and eat on the benches in the garden, however. If you wish to eat, there is a vegetarian restaurant on the grounds.

It's just ok, but at least it's free. The Chi Lin Nunnery must be a nice place in which to meditate; I can imagine it is very calming and helps the nuns go about their daily routine. The Chi Lin Nunnery also has a Buddhist temple in its compounds, and much like at the adjacent Nan Lian Garden, there are beautiful gardens and water features here as well. The temple here is free to enter and inside there are statues of the Sakyumani Buddha. It is free to visit, so if you're at the amazing Nan Lian Garden already, then take a half hour to explore this Nunnery. Otherwise, don't make much of an effort to come here especially.
Very peaceful. The nunnery has very beautiful bonsai and interesting rock displays. It is a very peaceful place to unwind and leave the worries and hustle and bustle of the day behind.

Tranquil park in the middle of hustle and bustle. Beautiful park near Diamond Hill MTR. I heard someone told me that the roofs of the buildings are wired in such a way that birds will not perch there and so they won't be soiled by bird poo. It really is clean, well designed, well managed, and definitely worth a visit. Bonus: it is free.

Peace in the City. Very easy to get to via the Diamond Hill Station. From there it is a 5-10 min walk. The street view on google maps is a great resource to familiarize with what the walk will look like for you. Nan Lian Garden is right next door too. Entrance to both places is free. Photography is mostly prohibited at Chi Lin Nunnery. Trip time can be from 1 hr to a couple hours, its really self paced and flexible to your schedule. opens at 7 am.

Amazingly peaceful amongst the bustle of the city. The Chi Lin Nunnery is beautiful and gives you a moments respite from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The gardens across the road are well kept and very beautiful, but as you step into the Nunnery it is as if the rest of the world disappears.You must be respectful to the monks and Nuns of course, but they are happy for you to wonder round, enjoy the water garden and for you to take in each of the buddha rooms, and for you to worship should you wish to. I felt totally at peace while I was there, and as it is set on a hill, the views are pretty stunning too.I think it may have been one of my favourite places visited in Hong Kong.

Nice oasis in the middle of Hong Kong. Extremely nice place - four beautiful pools containing lotus flowers of different colors, bonsai trees of all kind and at the moment a collection of fine stones. No entry fee, definitely worth a visit if you're in the surroundings. Plus, the nearby garden is fascinating.
Great Place to Visit. We went on Buddha's birthday so it was pretty busy but has great gardens and is interesting to see. Dont get to see the nuns but is easy to get to on the metro line.

Tranquil. We took a metro and got off at Diamond Hill MTR Station on the Kwun Tong line, from there we turned left and we followed the signs to the gardens which was about 100 meters away. The nunnery is very tranquil and well maintained away from huge crowds and noise of Hong Kong. There are two vegetarian restaurants here. We also saw the Nan Lian Gardens by the bridge and there is no entrance fee here.

Peaceful and worth a visit.. We visited in the evening and it was a really nice walk around, then it turned dark and the lights came on and we enjoyed a hour just sat around in the nice warm weather being surrounded by this nice place with nice lights.

Absolutely stunning.... Not being one of a particularly religious persuasion, I was a little wary of taking a trip out to see a nunnery.The site is easily accessible, a mere 20/25 minutes from TST by metro. Simply take the line to Diamond Hil, exit to the left and the nunnery is best approached after strolling round the gardens. A great place to escape the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, enjoy the peace and tranquility. Be sure though to show respect to those wishing to pray.
Breath taking. Many things to see. Nice walk and pictures are welcomed but seldom. Plan on at least 90 minutes. Easy to locate and get around
Serenity.. I really got a sense of peace and serenity when visiting the nunnery. The gardens and monuments were beautiful.

Take a break from the hustle and bustle of HK. If you are looking for the HK noise and crowds this is not for you.It is a Buddhist nunnery, so very tranquil, it was designed for pray. I personnelly find it very relaxing as there are buddhist chanting played softly in the back ground.The nunnery is split into 2 part, the nunnary and the gardens (seperated by the road). The gardens contain 2 vegetarian resturants/cafe, the more expensive is situated by the waterfall. It is a real tonic from the noise of HK.Luckly the nunnary has not been found by the mainland chinese so it is still very peaceful, but if you want to see a lively temple, Won tai Sin just 1 stop before Diamand Hill, it is rammed with mainlanders and has fortune tellers and many stall selling buddhist tack, I recommend you visit both for the comparison. Both enjoyable but in different ways.

Blissed out ine the city. Staying at the Novotel Century in Wanchai we used the MTR to get there which was simplicity itself. The MTR is clean, bright, so easy to navigate and almost deserted outside of the rush hour. The nunnery is an amazing replica of a Tang dynasty Bhuddist nunnery and is built totally from hardwoods using no nails or glues only joints in the timber. Situated in the Diamond Hill area of this most bustling of cities the calm that emanates from the places feels almost physical.We loved the quiet, the trees and flowers, the lotus ponds and photo opportunities (but do not use the camera inside the halls -very bad karma). The nunnery is a working temple and a charity so we bought some keepsakes and were given small gifts and a CD of chants recorded at the temple. A most wonderful experience
beautiful oasis in the city. Great classic wooden building. Beautiful huge buddhas. Loved it. Very peaceful and traditional. Went early and it was not crowded howe er was getting busier as we left.

Serene Place. Brilliant, but one has to be in a mood for it... Quiet, serene, Awesome Veg Food. Closes early, o check local times before you go. Worth a visit if you want to get away from busy Hong Kong

Small but perfectly formed. To get here you need to take the MTR to Diamond Hill, where you emerge into the inevitable shopping mall, the Hollywood Plaza in this case. But, a short walk under the (also inevitable) concrete flyover you can access the grounds of this nunnery. Inside there are many traditional buildings culminating in the main temple. There are also,exhibits on the finer points of Chinese wooden building construction if you're interested, and various displays of polished weathered rocks, which you can stroke and sit upon. In the centre is a golden temple set in a lake with red bridges either side. It's very picturesque, especially if you squint so as to block out the wall of shabby tenement buildings which, again inevitably for Hong Kong, surround the site. It all looks old, but I think is actually quite new. It has a bit of a Disneyfied air to it, but it is a genuine spiritual Bhuddist site, which brings with it an air of calm and contemplation. Worth a visit if you've already ticked off the main tourist attractions, or if you just want to escape the Hong Kong rat race.
Peaceful Oasis. This was a real gem. It was so quiet and peaceful to walk around the gardens in such a busy city. Particularly loved the water features.

Huh?. 744 out of 803 reviews give this 4 or 5 stars.Why? Is it to justify the time spent on what was really a disappointment , or because if everyone else thought it was good, it must be? This is the #3 attraction in Hong Kong?Are you kidding me?Had this on my list due to the overwhelmingly positive reviews.It's nice, but as another reviewer mentioned, there just isn't much to see. As an attraction - not worth the time and effort. Very few tourists around too, which should tell you something.

Beautiful gardens. We've been to a lot of temples, etc in China, Japan and Vietnam and this one was as good as any.The temple itself didn't seem to have a lot of 'feeling' though. There were guards on every corner, watching, waiting.... for what I'm not sure, but it was a little disconcerting.The gardens were beautiful and massive. Definitely worth a visit.We went to try the restaurant but it was quite busy and the menu didn't look all that interesting - and we eat vegetarian.We were one of the only people in the pottery exhibit (it's been extended until end of April or May, I think) and that was worth the $1 Australian entry visit - even just for the air conditioning and respite from the heat!
Chi Lin Nummery. Peaceful and Tranquil away from the busy city. Well worth taking the time to visit. One of the best Buddhist Temples I have seen.
What an awe inspiring day. Chi Lin Nunnery and the Gardens next door is a stunning escape from the busy city. No stalls, and throngs of people. The gardens were magnificent in the springtime
Oasis of calm.... Nice little spot in the city. You get a very strange sense of the contrast between religious temple and crazy city here.

Peaceful haven for weary souls. This nunnery is a beautiful way to step outside of the bustling rush of life in Hong Kong, & to just take a moment to refuel your senses. It's a beautiful reminder of the sensibility of the buddhist religion, & a lovely place to spend some quiet time in your own company. Thank you for allowing us to share this serenity for just a brief interlude during our holiday.

A beautiful and tranquil spot in the middle of bustly Hong Kong. It was so nice taking a break from the crowds and noise of Hong Kong. This park is so Chinese and beautifully maintained. We snapped lots of photos as everywhere we walked was picture perfect. It really takes you back in time to an era that life was less hectic and less tainted with Western culture. It is a must to visit together with the nunnery across the bridge.

A 'Park' with a difference!. We actually went there for a special evening meal but I had been there a couple of times during the day as well.What a lovely place even to just walk around taking pictures. They really have spent a lot of time getting everything looking pretty. The vegetarian foods are nice (even for a hard-core meat-eater like me!). The only trouble during the day is you may run into coaches of tourists and the place can get rather noisy/chaotic. So if you do go, go on a weekday, avoid during the lunch hour. If you do want lunch, make sure you make a reservation in advance.

Nice scenery and feel peaceful in there. Public park right at Diamond Hill MTR. Entrance is free. Worth a visit. Exhibition of Chinese timber architecture, rocks and potted plants. Chi Lin Nunnery right next to the park. Statue of Sakyamuni Buddha and bodhisattvas.
Beautiful gardens, peaceful site. This is a unique place - beautiful gardens, spacious buildings. A place for quiet and reflective contemplation.

beautiful and serene. This is a must if you visit Hong Kong. The nunnery and gardens are amazingly beautiful. This is a great place to take a nice stroll and take some amazing photos. It is easily accessible from the Diamond Hill MTR station.

Exquisite. Not 'lived in' like the Tin Hau Temple but this is an experience you should not miss either. A beautiful and serene place preserved for chinese and visitors alike and surrounded by tower blocks on all sides. We did not have enough time to appreciate it or the Gardens in full so be sure to allow time. Exquisite all the same.

Immaculate wood architecture. Chi Lin Nunnery is directly connected to (and often mistakenly photo'd as) Nan Lian Gardens, but is a separate location. The nunnery is made of fine dark wood and the interior grounds are immaculately kept with beautiful plant and rock displays for you to enjoy. There are four large statues inside, three for the guardians and one large Buddha - all are brilliant gold and in good condition, however you not allowed to photo them. Extremely peaceful.

Beautiful. The Chi Lin Nunnery is an extraordinary oasis of peace surrounded by Kowloon apartment blocks. I'm hesitant to leave a glowing review because one of its attractions was the scarcity of visitors but it was such a beautiful, tranquil place.

Calm and Serene. We took the underground out to visit the Nunnery and found the area to be extremely relaxing and beautiful. We doubled up our visit there with a visit to the Nan Lian Gardens just across the road.

A beautiful oasis. Take some time from your busy stay and make your way to the peace and tranquility here. Last time we went it was raining, this time warm and humid but both times really special.A peaceful place and a great place to meditate and be thankful for being in Hong Kong.

A place you can find serenity amidst the hustle and bustle of the city. The buildings replicate the design from Tang Dynasty without a single nail. The garden opposite is beautifully designed and built. The whole place is well maintained and free for visitors. You will find zen in the temple area. There is a restaurant there serving vegetarian food. It is one of the best in Hong Kong. There is a tea house where you can easily spend hours quietly, getting your inner peace.
Must do. We've been here 6 years and only just been now. Fabulous site - peaceful, interesting and connected to Nan Lian Gardens which are worth a look too. Definitely take visitors here in future.

You can skip it. If you are going to other Asian countries to see Temples with Asian character, it is advisable to skip the Chi Lin Nunnery. Too small, too simple and too young for a temple. It is out of the main tourist area, and if you are interested in the domestic life there is a medium size shopping mall close by.
Peaceful. Spend your time to see the garden, the temple and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. Worth to spend an hour.

Observe silence. Spent about an hour. Remember not to take any photos of the deities statues as notified by the signs around. They have a souvenir shop located downstairs. Take note of a small signage near the left side (viewing from the nunnery entrance) of the temple. They have everything from sutras,charms,jades,buddha statues etc.
Tranquil oasis. Lovely and peaceful and not overwhelmed with bus fulls of tourists like so many other temples in Hong Kong
City Oasis. A peaceful Tang dynasty style garden and temple. Exquisite gardening and traditional Chinese architecture. Worth to spend an hour with free admission.

Lovely place in the heart of the city. This is a really peaceful oasis. It's nice to have a wander around. However you are not allowed to sit anywhere (I was told of by security) which seems a bit strange.
Free entrance and good for making merit, nice temple. It is a great temple..and can walk from the diamond hills station only 5 minutes.. The are many kinds of Buddha inside..good for praying..

Peaceful land within a busy city. This is a beautiful place to visit within a busy city. Easy access next to the MTR station. Free admission and not crowded. The garden is well planted with Japanese styled architecture. A must visit!
