a must visit site. This is one of the most beautiful places i have ever visited quiet and sureal,the gardens below also are a must found it very easy to find using the metro from kowloon they have a small cafe/eatery on site with delicious food and very reasonable prices

Scenic Beauty. Although the nunnery itself is relatively recent, it is simply but elegantly done. Understated in wood, it is a peaceful respite with a beautiful garden of immaculately tailored trees. Not packed with tourists like the nearby Sik Sik Temple, it is a very pleasant stop worth about 30-40 minutes of taking in the scenery. Very near Diamond Hill MTR.

Tranquility & Old World Feel. Truly an oasis nestled within a modern urban environment. We allotted an hour for our mid-afternoon meander and ended up staying over 2 hours...everyone in our party enjoyed the heritage, culture and architecture...and felt a peacefulness in the surroundings. I think it's worth a visit for any tourist.
Beautiful. One of my favorite places in HK. Best to go just before dusk so you can see this place in daylight and at night - very serene and beautiful
An oasis of calm.. The chi lin nunnery is a bit of a ways out from the cbd, but walking through is very peaceful, a welcome oasis of calm in bustling hong kong.

far from downtown but you should go there. Temple is far from downtown but you should go there.
Some areas you can't take picture. but you would like walking and seeing the temple.

A beautiful peaceful oasis in the middle of an urban jungle. A peaceful retreat but a little distance from TST. The Nian Liam Garden follow on and are next to it. Opposite Hollywood Plaza for a break and coffee when you have finished.

Well worth the effort to visit. It is a sanctuary of peace and calm in a very busy city. Just stroll around and enjoy the tranquillity, the architecture and the gentle music. It is hard not to be calm here. It is a bit of a trek by MTR, but well worth the effort.

Calm and relaxing walk around the premises. We visited the nunnery and the park across the road, this place is very calm and relaxing as soon as you enter the park. The plantations and galleries for the bonsai trees and rocks are worth a visit.
Great place, worth a visit.

Amazing architecture. One of our best finds in HK. Amazing architecture beautifully set in a serene place. It was quite hard to believe that is was just several meters away from the busy Diamond Hill Station and the Hollywood Plaza Mall. We first visited the Nan Lian Garden and then crossed the street after the exit to look for the monastery. It was just later on that we realized that the garden (Na Lian) and the monastery (Chi Lin Nunnery) is connected by a footbridge whose stairs are just outside of the exit of the garden. A must-visit!

STUNNING!. This is an amazing place to visit. Try to bend your mind around the fact that all the structures in place were created without using a single nail. Mind blown. Kids marveled. The gardens are a site to behold.

Serenity. located near diamond hill station, this place is a must for those who are into temple/ancient buildings and away from the busy cities. Some structures have resemblance to ancient japan though, still this place should be on the list. One plus is of seeing the nan lian garden in the vicinity. So peaceful and serene.

Wow... . The nunnery is absolutely amazing. It's hard to believe that it is located within Hong Kong. The first thought upon seeing the nunnery was whether I was within the walls of the palace??? The buildings/temples together with the plants and water displays resembles that of the royal gardens within the royal palace (from what I see on TV), but on a smaller scale. It was truly an uplifting experience. It was hard to believe that a busy shopping mall was only 5 minutes away and busy roads were just next to the nunnery. Despite this, there was a relaxing atmosphere. I would recommend a visit here, which only takes up to an hour of your time. But bare in mind, the location itself is not that big. However, what was on offer was turely amazing.

Beautiful!. Combined with the "attached" garden, this has to be among the top half dozen places you MUST visit while in Hong Kong. It is tranquil, with plants and water bodies and a respite from the hustle of the nearby streets. There were not many places to sit however and I thought there was a bit too much cement. I preferred the garden to the nunnery, but this was still worth a visit.
Am I in HK?. The design of the building and the court yard, make me think that I am in Japan. Surprise to see this place in HK. Nice place to take a walk, peaceful, and very spiritual feeling.

Peace and tranquility. The nunnery is located on the main road and only a stones throw away from the shopping centre, so it's a real surprise that you forget all this once through the doors.The main courtyard is a haven of peace and tranquility and the numerous alters each offer a different view of the deity. You can explore to your hearts content and also be inspired by the fantastic views to the mountains in the background. You cannot ignore the high rise buildings in the view, but the juxtaposition of the old and the new is itself quite a sight.A walk over the footbridge nod you arrive at the connected gardens the main feature of which is a large red pagoda set in the middle of a small lake.the gardens are I immaculately looked after with not a leaf out of place.If you want and escape from the busy hustle and bustle of the town centre this is a great place to pass some time.Don't forget the camera though or you'll regret it.
Beautiful Gardens. March is not the most beautiful time to visit the gardens but it was still beautiful. Just beginning to blossom.
Grotesque statues - rather boring. This was a disappointment. Much better to see the ancient relics such as ancestoral halls, study rooms, and temples in the New Territories.

Combined review with Nan Lian Garden. In a word--MARVELOUS, in capital letters.Getting there is easy. MTR (subway) is probably the easiest. Get on Kwun Tong Line (end station is Tiu Keng Leng), get off on Diamond Hill station. No need to get into the Hollywood Plaza (mall)--NanLian Garden is just couple minutes walk. Then after finishing Chi Lin Nunnery is right on the other side.For food, there is Chi Lin Vegetarian inside the Garden.The whole entire area is free of charge and great escape from the city life. With all the different type of trees, rocks, landscaping and all the traditional buildings (built in Tang Dynasty style with not one single nail being used), it is definitely a MUST SEE (few hours at least) while in Hong Kong.

An eye opener of beauty, tranquility and architecture. This is a must go place. I suggest if you are in Hong Kong for a few days, visit this place on the second or third day. That way you can appreciate the tranquility this place offers in busy Hong Kong. It is conveniently located at Daimond Hill MTR station (take Exit C). The complex is built in the Tang Dynasty style and there are so many beautiful plants to see. This visit certainly relaxes and refresh the mind and body. As the nunnery is next to the famous Nan Lian Garden and also has a vegetarian restaurant, it is truly worth visiting this place. I spent more than 3 hours here and took lots of pictures. Oh, if you want some noise and city life after the visit, there's a huge mall next to this place called the Hollywood Mall.
Must see!. This place was breath-taking. Not expensive. Their cafe sells good stuff. Very clean bathroom, and the guards will help you where to go..

Beautiful. Beautiful place to visit, tranquility in the madness of hong kong. Easy to get to by MTR Diamond Hill station and a two mins walk. This place is still a quiet place to come and see the wonderful buildings and gardens it has to hold.

beautiful peace in a chaotic city. I loved the temple, specially as is a great contrast to its surrounding full of tall buildings. I went during the midweek so the place was practically empty and I was able to appreciate it even better.

Lovely Buddhist temple but without pretense. Attached by a bridge to the unmissable Nan Lian Garden this nunnery evokes reverence. No photos allowed of interiors but enjoy the peaceful nature of large potted bonzai, ponds, incense, Buddhist shrines, and gardens.
Beautiful, tranquil place. Lovely setting to escape and contemplate your life plan...... very relaxing and so close to the busy MTR and hustle of HK. This is a lovely oasis to visit.

Bliss. An oasis which is so easy to get to via MTR, you must take one more stop to do this (Diamond Hill) if you are visiting the Sik Sik Yuen Tai Sin temple. It is a beautiful and serene teak Buddhist nunnery in lovely gardens. There is a wonderful museum of exquisitely interesting rocks. Eat at the quiet, understated and excellent vegetarian restaurant within the gardens, the afternoon tea is delicious. When you leave, you'll be ready again for Hong Kong!

Exquisite Gardens. Off the Diamond MTR station, easy to find. Wonderful gardens and buildings to visit. Be mindful of the temple rules as it is a "working" temple.A little bit of calm and quiet in the big city.

An example of modern and ancient harmony. Tucked away neatly in the corner of a busy, bustling global city, the Chi Lin Nunnery is the perfect example of the harmony between ancient and modern worlds. Away from the traffic jams and the tensions of worklife, the nunnery provided much needed spiritual and mental peace to the visitors. The moment visitors enter this nunnery, all the sounds of the busy life vanish from one's ears and mind. The beautiful sound of clean water softly hitting the nunnery's pools, the calm faces of the various bodhisattvas and the impressive bonasai works immediately capture your attention. The calm, pensive faces of the Bodhisattvas fill you with a world of optimism and positive energy, driving away all your tensions and worries from your mind.If you are into cultural tourism, you can kneel down on the specially provided prayer cushions and offer a prayer to the great Buddhas; and if you are not, you can enjoy the lovely traditional gardens by clicking your photos with them as your background.A single disappointment is that you won't be allowed to click the pictures of the Buddhas and the bodhisattvas at the altars. To the avid collectors, there is a wonderful souvenir shop onto the right side of the nunnery, as soon as you enter the premises. Though one has to be careful about its pricing.
Peaceful. A great escape from central Hong Kong but nearby the MTR so you can just wander around, grab a bite to eat, relax and enjoy the scenery.

Peaceful and relaxing.. It was an amazing experience to be at peace with myself in this beautiful temple. It is a great place to just wander around and to just let your mind run free. This temple is very easy to get to by using the MTR subway. It is definitely worth the visit if you visit Hong Kong.
Relax. This place is really very relaxing and We can have a good walk and nice scenery. This is the best place for relaxing with family.

A must do in Hong Kong. We nearly didn,t go. Hong Kong was cold and wet and a mall seemed far more attractive. So pleased we made the effort. The MTR from Causeway bay was fast and efficient and the nunnery easy to find and free to get into. So well kept and beautifully presented. I would go back again just to wander around the tranquil gardens.

Serene experience. How extraordinary to find such a beautiful and peaceful place literally in the midst of the Hong Kong high rise buildings and freeways. It was a truly wonderful experience to explore the gardens and the nunnery. Highly recommend this and so easy to get to from the metro.

Peace and tranquility. This is a lovely little spot where you can actually hear yourself think....something not easy to achieve in Hong Kong. If you are in need of a bit of quiet time then this is the place to visit!

Seek for peace of mind, go to Chi Lin Nunnery. At the first step I made into Chi Lin Nunnery, they welcome me with smooth breeze.I felt my load had been lifted. This place is quite quiet if compare with some other nunnery or Chinese temple.Their big pond, their big wall stone and their wooden building feels me so calm.Try visit this place, I love it and you will love it.As they have choices for me to only back to April 2013,I'm gonna tell you, I visited this place in 2011.

just heaven, once you reach it. We stayed in Mira hotelbwhich is on the Tsim Sa TsuiIt took quite long to get to Diamond hill, but worth it!Sometimes i felt like it cannot be real. Quite big temple complex, with beautiful bonsai s in its yard.Cross the road by a bridge you get into Nan Lian Garden. Be prepared, taxi cost 80-85 HKD, taxi hopp in point is just a little walk from thr corner, close to the bus stop.Metro dark green line takes you there.
The Best Nunery in Far East. The Chi Lin garden have the most valuable pine trees in the Region. The Great Temple is most elegant and you may feel the atmosphere here.
Tranquility at it's best. A beautiful, peaceful oasis in the middle of hectic Hong Kong. Take your time and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and amazing Buddha statues
Peaceful spot in the city. Beautiful garden and worth the trip. Close to the MTR and the gardens (don't remember the name) across from the Chi Lin are also must.

Peaceful Haven. A highlight of our trip. A beautiful garden and temple in the heart of the city. The architecture display in the adjoiningg really helped draw attention to the details of the temple and the amazing workmanship. The park is easy to find- yards from Diamond Hill MTS station

Beautiful sanctuary in the middle of a bustling city!. The Chi Lin Nunnery is a must see if you have a few days in HK. It is a bit out of the way from central HK but very easy to get to from the Metro or the bus. As soon as you enter the Nunnery all of the noise and distractions of the bustling city at its doorstep disappear! It is almost startling to see the skyscrapers in the distance because for a brief moment you forget that they are there. Everything is pristine and neatly manicured and there are several beautiful Buddha statutes to view. If you are lucky you might even catch a glimpse of a Buddhist Nun strolling the grounds!

Place of calm in the middle of the city. I loved the afternoon I spent here, just enjoying the gardens and relaxing. Absolutely beautiful. There is no admission, you can do it in a hour and half or spend three-four hours as I did. I also went to the tea house and had a tea set, very zen. There is a mall across the street if you need to jump back into the craziness. Great picture taking opportunities here.

Tranquil Place. Very interesting wooden construction in peaceful surroundings and across the road from the beautiful Nan Jian gardens. Make it part of your trip, combined with the Wong Tai Sin temple. They're all within walking distance.

Oasis. Such a beautiful place! It is a must to take the time and visit both the nunnery and the Nan Lian gardens. Very well kept and clean with good vibes all around. It is very easy to reach it by MTR, so no excuses not to go. :)

I love this place. Really beautiful and peaceful garden in this caothic city. The Tang style temple is very impressive. There is a vegetarian restaurant in the garden. We managed to get a table for 1 hour and 30 min as the restaurant was fully booked so if you want to try maybe book in advanced.

Serenity amid the hustle and bustle. A calm and tranquil place where you can wander around and forget that a different world is taking place just outside the walls. As well as visiting the various shrines to Buddha it is worth your while to view the exhibition of precious stones on display around the inside wall of the inner courtyard.

Nunnery and Gardens together make great morning out. Easy to reach by train the Chin Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens should be seen together. They are located next to each other and easily accessed by the MTR Diamond Hill station. A great way to spend a morning.

Quiet harmony in a frantic city. Felt like a different world from the rest of the city. In a quiet tranquil setting it was lovely to visit this place and appreciate the peace. Bonsai trees and lotus ponds add to the atmosphere. Lovely golden statues in the temples and bowls of orchids.
Enjoyed getting away from the noise and busy city life.

A haven of tranquility in a busy city. We visited the Nunnery without any great expectations and left with wonderful images of a era that is has unfortunately gone. The gardens were a treat and the inner building truely impressive. Certainly worth a visit.
Peace within the City!. Plenty of bonsai trees in the gardens. Nice monasteries to visit. Has that healing energy and a joy to visit. Good for a destress from everyday life.
Lovely peacefull temple. Such a lovely peacefull place in a busy city. The statues are of an amazing beauty and so are the buildings.

Tranquility. Easy to find, a short signposted walk from Diamond Hill MTR. This is a very calming place that slows you down . The gardens are also very worth your time. Take half a day to enjoy a stroll around and the HK backdrop to the nunnery. And it's all free. Don't worry, as always there's a shopping mall attached to Diamond Hill if all that peaceful calm brings on the urge to shop.....

Serene, Tranquil. I planned for this place beacuse of the reviews I read about it on Trip advisor. I must say every word written about is totally true. It was an amazing expereince to be there in the midst of hills, peaceful atmosphere and not to forget the soul soothing instrumental music. Me and my husband both were kinda lost in the serenity of the place. So this is definately a must visit on HL trip.How to get there : if you are coming from Causeway bay, walk down to Henessey road and take bus no 671. Last stop is Diamond hill. When you will get down at the Hill you will see park Plaza, just keep walking around the plaza for 500m and you will find the nunnery.

Cultural bliss. The nunnery really shows some of the gorgeous architecture from Chinese culture. You feel as if you have gone back in time. Its tranquil and peaceful there even though it is surrounded by a busy city.

tranquility asian garden in Hong kong. I have been to HK so many times, somehow miss this place. If you (anyone) like asian garden/bonsai. This is really the good place. FREE. But don't come on sunday, someone else said, there are a lot of those-working-maid in HK and sunday, they will sit in the garden. Make it crowded. Today = Monday, I went very nice, just spend 1.5 hours is good enough to take some photo. Though it is really hot in summer(in HK). Best time is to go in the "fall" and beginning of spring(before fog rolling in).

Slap bang next to Diamond Hill MTR, nice respite from Hong Kong. We went here as the other tripadvisor reviews had said it was worth it and they were right. It s easy to get to on the green line MTR. You literally walk out of the shopping centre, underneath a flyover and go left. There are some traffic lights ahead and you can go right into a garden - I think it was called Nan Lian garden - and then walk to the left in there and it takes you the scenic route to the temple rather than along the main road. There is a pond and it really is peaceful after the hassle of Kowloon. It is free and something a bit different to do after all the markets and malls of Kowloon.

Very quiet, beautiful, must see!. It's close to Diamond Hill MTR Station, so easy to get there.The place is really clean and quiet.No admission fee.I can spend hours here!Must come back again.A paradise in the Hong Kong crowded buildings.

Peaceful and Serene. Beautiful, tranquil, spiritual. Look up and you see sky scrapers in all directions. So do not look up and enjoy this amazing oasis in one of, if not the most densely populated cities in the world. In the last two weeks we have been to many temples from Singapore to Hong Kong. None of them are average, they are all unique and special.

Lovely, Quiet Place. Easy to get to from the MTR (Diamond Hill Station) and no fee to enter are just two more reasons to visit this lovely place. It's especially appealing if you're looking for a change of scenery from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.Located right next to the Nan Lian Gardens, Chi Lin Nunnery is a continuation of the wonderful tranquility and beauty found there. The Buddhist statues which surround the perimeter are quite transfixing to gaze on, as is the center courtyard, which features a large bronze censer in the middle, and fountains. When we visited there was no crowd to speak of and we were able to just wander around at our leisure and take it all in. I told my husband that if I lived in the area I think I would come every day (and I'm sure there are many who do just that). It's a lovely, peaceful haven and one you should definitely make the time for when visiting Hong Kong.

Peaceful!. Amazing place.. Esp d beautiful buddhist statues and d serene landscape surrounding it... the best place to get away from all the hustle and bustle of the city.. Esp if your want to spend some quality time alone.. And easily accessible too.. Recmded for the stressed out traveller looking for some peace... Plus the nan lian gardens are a bonus...
very peaceful.. this was okay if you like to see a buddhist temple. the vegetarian resturant was serving yummy foods that wasnt to expensive. i enjoyed the nan lian garden more though.
Beautiful Bonsai's. Nice to have a walk around and it is for free. Situated just outside the Diamond Hill MTR. Very peaceful and nice ponds with lily's and fish.

Tranquil and Beautiful. This is a peaceful, beautiful area of the city and worth a visit from all the hustle and bustle! It is nice to take your time here in a city where everything seems very rushed. The temples were breathtaking, and the artifacts you could see were amazing.I enjoyed just sitting here for a couple of hours on a great afternoon.

Not to be missed. Easy to reach by the metro, this place was a highlight for us. The setting within the gardens is delightful, with its temple, lakes and waterfalls. The nunnery itself is also worth your time, with the gift shop to browse in also for souvenirs. We were there around Chinese New year and were delighted to receive CD's of chanting and calming music, and the little red envelopes containing a coin for good fortune........all free as gifts from the staff, together with sweets and good wishes. An absolutely delightful place.

A must visit site. Considering this area used to be the central hangout for the local gangs and drug users there has been an almost miraculous turnround to become an idyllic area with sculptured gardens. In the gardens you will find an ornate temple in the middle of a lake surrounded by waterfalls and tranquility. Take your time to meander round the gardens and soak in the atmosphere. Go hence then to the nunnery where there are excellent examples of artifacts relating to the Buddhist religion. Remember to show respect as it is a place of worship and contemplation with photography not being allowed inside. If you are visiting Hong Kong even for a short time drag yourself away from that shops and markets and enjoy some peace and serenity.

Chi Lin Nunnery. walking in from the hustle and bustle of the very busy street, into a calm peaceful, serene enviroment, lovley gardens, waterfalls, lots of seating areas just to sit and take stock or reflect

Garden oasis in busy city. Great for a stroll in new park designed in classic Chinese style adjacent to Nunnery. In the nunnery there is a small gift shop with several interesting items and souvenirs.

Peaceful Place !! Not too crowded. If you are planning for some place for praying. This one, for me, is a must-go temple besides Wong Tai Sin Temple.I got different feeling from other temples when I've been there. I feel the real peace and got my conscious back again after being chaos in the city. Besides, the architecture is different from ordinary Chinese temple. It is more like Japanese Style in my view.how to get there is so easy, just 5-10 min walk along the sign.

beautiful garden and architecture.. This place was one of the highlights of the trip to hongkong. Its connected to nan Lian garden. So start there and make ur way through to this nunnery. The architecture is just breath taking, well at least for me. This is the first time I'm seeing such architecture live and not in a kungfu movie.

Peace perfect peace. My wife and I felt completely at peace once entering this very beautiful and spiritual place.The place is here for people to come and pay their respects and pray to the Bodhisattvas, however quietly taking it all in would give anyone peace and enlightenment. This is not a tourist destination to sit or rush around snapping happily at all the sites, this is a place to turn the camera off take a deep breath and just take it all in.A real slice of paradise and a must if you are in Hong Kong. Lovely spot. I visited the place together with Nan Lian garden, which is just on the other side of the road.The nunnery was rather busy because of the chinese new year, but I highly appreciated the architecture, the beautiful ponds and the pavilions where the people was paying tribute to the bodhisattvas, in particular the one on the left, which is dedicated to Avalokitesvara.In the back of the main pavilion there were stalls selling handmade crafts done at the nunnery, but the prices were kinda too high.It is definitely a site worth visiting though.

Amazing place (to be reviewed together with Nan Lian Garden). I am totally amaze to find this tranquil and serene place in the middle of the concrete jungle of HK city! Firstly, the attraction is that the entrance is free. You will see a lot of old folks either on tour or some doing exercises in this beautiful garden. The beautiful bonzais in the garden are a joy to look at. There is a cafe and souvenier shop in the grounds. Also you will find a vegetarian restaurant (check opening times). The menu is available outside the restaurant and I believe it is HKD105 per pax for 1 set vegetarian meal.After wondering around the gardens, we walked over to the nunnery. You have to cross like a bridge to get to the nunnery. This is a massive building and the different types of buddhas and kuan yin statues are really stunning! I have seen many in different countries and must say I was impressed. Those devout Buddhist can pay their respect and burn some incense if they choose to. Very huge courtyard too. I have been to HK numerous times but am surprised I have not visitied this awesome place before. How to get there: Take the MTR and exit at Diamond Hill station. The MTR is at the shopping center called Plaza Hollywood. This is a cool shopping place and also plenty of food joints. Follow the exit signs and exit at Exit C2. You will be able to see signages to Nan Lian Garden. It is about 5 mins away. The garden will lead you to Chi Lin Nunnery so you should enter this garden. Both are worth the journey there and if you get bored, can detour back to Plaza Hollywood for some shopping and food.

Serenity in the heart of a bustling city. We absolutely loved the nunnery as well as the Nan Lian Garden. It was nicely planned and well maintained. Was completely taken by the serenity it offered and we immediately fell in love with the environment. Ample beautiful places for nice photos. So better make sure you have a fully charged camera and ample memory card.

A must see. We got there as they were closing up, so were unable to go through to what i presume is the main building, but even through the front gate to the gardens, it was just mesmerising. Bonsais. The stunning architecture of the building. The vibe. Its just a spectacular place to wonder around.

Great haf day destination. I have visited twice to date. It's accessible by metro. When you get off at Hollywood Plaza ( shopping mall). Head up the sidewalk outside the mall and cross to the right at the top of the slight incline where the cross walk is. Visit the nunnery first. Last time I was there they had beautiful bonsai trees on display near the lotus pools. The Buddhas are nicely displayed and if you happen to visit on a festival or public holiday, there may be volunteers handing out good fortunes. The have a really nice souvenir shop where I have purchased a bracelet on each visit. After visiting the nunnery, walk across the elevated walkway to enter the Nan Lian Garden. This is my favorite part of the visit. The garden has lovel vistas, gardens, a small art gallery, a restaurant, a rock display and even a water wheel. What is even more amazing is the contrast of peaceful garden to towering skyscrapers and bustling Hong Kong roadways surrounding it. If you are thirsty after a couple hours wandering the nunnery and gardens stop in Hollywood mall. There is a Starbucks on the upper level near the atrium.

Serene. A wonderful place to visit, for some peace and serenity among the bustle that is HK. Linked to beautiful Nan Lian Gardens, was a quiet unknown gem, but getting much more popular. Well worth a visit
Great place. Beautifull gardens and temples, this is a place you should not miss. Very calm. The tea place is very traditional, love it.

Calm in the Chaos. A very relaxing place to spend some time just wandering around. The gardens are beautiful and the space is very tranquil. The architecture at the Nunnery and the surrounding gardens was interesting and a contrast to the high rise buildings in the surrounding space. A great place to recharge and enjoy some quiet in the city.

Remains one of our favourite places to visit in Hong Kong. The Chi Lin Nunnery is a Buddhist complex that remains one of our personal favorite places to visit in Hong Kong. It is one of the most beautiful and well-maintained attractions in the city and it is free to visit. We recommend seeing the Chi Lin Nunnery together with the adjacent Nan Lian Gardens. The Nunnery was originally built in 1934 and was opened to the public in 1990 after being renovated in Tang Dynasty style. Since that time, it has become a very popular place to visit for Hong Kong residents and visitors. We usually approach the Nunnery from the Nan Lian Gardens, where you cross a decorative bridge to the main entrance. You first enter a lovely and elegant Lotus Pond Garden (open 7.00am - 7.00pm), featuring a courtyard with four small ponds, various shrines and statues, manicured bonsai and other trees. The landscaping seen throughout this courtyard (as well as the second inner-courtyard that you will see next) is just lovely and helps create a tranquil environment when visiting Chi Lin Nunnery. Towards the back of the Lotus Pond Gardens, you will approach steps leading you to the entrance to the second courtyard (open 9.30am - 4.30pm), which includes a mentioned landscaped courtyard, surrounded by various Halls of worship. Each hall features wooden figures or gilded statues of various manifestations of Buddha. The highlight for us is the Main Hall found towards the back of this courtyard, featuring five gilded statues, three of Buddha and two of his attending disciples. There are information signs next to each of the Halls to help explain what you are seeing. There are bathroom facilities and opportunities to buy souvenirs at the Chi Lin Nunnery. Another way to support the nunnery is to dine at the Chi Lin Vegetarian restaurant located in the back of the Nan Lian Gardens. All restaurant proceeds go towards conservation and management of the gardens. Tip: We enjoy making visits during the Chinese New Year period as the nunnery is much less manic compared to other temples that we like in Hong Kong. Many of the landscaped trees are in bloom this time of year as well. Tip: Photography is allowed in the courtyard areas of Chi Lin Nunnery. However, it is not allowed in the Halls and you are asked to not take pictures of the Buddha statues as well.

Not to be missed. Beautiful and serene-a must do if you visit the Hong Kong area. Whimsical manicured plants, water gardens, lovely architecture and a very high caliber sit down vegetarian Restaurant within the immaculate grounds. Relax stroll and enjoy one of the prettiest places anywhere.

Peace amidst the chaos..... Beautiful and very interesting to visit. Great attention to detail with the Lotus Garden and layout of the building. The golden gods were just amazing and some of them were enormous. Quiet reflection and peace surrounded this environment. Well worth a vist.

A haven in such a massive, busy city. The nunnery and gardens beside it were the highlight of my trip to Hong Kong. Peaceful and stunning. Easy to find from the train, it is a few minute walk from the stations with signs leading the way.
Specially for Buddhists. Nice place to visit. More interesting if you are a buddhist as it is a practisisng temple. Do spend a couple of hours in the adjacent gardens.

Hidden Gem. You won't usually find throngs of tourists in this serene and beautiful oasis surrounded by high rises. One of the few things in Hong Kong that is completely free!Take the MTR to the Diamond Hill Station and follow the signs as you exit. The nunnery and gardens are a 2-3 minute walk. The nunnery and temple buildings are on the north side of Fung Tak Road. Although the buildings are only about 25 years old, they are constructed in the traditional Tang style and built without nails. The real beauty here though are the Nan Lian Gardens across the pedestrian bridge. There's no shortage of beautiful spots for photos so bring an extra memory card!As you walk through the gardens, stop at the vegetarian restaurant under the waterfall. The food was excellent and staff was very accommodating.

Speechless. Amazing and beautiful serene garden. A complex of nunnery, temple, museums, snack bar, and vegetarian restaurant. They play a peaceful meditation music throughout the garden which created by the monks. Clear mountain like water flows and falls across the garden and gathered in the middle main pond where big Koi fishes live. This garden definitely will stop your clock ticking.

Spartan Meal. The restaurant is located in the Japanese garden which is beautiful.
The monastery meal is vegetarian which was great but a bit
too plain - no flavours.
The service was prompt but a little abrupt.
The cost was moderate.
Spend more time in the garden as it's the best feature.

A beautiful oasis in the heart of the city. This stunning garden and nunnery blew us away. It's a beautiful jewel right in the middle of the city, surrounded by roads and high-rises. The garden is amazing and kept in pristine condition by an army of gardeners. It's particularly impressive when you consider it was only built in 2006. The trees, the temples and the tranquil lake - not to mention the waterfall with a restaurant behind it - are simply breathtaking. And the nunnery itself is equally impressive.All in all, a place of tranquility that you simply wouldn't expect in the heart of a thriving city like Hong Kong.

Unexpected in HK. The Chi Lin Nunnery is very close to the MTR station, about 3 minutes of walk from Diamond Hill MTR station. It has a pond at the bottom and few shrines in it. The idols of Budhas and Bodhisatvas are a treat to watch. Just spend sometime in peace :)

Hidden treasure of Hong Kong. 700 year old monestary (though actually built 30 years ago) style, reproduced in exacting detail. it is a real living monastery/nunnery of buddhism. quite beautiful one of my favourite places in HK, and i take all friends and families there and they all love it for tranquility and history
Peace in a busy city. Gardens are beautiful and vegetarian cafe offers great food. Makes a wonderful change from the hustle & bustle.
very pretty and great view of the city. These gardens were lovely and the location of the Nunnery provided great views of the city. There is a nice tea room and a golden pagoda.

peacefull. AWESOMEit's very maintain free park in north Hong Kong, just drop at Diamond Hill MTR station and cross from Hollywood Plaza. we can enjoy the park with view gold Japanese style building, with huge pond and many fish. The plant, trees and flowers looking great.

A japanese look.. The nunnery is in a beautiful garden and set apart from the crowd, a short walk from the metro station. Unfortunately you cannot drink your sip of water or eat your banana on a bench, but go to the restaurant.

A walk in the park.... ..filled with the most beautiful of buildings, landscapes, shrubs and trees. Get there via the train to Diamond Hill station and it is a short walk along and across the street. The feeling of calm inside this area was amazing, seeing as there is a major fly-over nearby. Plenty of space to walk around in and not feel that there is too many people there. The trees and gardens were immaculate and the cleanliness of the general walkways was spotless. Would certainly recommended this place, if only for its calming experience.

Relaxing and manicured gardens in the heart of a urban setting. This is a fantastic afternoon trip fir a quiet and relaxing garden visit plus a cultural stop. Great for kids. Impeccably clean and kept- great backdrop of modernism. A must see.

Beautiful Tang-inspired Park. A lovely Tang-inspired park/nunnery located in a urban area. However once you stepped in, it's just all peace and quiet. The large expanse of the nunnery is quite amazing, considering it is built just next to/over a busy road. And it is not overflowing with tourists.

A serene place. A spiritual place where it is clean, quiet and serene.
Greenery and pond make it a beautiful place.
It is short walking distance from the Diamond Hill MTR. Cross opposite to Nan Lian Garden
Tranquil place. Very easy to get to on the MTR, a calm tranquil place with beautiful gardens. An interesting stone museum. No entry charge. Allow approximately 1hr to walk around nunnery & gardens.

Silence in a busy city. Peaceful, nice place to explore and easy acces by public transport it is nearby the subway station. You just have to cross a road,
The staff was very warm & helpful, by showing us around and giving time and energy explaining about the area and about exhibition that was there.
Tranquility in the midst of chaos. This "ancient temple" is actually just a few years old. It has a beautiful setting. As for the vegetarian restaurant, I would skip it.

A must to visit and the gardens as well. Spent New Years Day here. So peaceful even though lots of people as it was a public holiday in HK. Amazing that one of the best things we did in HK was free! It is so easy to find. Get off the MTR at Diamond Hill ...don't go up into the shopping center but turn right and follow the signs. Only a few minutes away..but like you stepped back in time to a different world.
Stillness in the centre of HK. The vegetarian restaurant behind the waterfall is worth a visit, and at 105 HK$ a bargain for a very filling meal

Another must in HK. The Chi Lin Nunnery is located just in front of the Nan Lian Garden (metro station Diamond Hill). Its beautiful dark wood buildings contrast with the granite of the rocks used for the bridge and fountains/ponds. Beautiful garden, with bonsai trees and dragon heads faucets. The whole complex is in great contrast with the modern towers you can see from there. Opens 7 AM to 7 PM. A relaxing spot in the hectic HK.

Beautiful Garden and Temple. This is a nice place to visit for Temple viewing. It has a very nice garden, lotus ponds, statues of Buddha. It is quiet. We even did a short meditation in the garden. You will get some good pictures from this place.
Nice old temple. The bonsai trees are awsome. Its quite funny to see from inside the temple and see the old building with the new apartment tower behind

Serene and very, very beautiful. We combined our visit here with the adjoining gardens and a MTR trip to Sha Tin to see the 10,000 Bhudda monastery. It is a quiet place of worship that welcomes visitors daily. If you have kids,remind them to hush a little! I am not Buddhist, but this place is a must see if you have time.
Beautiful garden away from the city.. Easy to get to and beautiful to walk around in. This place is a paradise in the heart of a bustling city.
Tranquilly. Fantastic gardens with a nunnery, Musuem and restaurant , within the hustle and bustle but you wouldn't believe how quite it is and it's gorgeous!!

Not on the usual tourist list but that is part of its charm!. We went here after visiting the Nan Lian gardens (also well worth a visit) and found it had a very peaceful atmosphere with beautiful buildings and ornate decorations. We were so glad we found this and found it very authentic and 'non-touristy.' A very memorable visit.

As lovely as everyone says. I saw this over the Christmas. The nunnery was beautiful and quite lovely. The architecture and sculpting of the gardens was quite visually enjoyable. It was surprising how they were able to make it so quiet and calm so close to a major highway.
Just a brief visit. Make sure you visit the park on the opposite side of the road and try the vegetarian restaurant. There's not much that much to see at Chi Lin Nunnery.

Thank you for suggesting this!. My husband and I combined a visit to the Sik Sik Yuen Wong Tai Sin Temple and the Nan Lian Garden in our trip to the nunnery. The temple is a colorful contrast to the surrounding high rises and the background of the hills. We went on a Tuesday morning and it was quite crowded. One of the big attractions was the bigger than life-sized zodiac animals that everyone (including us!) posed in front of for photos. After this we walked to the Nan Lian Garden where we were delighted by the beauty and tranquility of this well designed oasis in the midst of traffic-filled streets and a major highway. The nunnery is an extension of the garden. It's lovely lotus blossoms filled several ponds. We left feeling like enlightened tourists.

Visual Feast!. Easy to get to, and a visual delight to see! Very calming experience in a city of hustle and bustle! What made the experience better was that it was right next to the Nan Lian Gardens...which together made a pleasant day out!

A must visit of calm and tranquility. In the middle of a city of hussey and bustle is this nunnery of tranquility ,beautiful grounds and gardens and easy transport via MTR to get there .worth a visit to chill out !

Stunning. The setting of this beautiful nunnery and gardens surrounded by modern city skyscrapers and apt buildings is awesome. Take your time and your camera, so many photo ops! Got the walking guide from airport visitor center on arrival-this was her top recoomendation- and I was not disappointed.

beautiful. the Chi Lin Nunnery and the adjacent gardens were surprisingly outstanding given that our guidebooks did not give it a particularly glowing mention.The nunnery is beautiful and serene, but the garden was the real highlight. It is gorgeous and does not take that long to walk through it. 2 hours was plenty which made it the morning before were were supposed to fly out. Plus it is only a 5 minute walk from Diamond Hill station.
A peaceful quiet spot!. Bring your camera for great pics but also bring your minds to be stilled! Spot to eat vegetarian food as well, come and enjoy!
Peaceful, relaxing. The nunnery and gardens at Nan Lian are lovely. We enjoyed a quiet stroll and the opportunity to appreciate the garden's architecture.
Loved it. Just a beautiful place to go. Very serene with water and music gently playing in the background. Easy to find and lovely to walk around.

Peaceful and tranquil ....... An easy MTR journey from HK to Diamond Hill station followed by a short stroll to the Nunnery. You only need an hour to see everything but then visit the adjacent Nan Lian Gardens which are coulourful and a wonderful contrast of old set amongst the new which make for great photo opportunities. The food court at the nearby mall is very good value for money and frequented by locals.

Oasis. The gardens are healing and inspiring. Don't forget the gift shop across the street. Some of the products are made by the nuns. The vegetarian restaurant was a treat; but I was disappointed to miss the tea house (closed).

Peacefully beautiful. This nunnery has a very beautiful Chinese - Buddhist style and gives a calm and relaxed atmosphere during your visit, a totally different feeling from the rushed and crowded Hong Kong.It is very close to the Nan Lian Garden and the Wong Tai Sin Temple, so you can wrap up all 3 attractions before lunch.We very much recommend this attraction.
Serene, beautiful gardens. In the middle of bustling Hong Kong, the gardens here are very extensive & absolutely beautiful. Highly recommend.
Relaxing place. Nice place to walk around and relax. Kinda big place. Need to take sometimes to walk around. Located near Diamond Hill mtr, need to walk 10 min from there.

It is heaven. This should be the #1 sightseeing spot for Hong Kong. You never realize in this overcrowded, overrated city, you can still find a heavenly place like this.There are two parts to the visit, the Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Gardens. The Nunnery is a tranquil place well deserve your respect. But I will visit the Nan Lian Garden first. It is closer to the MTR station. The rocks, the trees, the golder pagoda, the pond, everything in such a harmony. Please ignore the 4 overhead highways right at the entrance. Don't let that bother you.At the end of the visit, you will see a set of stairs that will take you to the Nunnery. (Be aware, some times the stairs are closed, then you will have to exit the garden, turn right, and circle around the outside wall and take the stairs outside.A bridge will guide you to the main entrance of the nunnery. There are good description of the main gate, different Buddha statues that will entice your interest. But if you are not the religious or educational type, the big flowering bonsais, the lily ponds will.Look at the whole structure, from the main gate, pass the lily ponds to the main building, it resembles the palaces in Seoul, Korea.Enjoy it, take a lot of pictures or just sit down and reflect the purpose of your life. You will be happy that you come.If you like, have lunch at the veg place in the Garden. It's tailor towards the sweet and sour type of tourists and at extreme price. There are better veg restaurants out there. I try the one right next to Wong Tai Sin Temple, which is only one MTR stop away (take it from the Hollywood Plaza). I got better satisfaction there.Yes, MTR is probably a good choice to take you there. Bus route # 11 will get you there too.
Beautiful garden. Its a very serene place in the middle of the hustle and bustle of HongKong. Picturesque landscape, lots of Bonsai Trees. Free admission. Take the MTR get off at Diamond Hill station

Beautiful Temple. We thought it would be just a short hour to tour the place but we ended up spending half a day to walk around the whole place and appreciate the wonderful architecture of the main hall and the nearly smaller temples. The courtyard in the Nunnery had beautiful plants and flowers. Don't miss the Garden across from the Temple, that day we were able to view 3 different exhibtions, all for free. The Nunnery is close to the Diamond Hill Subway Station within a short walk. It's worth your time for sure.

Well worth a visit . A great change from all the shopping in HK; thoroughly enjoyed the Buddhist halls (note they close @ 4.30pm, earlier than the rest of the garden). Not sure if it was the time or day I went (Christmas day @ 4pm) but it wasn't too packed which is a luxury in HK!! Very peaceful, beautiful setting and it's free. Catch the MTR to Diamond Hill, a few minutes walk from the station.

Lovely spot for a change from hectic HK city sights. Visit along with the Nan Lian Garden which is connected to the Nunnery. Too bad you can't take photographs of the spiritual statues. Bonsai trees and ponds of lotuses are beautiful.

Worth your time when in Hong Kong. The whole complex is well kept as seen in all the structures as well as all other elements that comprise the nunnery. Very authentic traditional Chinese architecture. And it's even FREE! Hong Kong government must be very generous even to its visitors. The nunnery is a joint project by Chi Lin Nunnery and the HK government.

What an amazing find!. Very tranquil and beautiful. It was interesting to read about the different Buddhas. It was very ornate and interesting to watch how the Buddhists pray to the different ones. It is close to Diamond Hill MTR station.

A gem in the middle of Hong Kong. Well not exactly in the middle, you will have to travel to Diamond Hill (Kowloon). There is also a beautiful park planned in accordance with Feng Shui rules, a harmonious and calming place. Make sure to wait till in gets dark to see how it looks when the lights are on - lovely scenery. If you get hungry or tired or just want to spend more time there you can try a vegetarian restaurant or a tea house at the park.
Easy access to beautiful site. Well worth a visit. Calm and tranquil. Sights and sounds fascinating to observe. Don't miss nearby gardens.

Self Tour to Nan Lian Garden. Take the Kung Tong Line - (Green Line) to the Diamond Hill station. The station exit is on your Right. Do not walk straight ahead, unless you want to go up the escalators to enter the Plaza Hollywood Mall - which has a large food court & clean western bathrooms.Follow the signage, it is a 5 minute walk (very close).The Gardens are beautiful and picturesque. Don't miss the adjoining Chin Lin Nunnery.Both sites are FREE!!!
dont miss it. truly a remarkable oasis in crfowded Kowloonthe setting and gardens are breathtaking do spend some time in this beautiful spot

Magnificent architecture. Was pleasantly delighted that the nunnery is located so closely to the Diamond Hill MTR. Was even more surprised such a magnificent architecture is nestled in the middle of modern buildings.The nunnery is extremely peaceful and tranquil. The building is beautiful and very well maintained. A pity a part of the building is under maintenance. If not, I guess it would be even more awe inspiring. The lotus ponds are beautiful to look at.The highlight of the nunnery are the huge golden Buddhas. They are very intricately crafted and serene. A peaceful place to visit.

Tranquil - short walk from Diamond Hill MTR station. Worth a visit and allow a couple of hours as suddenly away from the skyscapers and bustle of Hong Kong there is this peaceful place. Bonzai Trees abound and over the connecting footbridge is the Nan Lian Garden

What a beautiful place and it's free!. The nunnery and gardens were spectacular to visit. We went early in the day so we had the place virtually to ourselves. The garden was well maintained and there were some great photo ops.

paradise in a concrete jungle. this place is simply stunning the gardens and nunery is maintaned tothe highest standards it is peacefull and very relaxing this is a must to see in hong kong i would rate it ecellant like the grand palace in bkk and anchor watt this is a must to go and see.
Really magical place. The best is to have a walk during the day when the nunnery is open. We unfortunately could only enter the gardens, the view was still spectacular and romantic I would even say.
Beautiful gardens and architecture. If you love beautiful architecture and gardens, the Chi Lin Nunnery is a great option to visit while in Hong Kong. It's free and it's not too busy during the week.

Easy to find and beautiful. A beautiful, peaceful temple and garden. Well worth a visit. Just follow the signs from the metro station and you are there within a short walk. There is also a good vegetarian on the site.
Tranquil & Beautiful. A lovely little corner of Hong-Kong filled with peace & tranquility away from the crowds & noise of the city. Lots of space & not overly crowded during the week.

Beautiful calm place.. Is easy to get to by metro and just a little walk after coming out of it. Wonderful to see that such a place can be amidst all the tower blocks and busy roads. Another place where you could spend time in relaxing and walking around happy you have done so. So beautiful that we took so many photos . Is definitely well looked after. Highly recommend a visit.

Tranquility and peace in the middle of dense city. I am always amazed at our international adventures because there are such peaceful and beautiful places that cities have just built around. We saw it recently when we were in Japan, especially Kyoto and now in Hong Kong. The Chi Lin Nunnery is surrounded by expressways and high rises and it is such beauty. We will definitely come back again. I recommend it for anyone that wants a great afternoon adventure that Is easy to get to (the MTR is 5-10min walk away).

A Peaceful Place. We decided to visit this place to get out of the city for a few hours. It's easy to get to by MTR, free to enter, and such a peaceful place to be. There are quite a few golden Buddha statues - quite lovely. But the gardens are what impressed me most - so beautiful. There are a LOT of Bonsai trees, ponds etc. One thing to note - be respectful as you're walking through. Security is everywhere, and you can't sit or eat anywhere, so do those things before you go! The gift shop at the end has some lovely hand made items for sale - worth a look. We were travelling with our older teens, and they decided to shop instead of coming with us. I'm glad they did - they would have been bored.

Worth a Visit. Visited Chi Lin Nunnery which was a surprise to know it was easily accessible from Nan Lian Garden. Both attractions are hidden gems and very easy to get to. There is no cost to enter. Our visit took place toward the end of the 2013 Chinese New Year, so there seemed to be additional exhibits and decorations....beautiful. There were also vendors at the back of the main exhibit hall. Do not pass up one for the other...definitely visit both Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden.

A heavenly experience. This place is a treasure which few people knows about. If you are a buddhist, you would love it very much. Words are difficult to describe how magnificant these golden buddhas statues are. It was such a wonderful experience to explore and i am looking forward to coming back again soon.

No nun seen. The serenity that you will be looking for is difficult to find here. The monastry is most probably hidden behind the walls as we could not find it. The traditional music comes from speakers. The place as such however is well maintained with beautiful ponds and flowers.

stunning. Well worth a visit, understated in a number of ways.....it was peaceful, scenic, well maintained and one of the cultural musts of Hong Kong, The buildings were amazing in detail and make you wonder how something as beautiful as this place could exist in a city of this magnitude. Stunning !

Amazing architecture and Buddhas (No Fees). Location : hardly ten minutes walk from the MTR and 3-4 mins walk from Nan Lian Garden. Time required to cover Chi Lin Nunnery is 40 Mins. Its amazing work all around in Chi Lin Nunnery, what a beautiful architecture, big golden buddhas, ponds, lotus. Only one negative things that they do not allow to take the photos of all big golden Buddha, and I must say that all these buddha’s are awesome.Tips1. Buy mobile sim card with data package (1 week unlimited data) which would help you to navigate the location in google at anytime. This you can buy right after the immigration counter of HK airport, at the time of arrival. 2. You can go comfortably with baby with stroller, there are staircases but also there is also an options go with baby stroller upto the ponds area, after that only staircases for golden big buddhas.
Peaceful. This was a peaceful place in the middle of the city. The nunnery and gardens were beautiful and are well worth a visit.

Must visit. Nan Lian Gardens was one of sites mentioned in the Hong Kong tour pamphlet. We didn't expect to see anything out of the ordinary, and were we wrong. This place is so beautiful. The ground is well kept with different species of trees. They are all well maintained and trimmed. As we walk along the ground, we saw Chi Lan Nunnery is within the garden. The nunnery is very peaceful and has several water lily ponds. There are endless photo opportunities here.This is a must visit place while in HK.

Fantastic Complex. Visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery and the adjacent garden are like seeing two venues for the price of one. We went on a day that offered free admission though. The nunnery is a great complex of assorted buildings around a courtyard. They don't allow photos of any of the deities but you can take pictures of the outside and the lotus ponds. They also had a great gift shop and a very clean (squat style) bathroom.

Be sure to visit the gardens. The nunnery itself was fine, not exactly breathtaking but still worth a visit nonetheless. I found the gardens opposite to be a pleasant surprise. Overall a nice, tranquil experience.

Wonderful complex. Great buildings, beautiful lily ponds, bonsai plants & statues make this a must see along with the Nan Lian Gardens connected to it.
A very peaceful retreat amongst the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong & Kowloon.

Wonderful. This was such a well kept, and large, area. Both the buildings and gardens were in excellent condition. There is no cost to enter and well worth a visit. Some of the Bonsai work was impressive in the size of the trees.
Amazing. Really worth the trip. Easy accessible by MRT (Diamond Hill). Nicely preserved in the middle of HK. Make sure to also visit the garden on the other side of the street.

Beautiful and peaceful. This is such a nice surprise, quiet and peaceful place in the middle of a hectic city. Both the nunnery and the gardens next door are free and easily accessible by subway. I enjoyed the beautiful statues of Buddha and the lovely lily ponds.
Nice, but a little staged. It is a nice monastery, but I prefer the older ones as this seems to be a little bit "staged authenticity". But the garden across the road is really great.

Chi Lin Nunnery Temple Complex. On my way to Sai Kung Town, I decided to visit Chi Lin Nunnery @ Diamond Hill MTR across Chi Lin Road covering more than 33,000 square meters, the temple complex includes a nunnery, temple halls, Chinese gardens, visitor's hostels and a vegetarian restaurant. Worth to visit as Chi Lin Nunnery buildings are the only buildings to be built in traditional Chinese architectural techniques dating from the Tang Dynasty in modern day Hong Kong.

Oasis of calm in the city. Closer to the city than you may imagine and worth the visit. Peaceful place with interesting buildings and garden surrounded by the towering residential blocks. You cannot photograph the golden statues but the gift shop has a small book of photos for $20.

The most beautiful. This garden is amazing. The best in HK. It looks like japanese garden, very kid gloves with bonzai and small lake. Very interesting is restaurant under the waterfall, but a little bit crowded. The disadventage is lack of banks. You can seat only in the restaurant and coffee shop. The garden is worth to visit.

Lovely oasis in the city. Free admission to these beautiful gardens and temple grounds. Lovely old architectural style and very impressive statues/altars of Buddhist deities. Obviously very lovingly cared for and well maintained. Certainly worth a visit and a peaceful oasis in one of the world's busiest cities. A really tranquil, restful spot. Lots of areas to sit and relax, very quiet.

Quiet and relaxing. Just spent here few hours for walking in a late afyernoon. We found this place was very relaxing and comfortable. It might be a great place to hide out from the noisy of streets. We loved the gardens and decoration here. Must see !

Worth to go. No admission. Beautiful garden in the middle of the busy city. High rise all around it but very tranquil in the garden. Walking distance from the metro station, diamond Hill. Just follow the exit sign at the metro station.

Amazing and well worth the visit. We took the MTR to get to the nunnery in Kowloon and once there we spent the best part of the day wandering around. the gardens/ponds/waterfalls are amazing and the gorgeous replica of a seven hall Tang Dynasty buildings and the gorgeous buddha statues are lovely and well worth a look around. We stopped for a refreshment at the nunnery and could not complain about the prices for the drinks we had. It was also free entry but you could donate to the upkeep of the nunnery.

Feng Shui magic. Great pool garden. Good information boards. Very calm. Steps and ramps so OK for wheel-chairs/buggies. Souveniur shop - pricey but some nice stuff. Takes about an hour - longer if you wish to be contemplative. Follow with a visit to the nearby gardens which are clearly signposted. Interesting place.

Peaceful oasis in honk kong. This is a must if you have time to venture north. It is easily accessible by metro and a beautiful sight to see. You will see pristine buddhist temples, rock gardens and if you are lucky, a nun. Highly recommend!

Stunner. Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden - expected to be another crowded and touristy place but surprisingly turn out to be a calm and peaceful place hidden from the noisy crowds. Very well maintained with beautiful bonsai's, plants, trees, fish pond and golden temple. The temple complex is quite a place to just sit down and relax and enjoy the surrounding with lotus ponds.Entry is free, and easy to locate. Glad I visited and hope it maintains it charm throughout.

Calm and peaceful. To escape the noise and bustle of the city head here. Just not on a weekend. The nunnery is immaculate and peaceful. The adjoining gardens are surrounded by huge flyovers but you wouldn't know it. They are quiet and very well kept. There is a veg restaurant and tea house here as well. The tea house serve top end tea with pu'er going for hk$500 per pot. So drink wisely!

An impressive replica of an original Buddhist temple.. We were drawn here by the reviews as somewhere to go on a wet day away from the shopping malls. It definitely lived up to the reviews and along with the gardens next door made a lovely trip ayah from the crowds. It was slightly disappointing to find it was a replica only finished in 2000 but it is a working temple and very beautiful.

An oasis in the heart of the city. We loved everything about this place! Do not miss it. Easy to get to on the subway, free to enter and so gorgeous. We especially loved the adjacent gardens with ponds, pagoda and a mini waterfall with a cafe underneath. There is also an excellent garden shop with really beautiful things to take home.
Wow! Amazing! . So it's a wee garden- it's not huge but it is so beautiful! Really worth the visit( and there is a mall with h&m and uniqlo too, just next to the MTR station( diamond one)

Pristine garden. A pristine garden - well manicured - green respite from HK's bustling streets. Could do with some more places to sit and take in the gardeners art.Easy to reach from down town by metro and only a short walk from the metro station at Diamond Hill.
Great and peaceful. It is free to visit and the gardens and main temple are immaculate. A wonderful way to spend a few hours of your day away from the hustle of Hong Kong. Lovely.

An Oasis in HK. Unexpected oasis in a very busy area of HK. You would never know it was there. Well worth a visit.
In contrast to the traditional buildings and artefacts, the modern block paving which covered extensive areas slightly took away its 'era'.

Stunning and spiritual. A few steps away from a busy road, but so tranquil and beautiful. One of the highlights of my trip to Hong Kong, it's a must see place in conjunction with the Nan Lian Gardens. Simple to find being well signposted from the MTR and then only a five minute walk.The building itself is incredible having been built without use of a nail, and I loved the collection of bonsai. There's also a gift shop selling quality items and refreshments are available.

Gorgeous Chinese buildings. Definitely worth the time to go check it out if you like architecture. Great opportunities for pictures. Also, it wasn’t crowded and very peaceful (at least when we were there). The gardens right next to it are also well worth the time to walk through.
Unexpected pleasure. This is really something different and well worth a visit. So peaceful and interesting. A calming experience.
Serenity in the city. It's so beautiful and calm with huge golden Buddhas. We combined this with a walk into the Chinese gardens next door. Really fun

Relaxing place. Been to hongkong twice and we searched for things to do reading the reviews really helped us decided to see this place . Amazing gardens and waterfalls very easy to find just get in to MTR diamond hill . It's also near the temple . Would recommend this place a most see
Quite time. Out of the city, away from the hussle and bussle of Hong Kong City. This place is so pretty and restful. Very much worth a visit and easy to get there by train.

LOVELY PEACEFUL PLACE. This would have to be one of Hong Kong's best kept secrets. It is beautiful. And it is so easy to get to into the bargain. Alight at Diamond Hill MTR and then follow the signs - the Nunnery is just across the road. The gardens around the nunnery are absolutely beautiful - complete with waterfalls, and places to just sit in the shade and watch the world go by, or else have a coffee. So different to the hub-bub of the main areas of Hong Kong - you wouldn't even know you were in the same city. We had been to HK a number of times in the past, but didn't know of the Chi Lin Nunnery's existence until recently. Apparently it has been there for years. Well worth a visit. And there is no entry fee.

Don't miss!. This is one of the best sites in Hong Kong! The buildings are beautiful. There are also plaques at each temple that give a description of what is in each temple. It's also very easy to get to - within a 5 minute walk of the MTR station. Don't miss this one.
Better than a massage. This was spiritual, cultural and adjacent to the gorgeous park. A day well spent, and perfectly located to visit.

My favourite temple. of all the temples I visited while in Hong Kong, this was by far my favourite place to visit. So serene and quite yet in the hustle and bustle of the city. There were no other tourists there and we felt like we were completely immersed in with the nuns going about their daily prayers.
Beautiful spot. Beautiful spot. It's the only building in Hong Kong built in traditional Tang Dynasty style. Very picturesque, especially with the adjacent garden.

peaceful and worthwhile. Its a very nice visit since its a quiet garden and temple. Not many tourists so it was even better to be able to walk around in silence. The temple gives you a lot of peace and its very pretty. Everything very clean and well built. You can get there by bus or MTR and for an hour or two walk around the garden and temple and then get back to the busy Hong Kong.

An oasis in the midst of activity. This place is highly recommended. I wouldn't say that it's a 'must go' to place but if you have the time then it is worthwhile. Very peaceful and surprising that it's in the midst of chaos that is Hong Kong.

Stunning architecture. Absolutely spectacular. Beautiful buildings, temples and gardens. We spent half a day at the Nunnery and gardens soaking up the sense of peace and serenity. Just spectacular. Not to be missed. The little gift shop is well stocked and items are fairly priced and the ladies are very helpful.

Absolutely Lovely. Did not get to see last time in Hong Kong due to rain, so was determined this time. We caught the train to Diamond Hill and walked the short distance from the station. It was well signposted and we found it really easily. It took us about an hour and a half to walk around and was well worth the visit, an oasis in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

Tranquility and Peace and Nan Lian Garden. This is one of the rare places in Hong Kong which is so peaceful and quiet. You feel soothed by the tranquility in the air. It's a good place to relax, to be away from the hustle of citylife in Hong Kong. You can explore the gardens and admire the architecture. There is also a good place to eat vegetarian lunch.

Beautiful and Serene. A fantastic place to visit in hectic Hong Kong. Don't miss the adjacent Nan Lian Garden. Both are must-sees. Visit them after the oppressive noise and business of the city wear you out. Entry is free.
Nice place. Was here after walking around Nan Lian Garden. A nice place to have a short rest after a walk in the garden on a very hot day. The vegetarian lunch set is nice and worth a try.

Peaceful haven in the middle of a busy city. This is a joy to visit - you come off the train into a busy station - walk around the corner and you are in the most peacful, quiet and immaculate gardens you can imagine. Make your way through the gardens and into the nunnery which is huge and tranquil for several hours relief from the hustle and bustle of the city. Its wonderful.

Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautiful! Absolutely beautiful landscaping. Built and maintained by the Chinese government, it is stunning. At night, the lighting is set so it will accentuate the beauty of the trees and landscaped stones. It is well worth seeing and I would recommend it highly. We went at night and were very impressed.
Ok if u have not been to many temples. Small oasis but smaller than I expected. If u have visited elsewhere you likely have seen more impressive sites and may want to skip this.

Peaceful place in busy Hong Kong. This special nunnery is connected to the Nan Lian Gardens which are also a 'must do' while in Hong Kong. This attraction is very easy to get to - just a short MTR ride to Diamond Hill then follow the signs. The nunnery has some lovely, well maintained Buddhist temples and gardens. Well worth a visit and there is no cost - our children (11 and 14) also enjoyed this trip. We spent 2 to 3 hours at here including the Nan Lian Gardens.

Supremely peaceful. Such an oasis of peace and beauty in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong! We enormously enjoyed our visit, the stroll amid the elegant gardens and ponds, the sound of the prayers and the always fascinating statues of the Buddha. A must see.

Peaceful, delightful Buddhist Nunnery. Smell the incense, hear the chants, watch the fish and fountains, walk through the peaceful buildings - this is a beautiful tranquil location with many Buddha statues and areas to offer prayer.

Great structure. For someone who has never been to Mainland China, this was an impressive structure. It is delightful to find peace and quiet in the city. Please ensure that you reach before 4:30 pm to see the nunnery. You can see the nunnery and then walk around the gardens, which are open till 7 pm.

Peaceful and beautiful. We went to this complex to during our trip to Hong Kong. It is such a beautiful place nestled amongst the skyscrapers of the city. The contrast is brilliant. It is a beautiful complex with various temples, ponds and lush gardens. Everything is so well maintained and the environment is so peaceful here. The architecture of the temples is spectacular. It was surely one of our favorite places in Hong Kong. Highly recommended.

Relaxing couple of hours. Coupled with the gardens next door this is an interesting and relaxing way to spend a couple of hours.The buildings are interesting especially the models in the garden building and looking up to see the skyscrapers whilst walking in a quiet garden is surreal.The MTR station with shops and cafe's is just next door but the setting for the restaurant under a waterfall is great anyway.
Very peaceful. Just a few minutes walk from the subway station, I found peace in the hustle and bustle of the city. It was beautiful and worth the visit! :)

Bit disappointed. I was expecting so much more (based on reviews) and therefore was slightly disappointed. I have seen much more impressive temples elsewhere. It was also deserted, so there was little atmosphere which didn't help. I would recommend going to Wong Tai Sin temple instead.

Traditional Hong Kong. This place is adjacent to Nan Lian Garden. Entrance is free. The architecture is really amazing. Good for photo opt. When we visit Chi Lin Nunnery, we just sit and relax and watch this beautiful architecture.

Beautiful Gardens in the Middle of The City. The Chin Lin Nunnery are beautiful gardens in the middle of Hong Kong!! The architecture is amazing.. there are different temples, bridges with water and different fish, 2 museums, one restaurant. It's just off the MTR station.. amazing break from the city. They're clean, and really beautiful.

Chi Lin Nunnery. Loved the totally serene and spiritual feel of the place. Nothing we didn't like about it really. Quite a few steps so maybe difficult for the elderly or disabled. Accessed easily from local transport
Peaceful. Lovely place to relax after shopping in hectic HK. Very peaceful, considering it is surrounded by a high way. Lovely.

Serene. Easy to get to from the Nan Lian Garden and worth taking the time.
A quiet oasis amidst the surrounding hustle-bustle so a wonderful contrast between the modern Hong Kong setting and the peace within the grounds.

Go for the beautiful setting, stay for the lunch. My friend and I were travelling Hong Kong and were recommended to visit the nunnery by her aunt, who is a Hong Kong local. We could not thank her more for the amazing find.The nunnery is a beautiful place with classic Chinese architecture and connects to a garden that is equally breathtaking. It is serene (which is surprising anywhere in Hong Kong), and would be a photographer's heaven.If you have time, try having the vegetarian food at the restaurant at the back of the garden. It has a minimum spend of 95 HKD per person (about $13 USD), but the food is delicious and the setting is nice (windows look out onto the man-made waterfall). They only serve lunch for a couple of hours each day though, so make sure you get there before they stop serving (around 2:00 pm)!

Chi Lin Nunnery - Serentiy in the Midst of bustling Hong Kong. Once inside the Chi Lin Nunnery - you should even think twice whether you are in Hong Kong because the atmosphere and ambiance around the nunnery is really serene. A very good place to find oneself in the midst of bustling Hong Kong. A must for every tourist or local.

Lovely in combination with Nan Lian Garden. We visited Nan Lian Garden (highly recommended), and realized it was attached to the lovely Chi Lin Nunnery. Combined, these two sights provide a beautiful and relaxing (and free!) oasis in the middle of the city.
Stunning. What an absolutely amazing place. The surrounding gardens are just breathtaking. In summer take plenty of water and something to shade ourself as it can get very hot.

amazing. magnificent
it was a very great surprise especial the inside of temple, is not possible to make a picture of the internal.
All statues inside it very amazing and also you can find the note of temple in english.

Perfectly peaceful. The nunnery is across the road from Nan Liam gardens. Take time to visit both. The nunnery is a buddhist place worship. The centre of the courtyard has perfectly groomed bonsais, Buddhist pines and a koi pond. Use the MTR to Diamond Hill, even better catch the bus outside the nunnery to Sai Kung afterwards

Concrete jungle oasis. The nunnery / buddhist temple is tucked away in a remote neighbourhood. It's surrounded by big skyscrapers but is very quiet and spiritual. An interesting place to visit when you feel tired of Hong Kong's frantic pace...

Peaceful and quiet in an insanely busy city. Gorgeous place, impeccably kept gardens and beautiful religious shrines, well worth the visit, cab from star ferry Kowloon cost 60 HKD
No cost for entry, amazing place considering the city that surrounds it
Serenity. What a beautiful garden. Quite new but so well developed and maintained that its a wonderful place to escape the hustle of Hong Kong.

Lovely place - easy to get to.. We are in HK in early Sept and the place is hot so we don't want to go anywhere too difficult to get to. We saw the review for the Chi Lin Nunnery and felt it fitted the bill perfectly. It is everything that is written about it.The place is beautiful and while you can still hear the road noise it is wonderfully peaceful. Some of thea areas are in use by the Nuns and you must respect certain restrictions such as no photographs within the prayer areas. One other not so obvious restriction is that you can't sit down (I did on some steps and politely got told to stand up). If you are based on the island or in Kowloon this place is a short MTR ride and only a 2 min walk from Diamond Hill station, it is well worth a visit.

Really Nice. A piece of history nestled between sky scrapers. Worth the time to get there. I liked the diplays of various Buddahs and the architecture was traditional, nice to see in all the concrete that Hong Kong is.

Silence. That is one of the scenic places you can enjoy in Hong Kong, speaking about scenery it is all about garden and ponds!!! It is a holy place with all respected Buddha statues. Worth a visit but not a must place.

Very stimulating. We went there after a heavy day in the city. Few stops on the subway to diamond hill and you are in a different world. Just opposite the station is this little haven of peace. The temple is stunning in the middle of a most beautiful traditional Chinese garden. At six the vegetarian restaurant opens. You sit behind a waterfall.

Amazing place!. Beautiful complex of temples. It is amazing that such a place is in the middle of an urban area. Relaxing gardens, beautiful temples and a very nice atmosphere. The small temple at the south of the complex looks more modern, but I really loved the colours.It is better to go early in the morning, when the noisy tourists have not arrived yet. The atmosphere is much more relaxing and authentic.
Nice. This is another peaceful place in HK. The main building was built without the use of nails. Located next to the Diamond Hill MTR station. Check out the Nan Lian Garden across the street.
Completely serene and gorgeous. The nunnery itself, and the adjoining gardens, are a little slice of calm in busy Hong Kong. I completely recommend taking the time to see this lovely place.

Peaceful and beautiful. I would recommend everyone to visit this place. Its beautiful architecture and also so peaceful in the middle of the city. The place very well maintained and does not have any entry fee as well. Its a walking distance from the Diamond Hill MTR station

was there 2011. Another beautiful garden, these gardens are just so quiet and serene,,just sitting and listening the the birds in the trees and blocking out the traffic noise that you can barely hear..
Very nice buildings. The buildings are great, it is interesting to observe the locals doing their religious rituals here.

best temple in hong kong. easy to find by metro. this temple have a real atmospheric feeling when we visited it was pouring down with rain which only added to the experience I would recommend to anybody visiting hong kong that they take the time to go and see this remarkable place

definitely worth the trip to check out the Nunnery, and Kwun Tong. Remember the plastic toys and clothing that were made in Hong Kong in the 60's and early 70's.
