They were made in the factories in Diamond Hill and Kwun Tong. As manufacturing in Hong Kong has become extinct, the land has been redeveloped into residential and mall. Best of all, the once dirty, ugly, polluted factories at the heart of Diamond Hill is now a serene and tranquil garden with a Nunnery. if you look south slightly westward in the adjacent park of the nunnery, you can still see a low rise (about 8-10 stories) with very little or small windows, it is the remnants of the factory town, and the building was once a factory. To me, the very appearance of this industrial building that can be spotted from the Nunnery is the best part of the sight seeing. i am just amazed at how Hong Kong has been transformed.The Nunnery itself is a park and a miniature Forbidden City like building designed for budhist nuns. it is truly a nice piece of architect that replicates an ancient building but done in modern times. Pay attention to the joints where the columns meet the roof, it is based on old construction technique that stacks inter locking wooden blocks similar to Lego blocks to ensure strength of the structure against the elements. The technique has been lost in today's Hong Kong, so the nunnery imports Japanese craftsmen to replicate the old architecture. All the wood is from Canadian west coast, and the granite from China. I couldn't help not thinking that the building must have cost a fortune. i asked the local of how on earth the nuns could afford the construction, as it turns out , most of the Hong kong performers in the entertainment business are Buddhists by religion. They might be superstitious in the sense that they want to ensure their career success will last for a long time. (Hong Kong performers not only entertain local populace, but to the whole Asia, so their revenue streams are very substantial). As a result, they donate huge sums to the Buddhists temples. The nunnery is actually a very wealthy institution with lots of real money backing it. The attraction shows that. It is definitely worth the visit, and i have no doubt that it is voted as Traveller Choice winner.
Chi Lin Nunnery. Well worth the visit to see immaculatly kept gardens. There are plenty of areas to sit and take in the surroundings at your own pace. Highly recommend a visit

A quiet and serene space in the midst of a city. ChiLin Nunnery is built with traditional chinese architectual techniques. Every wood of the structure is piece together without the use of a single nail. The design is very traditional and grand. A lotus pond in front of the main hall.

A beautifully restored, little known historic site in the heart of the city. This stunning series of buildings is little known amongst Western tourists and is a hidden gem in the otherwise built-up Diamond Hill. A short 5 minute walk from the MTR, this nunnery is actually an old people's home, so not all of the site is accessible to tourists. It has been beautifully restored and is great for people who love photography, as there are not that many tourists there. You can get some great shots with no people in them! A definite recommendation for tourists and HK residents alike.

Beautiful. The nunnery is located in the middle of a busy, noisy area. However as soon as you step inside the grounds it's extremely quiet and peaceful.
I really liked seeing this nunnery as it looked how I always imagined China to look.
I would definitely recommend a visit here.

Lovely gardens. You can do this as a quick visit, or take a full morning to leisurely stroll around. The gardens are beautifully sculpted and maintained, a treasure to find in the midst of all the high rise buildings. Would definitely recommend a visit!

Peace, well worth a visit. We are a family travelling with 2 boys aged 12 and 14 and decided to visit the gardens as a sort of relax after the past few days of sightseeing.First off the gardens are amazing, you have to see them. Get off he MTR at Diamond hill, go up the escalator turn right and follow the signs for 200 yards....very very easy to find.As you enter, you are met with beautiful Chinese and dare I say Japenese style gardens. Pools full of Koi carp, ancient Chinese buildings and that is before you entering the temple.The temple is fantastic and so serene.The walk around can take around 1 hour but you could easily stay longer and there is no charge.stunning place

clean and well kept. easy to go to from the Diamond Hill MTR Station. This is adjacent to the Nan Lian Gardens. There is an overpass to go between the two places so no need to worry about crossing the busy street. Place is clean, quiet and very picturesque. The moment we stepped in, my wife and I immediately thought about 2 movies....Kung Fu Panda and Mulan. The architecture on the buildings were very nice and the english description of the Buddhas helped us understand more about the culture. The place closes at 4:30PM so make sure to go here first before walking around the Gardens.

Peaceful spot in the middle of Hong Kong. Connected to the Nan Lian Garden, the Chi Lin Nunnery continues the serenity of the garden. Not a large area, with some of the actively-used portions closed to the public; an hour or less will suffice for a tour. Be aware of the photo restrictions placed on most of the statuary inside and be respectful. Easy walk from a green line MTR station; also a bus stop outside the entrance, but we didn't travel using it. Plaza Hollywood mall is across the street, which has a large food court.
Great place.. There is a vegetarian restaurant there too...not a place to miss.Go by MTR to Diamond Head stop, and follow the map. A treasure in Hong Kong.

Nice visit. We had no trouble finding the attraction. The garden and nunnery were very well kept. It's a nice walk throughout the complex and I was able to take beautiful photographs. I wouldn't go out of your way to see this unless you enjoy beautiful gardens and architecture. That said, you could probably spend 45 min to 2 hours there and feel satisfied depending on how many times you stop to enjoy the sights. At the entrance of the attraction you can pick up a pamphlet which describes the history and story behind the design.

Lovely day out. Read the reviews on Tripadvisor, was delighted I went. Amazing garden with some beautiful displays of Bonzai plants, ancient rocks and miniature versions of some Chinese architecture. The vegetarian restaurant inside has a beautiful setting and good food, however the service staff are not friendly and service oriented. Please clarify menu items and pricing to avoid wrong amounts billed to your final bill.

Beautiful place, exposes the old soul of hkg - populated with strong willed Buddhists. Lovely gardens and grounds, built with love, care and pride. A working nunnery with a devout and passionate following . Arrange to have the vegetarian lunch which is decent value and pleasant to round off your experience.For those of us who want to understand more of this religion, inquire when there's are chanting ceremonies; a big one in dec. It is truly impressive and gives a deeper insight into the old soul of the Chinese ( both well heeled and common) spirituality . I attended one such major chanting event for a recent passing in my family and had pre registered with the nunnery. It was an amazing and uplifting experience to participate in this even as an overseas Chinese with little experience in the chants. Only draw back is they speak very little English , and I was actually yelled at in English that this was not a tourist attraction when my occidental husband and my kids accompanied me to one of the organized chants. I guess that was the sole English speaking nun, when I tried to explain she continued to yell at me in front of a group of tourists. This was not cool, but could understand there may have been negative experiences. So if you intend to go to any ceremonies be prepared and respectful!

Incredibly Beautiful. I almost hesitated to review this site because it is so lovely & felt like a secret right in the heart of Honk Kong. Along with the Nan Lian Garden, the Chi Lin Nunnery was a tranquil spot and a welcome break from the crowds of Hong Kong. It's really is peaceful.

Pristine and looks very new. The Nunnery grounds are in very good shape. The statues looks new and high quality -- for me, it was a real contrast with the Man Mo temple. There wasn't a lot of incense burning here and I personally didn't get the sense it was active as a temple. It's easy to access from the Diamond Hill MTR station. it's quite quiet and peaceful. Worth the visit.I really like to take a lot of pictures and there were signs for "no pictures" in every building. That was a disappointment for me. Some of the statues were so detailed that it would have been nice to capture.
Renew your spirituality here. You don't have to be Buddhist to appreciate this wonderful place. Peace, gardens and beautiful buddha.

Pristine and peaceful retreat from the city. The Chi Lin Nunnery is beautifully designed and maintained. It's a beautiful way to leave most of the noise of the city behind, even though the high rises loom above. Also a nice cafe. Really great way to spend a morning or afternoon and easily accessible from the MTR transit.
interesting. its an interesting placeI'm not really familiar with buddha but this place open my mind a bitafter strolling around the garden coming here is a terrific ideaworth a visit
Nice nunnery. The nunnery is nice and very well managed; a must see for those nature lovers. I would recommend you to visit it particularly if you are also visiting Nan Lian Garden next door

Incredibly beautiful art and statues but STRICT no photo policy. This place was awesome and 2 minutes from MTR stop but you could not take any pictures of any of the cool stuff. Guards were everywhere so cheating the system was not possible. Still absolutely worth going to however.

Interesting Facsimile of An Old Chinese Buddhist Temple. Following the style of Tang Dynasty traditional Chinese architecture, this was recently built. The grounds were immaculate plus the Nan Lian Garden is just across the street and well worth the visit. I wish photos were allowed inside as it is already a fading memory.

Stunning. This is an absolutely beautiful temple, and situated in a stunning location. We spent 3 hours there, and between the gardens and the buildings there was such a serene feeling. It was one of the first places we visited in Hong Kong, and we highly recommend it.
Definitely a must see in Hong Kong. Easy to get to via subway from pretty much anywhere in Hong Kong. Free admission. Beautiful gardens and architecture.

Not a friendly place. The park is beautiful, though very small. Many paths are blocked and the workers often direct traffic one way only (no back tracking allowed.) I've visited this park at least 10 times (with visitors), and have never seen one worker smile. It feels strict, unfriendly, and cold. Pretty amazing they can do that, surrounded by such beauty in nature. Prices in the restaurants are very high.

Nothing Great. I really didn't find anything interesting about this place. Just a normal Chinese structure with open space to relax. Good location though. Connected with all modes of transportation. Chinese tea shop is all another run of the mill shop.

Chinese garden & architectural delight. Easy to get to, but it takes you a world away once you arrive. The gardens are laid out so you can take a nice scenic stroll enjoying a classic Chinese garden architecture where views are different from any position in the four directions. Then loop around for lunch at the vegetarian restaurant (warning: it gets v crowded so make rsvp's or be prepared to wait!)
Interesting. Well laid out buildings and garden. New construction (1998) but based on old architecture. Some interesting models of the construction styles and techniques.

Spectacular if you like asian gardens. This is a great way to spend an afternoon! Totally cut off from the rest of the chaos of Hong Kong...yet right in the middle of it on the Kowloon side.Beautiful gardens and the temple complex was also stunning! And all was completely free too! Definitely recommend!!

Nice place - by HK standards. This place is only a few years old, so if your are traveling to mainland china don't even bother. However if you are only in HK the place is worth a visit to experience some Chinese wood architecture. Nicely don't, but fake.

Delicious. Vegetarian fare with an explosion of flavors. This was such a neat experience. I could eat here daily... A little on the pricey side compared to the rest of the food we ate in Hong Kong but I really enjoyed it.

An oasis. Absolutely beautiful and peaceful in a busy/crazy city. We almost skipped it as we had limited time on our last day but I'm glad we decided to go. It was raining so we could not do a tour of the garden. Somewhere everyone should see.
Great. We visited here after the gardens and another place of spiritual quietness,it is here where we had our lunch and so once to out of the rush of Hong Kong for a couple of hours.

Great Place to Relax!. This was great! It's an oasis of tranquility in an amazingly crowded city. We had a great time and were able to converse with some of the staff about the history of this amazing place. I would recommend seeing it if you have the chance.

Worth the visit if you have a few days in HKG. If you have a few days in Hong Kong, it's worth the visit.5min walk from the MTR Diamond Hill station (the shopping mall "Hollywood plaza" which is quite good is located at the MTR station), easy to find (well indicated)Nice temple and chinese garden, a bit "kitsch"

Tranquil and Sedate. I learned of the Chi Lin Nunnery Buddhist Monastary and it's attached Nan Lian Garden through other travel reviews on tripadvisor. I would like to thank those who wrote a review urging me to visit.I made time to visit this wonderful oasis even in the short time I was in Hong Kong (just 2 nights) and I was most definately not disappointed.The nunnery and gardens is well sign posted and easy to find. The MTR system makes it easy to get to from all around the city too. Get on the MTR Kwun Tong Line and get off at Diamond Hill Station (The Hollywood Plaza shopping centre) and follow the signs to the nunnery. It is about a 2 minute walk around the outside of the shopping centre and across a minor road. The Nunnery and gardens (another attraction in itself) are both free to enter and are excellent. The nunnery was quiet tranquil and sedate. The Nunnery has a relaxing garden with lotus ponds and areas of religious significance in the grounds. The Nunnery is a working monastary and therefore none of the religious areas are allowed to be photographed but the garden in the grounds and the attached Nan Lin Gardens may be photographed.The Nunnery and gardens are a great way to spend some time away from the hustle and bustle of the city and get back to nature, even if only for a brief moment in time.There is a small cafe to buy food and drink during the day and also a Vegetarian restaurant located in the Nan Lin Gardens (though this wasn't open during my visit).The Nan Lin Gardens joins the Nunnery via a well designed walk way and is also more than worthy of a visit, in fact I would recommend that you do.I could quite easily visit the Chi Lin Nunnery and the Nan Lian Garden time and time again on numerous trips to Hong Kong and would recommend it to any one thinking of going to Hong Kong.

Amazing!. It is so beautiful, peaceful and makes you want to become a Monk/Nun. We had visited the Forbidden City 1 week before visiting here and we rated this better than the Forbidden City! Forget the hustle & bustle of Hong Kong and relax in the stunning landscape and amazing gardens. There is also a waterfall and wildlife. If you are in Hong Kong don't miss it!

Aaah, the serenity. I discovered the Chi Lin Nunnery through Trip Advisor and took the MTR from Hong Kong Island to Diamond Hill. The exit maps in the station tell you the best exit for the Nunnery. The walk is short.The Nunnery is truly serene and quite beautiful. The gardens are stunning, even though I'm not into them ordinarily. Juxtaposed against HK apartment towers, this is worth a visit.
Beautiful and quiet. In contrast to the busy downtown of HKG, this place is absolutely quiet!. Nice scenery, the directors often use this place for dramas.

Best vegetarian. Tried their banquet dinner for 12 people. Amazing beetroot salad for appetizer. Lots of deep fried mushrooms, and morel mushroom and cashew soup. Different vegetarian food from the typical Chinese 'fake' vegetarian food that is greasy and oily.
Nice change of pace in Hong Kong. Very quiet. We were able to be there for some morning prayer time and it was peaceful. No photos can be taken once you enter the nunnery.
Amazing. Gardens were immaculate, the whole thing was awe inspiring, well worth the visit. The nunnery was very peaceful, displays were amazing.

Beautiful and Simple. This is a simple and elegantly styled temple, not the bright colours like you find at Wong Tai Sin, but is appropriate to they tranquility of the neighbouring Nan Lian Garden. Visit both this and the gardens and you will have a contrasting escape from the crowds of Hong Kong. Pay your respects bowing 3 times to the buddhas.

Marvolous Garden & Buildings. Great architectural buildings & ponds, nice photographic place, be there when there is good light, can be covered along with Nin Lian together in 2 Hours or so & proceed to Diamond Hill station, take a train to Mong Kok for ladies market.

Beautiful.. Chi Lin Nunnery is located within the Nan Lian Garden at Fengde Road.This place with Buddha's statues and carvings, can be easily reached through MTR, getting down at Diamond Hill MTR Station exiting at Gate C-2. From here it is at a short 10 minutes walking distance.
NEW WITH AN AGELESS SENSE OF TIME. This is a tranquil retreat in a densely packed busy city. Nice to visit for some time out and reflection

Pretty Ordinary. Whether it is worth paying a visit Chi Lin Nunnery depends on how many Chinese temples you have previously visited. There are a lot of buildings which are only open for 'donors'. In other words, visitors like us could not get in. If you want to experience Chinese Buddhism and/or Dao, I would opt for Wong Tai Sin Temple where you could see a lot of worshippers as Chinese Buddhism consists of Dao and Confucianism.

Peace on Earth!. What a glorious place, so peaceful that again its difficult to appreciate where we actually are, in the middle of Kowloon! The craftsmanship alone is worth seeing, its just fantastic and free!!

A GLIMPSE OF CHINESE ARCHITECTURE. Chi Lin Nunnery is another attraction right beside Nan Lian Garden. You can reach this place via the MTR and get off at Diamond Hill station. Upon exit you will see the Plaza Hollywood. Walk to the street and follow the signs to get to the Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery. You may get to the one or the other at the ground level; or you may take the stairs and cross the bridge connecting the two attractions. There is no entrance fee but it’s open until about 6 or 7pm. We were able to take pictures while inside after we asked for permission. A 30-minute visit would be enough to capture the glimpse of this beautiful Chinese architecture.

Made of canadian woods. Although it's a recent construction and I'm not and expert in Chinese temple, I was quite impressed with this one. The garden and the temple worth spending few hours. Unfortunately it was raining the day we visited, but it was a very relaxing place.

chi lin. What an amazing experience for any gardeners or just wanting peace for the soul. Allow at least 2-3 hours to enjoy. Note- no eating in the grounds but there are 2 eating places to enjoy vegetarian food and tea. Go to the gift shop for things different.
Meditative and spiritual. The nunnery is special because it makes one feel at peace. Tune in to the chanting and you can take the peaceful feeling out with you when you leave..very beautiful place.

Time to take stock. The nunnery sits in an ancient Buddhist temple. It oozes peace and calm. The garden is fantastic with water features and lotus flowers. It is a great place to sit and contemplate away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

Peaceful within a stones throw of bustling HK. A million miles away from the frenetic pace of Hong Kong Island but so easy to get to. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill and it is so well signposted that you cannot miss it. The building itself contains a nunnery but you cannot visit their quarters. What you do experience is the architecture of a religious building built into courtyard settings and structured gardens which is immaculately kept and a pleasure to walk around. Very peaceful but when you look back from any of the terraces you are surrounded by the skyscrapers of Kowloon, the flyovers of the city traffic and a very good shopping mall but you just would not know it. From here cross the main road and visit the gardens opposite the nunnery to complete your peaceful retreat. A gem and a good morning out.

Traditional culture in modern HK. Continuing the theme of the Nan Lian garden across the road, this is a beautiful and tranquil spot to visit. The nunnery is still active so you can see the nuns worshipping if you are there at the right time of day. A nice bit of traditional Chinese culture in a sea of modernity.
Average, nothing great about it. I didnt enjoy this place at all. I went on the recommendations of Trip Advisor members but was disappointed. Avoidable if the place is out of the way.

Beautiful and Peace Monastery. Contrast to Hong Kong daily live that fast and rush, Chi Lin Nunnery is a peace place that u will feel relax and happy.
This is Free / No Admission.

Nice and Peaceful. What a lovely place to go and get away from the everyday Hustle and bustle. Can't believe that all this is free as we were expecting to have to pay to get in. Take your time as you stroll around the lovely gardens. You can access Nan Lian Gardens via the steps and without having to croos the road.

Truly Wonderful Experience. After the relentless material assualt upon the senses provided by the tourist destinations of Hong Kong the Chi Lin Nunnery is the very antivenom the soul requires. It is a monument to what is truly remarkable about the human journey of historical Asia.
Fabulous. A wonderful oasis in a crowded city! Just fabulous. The Vegetarian restaurant in the gardens across the road was also very good although we had to wait for a table (Sunday)

Peaceful. Very lovely. We had had a terrific lunch with friends at the vegetarian restaurant. Then a stroll around the very beautiful gardens and a visit to the nunnery. We had a great time.
To get here take the MTR to Diamond Hill and the C2 exit and enjoy your visit. We plan to visit again soon.

Have been there twice. If you plan to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery, make sure you bring a little extra time to stroll through the Nan Lian Garden. If you love bonsai trees, you get to look at some at the Nunnery. It is a place to take a break from the hustle and bustle. The Nunnery is well kept :-)

Peaceful. Surprisingly beautiful and very unexpected. The gardens and the nunnery were both exceptional and worth a visit. We live in HK but had never been here and now we want to go back again! I would highly recommend this place to all seeking som e peace and quiet from the hubbub of the city. Best way to get there is the take the MTR to Diamond Hill station from where it is a short walk.

Beautiful with great photo ops. Our family had a wonderful time hanging out here and taking "hundreds" of photos. It is such a beautiful and pristine place just outside of all the hustle and bustle of HK. A must do if you have any interest in temples, bonzai trees, and amazing gardens.

Gotta go!. This place is beautiful and really worth a look. You only need to spend 30 minutes there if you are short of time but it is so serene and peaceful. The garden and architecture is breathtaking. There is a souvenir shop there but it is not very good at all. Over the road, which you can access via a bridge from the nunnery, is the Nan Lian Gardens. These again are just beautiful and a must to have a wander through. There is a souvenir shop, snack shop and a full restaurant in the gardens. Not necessary to eat there as there is a large shopping centre with a very good food court located just outside the gardens. Both are only a short train trip from Kowloon.
Beautiful tranquil place. We view this attraction along with the gardens. Had breakfast at the cafe with is a vegetarian cafe.

Very Peaceful Place in Busy City. Good place to relax and unwind, but quite small. As it is located next to Nan Lian gardens, it is worth going to just to escape the busy city streets. You can probably walk around the gardens and nunnery in about an hour.Great places foe photos but agree with some other reviews - it isn't essential you visit here.If you are in Hong Kong for a few days, dont worry, but if you have a spare afternoon on a longer break, i cannot recommend this enough. On the other side, even if you are in Hong Kong for a few days, if you prefer peace and quiet, then this is the place for you!!

A Place of Solitude. The gardens at Chi Lin Nunnery are just beautiful ... a place of solitude amongst the noise and bustle of this big city. So easy to find just take the MTR Diamond Hill and follow the signs.. a short walk. Go through the gardens first and then the temple.

A place to be respectful. This is a lovely Buddhist place of worship and if you spend the time reading the material around the Nunnery then it is hard not to have a real respect for the teachings and practices of this religion. The architecture is stunning and the setting is very beautiful. Combined with the Nan Lian garden these free attractions are well worth the trip.

Tranquil oasis, but not really a "must do" on a short trip. A feeling of peace and tranquility descends on you as you walk into this Buddhist nunnery. The architecture of the building, the lotus ponds and the lovely gardens, accompanied by the smells of wood, incense and the soft chanting in the background - so calming for the eyes and the soul!That said, I am not sure if this deserves to be on the 3 days in HK list... Especially if you have traveled around Asia and visited Buddhist temples, palaces, Japanese/Korean gardens, etc. I would rather recommend visiting the Big Buddha on Lantau island (which is already on the list) or Sai Kung country park (not on the list), where you can hike if you want to or just take a taxi ride and enjoy picturesque views, rounding up your visit with a nice seafood meal.Chi Lin nunnery is worth visiting if you are on a longish trip to HK and getting tired of eating out, drinking and shopping. And if you do make it there, check out the Nan Lian gardens too.
nothing extraordinary. Just another Chinese monastery.. can be assessed through Nan Lian garden. Skip it if you are on a short vacation.

Great architecture and detail.. The building is beautifully constructed and the courtyards full of lotus ponds were absolutely beautiful. The Buddhist quotes on rock and stone formations lining the walls were interesting and a great way to spend some time after the Nan Lian Garden.

Really nice and calming. Visited the nunnery and Nan Lian Garden at the same time. Both really nice, calm atmosphere, stunning environment, and really easy to get to (Diamond Hill metro statiuon, then a two minute walk). A different side to Hong Kong
Great building. The nunnery itself is a great example of this type of building. The whole area is peaceful and nice to stroll around in. It is a very impressive site to see.

Beautiful Place - must see. We thought the Nunnery was a great place for a quiet stroll around in HK. It was great to gain a better understanding of the customs of Buddhism and see some of the offerings within the Nunnery. Definitely worth a look - combine with your walk through Nan Lian Gardens!

Peaceful and serene - the other side of Hong Kong. When people think of Hong Kong, they think busy, shopping, business - you dont think, quiet, peaceful, calming. Got to the Chi Lin Nunnery - it is beautiful. Also while you are there go across Fung Tak road to Nan Lian Garden - it is beautiful as well. When you get tired of the crowds and the shopping in Hong Kong Central, catch the MTR on the Green - Kwun Tung Line to the Diamond Hill station use Exit C2 and go to Chi Lin Nunnery entry is free.

Stunning space - Loved it.. Highly recommend this tranquil space. Such a relief from the hub bub of the rest of the city. Great traditional Chinese plantings and adjacent garden. Easy to get to on the subway, and Diamond Hill in general is very user friendly for all.
So tranquil in the middle of a busy city. This was so tranquil and beautiful in the middle of a busy city. It is a very well maintained. The lotus gardens were magnificent.

Amazing Landscape in Hong Kong. A must of beautiful places you would like to visit in Hong Kong. Stunning landscape with lots of weird pine or spruce trees, so much green in a busy and nosy streets of Hong Kong. Restaurant with water curtain makes the place so unique, Sound of water fall and water lilies makes the place so peaceful. One doesn't have to like Buddhas or temples, it's a hide away places for a piece of mind. Back ground modern tall buildings spoil the scenery when taking pictures, try to avoid them.
Lovely Place. It is near Nan Lian Gardens - very tranquil and peaceful. Although I have to admit that they limit photography inside the hall where their saints are located.
Peaceful Serene Stroll. The plants and trees are nicely manicured. It's a nice peaceful stroll through the Nunnery, a great place to calmly think. The vegetarian restaurant is excellent as well.

A Piece of Heaven on Earth. Located at Diamond Hill, transport would have been quite easy by MTR but I was staying on HKG island that week and decided to go by taxi in order to spend more time there. The cost was around HK$120 (I think) and I was lucky there was no traffic jam that day.Nan Lian is situated opposite the Nunnery . Certain areas are off-limit here but there's a gift shop where I purchased two fans with very nice quotes. The sales staff are all volunteers and very helpful. For non-Buddhist we love to buy all those trinkets and bracelets/bangles. But one particular volunteer tipped me that for non-Buddhist it's better to look out for the 'blessed' writing/beads found in some of these things in case there could be a 'clash'. Whether you believe it or not, it's individual. Visitors can also offer 'oil money' (heong yow) so that prayers are offered for the deceased or living. Amount of contribution is not restricted but definitely 'from the heart'.Across the road is Chi Lin Nunnery. I was blown away with the sculptured trees, bonzais and even rocks look so natural (after years of weathering). Architecture was beautiful, so many smaller gardens and buildings to explore and take in. But I like the idea of the water theme, huge ponds filled with kois and goldfish (my favourites) .There's the 'rock gallery', gift shop , vegetarian restaurant (popular with both locals and tourists) sitting behind a manmade waterfall. It's customer friendly as there are stairs as well as lift in the restaurant. Do not expect huge servings here but going in a group certainly helps with bigger selection. Perhaps I was restricted as I was alone that day, but what I ordered tasted delicious (remember it's vegetarian).One exceptional place to pop into is the Chinese Timber Architecture Gallery where you can see (cameras prohibited) mini replicas of famous temples/monastery and even one of the palaces in Forbidden City. Besides that it has smaller structural samples to show the actual construction of these marvellous buildings. There could be upto 7 or 8 different joints just for one beam, all done without a single nail. It is too awesome and I wish there were more. I was also lucky because they had an exhibition of Suzhou Hand Embroidery. Again cameras are forbidden. Entry for this is extra but not expensive. I spent almost 4hours here at a leisurely pace. Definitely will re-visit.

A must see. Gorgeous & peaceful. A must, especially if you combine it with the Nan Lian Gardens which are situated next to the nunnery. When we visited there were only a couple of other people so you are not faced with hords of people. Take your time & wander around the various buildings. The architecture is outstanding. These timber buildings have been created with out use of a single nail ! Easy to get to via metro ( Diamond Hill stop). If using the metro visit the Nan Lian Gardens first, with a side trip to the Nunnery, briefly re-enter the gardens to walk back to the Diamond Hill stop.

Cross the road from Nan Lian Garden. Worth the visit, when you came to visit the garden if Nan Lian. Taking photos is allowed in most of the place, the place has an impresive architecture. I liked that place

Peaceful spiritual journey. This heavenly place is just besides the beautiful Nan Lian Garden. The Buddha statues, the architecture, the decorations, the carvings and the attention to details are so good that I am lost for words.This is a truly peaceful place and the atmosphere is very spiritual. This is one experience never to be missed in Hong Kong.Chi Lin Nunnery is easily accessible from the Diamond Hill MTR station. I recommend visiting the Nan Lian Garden first and then the Nunnery.

a Beautiful place in an oasis of Kowloon. Toured here as part of a ship's tour. The gardens are just beautiful. The temple is a reproduction of a 9th century Tang monetastary made without nails nor screws. There are several side Buddha temples as well as the main temple. Amazing is that the temple is surrounded by mega apartment buildings. Parking is conventient and there is no entrance fee.

a highlight. This is a beautiful active Bhuddist nunnery with everything clean, orderly and with gorgeous art and small shrines (?). The garden is a display of symmetry and amazing bonsai plants, shrubs and trees. They also have a nice little gift shop
Stunning trees and gardens. Well worth the trip and very easy to get to on the metro - a few metres from the station. Trees in particular are stunning.

beautiful, spiritual. Great place to get away from the bustle of Hong Kong - Gardens and lilly ponds and bonzai landscapes great. Rockery also first rate. Easy to get to, no fees, a perfect place to stroll and relax
amazing place!. I felt like i was in Japan, or Korea the first time i came to this place. The most thing that made me amazed was there was no entry ticket! U can visit this place for free! Loved it!

Worth while visit with camera issues!. It's a great place to spend a couple of hours, with wonderful gardens and some interesting architectural styles.Their policy of limiting photography however seems at odds with most other similar attractions throughout Asia where photography and donations are actively encouraged.

Lovely place, not for young kids. Really beautiful and relaxing. LOVE the gardens. But if you have young kids and they like to run, don't go. There are employees everywhere that will reprimand you if your kids are running or loud - which makes it not so fun for some of us. There is a vegetarian restaurant under the waterfall to eat at.
beautiful spot - not to be missed. Whenever we're in HK we like to take a visit to the nunnery. An oasis of calm and tranquility in the midle of the city. A very spiritual spot.

Tranquil. It was so beautiful and relaxing walking around. This is a must see for everyone. There were amazing bonsi trees. I felt so chilled out after my visit. After the noise of the city, this is a place a tranquility.

One of the most memorable places I visited while in HK. I visited this place along with the Nan Lian Gardens and the monasteries and covered walkways were some of the most impressive I've seen before. Everything was very well cared for and woodwork is just beautiful. The landscaping and shrubs are also very well maintained and created the ultimate picturesque setting for photos (although one is prohibited from taking any photos of the Buddha statues. * There are alot of security officials around the monastery to ensure this.  Pictures can still be taken of the monastery and trees though and when you're inside the perimeter it feels very peaceful and calm.  The weather was nice making for an enjoyable experience as well so try and only go to this place when the weather is nice as the entire area, including Nan Lian gardens, is located outside.  * As it is a place of religious significance, it like the Nan Lian Gardens is free of admission. When you pass through the Nan Lian Gardens which is right below the nunnery, there is a small place where you can actually get drinks and I believe some food so feel free to stop in there if you are hungry or thirsty.  Enjoy and I highly recommend visiting both the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Gardens! This place can be easily accessed via the Diamond Hill MTR. Just get off, go out of Exit C2 (I believe) and look for the red sign that says Nan Lian Gardens. Follow the sign and walk across the road and you'll be there in about five minutes.

Gorgeous!. The architecture here is incredible, and absolutely worth visiting. The "nunnery" is actually a monastery, I believe, and is still running. A lovely place to wander for a little while, and welcome respite from the busy Hong Kong streets.
Take time to appreciate the history. Even when the weather is only fair this is a superb place to visit , give yourself plenty of time , a real oasis in a busy city
Charmimg place. Simply remarcable....Go and see....Near by is a very famous temple and large moll for shopping....Really HK is a city of contrasts...Love you, HK!

Interesting. We visited here as well as the Nan Lian gardens. It is a large complex. I am not sure why it is referred to as a nunnery, as we only saw 2 monks and no nuns. It does look a little manufactured compared to the ancient temples in Asia but still worth a visit

Amazing. Leading from Nan Lian Garden, you could a huge wooden structure - Chi Lin Nunnery. A temple built with wood without nails. This temple right in the middle, with high rise buildings on the sides. It created a amazing view . Inside the grounds of the temple, there were ponds of water lilies forming a peaceful sight.
A beautiful tranquil spot. Leading on from the Nan Lian garden we visited this spot and wondered at the buildings and their contents. The water lillies were gorgeous too

Tranquile and stunning!. This acting nunnery and garden is a hidden gem of the city! This is a temple complex of wooden shrines in Tang dynasty style. It is known for the highest wooden buildings exist that were build without using nails. There are 2 ponds with lotuses and everything is made in according to fen shui rules. The place is so tranquile and silent that made me philosophize about life:) The garden itself is made in according to fen shui, and water, wood and stone are used in the design of the garden. There are lots of bonsai trees and signing birds around. There is tea house and pond with gold and red fishes. How to get there: Diamond Hill MTR station, exit C2, 5 min away from the station, follow signs. I would highly recommend to visit and enjoy the serenity of this place. This is an ideal place to hide from hustle of the city and to realize that HK has much more to offer than skyscrapers and shopping.

Beautiful nunnery/monastery in the city. Beautiful nunnery/monastery - simply unlike anything I've ever seen before except in movies. And it's right in the middle of an urban area in Hong Kong, so it's quite a contrast with the grounds and buildings set off against the Hong Kong skyline. We were fortunate enough to be there when the nuns and monks were praying, so we got to listen to the chanting which was beautiful.

peaceful and meditative. loved taking an hour to walk through the nunnery. what a lovely and peaceful place. perfect to collect your thoughts and enjoy the silence. after the nunnery, take a short walk to the veggie restaurant in the gardens! best food around.

Loved it... beyond words. The energy there was amazing, almost surreal, I went there on a weekend morning so trains were not packed and getting there was a breeze, there are signs leading you to the temple once you get out of the train station.. This might not be HK's biggest attractions, but Chi Lin is my favourite.. Do pop by Nan Lian gardens too for a quick see, there was a nice tea house but was short of time and could not pop in, would have been nice to sit there with a book.

Highlight of my Hongkong trip. I only had one day free time in Hongkong and decided to go to Lantau and to ChiLin.
ChiLin was my highlight of the day! Silent, peaceful, great architecture and all for free! What a lovely place.
Don't miss the garden besides the nunnery!
Combine with garden. Felt so peaceful this entire time. Literally a world outside Hong Kong... not a complete trip without the garden nearby and the nunnery!

Tranquility. If you seek a place to rest, reflect, renew; this is the place. Pay special attention to the impressive structural details--no nails. Along with Nan Lian Gardens, this is a "do not miss".
Serene. Stunning. Ponds with lilies and sculptural fountains. Side chapels and main shrine perfumed with incense left by worshipers. Good setting for reflection.
Worth seeing!. Typical chineese gardens, well maintained. We trully recommend seeing it! It is available by green metro line.

A beautiful temple right next to Nan Lian Gardens. See this when you see the Nan Lian Gardens. Kill 2 birds with one stone. No charge and a very nice temple. We did both in about 2 hours. This gives you another taste of HK
Easy to visit, a must see in Hong Kong. Definitely a must see in Hong Kong. Easy to get to via subway from pretty much anywhere in Hong Kong. Free admission. Beautiful gardens and architecture.

Well worth a visit. Magical when you step inside. I would recommend a visit here as it is peaceful and lots of photos to be taken here. The shop here is affordable and you can pick up some holiday presents. Staff are very friendly and helpful.

Oasis. This is one of the most relaxing places in the city. The building is absolutely stunning and surprisingly quiet even though it is surrounded by high rises and highways. The gardens and lily ponds are gorgeous, this is just a lovely place to escape to while in Hong Kong.
Good for Relaxing. Easily accessible via Diamond Hill MTR station nearby, the park is a gorgeous quiet place away from the Hong Kong crowded area. Pretty good place for taking pictures and relaxing.
Peaceful in a busy city. Beautiful recreation. Peaceful chants via PA system. Lots of stairs to negotiate. Bathroom clean down the gift shop area.

good for taking pictures. Its a lovely green patch in the concrete jungle of HK. The unqie architecture (not a single nail has been used in building this nunnery), the main hall and the Lotus Pond is impressive. Lovely statues of Avalokiteshwara and Sakyamuni. I went during the CNY celebrations and found the volunteers at the nunnery very very friendly and sweet. They were eager to exchange ideas about Buddhist principles with curious visitors and were curious about places they had never been to. I left with many hugs from the wonderful staff.

Good if visiting Nan Lian Garden. Essentially this is a religious venue and quite rightly photography is forbidden. If you are visting Nan Lian Garden then cross the road to view the lotus garden. The buildings though quite impressive are not that old, being built of Canadian Cedar. If you are a Buddhist then this certainly of much more interest. Whatever your faith it is a place to be treated with respect.There is a gift shop which is located discretly down a flight of steps and if you wish you can make some very expensive purchases there.
Very good. Very peaceful and well maintained. Buddhists will feel very well at home with the big statues and the amazing architecture

Nice courtyard. I liked the courtyard. I felt I made a time-travel and find myself somewhere in ancient times in a strange but pleasant place. The golden statues of Buddha and some gods was interesting to look at. The rest was nothing special and pretty boring.
Beware closing times. Went to Chi Lin Nnnery but apparently they close once the sun down (february). On the outside okay but nothing like a great old temples of Angkor Wat in Cambodia. Just okay.
Elegant wooden contruction. Very attractive building although not old. Surrounded by pools with pretty Lotus flowers. Combine with nearby gardens.
nice but nothing special.. nice but nothing special. We visited along with the gardens. If you're a bit out of time, don't bother with this.

Picture perfect place with not much character. This temple is well managed, lovely garden and great sign ages in English. Place is very clean and orderly but you hardly see any nuns. I have a feeling that the part open to tourist is just a façade and actual worshipping is done elsewhere.

Pretty. Coupled with a visit to the Nan Lian Garden, the Chi Lin Nunnery adds to the serene and peaceful location in the middle of Hong Kong. Easy to get to, being a short signposted walk from Diamond Hill Station. There is not much to 'do', but there is some really interesting plaques with the history and general information of the nunnery.

The Solemn Temple. What I like about the Chilin Nunnery is the unassuming quiet expanse of the place. It is not too big or too small. Being off the tourist path , you are assured of a solemn time for reflection , be your are a Buddhist or not. The approach through the first gate is a memorable one !
Fantastic. Easily reached from Diamond Hill MTR. Tranquil and stunning. Obviously very well cared for. The Buddha statues are really worth a trip.

Stunning Beauty. A trip to Hong Kong is not complete without a trip to the Chi Lin Nunnery. It is connected to an area of beautiful gardens, lakes and landscaping, making it one of Hong Kong's
Local treasures!

A place of tranquility and rejuventation. The peacefulness and serenity that one experiences in the bustle of Hong Kong is totally unexpected and most welcome, particularly after a day hectic of touring. The Nunnery is a place of quiet and self reflection whilst a walk in the garden across the road renews and revitalises the most weary of souls. I would recommend that you visit this attraction.
What a nice surprise. This is a little heaven in the middle of a vibrant city...simply beautiful and very zen. I loved it!
What a nice surprise. This is a little heaven in the middle of a vibrant city...simply beautiful and very zen. I loved it!

A slice of peace and serenity in high rise Hong Kong. Chi Lin Nunnery is off the usual Hong Kong tourist trail, which makes it all the more worthy of visiting. The Nunnery is a large wooden temple complex made up of elegant wooden architecture, treasured Buddhist relics, soothing lotus ponds and silent nuns making offering of fruit and rice. There are a series of temple halls which house gold, clay and wooden statues, photography is forbidden in these halls.Amazingly Chi Lin was established in 1934 and renovated in the Tang Dynasty without a single nail supporting the entire wooden temple. It is certainly worth a visit, there are some wonderful photo opportunities outside. The nunnery is open from 9.00am-5.00pm and the gardens from 6.30am-7.00pm. To get there get off at Diamond Hill station, take exit C2 and it is a five minute walk. There is no charge to go inside. Don't forget to visit the nearby Nan Lian Garden if you are in the area.Chi Lin makes a peaceful and relaxing afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Island.

Tranquil with Pagodas and beautiful gardens. Although I am not the least bit religious but this is the 3rd time I have been to this site and it always leaves me amazed at how peaceful and serene it is. This is a place I will visit every time I am in Hong Kong. In my opinion it is worth 2 or 3 hours of anybody's time visiting this and the gardens across the road. It is impossible to describe adequately just go and see it for yourself It is very easy to get to and is near Diamond Hill MRT Station

you'll feel like you're in a chinese period film. is it just me? but when i came here it felt like i'm in those chinese old movies, with temples and army. we went in first to this room where you will see models of temples from different dynasties. its awesome how it was built, very detailed.. i would like to have it as a doll house,if i have dolls (which i don't)..visitors are allowed to take pictures, except on the other part of the nunnery where you will see huge bronze buddhas and hindu gods (not really sure if its hindu though)

a serene place for worshipers. situated right next to the gardens. for someone like me who is not a church attendee or has a strong following to any god, I have to admit I did appreciate the chi lin nunnery. I would call it an outdoor church or something to that effect. the nunnery had 4 points and each of the points had a Buddha which people prayed in front of.together with a visit to the gardens, the nunnery will be a memorable experience

A very small area. Nice place for pictures, but nth much to do.. I think this is quite a nice nunnery, but don't expect to see much. You will only be able to access the main ground, just a temple square with some fountain. Good picture opportunity, but skip it if you're only in HK for a few days.

peace!. one can really feel the difference upon entering the grounds of the nunnery. somehow, the infrastructure seems to be able to block out the noise from the city below and transport a person into a state of peace and tranquility. love it!
must see and enjoy. A quiet oasis in Hong Kong - good diversion from the city hustle. Recommend giving yourself an hour to take in a leisurely stroll
beautiful. the place is easy to reach by metro and is 100% worthing, beautiful traditional architecture and a perfect place to take photos.
nice part of hong kong. try to go during a weekday and off season from the chinese calendar holidays. its a nice monastery to visit.

Nice place to visit. Place closes at 430pm, did not manage to see the inside, only walk around the compound. It's accessible through MTR Diamond Hill. Walk through Hollywood Plaza's Marks and Spencer. Then it's a 5 mins walk from there.

Beautiful peaceful gardens. Take a break from the chaos of Hong Kong streets - take the MTR to Diamond Hill station and walk around the beautiful lake in the gardens at the Chi Lin nunnery. There's also an amazing Bonsai garden and amazing carp pond.

Gorgeous Architecture and Beautiful Wood Structure (No Nails). This is a beautiful work of art in so many ways! There were no nails used in building this amazing architectural wonder!! The wood used in building the structure came all the way from Canada and many visitors were there to see this way of building a structure like this!!The Nan Lian Gardens next to this Nunnery are well worth seeing, as well! And the Lotus Gardens are also magnificent to see! The stone moat where the lotus flowers are in full bloom have carved serpents heads, from which the water pours out into the pool! Very nice! Well worth the 2 hours or so it takes to see this attraction!There is a waterfall and there is a restaurant behind the water so I would love to return and try the restaurant.....I think the setting behind the water would be very unique!!

so green, so peaceful, in the heart of kowloon. The title says it all, so peaceful, so green, with marvelous gardens and fantastic wooden temples built without a single nail. Don't miss the tiny museum that explains how those buildings are put together!
Pleasant. A visit to this Nunnery was a very pleasant way to fill in the morning before going to the airport. An oasis in the hubbub. The adjoining Nan Lian Gardens were more interesting,

Small but nice. very nice but small nunnery with a specific (let's call it historical or mystic) atmospere. It is definitely worth to visit in combination with the Nan Lian Garden for a short (1 or 2 hours) trip.

Don't miss it. Such a lovely place to see. Beautiful breathtaking gardens and surroundings. Apparently many of the coach tours don't stop here because its off the beaten track. Make the effort and take a taxi if you're not keen on trying to manage with the subway. Tranquil and serene you definitely leave in a relaxed state. You can also see the infamous "red" bridge! (Infamous because its not red but bright orange).
Beautiful and serene. The gardens and the grounds are breath taking. A very good stop from the hustle and bustle of the busy surroundings. Make sure to go under the freeway and see everything.
Nice.... This is another peaceful place in HK. The main building was built without the use of nails. Located next to the Diamond Hill MTR station. Check out the Nan Lian Garden across the street.

Beautiful Place to Visit. Within an easy walk from the MTR station in the Diamond Hill neighborhood of Kowloon, Chi Lin Nunnery is not exactly old (rebuilt in the 1990's), it is a beautiful place to visit and meditate. Don't miss the beautiful gardens across the street from the Nunnery!
Peaceful and beautiful!. Nice change from the hustle and bustle of city life. Opportunity for beautiful pictures and stroll through the garden

Special. You feel like you're transported to a land faraway when in fact you're still in the middle of hong kong. it's a bit of a trek from central but worth the journey. very easy to get to from the MTR station in Diamond Hill. Plus is connected to a lovely park (sorry, forgot the name!)

A must do in Hong Kong. I can see why Chi Lin is ranked so highly on Tripadvisor. It a great place to have a break from the frantic pace of HK and Kowloon, and is definitely worth the trip on the MTR. Make sure you tour the gardens and the main nunnery buildings which house some amazing Buddhist statues.

Nice get away. Nice park, but not that big. If you need some time out from the hustle and bustle it is a nice change, but I personally regret I didnt do the one hour hiking trail up in the hills by the peak instead.

Truly a gem in hustle bustle Hong Kong. The nunnery and Nan Lian garden are very close to each other. We walked through the garden, breathing fresh air amongst greenery ,soothing and calming music. Admired the intricate Tang Dynasty style buildings of the nunnery. Enjoyed looking at the display of beautiful rocks, bonsai and mini wooden temple buildings. The very friendly and polite garden staff showed us the way to the vegetarian restaurant behind a man-made waterfall where they served wonderful and very fine vegetarian meal. It's truly a gem in the big city, a tranquil getaway.Yes admission is free.

Beautiful and relaxing. A local friend took me to the nunnery and it was so beautiful and peaceful. After the madness of HK cities, I found the garden so peaceful .... and it is so accessible by MTR. Will go back again just to get away from the crazy rush of Hong Kong to sit in the garden and read!

not to be missed!. Even if you have a few days to spend in HK, go thereYou will visit the Lian Nam gardens and the Chi Lin Nunnery that are only separated by a bridgeNo entrance feeA super quiet place, some kind of quiet haven in a busy cityThe Gardens are extraordinary super clean all the trees are perfectly trimmed ... splendidthe Nunnery is fabulous .... you could believe you are in Kill Bill ... only the music is missingGo there !!My advice : ask the hotel to write you down the address, as many taxi drivers don't speak very good english ...one thing i LOVED in this place.... no food nor beverages are sold so much difference with all these places in europe or anywhere else where people spoil everything drinking coke and eating chips ... you wont find this here !

impressive to see. i had never seen a nunnery before and was really impressed by the beauty of it. The gardens were so pretty as well! I didn't had the feeling I was in such a large, noisy and crowded city.

Pretty and peaceful. For an urban attraction, very peaceful. Very clean and not commercial like similar attractions in China. No entrance fee - similar attraction in China would cost RMB 30.00 or more. Each display was well documented with both Chinese and English details. This was very much appreciated after spending 13 days in China where there was very little English descriptions for the displays.

Beautiful lillypad pools. Visited the Nunnery after a walk through the Nan Lian Gardens. Enjoyed the scale and symmetry of buildings and ponds and felt I was in a calm oasis completely separate from the Kowloon hustle and bustle. There are several very impressive Buddist statues which are beautifully maintained but for me the highlight is the liilypad pools.

Perfect break from HK bussle. The Chi Lin Nunnery is a magnificent old building and temple across the road from Nan Lian Garden. It has beautifully tendered bonsai plants that reek of history. The temples are interesting. Combined with the gardens which were not very busy when we visited mid-week it was a pleasant afternoon. Had lunch in the garden restaurant which was good vegetarian food and then caught a crazy taxi ride back to the city. If you have time worth visiting.

Absolutely charming and relaxing place. To find such a little piece of heaven in an overcrowded and never-sleeping city was a real surprise. I had heard of the place and have to admit that the lotus ponds, the temple, the bonzai, buddhas, praying areas are all gems and make you feel instantly relaxed.It's just a 5 minute walk away from Diamond Hill MTR so don't hesitate and go there with it. We took a taxi from Wan Chai and it cost 160 HKD (not a fortune but the MTR will leave you at around 30 HKD for two persons to go back to central).
Oasis of calm. This nunnery is in the middle of Kowloon, and an oasis of calm. Interesting building and beautiful gardens. Well worth a visit.
Good as an add on visit to Nan Lian Garden. Nice as an add on if you are visiting Nan Lian Garden. very nice courtyard area but much was out of bounds for visitors.

Vegetarian heaven. The restaurant at the nunnery serves fantastic vegetarian meals. I was worried about finding good vegetarian food in Hong Kong and went here on a recommendation - and went back twice to eat here. There are so many options on the menu that it's quite hard to choose, but there's a set five-course lunch that is really worth trying.The nunnery and the park are beautiful and I could hardly imagine an oasis like this in the midst of a densely populated, frenetic city. If you're vegetarian, you must go.

zen in HK. Less than 5 min walk from MTR, but suddenly you're in silence. Spend a few hours strolling slowly through the grounds and have lunch at the the veg restaurant -- busy on the weekends so arrive early. See if you can reserve a table by the windows. The other restaurant is more quick food, but fine for lunch as well.
A piece of paradise at the heart of HK. Decided to visit on a whim and couldn't be happier. Peaceful, full of character and simply beautiful.

Favourite place in HK to get away from it all. A beautifully kept and serene place to go just minutes walk from Diamond Hill MTR. Never crowded which is curious as it is a beautiful place to admire the architecture and gardens for relaxed contemplation.

Get your cultural hit here. Loved the place. So well looked after, interesting and descriptive information on the various statues and prayer rooms. It is free and next door to the Nan Lian Gardens (soon to be joined by a bridge). If you have seen the highly touristy, bustling, busy Big Buddha, then don't forget to add this to your itinerary for the quiet and much slower place of worship.I would urge visitors to drop their loose change into one of the collections boxes, this place deserves the donations for what they are giving free for the visitors to Hong Kong.

Day tour to the Nunnery. The gardens are stunning. A sea of tranquility in the midst of a very busy area. Beautifully maintained, and all work kooks to be done by hand. We had a cloudy day and I'm sure sunshine would have made it better. No picture takig in the prayer rooms or ehhibits. Too bad they're beautiful

Hidden oasis in the city. This is a wonderful place to take visitors from out of town, who are expecting Hong Kong to be nothing but buildings. It's a lovely garden to walk around, and then you should have lunch at the vegetarian restaurant. It is sometimes hard to identify what you're eating, but you will leave satisfied and it's excellent value for money.
quiet grace. what a great way to spend an hour! The gardens are lovely and the ambiance of the whole complex makes you feel relaxed and more at peace with the world

loved.... Name had turned me off but it was awesome. Danny Fung from Hong Kong Urban Adventures took us. We were looking for an alternative to the Big Buddha. It was really beautiful and the gardens are the best in the city. Many huge buddhas and very well done.

See the different side of HK. Very very nice place to relax yourself from the usual busy and noisy hong kong.. you wouldn't regret this trip! It's very close to the Nan Lian Garden and around 10 minutes walk from the MTR Diamond Hill Station..

Lots of photo spots. Even though the religious icons aren't supposed to be photographed, the lotus ponds and architecture provide many good shots. It's a very peaceful spot to walk through. Very glad we added it to the Nan Ling gardens.
Peace of mind. Feeling inner peace since the first step in this place even in the midst of a big-city environment and just a 5 minute walk away to Nan Lian Garden.
Peaceful. Had a very nice day here away from the hustle and bustle of Kowloon,amazing grounds and architecture
Beautiful!. A must see while inside Nan Lian Garden. Great architecture and there are usually nuns chanting inside. Don't skip it!
Nice nunnery. Nice nunnery, very peaceful. Just in front of Nan Lian Garden so could be a good idea to combine both visits.

Top FREE attraction in Hong Kong. Well worth the MTR ride to Diamond Hill and a short 5min walk to the gardens and the temple complex. Amazing garden compositions, superbly taken care of, great photo op place, and most importantly all for FREE:-)
Interesting. Again visited as part of my visit to Nan Lian Gardens. A quick visit was had. Interesting place. Very well laid out. Only needs a quick visit. We found ourselves through in half an hour.
A twofer. Just across the road from the wonderful Nan Lian Garden is the Chi Lin Nunnery. Don't miss either of them. Very different environments, but both are amazing. Peaceful, relaxing, thoughtful.
Beautiful! Too bad photos are not allowed.. Beautiful nunnery across the road from Nan Lian gardens. Worth visiting. Too bad you cannot take photos.

Glad we went there!. Chi Nin Nunnery was on our itinerary but we don’t know much about it so if we have to skip it – it’s OK! Aren’t we are glad our relatives took us and we definitely enjoyed the peacefulness surroundings there – no huzzle and buzzle. Once you are inside you couldn’t hear the traffic noise.We went there for lunch so we left early from Causeway Bay and took the MTR there, not that far away maybe 20 mins. It's right at the MTR station. We arrived early and walked around the nunnery – it’s magnificent and saw some young school kids there on their outings. Lovely architect, the temple was built without nails holding it together, the nice waterfall and other landscape.There is a vegetarian restaurant which serves authentic food, it seemed to be very popular with locals/visitors because it was packed and still more lining up when we left. The food was good and different and we truly enjoyed it.

Most beautiful place in Hong Kong. This nunnery and its gardens are beautiful and tranquil. Could easily spend half a day wandering around admiring the beauty of the rocks, the bonsai trees, and the Buddha statues. I came particularly for the restaurant, which is located in the gardens across the road from the main nunnery complex (cross road at the crossing, enter gardens, then walk left till you get to a big waterfall). However a warning: on weekdays out close for lunch at 2.30 then reopens at 6 for supper. I missed lunch but was saved by the snack shop which served sandwiches and tea all afternoon.

The most under-rated attraction in HK!. GORGEOUS garden...waterfall, general layout and set-up. Interesting GOLD pagoda in the middle. Love the nunnery - beautiful - lots of great picture opportunities. Easy to get to by MTR - worth going there!

Chi Lin Nunnery--a surprise in Kowloon and Hong Kong. The beauty of the grounds and temple gave us a sense of tranquillity in the middle of such a frenetic metropolis of high finance. There is a vegetarian restaurant which serves authentic, unusual food--seemed to be very popular with locals but not one of our favorites. Still very happy to have had the experience of eating a traditional Buddhist lunch.

calm amidst urban calamity. It is a part of the classical Chinese park known as Nan Lian Garden located next to a shopping arcade, elevated highways and skyscrapping apartment blocks. Kind of surreal but really unique by Hong Kong standard. It certainly is a patch of calm amidst urban calamity when I was there on a Wednesday morning at 11am, cannot vouch for it when it gets busy and packed with people.
A beautiful building housing beautiful buddhas. A quite respite in Kowloon which houses some of the most beautiful buddhas that I have seen in Hong Kong.
A jewel. The atmosphere is unexpected in buzzling HK. The trees and rocks are breadth taking. The vegetarian restaurant is not to be missed.

A quiet nunnery. It is a rather neat and stylish nunnery. It is very different from other historical chinese temples. The nunnery is rather quiet and can certainly help calming down your mind during the visit.
Peaceful and tranquil place in a busy city. We visited this nunnery and found it so tranquil and peaceful. It was a haven in a large , crowded and noisy city. Well worth a visit

If only walls could talk..... Very peaceful. Beautiful statues etc., humbling to witness the many followers in prayer. Immaculately kept. Unfortunately access was a little confusing as main bridge entrance was closed - as were the water gardens.

A Peaceful Break. This is a nice, peaceful place in the midst of a loud, busy city. There's not a TON to do or see, but you can combine a visit here with a stop at Nan Lian Garden just across the street for a nice, quiet afternoon whenever you need a break.

Beautiful, interesting but a little far. We loved visiting the nunnery and the garden, but it was a long trip by subway from our Causeway Bay hotel, and it happened to be a very warm and smoggy day. I would skip it if time is an issue but we have no regrets.

An island of tranquility. Beautifully designed temple and lovely gardens. This spot seems devoid of tourists in spite of being one of the loveliest and most peaceful places in the city. Well worth a visit.

Oasis of peace. This Budhist nunnery is a spiritual oasis in the concrete brouhaha of Hongkong! Along with its beautiful garden and waterfall restaurant, it is easily one of the MUST DO places in Hongkong, for even those averse to religion!!

Peaceful, as long as.... This is a great stop if you are looking for a peaceful stroll as long as you get there before the bus loads of tourists.We arrived in Hong Kong first thing in the morning and our hotel room was not quite ready, so we took a taxi over and at 10:00 the Nunnery was open and was the perfect way to explore a temple that was not built that long ago, but already has great potential. Make sure you tour the nearby Nan Lian gardens.
Take the time to visit. If you visit the Nan Lian Garden you should also visit the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery. Lovely architecture, a spiritual place that is quite special in many ways.

Nice Facilty..good morning visit along with Gardens.. A nice buddhist temple worth visiting along with the gardens next door. Many statues and interesting wood work. The main facade is current under renovations and the main courtyard looked to be being prepared for an event (sound system, lighting, etc). So it could have been a better visit, but nothing was going on in the area of buddhist halls. A nice morning visit.

A quiet temple in the middle of the city. Old temple renovated (maybe a little too much, lost its spirit) in the middle of Kowloon (about a 15 minute cab ride from Tsim Sha Tsui). Make sure you also visit the gardens that are across the street from the temple.
Pleasant Stop. Garden was very nice with water, trees and pleasnat walks, but Nunnery closed for renovations apparently

Quiet stop in a hectic city. Although it is all brand new (build in 1997) a gives a good impression of typical Chinese traditional worshipping. I cannot decide for myself whether I consider it fake or not, this is just the way Chinese do these things. Combined with Nan Lian gardens it is definitely worth a trip, you can spend some 2 hours in a very quiet and relaxing environment in the middle of this hectic city. If you choose to have lunch or diner at the vegetarian restaurant in the gardens, you may add an enjoyable hour to that trip (note for lunch a minimum spend of 85 HKD applies - for diner it is even higher)

beautiful place and gardens. Easy to find, what amazed us is how the place is built within a busy intersection of the road network, overlooked by countless blocks of flats but still manages to retain its sense of peace and tranquility.Not many people when we visited. Definitely a place to chill after spending time in the city. The buildings are beautifully constructed and the gardens across the road are superbly presented to.
Chi Linn - worth a visit. The Chi Linn Nunnery is easy to get to, it's about a 5 minute walk from the Diamond Hill MTR. The buildings are interesting and it's a nice chilled out place.

A must see!. One of the most beautiful sites in Kowloon, this gorgeous nunnery is not old, but feels it. The Buddhist temples are breathtaking and there is a great, no-pressure gift shop worth seeing.

Dining in a perfect environ of a nunnery. The vegetarian food is good, but the atmosphere is even more impressive. Dinning combined with a visit to the nunnery and temple will give you a well planned half day. Good for couples or family. Go on a weekday as it will be less crowded.
Great walk. Very peaceful, go early in the morning (10am) not so many people. Worth the look and walk not far from MTR
Lovely little nunnery. Beautiful buddhas and relaxing garden. No photos were allowed and they did not have any postcards or photos for sale.

Tranquil and soothing. Great place to take a break from the city hustle. Beautiful nunnery with well kept lotus pond. Make sure to respect the silent environment since lots of people come for praying.

A gem in a ting city of HK. This is a treasure and a delightful place to visit Time after time. It is a nunnery which is built in a very very lovely quiet setting near Diamond hill. You can get there by the underground. The nunnery is well organised and it is spotlessly clean. It is never busy and very very tranquil. you can spend half a day just walking around admiring the beautiful trees and plants and beautiful marbles and rocks, needless to say their Buddhas. They have a gigantic pond which is like the size of a football field with hundreds of beautiful Kohl Carps fish. They are the stars of the nunnery. There is a museum and also a very clean cafe for people to relax in. There is also a restaurant with waterfall on the outside. The whole place is amazing. You don't need to be a Buddhist to visit this place.

Chi Lin isn't chillin'.... This has been on both our must see lists for Hong Kong for the past several trips, but since we use public transportation, it hasn't made it since it is north of the Mong Kok area and a bit of a way out of our orbit. I'm glad we've crossed it off our list and don't have to think of it as a must do. It isn't. There is a modest, concrete encased garden to walk around, and a concrete path that takes you by several smaller altars as well as the main hall. No photos at any of those, which we scrupulously observe, but that wasn't good enough for the bored, unfriendly "security" people who roamed the facility and barked at BOTH of us for imaginary infractions of rules - the chief one seeming to be that we were westerners. The nuns are off somewhere else - this is just a cold, distant place to walk around and, if you Chinese Buddhist, you can pray and leave monetary offerings in a few locales. A must miss.
Beautiful gardens. I totally recommend that you visit these gardens. So beautiful. But do not sit in the gardens you will be moved into a room where you can't soak in the nature!
My favorite spot. It was odd being in a place that had such distinctively Chinese architecture and then looking up to see the high rises surrounding you. Beautiful flowers, ponds and statues.

Serene oasis, must visit. A beautiful oasis within the jungle city. Easy to find and get to with the MRT, follow the signs. There is a information counter near the main entrance gate. Suggest that you get a pamphlet so you have an idea of the layout and points of interest. Best if you reach there by 9am, that gives time to take a slow walk into the nunnery grounds, view the prayer halls which opens at 9am. There are descriptions and explanations of the Buddhas and dieties within the prayer area. There is also a vegetarian restaurant that has a nice water feature beside it. Its v quiet even though the nunnery is in the city. Real treasure and treat to visit.
Beautiful gardens. The Chi Lin Nunnery is a wonderful escape from the city. It's beautiful and tranquil. Great picture spot.
Very scenic and peaceful, worth the effort. This is a beautiful park and a bit of an oasis in the middle of HK's concrete jungle. I would highly recommend a morning or late afternoon spent here.
Serene, interesting and worth the trip. A beautiful, large nunnery in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. A favorite place for me to visit when I come to Hong Kong and have the time to go there.

Tranquility in the city. Also please enjoy the gardens. The nunnery is easy to get to and very nice. Also a nice souvenier shop (consider a bamboo towel...mine mopped my sweaty brow for weeks and never developed an odor, fitting nicely in my purse).

Surprising tranquility in Hong Kong. We've just come back from a visit to Hong Kong having lived there a good few years ago and it was trip advisor that persuaded us to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery.What a delight....Most surprisingly there is no admission charge and it would be fair to say that everything about it was exquisite. The buildings, the gardens, the general layout and the peacefulness really takes one by surprise. Whilst the inside of the buildings were a photographic no-go area, there was more than enough outside to take pictures of and to treasure from the visit.Go early during the week and avoid any potential crowds,,,,,,,,,,,,,,a real gem of a place for which you will not be let down. A short walk from Diamond Hill MTR.
Lovely. A very nice retreat from the concrete jungle and busy city, worth the trip, the neighbouring gardens are a treat.
Tranquility in Hong Kong. This is a little bit of magical tranquility is such a busy city. Just take the train and a short walk and you will be astounded, just beautiful.

away from the hustle and bustle. the amazing thing about this place is that it completely locks out the hustle and bustle of the city and it is located right in the middle of a neighbourhood where tons of cars and taxis (honking away)... the serenity and intricate design were just breathtaking
Stunning. This place is beautiful! I found it really atmospheric, they play background music which gives a really eerie feel, really enjoyed my visit.

Peaceful and Quiet. A great place to escape to away from the hustle and bustle of busy Hong Kong. Easy to reach on the red line MTR, and a short way from the station. As usual in Hong Kong, well signposted. Take time to visit the public gardens across the road. Very worthwhile.
Quiet place in a busy city. Liked being able to walk around without crowds. Dislike not being able to take photos. Though this is understandable in a religious context.

A magical, peaceful garden in the middle of the city. We randomly found this place because we were looking for a vegetarian restaurant. When we saw that it is located in a Buddhist garden, we decided we needed to give it a shot. Less than two minutes walk from the exit of the Diamond Hill MTR station, in the middle of a residential neighborhood, with sky-scraping residential buildings on all sides, and a highway bridge hanging above, you have no idea that this gem can exist here. But as we entered this place, we knew we found a very special place. We made dinner reservations and arrived when it was already dark. The garden looked magical at night, and walking through it, trying to find the restaurant, felt like an amazingly relaxing experience. The restaurant itself is satisfactory: great service, ok food, very cheap, and pretty loud. We would come back just as an excuse to walk through the Nunnery. Pure magic, and very romantic
Tranquil and Calming. This is not far from Nan Lian Gardens and is also a must. It is a tranquil and we came across many people praying to each shrine. The grounds of the Nunnery are immaculate.
Great and easy to get to.. Beautiful place. Reminds you of old, original Hong Kong. Just take MTR to Diamond Hill. Amazing place the nuns are very friendly.

peaceful solution. A wonderful oasis right in the middle of bustlingbHong Kong. Loved the lotus ponds, the peacefulness and then the chanting from one of the lower rooms where the faithful were he day we visited. Definitely added a ring of authenticity to the fact this is a working nunery. We did visit the soevineer shop, kind have no choice ad one must either go that route or back. Wonereing if the money did indeed go to the place we were please to see a sign that confirmed it does. Spend an hour or two, then go across to the park. Only hitch was the bridge access was closed for construction.

Beautiful Buddahs. This nunnery is just across the road from the exit from Nan Lian Gardens and is well worth a visit. There are a number of shrines within the nunnery with the most beautiful statues of buddah and a tranquil square full of ponds and plants.
Got the feel. Got the peaceful, tranquil feeling that is the buddhist religion. Magnificent and a lovingly cared for Buddha. New footbridge from nan lien gardens to the nunnery is under construction.

Beautiful, quite, tranquil. It is amazing that in the middle of such a busy city there is such a quite, beautiful oasis. A must-see when you are in Hong Kong. It doesn't take a ton of time to see, but you will want to stay longer.

One of the Top Free Attraction in Hong Kong. The Nunnery is located in Diamond Hill, just a short walk from the Diamond Hill MTR (the local metro) station. If you visit on a weekday, there were hardly any one there. The nunnery was renovated in the 90's and is built to looks like building in Tang Dynasty Style, the wood structre is very elegant, and has a series of temples.
