There is no charge to enter the nunnery, there is a donation box in front of every temple, any one can donate money into the box, believer or not. The series of temples have similarities to temples in Japan, then I am not an expert. It seems to look like those I visited before in Japan. There are couple of large lotus pond in the centre of the large court yard. It is very soothing entering into the complex. My understanding is that there are tons of people over the weekend. Hong Kong is a tiny place and there aren't that many places that has plenty of greens. Nearly everywhere has plenty of spectacular pine trees. I was so taken to the whole thing. You cannot take photo if you go inside one of the temple.

A rare piece of zen in the heart of one of the busiest cities in the world. The architecture is beautiful with consummate elegance and the grounds are impeccable. One feels as if transported back to the Tang dynasty in this sprawling nunnery. Also, the location is very convenient, just a short walk from the metro.

Very interesting.. The outer gardens were very nice. A great photo opportunity. The inner temple was beautiful. I wish I learned more about Bhuddism befoe I went. Pictures were off limits in the inner temple. It was a place of reverence.

Breathtaking. Wow! What more can I say! If you want beauty, serenity and traditional Chinese culture in the heart of a city - this is the place to go! A worthwhile visit, and only a few meters from the Diamond Hill MTR station. The quietest place we visited (in terms of people numbers) in HK, which was a welcome break. Right next to Nan Lian Garden, which is amazing!! Entrance is free. Stunning monastery, koi ponds and entrance 'garden'. A must see. One of the best attractions on our entire journey.

Beautiful.. If you visit the Nan Lian Garden you must visit the Chin Lin Nunnery you are not allowed inside the Nunnery but the grounds, lily pads and shrubs are much to be admired. It was very peacefuland calming.

Beautiful, stunning. One of the biggest temples in the world that was built without using any nails. Beautiful pond with flowers for photography. Unfortunately could not get into the temple because we arrived after 5pm and the nunnery was already closed.

Chi Lin Nunnery and Gardens. What a remarkable oasis from the sometimes daunting traffic and people of Hong Kong. In Kowloon and an easy metro ride from HK or Kowloon to Diamond Hill you enter a lovely garden and rockery. It has beautiful lotus ponds, trees, and flowers. The best part besides the walk and peace to found here is the amazing architectural exhibit that has wooden models of temples and the forbidden city. There is a changing art exhibit, a vegetarian cafe, and an exceptional gift shop. Good prices and quality products for gifts and lunch.

Chi Lin nunnery a must to visit. Just next to the nan lian gardens, cross the bridge and you can see the lotus ponds, flowers, a Chinese temple with buddha, kuan yin. Of course a holy place, it has the grand lay out. We went there on a Sunday. Very peaceful and quiet. The decoration was very impressive with oak wood. Traditional ambience. Not to be miss and worth the time visiting.
Gorgeous. Sit near the Clock Tower and watch the 8pm light show, then stroll the Avenue of the Stars. People watching is fun, but the view will take the air out of you.
Breathtaking. This complex is beautiful and serene. Walk te beautiful grounds and see the shrines. Stop across the street to see the beautiful gardens, both are free.

beautiful garden below highway bridge. it's so peacefull and beautifull garden and pond..everything profesionally taking care from plants to buildings. the garden was connected to nan lian garden by bridge
peaceful and serene. just what you need after a busy day of sightseeing. Take the time to relax and enjoy the moment. Would recommend to anyone looking for a quiet moment

rules reminder......... Just friendly reminder to all tourist to respect all rules & regulation to the places that we visited. You’ll see some area in this place written “NO PHOTO ALLOWED”….so please do not take photos, no matter how much you want to, even either by your mobile phone. And keep your voice as well. This a holy place and you’ll hear nunn praying, so don't be noisy. I saw some tourist being selfish neglect this rules, especially those who came in a group and it cost trouble at the end. Avoid this kind of disturbing behavior. Just enjoy the place with good manner.
Interesting and impressive statues. Impressive Buddhas, and it was interesting to read what each statue represented (in English, as well as Chinese). Lotus ponds were pretty too.

Environment of calmity. This is just next to Nan Lian Garden so you can plan these 2 places to visit together. Contrast to Nan Lian Garden, the nunnery is more barren with coarse marbel covering the ground. Our stay there were short as there is a buddhist chanting session oging on and we do not want to disturb the devotees.It is certainly worth visiting but make sure you don't do that on Sunday morning.

Worth a visit. The nunnery was worth a visit even though neither us nor our guide had seen a nun there. There are Buddhist gods in rooms situated around the square shaped temples. Photos of the gods are not permitted ,it is a lovely place and people do come here to pray. There is a small if expensive shop a small wooden elephant you could fit in your hand cost about £400-£500.Worth a visit if you have never been to a buddhist temple.
Calm. This Nunnery that connects directly with Nan Lian Garden is so perfect. You will want to meditate and ponder the meaning of life.The Bonsai, The Dragon flies, The pumped-in chanting.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit. Stunning. Rode the subway and its just over the road. Gardens amazing too and the rooms and views are great.

Very spiritual experience.. We really enjoyed wandering around inside and marvelling at each Buddha. You can't help but be affected by the serenity and air of spirituality when you see locals calling in to worship on their way past. Beautiful experience.

A little bit of peace in a busteling city.. It is worth the 10 min MTR ride to Diamond Hill to get a bit of peace and quiet.I loved this place, the huge Bonsai trees, and perfectly kept gardens were a real contrast from the rest of HK.if you have time have afternoon tea in the restaurant, it will be an experience sitting behind a waterfall and looking through an immense window into the gardens.

Nice, but nothing more. This attraction was nicely tucked in-between Diamond Hill residential tower blocks and made a nice change from the bright lights of downtown HK. It was very easy to find and very well maintained. However, as as a result, it lacked some of the character that other nunneries I've visited before have.
Lunch in the gardens. Vegetarian restaurant in the gardens great, weekends busy. Visit the gardens mid week, and the whole place is very tranquil.
Tranquil place to relax between the hectic city. Very nice nunnery to come down from the hectic Hongkong city after or between the exhausting sightseeing. Very peaceful and nice place.

Calm and pretty. Prepare tonnes of photos to be taken, stay and breathe in the calmness in this nunnery (temple).
It's very comforting place to ease the mind

A quiet oasis. We were unable to visit the main temple area, but the Chinese garden is such a contrast to the noise and chaos just outside its gates - amazing! The garden features a lot of smaller trees. To my uneducated gardening eye, these seemed to have a Japanese bonsai age and quality, although they were grown much bigger out in the open.Several wooden buildings held other exhibits, and were exhibits in their own right - no nails! Although not a vegetarian, I had an excellent vegetarian lunch in the pleasantly air-conditioned garden restaurant under a waterfall - very welcome on a hot summer day.

Peaceful stroll. Easy to get to. Take the subway to Diamond Hill. The nunnery and gardens are clearly signposted. The enclosed gardens and nunnery make for a very pretty and peaceful stroll, especially if you want to take a break from the city bustle.

Serene. Quiet. Peaceful. Serene. Pretty much what you would expect a Buddhist nunnery to be. No photography allowed out of respect for the deities and worshippers. Much more shade than the neighboring gardens. Only takes 10 minutes to tour, unless you stop for prayers.

Peace and tranquility in Hong Kong. Directly across the street from the Nan Lian Gardens and accessible from the Diamond Hill MTR stop, the Chi Lin Nunnery is a beautiful attraction to visit. The gardens and temples are well-maintained and English descriptions provide worthwhile context. Budget no more than an hour or so to take in the sites and enjoy a little peace and quiet. When you're done, the mall near the MTR has an excellent food court located on the 3rd floor.

Combine with Nan Lian Garden. This trip combined only took about two hours, and that includes getting there from HK island. It is definitely worth a visit and you should combine it with Nan Lian Garden. In fact, I recommend entering through Nan Lian Garden and following the path that ends at the base of the Nunnery. The architecture is phenomenal and it's free! Definitely a must do. Knock it off your list during the week and you'll have the place to yourself. Easy morning trip and you can grab lunch at the veggie restaurant in Nan Lian Garden or at the mall at the Diamond Hill subway stop.
Beautiful and cultural. I loved it! Together with the Nunnery: one of the most amazing, cultural and beautiful sights in Hong Kong.

Do it with Nan Liang Gardens. next door to Nan Liang Gardens, next to Diamond Hill MTR station.Very quiet and tranquil. Makes a nice difference from the hustle and bustle of HK. Only the main square available to tourists. The main prayer hall was out of bounds. Photographs of the golden buddhas not allowed.
Strange place but worth a visit. Took in the nunnery as part of a HK tour - fascinating place with some good stories behind it...take a look if you are in the area

So Beautiful.. That's among the most beautiful places in Hong Kong I think - and certainly one of the most serene. Although it is surrounded by the typical Hong Kong style skyscrapers, the place itself couldn't be more calm and relaxed.I still can't believe there is no entrance fee for such a beautiful place. We spent around 2.5 hours there, including the Nan Lian Gardens. There isn't much more to say, really - a beautiful, serene place in the middle of this bustling and busy city. You'll get some of the finest photos you have ever taken!

A beautiful serene working nunnery. We visited the nunnery after visiting the gardens just across a very busy road.And like the gardens was an oasis of calm and peace.The nunnery was beautifully kept and during our visit there were many people worshiping at the beautiful Buddhas and Buddhavistas and in the background we could hear a nun chanting her prayers.

Not unmissable. Pushed my husband to go here as fancied a little beauty and culture amongst the shopping! But actually was a bit of a schlep to get there, and whilst a pleasant enough garden, wasn't so lovely or interesting. All quite modern, with concrete pathways. Some nice planting, but that's all...nice
" Amazing wooden structure". This historic building is all made by wood. A grate place to visit and learn about Buddhism. Peaceful and beautiful.
Serenity. Never found a more peaceful place in Hong Kong than this. Beautiful visit and highly recommend a visit, even though it's away from the city center. Don't miss it!
Serene escape. Great place for a little tranquility in a bustling metropolis.

Serene walk: low rise buildings in strong contrast to surrounding highrises. Enjoyed the peaceful walk through this monastery. Lovely waterlilies of assorted colours. Adjacent to Plaza Hollywood where there is an expat supermarket. Plaza is quite handy to cool down after being out in the summer heat and humidity. Get off at Diamond Hill MTR station. Nan Lian gardens connects directly to Chi Lin Nunnery.
oasis of the city life. very peaceful. very quiet. good temple built in the city. feels very calming and relaxed.
Chi Lin Nunnery. Loved the quaint gardens, maybe a nice cultural demonstration would be nice,

Magnificent. The temple is in a walking distance to the MTR. Even there is no admidssion fee, the temple and surrounding is very well maintained. The architecture is elegant. The garden is beautiful. It is worth visiting.

Beautiful - do not miss. Short walk from Diamond Hill MTR.The architecture is amazing for one, yes, it was only built recently but the skill level involved to create it is to be credited,There were very few people there, mainly worshippers, which certainly made it a peaceful area. My daughter began bowing to the Buddhas, as at 2, she is of that age.The Buddhas were beautiful and contained a write up on each one in English, which I found very interesting, as I had never been exposed to it before.Please go, be respectful and enjoy the peace, serenity and fresh air.

Highlight of visit to Hong Kong - DO NOT MISS. Stumbled on Chi Lin Nunnery in a magazine, and decided to make a visit. What a find!! It was the highlight of my visit to Hong Kong & Shenzhen, and the magazine wasn't wrong when it said it was not much visited - there were only a handful of people, and no westerners! A little garden haven in the middle of a city.Take metro line to Diamond Hill - only a few minutes from station - and its well signposted from there. The nuns are buddhist and the temples and gardens are absolutely beautiful, with water features and fountains. I love chinese/japanese gardens, and I just loved everything about the landscaping. It is immaculately maintained. Cross the bridge over the road to the garden on the other side (name escapes me!) and again it was WOW, WOW, WOW. With a traditional golden pergoda and footbridge, and ponds and the trees and shrubs are beautifully planted. Has a tea house and a shop.LOVED IT.

An architectural masterpiece.. Although of recent construction, the monastery has been built of timber in the style of the Tang Dynasty. The buildings, open to the public, are stunning and a credit to the craftsmen who built them. Combine a visit with the adjacent Chi Lin gardens, you will not be disappointed.

Small but interesting. It was quiet, serene and had rooms to peak in at Buddhas. It's not very big and will not take you long to walk thru. I was glad it's next to the Nan Lian Garden for a little added adventure.

Beautiful buildings set in lovely gardens.. This is such an impressive place to visit. The buildings are magnificent, the gardens too. I love how the Chinese manage to build such wonderful buildings that stand the test of time and surround them with the living sculptures that are the bonsais and compliment them with the sounds of running water and birdsong. It's across the road from the Nan Lian gardens, joined by a walkover across the highway. I had shivers down my spine when I went into the main building and heard the monks singing. It was probably a cd but sounded like it was live and was a wonderful experience. Thoroughly reccommend it.

Quiet temple for peace of mind. For those who are into Chinese temples and architecture, this is worth the visit. Tranquil, peaceful, very well-maintained and with 4 beautiful lotus ponds within the temple ground. Apart from the various Buddha's statues, I was led to understand that this temple was built using ancient Chinese architecture and engineering, meaning not a single nail is used in the construction of the buildings!Go across the street and visit Nan Lian gardens to complete a peaceful afternoon...right in Hong Kong!!

Beautiful lotus garden. Nice quiet place, incredible lotus garden nd buddhist images. Nice souvenir shop at end...really close to the MTR. Together with nan lian rden the nicest attraction we ve been.
For the holy buddhist. I'm into temples thus this place appears totally cool to me~Not alot of deities thou. There's english writeup about each god.
Beautiful park. Very peaceful temple and park. Go eat the at the restaurant very good, if a little too healthy.

Amazing Architecture.... If you are going to the Nan Lin Gardens then you should also visit the Chi Lin Nunnery too..!The buidings, gardens, ponds with lotus flowers are imacutately kept...another fantastic escape from the hectic city...
Chin Lin Nunnery. It is just opp NanLian gardens.A quiet Buddha temple with Lotus ponds and greenery all around in the midst of money making Hongkong.A must see

Beautiful. Chi Lin Nunnery is a very quiet, peaceful, beautiful place to visit to get away from the crowds of the city, just a slow pace and everyone enjoying the scenery and the Temple..Just peaceful and lovely

Awe-inspiring. As other reviewers note, visit this when you are visiting the nearby (Nan Lian) gardens. It is a lovely property with a very important, religious feel--many people praying, monks tending to the dieties. Very interesting and beautiful. We also enjoyed the gist shop at the end. As I noted in a related review of the gardens, food is available in the mall associated with the nearby metro stop.
nice temple. very nice, very quiet, very clean temple sitting in the middle of the city!

Wow.... chi lin nunnery is just a stone's throw away from the nan lian gardens and it will be a pity not to go there when one is already at the nan lian gardens.When you step into the temple, it has a sense of calmness that seems to calm the spirits down and makes one forget about the fast paced city of Hong Kong right beneath your feet - literally!well worth a visit
Simply awesome. It's one of the must-visit place in Hong Kong. If you want to avoid the crowds in HK, this is one of the best place to be.
Beautiful. Beautiful, dazzling and very peaceful. Absolutely beautiful and a must see while in Hong Kong. Take a moment to relax and meditate here--you wont be sorry.
Very nice and quit. Nice place to get out of the busy city very near to the mtr

Peaceful Awesome Gardens. The gardens are stunning and peaceful considering you are in the middle of one of the most populated cities in the world. The Temple itself is also stunning and has some incredible Bonsai trees just be careful about taking photos as guards are everywhere and quick to advise you if you start to take photos of the insides of the Temples or people praying. Well worth the visit even if you are not into gardens, Bonsai or Temples.

Hidden Gem. I read about this spot in the guide book but didn't have much detail. As it was free, figured I didn't have much to lose. What a lovely spot!!!As there wasn't a tremendous amount of info, relied heavily on the guidebook for detail, but enjoyed this beautiful location immensely. It's peaceful and quiet and yet not too far away from anything. While away a few hours here on your next trip to Hong Kong.
Picturesque Garden. Very beautiful garden. The architecture in the nunnery was amazing too. A great peaceful visit away from the busy city life of Hong Kong.

Saturday leisure walk. Maybe if I go during weekdays, I might have different opinion to the place. It is a good park to enjoy leisurely and without a big crowd. The architecture is excellent. Worth to put into your travel plan.
great temple!. very clean and pristine and really a haven away from the hustle and bustle of the city crowd!
JoH883. The vegetarian food in the cafe was great (and we're not veggos). I wish we'd had enough time for lunch in the restaurant. I will definitely go there next time.

Chi Lin Nunnery. The grounds are so well looked after and the wooden buildings are immaculate. Do look at the intricate details of the roofs before your attention is taken by the wonderful golden Buddhas under the golden canopy in the main temple.The Nuns if you are lucky enough to see one have shaved heads and wear dark brown robes.Everything is really well cared for and gleams. Even the fruit put out in bowls as offerings is polished
Peaceful oasis. Convenient location near Diamond Hill shopping centre; beautiful gardens

Quiet little part of HK. Very authentic reproduction. Lovely place to take photos even in the rain when few visitors are there. Tip - go across the street and visit that park as well, and try the vegitarian restaurant.

Peace of mind. Visit is best teamed with a visit to the Nan Lin Gardens which is connected via a flyover. A gem of it's own though. For photographer, no photos inside the temples itself but photos are allowed of the garden complex.

Beautiful - Unique in Hong Kong. Such a beautiful place and it is immaculately kept.We went there on a rainy day and we were surprised at how beautiful it still was, the mood of the place was peaceful since it was lacking in visitors on this rainy day and it all made the place feel very ZEN and calm. Well worth a visit and try to go at quiet days (weekdays/rainy days).

Together with Nan Lian Garden a beautiful, tranquil place to visit with a very good vegetarian restaurant. Our favorite place in Hong Kong. Relaxing, beautiful and amazing place to slow down in the fast city. Restaurant is excellent

A little oasis of serenity. TripAdvisor should really merge the Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Garden listings into a single listing as they are connected to one another. I can't imagine you'd see one and skip the other.However, if I'm to speak just of the nunnery, than I'll say that it's a lovely little oasis that doesn't take long to walk around. As far as I could tell, there are two large courtyards that the public has access too. The first contains four ponds and plenty of manicured shrubs and is filled with the sound of running water and birds chirping. The second has several Buddist shines off the walkway around the edges, and the faint scent of incense wafts into the air from these. Some of these shrines are in rooms with large numbers of prayer cushions in them, so I imagine if you get there at the right time, you can see the nuns in prayer. When I was there, recorded chants were being played over a PA system, which was quite soothing, I have to say. As an added bonus, the nunnery has quite a large gift shop with some nice items that are a departure from the usual Hong Kong market trinkets.
An oasis. Tranquil & pretty, feels like you're no longer in HK. Interesting large stones from Mainland China for viewing. Very expensive tea house by the pond that did not seem too busy.
Chi Lin Nunnery. Beautiful spot and gardens, a peaceful oasis in the middle of the city
Best vegetarian in Hong Kong. Food is outstanding and the atmosphere is high quality. Beautiful gardens to walk around in after a nice lunch too.

Beautiful!. We thought this place was wonderful. Very beautiful and calming.There are two places to eat on site, the first a small cafe and the second a wonderful, large vegetarian restaurant with an amazing waterful outside the large windows. There were 5 of us and the waiter was very patient and helped us order a fabulous variety. The food was amazing. Highly recommend.

Great cafe. I've visited twice now and both times got caught in rainstorm! Lucky we managed to find a table at the cafe, twice! The Lemon Tea and Coffee is lovely and the vegetarian toasted sandwich satisfied my hunger pangs. Great place to visit and the gardens are absolutely perfect!
worth a visit. Wonderful to be surrounded by a pristine garden in the urban landscape. Simple fresh food without airs will see you leave with a smile. Best to book for the weekends.
tranquil, interesting. very enjoyable visit can be combined with Nan Lian Gardens
nice. pace and tranquility is the key words that fit in here.
Get thee to the nunnery!. For real meditation and beauty, get thee to the Chi Lin Nunnery

Tranquility in an urban jungle. Beautiful gardens and the architecture is amazing. Its hard to imagine the quiet in the middle of 7+ million people.
We lived in HK for 3 years before we discovered it and now we take all visitors there.
Quiet in the city. I loved the veggie restaurant tucked behind a waterfall.

See with Nan Lian Garden. The garden is right next door, so do plan an extra hour to visit the nunnery. Brand new, so it lacks some of the historic flavor of temples on the mainland, but worth seeing.
Peaceful and interesting. Located ajoining Nan Lian Garden. You cannot take photos inside temple.
Very Nice. Very nice place. It is near Nan Lian Gardens - and together they are a great half day away from the noise and crowds of Kowloon... Don't miss it.
Modern building. A modern beautiful wooden building near the gardens. Authentic but for those who have spent time in Asia heritage is always more interesting.

Not To Be Missed. If you have a couple of hours, a ride to the MTR station at Diamond Hill will bring you to the Chi Lin Nunnery as well as the Nan Lian Garden. The Nunnery looks old but it's modern. It you're lucky, you'll see the nuns in prayer. The various buddhas are beautiful and the lily ponds just add to the peacefulness of the surroundings.

Delightful. If the hassle and bustle of HK is enough, a visit to the nunnery, easily accessed by MTR and well signposted, is worthwhile. The place is ranquil and serene. Don't miss the vegetarian restaurant under the waterwheel in the nearby Nan Lian gardens, the food is modestly priced and yummy.
A beautiful serene place. Away from the crowds and bustle of Hong Kong the Chi Lin Nunnery and the gardens around it make for a beautiful, meditative stroll.
A great oasis in busy HK. The temple/nunnery and gardens are on either side of a busy highway but a wonderful oasis in this super busy city. Amazing bonsai and other dwarf trees. A must see.

probably more interesting sites to visit. This was more interesting to me than the Nan Lian Gardens across the street, but I don't think I'd recommend it unless you're really out of ideas of what else to do in HK. If you need some respite from HK, I'd choose one of the islands or Stanley.
Worth the visit. Definitely a change of scene from HK's usual sights, there's a very well kept garden, rockery and a cute teashop.

Excellent place to experience some tranquility. The architecture is great and the lotus ponds tranquil and quiet. Really enjoyed walking around the monastery looking at the manicured trees and flowers in the lotus ponds. A great place to visit and offers something very different from other HK attractions.
Best nunnery in HKG. i think this is simply the most beautiful place to visit in HKG, combine this with a visit to the adjoining garden and its excellent vegetarian restaurant
An oasis surrounded by bus fumes and tall buildings. If this site were in a less dense area, it would be lovely. But it's not, and I found the walk to and from the bus stop really unpleasant.

An oasis of peace. Hmm This is definitely not your average tourist attraction, there are no bustling groups of tourists and souvenir shops every 5 meters. instead, it's a small, quiet place of worship that makes you wonder about Buddhism. It's very different from the usual smoky temple, and I definitely felt a sense of awe and respect for the religion after visiting this place. I did not spot many nuns though. Do visit the place if you're in need of stress relief.
Nice. Probably not a must visit by itself but when combined with the Nan Lian Garden it it worth the trip. Photos aren't permitted as it there are people worshipping.

Amazing and Stunning.... Wow! It's my first time to see a buddhist temple and my jaw dropped of amaze. I never expect to find this beautiful place. This is connected to a serene and gorgeous garden. You can enter here for free. You can take pictures as long as you want except for the Buddha statues - no pictures allowed. Keep silence as you approach the altar to give some respect to those who are praying.
Beautiful place. Along with the NanLian Gardens this is very very calm and peaceful. Absolut must when in HongKong. The stress is left outside the entrance for sure.

Beautiful spot connected to the Nan Lian Gardens. A quiet nunnery with 4 stunning lotus ponds outside, the Chi Lin Nunnery is a nice quiet place to visit. Several bonsai trees in the courtyard and the lotus pads in the pond, along with the chanting make it very serene.Apart form the large gold center statue of three Buddhas, there are several statues situated in different rooms around the courtyard with explanations of what each signify.Be warned that once you enter, no photos are allowed.

Chanting and Enchanting. The staff were so friendly and the facilty so naturally spectacular that I can't believe I just stumbled upon this site by taking the MTR to Diamond Hill station and going for a walk.

Beautiful. In a city as noisy as Hong Kong this was a welcome piece of tranquillity. A stunning nunnery with excellent gardens and well worth a visit. Further lovely gardens can be found across the road.
Excellent. We were amazed by this place and it has a small display bit showing how the joints are used instead of nail well worth a viist we did Nan Lian Garden at the same time
I do love this place so much. This is a "magic" place dont' miss both the gardens and the nunnery, walk around the gardens feel relaxed, enjoy the beauty of the place
A very peaceful nunnery. It is a very quiet temple but there is nothing much to do other than to take photos and appreciate Chinese temple and architecture.

It's amazing this place exists in the middle of the bustling city that is HK. It is amazing in that it is a hidden gem -- quiet, space, and trees, surrounded by tall skyscrapers and residential buildings all around. Prepare to spend 4 hrs here. We got here around 10:30, walked around and then had a vegetarian lunch, which was wonderful. We admired the bonsai trees, the various temples and sat to read and take a rest. I noticed that more tourists show up after 1pm here but if you come earlier in the day, it's truly a sanctuary where you almost don't see anyone else, which is great and hard to do in a city like HK!

Peaceful Moment in Hong Kong.. Just across the road from the Nan Lian Garden.You will have a peaceful moment in Hong Kong.Unfortunately, they are not allow to take photo inside the temple.But you have to see it. Worth!!!

This place was just amazing... Calm and Peaceful. I could have sit there for hours listening to the chants. The detail of the place is great as well, not a single nail was used to construct the Nunnery.
Beautiful construction and nice place to relax. Very nice garden with beautiful lotus. Spend a few hours walking around is worhty. But there is not much space for resting.
If you have a chance to go...go.. Beautiful oasis in the midst of a busy city. Gardens are beautiful, and you just seem to relax the moment you enter. Go and enjoy as its free and fun.
Serene and calm oasis. Absolutely loved the Nunnery together with the Gardens. Very easy to find and free to go in. A calm and peaceful oasis in the frenetic pace of Hong Kong.
Beautiful. Combined with the Nan Lian garden, well worth the visit. Again, lovely gardens and temples.

Escape from the hustle and bustle of life!. This peaceful place of worship is a gem in the middle of skyscrapers and criss-crossing roadways. It is a Buddhist Monastery and is free to visit. It is very peaceful and unlike some of the smaller temples we visited, did not have incense burning throughout so made for a more pleasant visit. Photography is permitted apart from the religious "alcoves" . The lotus garden and nearby Nan Lian Gardens are stunning.

Calm and relaxing place surrounded by the city. A nice place to walk around and see the temple (?) architecture on a short day trip combined with Nan Lian Gardens which is connected. Very calm and peaceful place and usually you can hear audio being played of monks chanting as you walk through some of the areas. Easy to get to---5 minute walk from the Diamond Hill mtr station take the exit for "Hollywood Plaza" and follow the signs.

Paradise. Well worth a trip on the Mtr, make sure you come out of the right exit, saves a huge walk and getting lost, very nice shopping mall at mtr exit. Chi Lin Nunnery, a lost paradise, so peaceful, beautiful, yet sky scrapper all around. Typically Chinese building, so perfectly done, loved the gardens, ponds, well worth a visit. Please can we have some seats though, children not happy having to stand around.
Next to Nan Lian Gardens. It is s really part of the Nan Lian garden and free again so if you go to one you will in effect walk into the other anyway

Lovely peaceful spot ... in the middle of bustling Hong Kong. This is the most beautiful and peaceful lotus garden, right in the middle of bustling sky scrapers, whizzing traffic and just a busy city. It is a lovely place to visit, wander around, take in the beautful temple, lake, lotus flowers, the monastery is beautiful and the architecture is stunning. You can just forget about the rest of your world while you wander around in here. It's lovely and very easy to find, very handy to the train station.
Serenity within the neighbourhood. It just feels wow when I stepped in. Check out the bonsai, the statues, the nunnery design.

Traditional Chinese experience in modern-day Diamond Hill. There are wonderful walkways with traditional landscaping, ponds with fish, a cool restaurant with a view under a waterfall. It is a peaceful experience also close to the Nunnery with amazing traditional wooden & stone architecture that looks extremely expensive. You feel like you traveled back in time.
Pray!. A serene place to pray, and enjoy the beautiful Chinese temple and lily ponds.Getting there by MTR Diamond Hill and walk 5 mins (follow sign)

A retreat from Hong Kong's business buzz and shopping madness. A visit to Chi Lin Nunnery as well as the adjacent Nan Lian Gardens proved to be a good decision to include it in our itinerary.The place offers a serene break from the usual places tourists go to in Hong Kong such as huge malls and other shopping places where the crowds are and always abuzz with noise.I surely recommend making a quick trip to this place while in Hong Kong.
Beautiful. Beautiful garden and settings - if you like Asian scenery and ornaments. I enjoyed it very much.
Nice small oasis in busy Hong Kong. Nice garden and temples in the middle of the tall buildings.If you have seen other temples in China or Japan, it is not a big deal, but hey, still nice.
A haven of peace in a busy area. 5 minutes walk from the MTR I can relax and meditate in the peace and calm of these beautiful gardens and nunnery. Guided tours are also offered for those interested.
Oasis. Great place to visit and wonderful traditional tea rooms. Thank you Billy for suggesting!!
A Delightful Visit. Just nearing sunset we were shown this incredible oasis!. Just stunning and free.Not widely known but it should be one of the places to visit especially at dusk just spectacular!
A must-see along with Nan Lian Garden. This temple is connected to Nan Lian Garden so you can't miss it. You can feel the sacred and enlightening atmosphere while walking around this place!
Beautiful. Go to both the Nan Lian Garden and the nunnery buildings - just great. You will be happy you took the time. So easy to get to from the metro.

Second half of our garden tour. We went to the Chi Lin Nunnery after taking a break. No, we did not go to the vegetarian restaurant. The line was too long for our hunger. We walked back to Plaza Hollywood...Once you got closer to the more religious areas, it was more about taking in everything peacefully without a camera. If you choose to, you can specifically pray for the health of your loved ones.
Do not miss out. Well worth a visit, very peaceful and the restaurant is a great place to eat. We had dinner here and it was one of the best.

Excellent garden. We visited the Nunnery and Nan Lian across the street.
Beautiful tranquil garden, large Koi ponds etc.
10 min cab from Mong Kok
appreciate the building method. what amazes me is the building method, not just the building itself. Though this nunnery is kind of new thing, it is also worth going.

Serenity. It's a monastery built in the heart of a bustling city. There's a sense of peacefulness when you're inside. Ornate Buddha statues and lotus ponds with prayers being spoken through speakers.
It's a nice change from the crazyness on the island.
Oasis of calm.. Again this is not so close to the city centre but easy to find from the MTR and well worth finding.

Beautiful temples. Located opposite Nan Lian Gardens at Diamond Hill MTR this is well worth the visit.
Beautifully coloured temples, but as this is an area of worship be mindful that photography is not permitted in all areas.
Clean and Serene Monastery in the City. A nice break from the craziness that surrounds it - filled with lots of religious symbols and beautiful urban ponds.
peace in chaos. lovely little bit of calm in an otherwise hectic city, great way to finish a tour of the gardens
Incredible. It is absolutely amazing. One of the prettiest places in Hong Kong.
A true oasis. Beautiful gardens right in the centre of the city. Quiet, calm, lovely tea area. Bring a book and relax, away from the hustle and bustle for a few hours

OK. Nice and new; disappointed that no photography was allowed in some areas. Non-flash photography would have been nice (some other religious sites let you take pictures as long as you don't take pictures of people praying). When you're done looking around make sure you cross the bridge and visit the Nan Lian Garden as it is absolutely stunning.

Serene. Chi Lin Nunnery had high marks on my guidebook and it didn't disappoint. It is awesome right from the entrance in a sort of overpass connecting to Nan Lian Garden. The moment you take in the atmosphere inside with the lotus ponds, Buddha statues, and great architecture, I was just in awe.From the MTR station it will be about 5 to 10 minutes walk but there will be a staircase which will lead to the main entrance, or you can enter the Lotus Pond beside the highway and enter from the side entrance. Some monks were walking around during my visit and a few other people. The weather was gloomy but overall I thought it was a great place to visit. Do check out the Nan Lian Garden across the road.

Lovely break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. If you are looking for some quiet and peaceful time away from the craziness of Hong Kong, take the MTR to the Diamond Hill station and follow the signs to the Chi Lin Nunnery. The Nunnery is right in the middle of a residential area of Kowloon, with skyscrapers all around, however when you walk through the gates of the Nunnery its like you have walked into the middle of a secluded temple. The Chi Lin Nunnery is an active Buddhist, and retirement community for Buddhist Nuns, so it is not uncommon to see people making offerings and praying while you visit. You may also see some of the nuns that tend to the gardens. You can take pictures of the exterior of the temples, however you can't take them if you stand inside the entrance way of each temple.The are in Japanese style and are truly amazing. And the landscape within the temple complex is outstanding. I found the temples and the grounds to be very relaxing and really could have stayed there all morning. However you can see the entire grounds and temples in an hour or so, so if you are pressed for time you can still get this in on your visit.
Peaceful. Pleasantly surprising, this unexpected treasure in the middle of a bustling concrete city is a Must-Do.
Must visit. Beautiful, koi ponds, bonsai, soothing environment. See review of Nan Lian Garden

Truly the best part of Hong Kong. This was by far the most serene and inviting spot in Hong Kong, beautiful. We had lunch at the retaurant, delicious. This should be the number 1 attraction on your list, far more intersting than the 5 minute Star Ferry trip across the water or another mall featuring Gucci or Valentino.

Along with Nan Lian Gardens, one of our very favorite spots in all of Hong Kong. We returned to the Chi Lin Nunnery, along with the Nan Lian Garden this past weekend, as we have many times since having move to Hong Kong. These two attractions, combined have become a favourite spot in Hong Kong to visit and spend time. We do favour the Nan Lian Gardens but the Chi Lin Nunnery is equally as impressive. Exiting Diamond Hill MTR station, below the Plaza Hollywood shopping mall, you are five minutes walk from the Chi Lin Monastery grounds (free entry). However, the Nan Lian Garden (also free entry) is in between these two locations so it makes sense to visit there first. What we love about Chi Lin Monastery is the courtyard lotus ponds and numerous shrubs, plants, trees and bonsai,which are very well-manicured and maintained. We've watched, nurturers painstakingly tend to their projects over the years. The health, appearance and beauty of the specimen within these grounds is testimony to the love and care given at Chi Lin and the results are an impressive courtyard with much to feast your eyes upon. The only complaint we have for the Chi Lin Nunnery is the lack of seating area for visitors, making it more difficult to just sit and enjoy the serenity created within these grounds. There is more opportunity for this form of enjoyment and relaxation across the bridge at the Nan Lian Gardens. The Chi Lin Nunnery is no longer a hidden gem in Hong Kong. It is now regularly considered a top ten attraction in the city, along with the Nan Lian Gardens. It is a place much loved by locals and residents in Hong Kong and something that all visitors should try to make time for. Combined with the Nan Lian Gardens, this is the most beautiful spot in Hong Kong.

Sterile. Visited this after the gardens and although the place is beautiful it is a very sterile sanitised version of a Buddhist temple. You were not allowed to sit to listen to the chanting, or go anywhere near the buildings. We tried to ask the security guard a question but he claimed to not understand English until I sat down to listen to the chanting and he came up and told me to move in very good English!! Buddha would have not approved of this as I am pretty certain one of the things he said was "just sitting" which is one of the most popular Buddhist meditations!

A definite must see!. We loved the nunnery and gardens. The gardens were meticulous and the people working used the smallest scissors to trim everything to perfection it was amazing. The whole place was very peaceful and quite and such a neat site to see as it is tucked away in such a busy and bustling city. There is also a tea room located in the gardens I believe but we didn't visit it.
Very peaceful experience. I thought the nunnery grounds too be tranguil and peaceful. It is adjacent to the Nan lian Garden, and the tour of these two areas was the highlight of my trip.

Just Breathtaking. This was one of the highlights of my visit to Hong Kong. I would argue that no trip to Hong Kong is complete without visiting the Chi Lin Nunnery and the associated Nan Lian Garden. Although it was only founded in 1934 and rebuilt in the 1990s, it was built using ancient Chinese architectural techniques and gives you a real idea of what places such as this must've looked like hundreds of years ago. I found the juxtaposition of cultures (ancient temple and gardens separated by modern highway and the huge apartment blocks associated with modern Hong Kong in the background) was particularly interesting. It's within very easy reach of Diamond Hill MTR Station and also has an excellent gift shop.

a look that's cultural and peaceful. set apart from the buzzling city outside, the nunnery provides a scene of eastern zen and wonderful landscape. having a snack bar and a restaurant inside was excellent!
A beautiful place to relax. It's off the main strip but Chi Lin is worth the MTR ride out to Diamond Hill
Excellent glimpse of another culture. Just so different from what we are used to. Peaceful, exotic and extremely interesting.
a quiet oasis in the middle of a bustling city. The most beautiful, peaceful and relaxing place in HK. An absolute must see!
oasis in heart of city. A beautiful place surrounded by high rise buildings. Very peaceful and free entry. Would recommend a visit.
History incarnate. For history buffs this is a MUST. Otherwise I think you might find it quite boring.

A sanctuary. I always come here when I visit Hong Kong to get out of the crowd and noise. I have eaten at the restaurant, had tea at the tea house, visited exhibitions, bought books at the shop, and snacked at the kiosk. I have spoken to the Bonsai man and received good and courteous service from everyone there. These operations are across the road from the temple, linked by a overhead bridge and stairs.
Calm in the middle of a busy city. Beautiful temple build recently but with traditional workmanship.
Bliss in the City. Very easy to reach by MTR and what a find. A haven of tranquillity and all us tourists infected by the sense of peace and harmony. Do not miss.

wonderful. This should not be missed.The lotus ponds and the nunnery are really beautiful and well worth the journey on the MTR to Diamond Hill.However what we liked most were the gardens just over a bridge in front of the nunnery. I did not think that peace and quiet could be in a large city.Surrounded by motor ways and tall buildings this is a place to relax,with plants, trees, a large lake and koi carp.There is also a restaurant but it was closed when we were there. Worth the visit

Ancient time in the middle of the city. It's a nice and peacefull environment but the biggest asset is the garden next to it.
The nunnery has some nice bassains but is not realy worth a visit without visiting the garden that it is connected with.
(Maybe I have just seen to many nunnerys.)

Bit over rated.. An authentic nunnery built without any nails to traditional design. Beautiful setting and great contrasting views from the gardens of surrounding Hong Kong. Pity about the noisy adjacent dual carriageway but can't be helped- it is Hong Kong.

A great spot in a great City. Easy to get to from the Diamond Hill Metro stop, I found myself going back to old China when I entered the gardens and then the nunnery. Quiet, tranquil, and stunning made for a great visit. I loved the Lilly ponds (four of them) and then the location where they kept the buddahs. Unfortunately, you could not take photos of the buddahs, which I understand, but had been spoiled because we could take photos at the monastery where big buddah was. Still, quite the cool setting amidst all of the high rises, in modern Hong Kong. About a five minute walk from the metro.

Very pretty views and gardens. This was the first place we visited on our first day in Hong Kong. (It was a little bit of a walk from the subway if you have trouble walking.) The views are beautiful and it is very peaceful in the heart of Kowloon. The gift shop has some unusual gifts that you will not find at other Hong Kong museums or attractions so be sure to look around.
Absolute oasis in HK. Perfect place to escape from the hectic nature of the city and chill for a while.Only a short and easy walk from Diamond Hill MRT station
Peace and quiet in the big city. A nice naturalist Chinese garden that is a very calming counterpoint to the big city. Amazing to think that it's less than 10 years old.
Beautitul and serene.... Very inspirational, quiet and a nice stroll along its gardens. Must appreciate the architectural aspect of this temple/nunnery. Must see.
A great design!. Great location, just opposite Diamond Hill MTR.Very special design compare to other temple. Love it!

Serenity in the midst of chaos. The gardens are a repreive from the hustle and bustle. You can hear the birds sing, enjoy the bonsai trees, waterfalls, lotus ponds, stone sculptures. And the food (vegetarian) is excellent.
Terrific gardens and good food. We loved the gardens and had a very good veggie meal in their restaurant.

Beautiful Buddhist Temple. Founded in 1934, this Buddhist temple was built in 1990 following the style of Tang dynasty architecture. Instead of nails, a special interlocking system holds its wood structure in place - the only building of its kind in Hong Kong.

Visit on a rainy day. The day we planned to visit the nuunery and gardens was rainy, but we went anyway. It was truly beautiful. The set meal at the restaurant is the best vegetarian dishes I've ever tasted, but the service was lacking. The restaurant open at 12 noon and the view through the waterfall is awesome.

wonderful buddhist temple. have been here many times as it is a wonderful place to visit. it is very clean and peaceful here. the location is very easy. you just have to take the hong kong MTR (subway) to the DIAMOND HILL station and just follow the sign which are in english and very clear. the temple is less than a 10 minute walk from the mtr station. it is very beautiful and there are signs in english so that you know the names of all the different buddhist Gods and Goddes. there is a beautiful chinese garden right infront of the temple. the garden is a must visit also! the diamond hill mall is also right on top of and on the way to the temple so you can eat and shop here.
Amazing food, book early!. The range of food was really amazing. Ideal for non cornivors and the service was to the best Hong Kong standards
Must see. This is the most tranquil spot in all of Hong Kong. So worth the short ride on the MTR - spotless and enchanting. And free!

Beautiful place and garden. Caught the MTR to Diamon Hill Station - crossed the road and was easy to fouind. Entered via the non - main gate but still looked around and the souvenier shop was reasonably priced.

Peaceful and beautiful spot. This is a beautiful and peaceful spot in the middle of busy and crazy daily Hong Kong life. The buildings are lovely, but it was the walk through the garden (Nan Lian Garden) that captured me. Take a snack or lunch and sit down and take break in a very quiet and peaceful spot. It's a short walk from public transportation - station that stops at Plaza Hollywood I believe

A lovely sanctuary juxtaposed against a modern skyscraper backdrop; worth the visit!. First things first: if you're seeking ancient temples and artifacts, this is NOT the place for you. However, if you're willing to overlook the fact that the nunnery is relatively new and can go with an open mind to enjoy a beautiful and tranquil space nestled within a very busy city, then I strongly recommend a visit. We have taken all our visitors to Hong Kong to this site and they have all enjoyed it thoroughly, particularly when we share the previous disclaimer in advance. To be sure, there are some people who have visions of ancient temples---for this, go to the Mainland or elsewhere across Asia. There are some very nice photo opps within the grounds of the nunnery, including a golden pagoda, bright red bridge, and some golden koi fish that look like they should be mechanical, but they are real. It's inexpensive, relaxing, and a nice place to visit for an hour or so. Your friends will remember it and so will you.
A glimpse of old Hong Kong. Well worth a look. Colonial style timber decor and soemthing of an oasis of peace in a big busy city

An oasis of peace and calm. The Chi Lin Nunnery borders on the most exquisite garden, with a pagoda in a lake, many beautiful sub-areas like a rock garden, vegetarian restaurant and lots of tiny bonsai-like trees. In the garden, lovely music wafts out of speakers hidden amongst the plants. The calm, peace and ordered feeling of the place are quite unique. Even though the entrance is right under a major flyover road, I was totally unaware of any traffic noise while there! Inside the nunnery, there are many enormous golden Buddhas attended by various figures from the tradition - no photography permitted in the shrines. The Rock Garden, indoor and outdoor, contains specimens of rocks like I've not seen anywhere else - amazing beautiful stratification, colour and HUGE in size, some of them. GREAT vegetarian restaurant to top it off, too. A fabulous day out, good for body and soul.

Stunning Monastery with vegetarian restaurant. Stunning monastery that resides inside Nan Lian garden. The garden is very pretty too. You can find the directions after you get off at Diamond hill mtr station. There is no fee to visit this attraction. They have a vegetarian restaurant inside. The food is tasty Chinese vegetarian food. If you can't decide on the food, then try their set menu to experiment. It is a nice day out.

Excellent place to visit. Chi Lin Nunnery is a free attraction built in a Tang dynasty style. It a bit of peace and quiet from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The trees and ponds are amazing as well as the temple itself. A nice trip out for anybody and Nan Lian Gardens nearby are also worth a visit.
natural and recommended. it is beautiful and natural but cant imagine in a green environment but still can hear traffic noise.. but overall very good..

Worth the trip, easy to reach. From the MTR station Diamond Hill walk east around the shopping center, through the Nan Lian Garden, and into the monastery. Less colorful and more serene than Wong Tai Sin temple (nearby).
Lovely setting. A beautiful setting adjacent to Nan Lin Gardens. The lotus filled ponds take a great photograph. Peaceful place in a noisy city. free and close to tube.
Peaceful. Beautiful, peaceful place. Easy to find from the Diamond Hill MTR. Attached park is lovely. A great place to wander for an hour or so.

Best 'Attraction' in Hong Kong...and free!. We visited Chi Lin Nunnery on a morning and intended to stay there a couple of hours before carrying on with our trip. We ended up staying there something like five hours! This is the best place to go if you want a retreat from the hyperactive centre. At the Diamond Hill MTR, you need to go outside the shopping centre and follow the signs, the Nunnery is well indicated. You won't be disappointed. The complex has taken something like 10 years to be built according the Zen rules. As soon as you enter the Nunnery, the peacefulness of the place becomes palpable. The very quiet chants on (hidden) speakers and the constant steam watering of the flora add to the atmosphere. After visiting/viewing all the buildings, including a free exhibition about Buddhist sculptures and paintings, we decided to head for lunch at the Nunnery restaurant, under a cascade. That was probably the best food I had in Hong Kong altogether. It is exclusively vegetarian and specialised in mushrooms. The meal was extremely refined, the (free!) Pu'er tea and mushroom appetizers were of the best quality.In order to finish our incredibly relaxing matinee, we decided to visit the tea house afterwards. It is fairly pricey (£8 per tea, one tea per person compulsory) but it was worth both the tea itself, of excellent quality and abundant quantity, and the tea serving demonstration, surrounded by a wonderful decor. The best place for an escape from hectic Hong Kong.

My favourite part of our Hong Kong stay. A visit to the Chi Lin Nunnery was my favourite part of a recent holiday to Hong Kong. It was so tranquil and calm. Very easy to get to, only a few stops from Nathan Road and we combined it with a visit to the gardens across the road from it. The gardens and worship halls were stunning. My 5yr old complained that he was going to be bored there and in the end we had to drag him away ! A very good learning experience for us all.A lovely side to Hong Kong that we hadn't experienced before.

Peace amongst the craziness of Hong Kong. If you want a break from the markets and the hustle and bustle then Chi Lin, surrounded by tall apartment blocks is the perfect place. The temple halls are stunning and the courtyards full of bonsai trees are a delight for the eyes. The attached gardens are also a haven in this hectic city. Easy to get to - about 100 metres from the subway and there is no cost! So magnificent value.
No nails. 30 minutes by MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui. Tucked practically under freeway exchange, but still tranquil oasis amongst the high-rises
Serene. The gardens are immaculate and beautiful. It is a good place to get away to for some peace and quiet.

Tranquility in Busy HK. What a beautiful place to stroll, particularly in the early hours when you have the whole place just to yourself. Very clean and peaceful. Just a short walk from Diamond Hill MTR Station (Exit C2). There's a very nice garden just across the nunnery connected by a small bridge.
Peaceful. Such peace in the middle of busy Hong Kong. Beautiful gardens, well worth a visit. Easy to get to on the Metro.
quiet peaceful place. a must for quiet time and the gardens are beautiful, amazing building , and the chant is soothing

Magical. absolutly a beautiful experiance. Steve one of the employees gave us a tour which we enjoyed very much. He was most informative and professional. Also had lunch under the waterfall in the delicious restaurant. The garden was breathtaking. This was my favorite Hong Kong experiance. It is free!
w

How's the serenity!. This place is a little surreal – beautiful oasis in a concrete jungle. Thank you trip advisor for sending us this way otherwise we would never have known it existed. Continue on over the overpass bridge to Nan Lian Gardens to complete the visit. Had a little trouble explaining to the Taxi drivers where we wanted to go (didn’t have a map on me at the time grrr) one driver asked if I wanted Hollywood gardens which unfortunately I had never heard of, we found a driver who knew what we were talking about and drove us there and we saw the big Hollywood Plaza sign close by ahuh “Hollywood Gardens” now makes sense ;) We went on a Sunday morning... the Lotus Pond Garden is open 7am to 7pm

Maybe Hong Kong's best temple to visit. Hong Kong have many many temples, most are very small with smell of burning of incense, except Chi Lin Nunnery, it's park like complex with beautiful buildings, it was supposely a duplication of the Tang dynasty temple style and they did a very good job, if you like to see at least one temple while in Hong Kong, this is your best choice, it's located in Kowloon, near Diamond Hill MTR station, just take few minutes to walk.

A Hong Kong Sanctuary. I loved visiting the nunnery and the garden below. It was so peaceful and beautiful amidst the craziness that Hong Kong is. Walk the gardens below and then have Tea in the Tea House. Bring your walking shoes and your camera. Take your time in the garden and enjoy it's peace. It will rejuvinate you before you go back into the city.

a place of calm in the centre of the city. a short walk out of the MTR station and you enter the most amazing calm space the buildings are stunning built from large grey stone with dark wooden roofs and doors. you walk into the fist level and are surrounded with ponds full of lotus flowers you then walk into the temple and look upon massive golden buddahs each level offers different sights and you will be amazed that this place exists as when you look up hugh tower blocks tower above the nunnery.the gardens attached to the nunnery are also worth spending some time wander around. This place was one of the highlights of our trip. i would also recomend the gift shop lots of lovely items

Beautiful-do it with the Nan Lian Gardens. This is an amazing combination-the Nunnery and Gardens. Mind-blowing. I don't understand all the reasons why things are designed this way or that way, but honestly is it so beautiful. It's a crazy thing having such a serene place surrounded by high rise, but that's HKG! I took so many photos [blush]. The day I went it was 6*C and drizzling, but was just magical despite me being soooooooo cold!I didn't take my kids that day, they went to see a movie but I think they would've liked all the pathways and buildings and bridges and lotus ponds...and the sign that said 'NO FROLICKING'!Loved it.

Beautiful classic garden - great escape in Hong Kong. Lovely spot to walk at a leisurely pace and see magnificent garden settings - lotus pools, an island pagoda, tea house, quiet vegetarian restaurant, beautoiful stone and wood accents, varied trees, bonsai type miniatures...The nunnery itself is magnificent - a huge, brooding old fashioned structure (I think you can visiit - it was closed when I was there), and the various restaurants, shop etc all profit the establishment and are run in a taseful way by the nuns themselves.Easy to reach from the MTR Diamond Hill stop - good signage leads oyu right across the street. No charge for entry. And easy single stop from Wan Tai Sin Temple - and almost the complete opposite in vibe!

Hidden Gem in Hong Kong. Near the Diamond Hill MTR in Kowloon is easily one of the best surprise attractions in Hong Kong. The Chi Lin Nunnery hosts a fantastic garden area that rivals anything you will see in the mainland, Korea or Japan. The landscape, quality ponds and plants are very beautiful. The buddha statues inside the compound are in excellent condition and lovely appearance. Combined with the attached Nan Lian Garden, this makes a wonderful combined attraction in Hong Kong, one that our guests find most impressive and one of our personal favorite places in Hong Kong. We personally visit several times a year, its so peaceful and beautiful. We highly recommend the Chi Lin Nunnery as a Top 5 or 10 attraction in Hong Kong

A calm oasis amongst the high rises. The Nunnery is located really close to the Diamond Hill MTR. Follow the signs to get there. It is extremely quiet and peaceful. Lotus ponds, bonsai and gigantic statues of the Buddha and his avatars. Go visit to check the amazing juxtaposition between the Nunnery and the high rises - sure makes interesting photography.

beautiful Japanese style garden. We spent most our time in the Nan Lin Garden; which reminded me of Japan more than China. Had a tasty drink in the efficient snack bar. Lovely calm surroundings. Very easy to find.

So tranquil. The Chi Lin Nunnery is really easy to get to, we visited this attraction as part of the HKTB "Wong Tai Sin" walk. We spent about 3 hours at the gardens and nunnery - they have an excellent gift shop with quality souvineers. Toilets were clean too. There was a place to have lunch / snacks but we did not eat here. If you have time and want to get away from the city, I do recommend visiting this attraction and it is free.
A beautiful and peaceful place. We really enjoyed our family visit to this garden and Nunnery. It is beautiful and well worth a visit. It is very easy to get to by subway. Plus, entrance is free!

Peaceful Retreat in the heart of a Big City. This Buddhist complex built in Tang dynasty architecture is a welcome retreat from the hubbub that is Hong Kong.It is attached to the Nan Lian Garden (see separate review) and is free.MTR Diamond Hill Station Exit C2, and follow the signs.You may want to see the Gardens before so that at the end you come back to the road leading to the MTR and the shopping mall.There are several Deities (no photos allowed) around the complex and a serene lotus pool with no carp but lovely flowers if blooming.As you walk around, you can hear the lone strumming of a musical instrument and it immediately puts you at ease.It is very quite as no one speaks here...at least we didn't!The main temple has many Deities and their helpers and is well served by the local worshipers.We never saw any of the nuns, as there are areas out of bounds for tourists.It doesn't take long to walk round however you immediately feel rested and the world outside is very far away.The camera got a workout just the same and we were glad we made the detour to see this peaceful complex.We enjoyed it along with the Gardens.There is Buddhist religious items and an English guidebook for sale at the Temple.Next door at the Gardens there is another souvenir shop with quality items and a vegetarian restaurant looking over the gardens.Take the stairs down as you tour the complex.Be sure to make some time for this little gem in a very busy city!
a beautiful place. this is definatley worth going to see, it a beautiful quite place in the middle of the city and it's fee! easy to get to sign posted.

Tranquil, Beautiful, Worthwhile. I have to agree with the other recent reviews of Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery. I generally prefer more 'action' in the tourist attractions that I visit but this side trip was worth it. I won't repeat what others have said but give a few details, that we discovered, not previously mentioned. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill, use the C2 exit. At the top of the 2nd lot of esculators turn right, prior to entering the shopping centre. Nan Lian Garden is directly over the road but you have to walk up to the top of the road and use the pedestrian crossing to get to the entrance. At the end of Nan Lian Garden you flow seamlessly onto the steps that lead to Chi Lin Nunnery (Buddist Monastry/Nunnery). Both Nan Lian and Chi Lin are free. We took a little over an hour to stroll through both but the time flew. My young teenage daughter enjoyed the whole she-bang as much as we did. Be carefull, the camera will get a workout, but you can't use them inside any of the displays. When leaving Chi Lin you end up fairly close to the entrance of Nan Lian / railway station, almost completing a big loop.

Peace and tranquility away from the Hustle and Bustle ..... The weather forecast was not good for today in Hong Kong so it was going to be museum day. But after the morning visit to the Hong Kong Museum of Art (recommended for the Chinese porcelain if nothing else), the sun was out to I changed our minds and we went off north to visit the Chi Lin Nunnery which sounds an odd place to visit but after reading other TA reviews our interest was aroused. It is difficult to write about this trip without running out of superlatives. First let me say that no visit to the Nunnery should be made with first going to the Nan Lian Park: this was only created a few decades ago from an area notorious for crime and nothing could be further removed from its past than this. The majesty of the bonsai, the tranquil koi in the crystal clear lake, the waterfalls (the electronic birds!), the exhibition of wooden architecture, the rock sculptures all combine to form an experience which will last a long time. I do suggest you go to the park first to “unwind” from the frenzy of outside life and then take the stone steps up to the Nunnery which if anything is even more tranquil. Four giant lotus pools with fountains play before the Buddahs which stare out in all their golden glory, smiling beatifically upon us poor mortals, subdued chanting voices and the gentle clang of bells add to the serene atmosphere. It’s quite magical and if you don’t leave feeling somewhat cleansed, you’re a hard person! Highly recommended – but possibly not for childen.

Thank you for the recommendation!. After researching on attractions to visit in Hong Kong, the Nunnery always came up highly recommended, so I decided to pay it a visit, and I am so glad I did! First of all, the Nunnery is very easy to find, getting off at Diamond Hill MRT station and through the shopping mall it's then signposted. As soon as I stepped into Nan Lian park which leads to the Nunnery, I felt calm. The park is well kept and offers quite a few sceneries spots such as a waterfall and the golden pagoda, and these make wonderful photo opportunities. There’s large lake in the garden ground and is home to some beautiful Koi carps. I then crossed the passway which leads to the Nunnery, the temples were beautiful and Bonsai trees were interesting, and best of all, there weren’t that many people there at all, we saw about 5 people in the park, and a few dotted here and there in the Nunnery, but a great escape from the crowd!Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Park is truly an oasis in the bustling city, whilst on the many occasions I stopped and admire the sceneries I had to thank the previous reviewers for recommending this place! Don't be put off if you are not religious, just go there to look at the architectures and fantastic views, you will not be disappointed. I left the park feeling calm and relaxed and even felt somewhat cleansed, a truly amazing experience!

Simply Gorgeous!!!. This Buddhist nunnery is amazingly beautiful - a fantastic, faithful replica of a huge Tang Dynasty temple complex in Shanxi, China. Architecture buffs will be wowed by the breathtaking wooden construction, not a single nail was used to build the entire structure. The bonsai specimens here are truly state-of-the-art, including some very rare techniques, eg. hanging bonsai. This, along with the adjacent Nan Lian Temple, truly transports the visitor to ancient China, there's so much to see, galleries of wooden models of other famous ancient structures in China, poetically themed gardens, beautiful teahouse overlooking a large lake with huge, colourful kois, yet everything is calm, zen-like and meditative. Abstract, very quiet traditional Chinese music and Buddhist chants wafted as we meandered through the grounds of the temple and the garden. An afternoon well-spent. We emerged in a highly relaxed state of mind, the experience stays with you for a while.I find this visit much more enriching and fulfilling than most of the other well-known temples in Hong Kong, which are rather crude compared to the highly refined aesthetic of this attraction. A TRUE MUST SEE.

WOW a must see!. On the edge of a beautiful park, and near the base of a mountain. easy to find right outside a MTR station with a mall in between the station and the park for lunch or a snack, because theres no food allowed in the park. one of my party got reprimanded for trying to eat a powerbar while walking. the nunnery itself is still active, although we didnt get to see any nuns, but the real attraction is the gardens connected to the nunnery. beautifully landscaped and manicured, its an awsome place to walk, meditate, or relax. its a photographers dream, and we were lucky enough to have fog rolling down the mountian behind the park, making the breathtaking views even more spectacular. theres a restaraunt with a viewing window which is just behind a manmade waterfall, as well as a teahouse within the park. a giant koi pond also adds to the ambiance.

Serene and beautiful. We were advised by forum members to have a look at the Nunnery, as we didn't just want to come to Hong Kong to shop. We are SO glad we took their advice.We went in January 2008. We travelled by MTR from Causeway Bay to Diamond Hill. We got sidetracked after arriving at the MTR by the large shopping centre right at the exit. My daughter was dieing for a coffee, so we stopped in at Starbucks. The coffee and cake were very nice. Bought a few "hello kitty" items for our daughter at home then off to the Nunnery.It is only 2-3 minutes walk from the MTR. On the way past we saw the Nan Lian Gardens and thought it looked interesting. We walked up the footpath to use the road cross over and looked down on the gardens - amazing. We would look at these after the Nunnery.We were amazed by the number and size of the bonsais greeting us at the walk up to the Nunnery, they almost guide you to it. It is ABSOLUTELY beautiful. Make sure to have people in your photos, just so peple can see the scale of the place.Through an outer building and into a large rectangle with buildings on 4 sides each with an alter. The area once again in here is SO beautiful and SO peaceful. We took so many photos and I was very sorry when I took a photo of one of the buddhas, I did not see the no photos sign.We left and went down to look at the Nan Lian Gardens - we could not believe what we had stumbled onto. They are amazing. The architecture and plantings are beautiful and the golden pagoda beckoned many, many photos. Please do not miss this stop when visiting the Nunnery.We were on our way to Sai Kung, but spent so long here, that our time in Sai Kung was cut short.This was one of the highlights of our trip, not mentioned in many travel brochures but something I am so glad we found.
